Nice spicy, fruit and even light hoppy and light sweet malty aroma. Hazy orange-red color. Minimal white head. Medium sweet, light sour, very spicy taste. Medium body. Light sticky texture. Very light alcohol warm, light dry finish.

Bottle from Csak a jó sör. Poured deep ruby and a tan, lacing head. Fruity notes of peach, melon, raisins, honey. Somewhat earthy. Aroma of dark chocolate, more raisins, caramel. Sweet taste, somewhat lighter body than I expected from the style. Low carbonation, closed with a sweet finish. Dry, slightly hoppy finish. OK.

Bottle at paulener bar. Pours deep red with chestnut head. Big malty aroma. Wasn’t sure about this at first but enjoying it more as it opens up. Taste of caramel, cherries, plumbs. Well balanced, perfect level of sweetness, finishes nicely

11.2oz bottle poured into a stein. Smells strongly of raisins/dried fruit and a general maltiness. Tastes pretty much the same but with a warming alcohol taste (maybe whiskey or brandy). A great beer for a cold day.

50cl bottle from Munich train station.
Clear amber pour.  Decent off white head.  Lovely dubble bock.

(50 cl bottle from Bavarian Imports) Pours a clear, dark amber with medium, white head. Aroma is .. not much: A little sour and a little malt and molasses? Medium-bodied on the palate, oily texture, lively carbonation with a sweet finish. Taste is moderately sweet with acidic notes. Girlfriend says: "It’s too acidic."

Light brown color with a big creamy head. Mild malt sweetness in the nose with a dark fruit appeal, prunes and grapes. The flavor also contributes dark fruits, namely plum, prune, and cherry. Toasted malts with a subtle chocolate bits. Some alcohol heat. Creamy body with a medium body and carbonation. Pretty good example of the style.
Gifted by Bierkrug - Thank You Good Sir! Nice spices in the sip - definite alcohol in the aftertaste... Not the best doppelbock, maybe a middle of the road.

Poured from an 11.2 oz. bottle into a pilsner glass.

Pours a deep caramel brown with yellow-orange highlights and a 1/2 finger off-white head. Very little lacing.

Smell: Sweet caramel malt, melons and a touch of dried dark fruit.

Taste: Sweet caramel and a touch of fruity sweetness up front followed by a more subdued malty sweetness in the middle before ending with a mix of toasted malt and a hint of bitterness. Aftertaste is dry and somewhat muted.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a fairly high amount of carbonation. Goes down smooth.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. I could see myself drinking a couple of these under the right circumstances.

Overall: Good beer overall. Not the best dopplebock in the world, but it’s still solid. I’d say it’s worth a shot.

Location: Draft at Pilsener Haus, 8/13/11




Aroma: The nose is dark fruits, malts, caramel, and some other sweet notes


Appearance: This one pours a fairly dark, reddish-amber color with a beige head


Flavor: The taste is relatively sweet too, with notes of caramel, dark fruits, and a touch of wood


Palate: The body is medium (plus), with a somewhat sticky and oily mouthfeel to it


Overall Impression: 
Overall, I thought this was a nice example of the style.  A really solid and enjoyable beer.  I had a few light pils-style beers on this trip since it was hot and those are great on a hot day, but I couldn’t resist trying this one too.  I need something a little bigger, and this one fit the bill perfectly.

Deep caramel mixed with honey hue. Small white head that leaves no lacing. Big malty aroma, caramel and a hint of vanilla. Same in the taste department, with a bit of roasted grain and biscuit. Excellent beer.

Pours dark brown from bottle with a thin head. Big malty notes on the nose. Medium mouthfeel. Lots of caramel and malt on the tongue. This stuff is like beer soup. Nice amount of linger to the finish. Lovely!

Aroma is malty with a fruity undertone and just a hint of spice. It pours a clear cola brown with a respectable light tan head. Flavor is quite strong, malty with undertones of spice and apple. Texture is fairly smooth and tingly, and it has a fair amount of body. Definitely worth seeking.

0,33 l. bottle. Clear amber colour with a small, white head that quikly fades, just leaving a thin head around the edge of the glass. Lots of sweet stuff in this beer: Massive malt aroma with caramel, chocolate and nuts, notes of alcohol, this a doppelbock.  Heavy sweetness, to much sweetness for my tastebuds. Medium to full body with a oliy texture and a long finish with notes of all the sweet stuff and faint alcohol. Not my preferred style of fluid, but a lot of history and quality in this beer.

Der Paulaner Salvator macht vom Etikett her auf Lustig. 
Was sich aber nach dem Öffnen der Flasche offenbart, ist alles Andere als lustig. 
Geht die Farbe noch in Ordnung, so hat das malzige Aroma einen heftigen Unterton nach Gemüsebrühe. Geschmacklich weiß man nicht genau wo es hingehen soll: Zur Malzigkeit gesellen sich fehlplatzierte Bitternoten im wässrigen Millieu. 
Nichtssagend der Abgang: Kraftlos verpufft der Doppelbock im Rachen. 
Salvator heißt soviel wie Retter, Heiland. Und richtig: Dieses Bier ist das Leiden Christi!Test vom 21.10.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche
At Zum Paulaner, Stuttgart.  Not to my taste judging by other ratings!  A very malty, sweet sticky beer with a huge malt kick.  Urgh!
Amber red with a froathy white head. Aroma of malt, bread. Full bodied with an oily texture and malty taste. A bit "too much" alcoholic. A pleasant beer, even though not proper to drink during summer

Pours a deep copper colour with a faint creamy head on the edges. Aroma of sweet bready malts, caramel and banannas. Flavour of sweet bready malts, caramel, nuts and some sweet berries. Very smooth mouthfeel with a warming, bready, fruity, malty finish. Alcohol is quite well hidden.

33 cl bottle, BBE 06/12

Sweetish, malty aroma, but unfortunately with some solvent and metal. Rather thin palate for a DP. Flavour has also sweet malt with metal and hints of solvent. Not nice.

330 ml bottle.

Pours a deep copper colour with a faint white head on the edges. Aroma of sweet bready malts, caramel and nuts. Flavour of sweet bready malts, caramel, nuts and some sweet berries. Very smooth mouthfeel with a warming, bready, fruity, malty finish. Alcohol is quite well hidden. Nice Doppelbock.

330 ml bottle. Hazy dark amber colour, thin off-white head. Caramel-malty aroma with spices and dried fruits. The flavour is syrupy-sweet, with dark fruits, nicely spicy finish. A hint of alcohol warmth is also present. Ok.

Bottled, 33 cl. Pours cloudy red with a nice beige head that disappears completely. Aromas: Strawberry, banana, vanilla, malt, caramel, hints of coffee. Taste: Sweet, medium (-) bitterness. Hints of salt. Bread. Palate: Medium (-) body, little thin, high carbonation. Nice aromas but frankly too sweet for my real liking.

Salvaattori on tumman punainen ja kirkas olut. Vaahtoa se muodostaa niukasti. Sen tuoksussa on karamellia, tummia hedelmiä ja kanelia. Olut on makeahko, kuiva, hedelmäinen ja mausteinen. Kevyttä kamaa, vaikka volttejakin löytyy. Alkoholi tosiaan tuntuu kokoajan läpi jonkun verran ja sen takia sanoisinkin, että tämä on kylmempien kelien olut. Näin heinäkuussa ei ehkä pääse ihan arvoonsa.

Beer pours nutty brown, clear with dissipating small off-white head. Aroma is predominantly malt, caramel, honey and some yeast. Flavour is sweet with caramel malt and dry fruit notes. Palate is somewhat oily. Finish is malty well balanced (not overly sweet) with a touch of hop bitterness. It is a very satisfying bock - I like.

50cl bottle. Pours cloudy amber with steady bubbles and a small head which disappears in a few minutes. The nose has toffee, bananas and apple sorbet. The taste has a sweet ’n’ sour thing going on - apple and alcohol sweetness and yeast sourness. The palate is big in structure, fairly big in texture, refreshing on the end but with a big alcohol burn. Overall, I found this more interesting than good.

Watery as hell. Smells like a loaf of bread, a slight touch of belgian sugar and dried fruit save this from tanking. The flavor offers me absolutely nothing. I literally cannot even come up with flavors to BS. Water, a slight hint of yeast and maybe some malt if I’m really trying, and then that’s it. Awful. A nice appearance is the only thing that saves this brew. My roommate, Patrick says, "tastes like piss!"
Pretty nice doppelbock, better than I had expected. Copper color. Smell malts, caramel, nuts, and sweetness. Decent taste. Medium body and carbo.

Underrated doppelbock, better than the Celebrator (which I always thought was vastly overrated). Nice body. BIg maltiness on the nose, but nowhere near as sweet as expected, which is great. Very balanced flavor or malt and wood. Great beer. Several months past best before date.
Sweet aroma, malty. Amber/brwon appearance. Light sweetness in taste, lightly bitter, malty, roasty.

500ml Bottle (Tack Gert and Eva) - Dark amber/red with a small head. Malty,fruity and slightly musty aroma. Fruity and slightly tangy taste with notes of berries,caramel and hints of maple syrup. The alcohol is not as evident in the taste as I was expecting it to be. A tingling sensation can be felt on the tongue in the finish.

Pours a deep copper with cream coloured head. Sweet aromas dominated by stone fruits, cinnamon and sweet malt.  Flavours are sweet but not overly so. Darker stone fruits seem to come through in the taste. Minimal alcohol. Full mouthfeel. Relatively dry finish. Yep great beer.
Reddish orange in color. Decent sized head with minimal lacing. Nose is sweet, malty, honey, doughy. Palate is sweet, honey and spice. light bitter finish.

Red amber colored with a small off-white head that leaves minimal lacing.  The aroma is malty, a bit of caramel and coffee and just a hint of hops.  The flavor is likewise malty, with some nuttiness and a touch of bitterness.  Nothing bad here, but nothing exceptional either.
Bottle. Pours a hazy amber with tan foam. Smells of badly and wheat with hints of alcohol and caramel. Tastes lightly bitter with lots of caramel and hints of peanuts and alcohol.
Roasted, even burnt. The 8 % took me bysurprise. Other details are already quite dim.

Bottle @ Home. Pours golden with a small offwhite head. Aroma of malt, caramel, nuts, sweet fruit, brown sugar. Taste is malt, sweet caramel, nuts, oranges, raisins. Medium body, soft carbonation, slightly achohol in the finish. 230611
Some head, dark golden. Light nose, with a little.malfunctioning caramel and orange, raisins. Medium body and fime length. Taste is sweet, fruitcake, Orange and quite powerfull.

frankfurt, germany.  .5L bottle poured into a snifter glass.  pours redish-brown with a bit of an orangy color.  very small head, almost non-existant.  aroma is very malty and bready with caramal, honey and maple syrup notes.  very sweet aroma.  flavor is very malty but sweet.  fruity, caramel, and a healthy amount of alcohal at the end.  amazingly complex but a bit hard to drink as most doppelbocks are.

11.2oz bottle in a stem glass.  Pours deep copper/amber with a lingering, cream-colored head.  Aroma strong of nuts, hints of cereal and caramel, and a decent amount of hops for this beer.  Flavor about the same.  Average texture.  Surprisingly good for a German beer.
Bottle. Brown with medium off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, nuts, fruit, dried fruit, little, sweet, hops and a little bitter.
Pours with a lighter color than expected, amber color, little head.  Good tasting Double Bock, not a great balance.  Maybe too much CO2, Probably average from German standards, but still drinkable.

Tap @ Kaisla, Helsinki 09/06/11. Burnished copper with a medium, thick, long-lasting, off-white head. Aroma is bready malts. Taste is sweet, bready malts with a slight herbal finish. Palate is medium. Very one-dimensional.

Poured from a 12oz bottle. Pours copper and hazy with a thin white head with little lacing. Aroma is strong of some kind of spice or wood. Flavor is malty, and pretty blah. I’m very confused about this style because Sudwerks dopplebock is black and delicious. So I’m going to work on that.
Bottle from lcbo, not a big fan it has a dark brown pour, smell is very woody and the taste is so as well, it had a harsh finish and ruff aroma the edges, interesting stuff

Sweet fruits, caramel, bread & hints of alcohol. The aroma is quite strong & malty. 

Sweet malts and to a lesser extent caramel, there also appear to be a hint of honey and bread. There is a lingering sweetness which is very nice. 

Smooth, medium bodied beer with almost no carbonation. Very easy to drink despite the high alcohol content. Crisp and well balanced. 

A strange, new combination to me but one that I enjoyed &hope to find again. 

1001 Beers to try before you die:

0.33 bottle. Reddish, dark amber color, clear, very small head that disappears afer a while. Aroma was caramel, fruits, alcohol. Taste is buttery, especially if left resting in the glass for few minutes. Then also yeast, cherry. Thick, strong, oily and sticky, got a booze from just one. (June ’11)

(Resampled April ’12). Almost as said above, can’t feel fruity notes but lots of sweet malts. Texture is dense and oily and the brew is overall ethylic. Taste sweet and the finish is moderately bitter.
Poured into a pint glass. Appearance is translucent mahogany with no head. Aroma is prunes and alcohol. Taste is much like the nose: prunes, raisins, and finishing boozy. Not really my cup of tea.

Gorgeous deep amber colour, slow dissipating head. This has depth and bucketloads of aroma. Oranges, bready roastiness, toffee, caramel, nutty yeastiness, butterscotch. So much going on.
Enormous, soft, silky, tasty, luscious fruit flavours and warming alcohols. A long lingering finish. Everything I thought a doppelbock ought to be.
Aroma was spicy but not very malty. Had a somewhat bitter aftertaste. Very average for a Doppelbock. Does not come close to my favorite, Spaten Optimator.

500mL bottle - Pours rosy amber with a small off-white head that doesn’t last very long. Sweet, yeasty malt on the nose, with some grape jelly. Taste is roughly the same, yeasty sweet bread, super malty with a bit of grape jelly. Touch of alcohol and light hopping on the finish. Pretty syrupy in the mouth with light carbonation. I know this is supposed to be a classic doppelbock, but I have to say it’s not my favorite.
Dark brown with a small head. Aroma of caramel, fruit, alcohol and bread. Taste is very malty and sweet with a definite alcohol presence. Medium body. Just a bit overdone on the sweet malt.

Pours a dark brown color with a very small head and no lacing. Aroma is cherry, caramal malts, and honey. The taste is all malt, sticky sweet honey malts and a little alcohol burn. Pretty good beer if your in the mood for something malty.
Pours dark amber with no head.  Aroma of caramel and sugar.  Somewhat thin palate with sweet taste.  Pretty good.

Light head which quickly dissipates. Medium amber with hazy clarity. Sweet, malty aroma with hints of banana. Palate feel is a little on the flat side. Not much carbonation. Taste isn’t as malty as the aroma might lead one to believe. Balanced profile but I can’t find anything about this beer that separates it from others like it. Great beer for session drinking with German food, like any Paulaner.

Bottle at World of Beers.  Try it for yourself if your not sure the one thousand seven hundred and forty eight other ratings aren’t correct.....
Re-rate (4-5-21).  On tap at Biergarten Boca. Murky light brown pour with like kaki head. So freaking good. Perfect balance of sweet caramels and dough/bread notes. Not overly sweet with a fantastic mouthfeel and body.
12oz bottle. cloudy gold, solid head. aroma of bread/yeast. taste of caramel, light alcohol
Really enjoyed this beer. Great dark malty aromas of heavy bread, maybe molasses, but not too much. Just right. Not much carbonation, oily/creamy in the mouth. Very enjoyable.

bottle in a weizen (finally got the spelling right) glass - pours misty and dark amber with rich tan foam.  Aroma is robust with a blend of plums, liquorish and/or chocolate.  After a second sniff, the alcohol is present.  Taste is sweet and bitter like the chocolate you get with espressos.  Provides a long finish with a creamy film.  Enjoyable in every aspect of how a beer should be, but the search continues for the "perfect beer".

Bottle. Khaki head on a ruby brown, clearish body. Nice toffee, dark fruits, prune, and some slight toast and sweetness in the aroma.  Malty, rich, but not overly sweet.  Toffee again, and a bit sticky with plum sweetness and bitter malt in the finish.  Medium body and a bit viscous.  Nice brew.

After reading about this many  times I couldn’t wait to try it.
I know the Germans and Belgians can brew some very deceptive beers but this just didn’t live up expectation.
Teak in colour, a little malt and raisin on the nose.
Full bodied and fruity as expected but too heavy throughout.
Bottle from Beers of Europe is in good condition but I’ve been drinking Worldwide ales now for over 20 years and this doesn’t float my boat.
Personally I prefer the smoked beers, but each to their own...

330ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy auburn colour with a tan head.  Aroma is heavy with fruit notes (almost fruit punch, peach, cherry, orange, apple cider) caramel, and corn syrup candies.  I was surprised by the taste, as I was expecting full on sugar, but it’s much drier that I was expecting.  Starts with a sour note, followed by burnt sugars, woody notes, dried fruit, toasted malt, with apple, molasses and bitterness in the finish.  A full on bargain.
Bottle at a club in Bavaria that the U.S. Army took over in 1945.  Hazy dark amber color, medium beige head.  Aroma of burnt caramel.  Taste is dark roasted malt, dark caramel, butterscotch.  nice.

Picked up this bottle at Chevy Chase in DC. Served in a pilsner glass.

Pours a moderate brown color with a bit of a copper hue. There is a single-finger light tan head that sticks around for a bit before falling and leaving a bit of spotty lacing. The nose is pretty plain with a bit of sweet malt, bread, and caramel. Nothing too much in addition to that, and even those are pretty faint. The taste follows along the same lines--there really just isn’t that much going on and I’m not impressed with the complexity of this one. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with a bit too much alcohol in the finish. Drinkability is okay, but nothing I’d seek out again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-24-2011

Pours out a rustic deep hazy copper, with not much head; maybe I poured it wrong.  Aroma is very malty indeed. Im getting tones of toast, pale malt, caramelized sugar, apple and honey.  Taste brings back all the malty aromas onto the palate--honey, toast, pale malt, caramel, a touch of fig, and a touch of twangy hop bitterness at the finish.  I remember liking this a ton a long time ago, but now, I just don’t know...

Poured a hazier amber color with a good head that stayed.  Aroma full of malts, caramel.  Taste was a medium sweetness with a lite bitterness.  Medium bodied, creamier texture, ave carbonation, long finish.  Smooth tasting, with caramel, some sweet sugars, malts.  Not a huge doppelbock fan but this was good.

Dark orange / ruby brown with a rather quickly diminishing tan head. 
Aroma is malty and sweet. Heavy fruit sweets, dried sweet figs. Flavour is dominated by sweet malts, sugary, caramel and dough. Molasses tone. Only slight hop bitterness. Finish: malts, syrup, not lingering for long.  Classical doppelbock, rather too sweet for my liking though. 
(From 0,5L bottle)

500 ml bottle purchased at Royal Liquor in KCMO. Best before 05/11 L15001V marked on the label. Pour is a very hazy orange brown with a one inch light tan head that falls noisily and pretty quickly. Aroma is apple cherry fruit sweet malt, honey, some straw floral (dried flowers?) along with a dusty mechanical mild dirtiness (this clears quick). Taste is cleaner, though still is pretty heavy on the fruit sweet maltiness. The straw and floral is present as well, and as the beer warmed the straw integrated nicely with the honey fruit sweetness of the malt. There is a touch of alcohol heat in the back, but does not detract at all. Palate is medium bodied, nicely unfiltered, mildly cloying and pleasantly warming aftertaste.
(Bottle) Smells sweet, like grape and figs. Slightly dark amber colour. Bit thin mouth feel but a nice almost liquorice aftertaste. Nice beer
Great double bock. Malty head. Nice deep taste. Great pour.    Amazing beer

Slightly hazy amber. Poured into a mug  from a 12 oz. bottle. Small with white head that reduces to a small ring. Small carbonation bubbles in the glass. Aroma is of dark fruit especially raisins.  Taste is of sweet malt and raisins. The ABV is 7.9% is very well hidden. Toward the finish there is a rye bread flavor after it warms. The finish is somewhat dry.   Overall, for the style if available I would buy again. It’s tasty.  Thanks for the bottle LiteWait!!

Slightly hazy amber. Poured into a mug small with white head that reduces to a small ring. Small carbonation bubbles in the glass. Aroma is of dark fruit especially raisins.  Taste is of sweet malt and raisins. The ABV is 7.9% is very well hidden. Toward the finish there is a rye bread flavor after it warms. The finish is somewhat dry.   Overall, for the style if available I would buy again. It’s tasty. Shared with AirForceHops.

Pours a fuzzy copper. More orange than brown with not much head at all. Smells of butterscotch and sweet bread. The taste is big, smooth, and creamy. Lots of butterscotch, but a bit of a sour bite in the finish. Some late alcohol and sweetness, too.

It’s quite good. I’d put it in the top tier of doppelbocks, but I wouldn’t say it’s my favorite.

0.5L bottle in Berlin. Pours a caramel brown. Smells of roasted malt and molasses. Mouthfeel is thick with a full flavor of toasted malt, caramel, brown sugar, molasses, wheat, slight bitterness, and alcohol. Morphs from sweet in to slight bitterness In the finish. Quite good. Puts other similar beers to shame.

It has deep amber color  with a thin head that disappears quickly. Has a very smoky malted aroma with a touch sweetness. The taste is very similar but finishes with a mild sweet and sour taste. A very interesting brew indeed and I’m glad I tried it. This is as close to the Doppelbock I had in the army while in Germany back in the 1980’s.

Paulaner Salvator has a thin, off-white head and a very hazy, orange-amber appearance, with a little bit of lacing and a good amount of bubbles streaming up the glass. The aroma is strong on the citrus and malt, but no hops are there. Taste is likewise citrus and barley malt, and alcohol is present across the sip. Hop character is minimal. Mouthfeel is heavy and thick, and Paulaner Salvator finishes harsh and not particularly easy drinking. But, I did like it and found it to be an interesting drink. Overall, it’s pretty good, and I’d recommend a try. It’s like Hurricane High Gravity, in some respects. That’s what came to mind.

RJT

Bottle.
Dark reddish brown brew with some bits of white head.  Not much going on aroma wise - malty and ripe fruit.  Flavor is slightly sweet, nice bready malt and some chocolate.  Very nice!
Red body with small white head. Aroma is of caramel and almonds. Smooth, low carbonation texture, flavour is a bit alcoholic, sweet, with notes of caramel.

nutty, caramel aroma, very dark and treacly in appearance, strong taste which lingers in the mouth.  very strong beer which can be enjoyed only in limited quantities owing to the strength. Very pleasant

Pours a medium copper with thin beige head.  Smooth, flavorful, very easy to drink.  Smooth with the malt backbone - nice offering.  Although higher in ABV as a Doppelbock, very easy going down.  Prost!

Rating #499, bottle from Edeka in Vilshofen, Germany 
 


Drunken from a Lagerglass. A brown-yellow beer, and somewhat lighter than I expected. The aroma dissapointed me with only some malts and light alcohol, but the taste is better and gets better as the bottle empties. Flavors are a mix of chocolate, malts, bread, alcohol, and a rather vineous finish with a good amount of bitterness. Soft and a bit thick beer, pleasant palate. All in all a really pleasant brew, but it lacks a bit of everything to reach the real craft brew class.

Very dark brown in colour with a short lived tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty with hints of fruit. The taste is strong malt with fruits, caramel and hints of bready yeast. Nice soft mouth feel. Full of flavour and quite nice.

bouteille 50cl. Rousse, mousse beige
Arôme malt et caramel avec des notes de torréfaction, le tout se ressent en bouche avec en prime des notes de malt et chocolat, le houblon reste en retrait donnant un fini légèrement houblonné.

What an amazing pour almost carrot colored and unfiltered.  Explosively carbonated and nose is lively with a raisiny malt.  Refreeshing to start but then delves into a complex yet light medly of malty cider, orange, allspice and brown bread.  Well balanced but slightly too much flavor for an almost sparkling beer.

pours a rusty/cloudy reddish brown color with respectable head.  Smells of ripe, fruit, boozy fermented apple juice and pears.  Taste is big and sweet.  ABV is very well masked.  Warming, but not boozy.  Mouth feel and texture is thick and lively in carbonation.  Focus is on the malt with a nice sweet dynamic finish.  Gets better as you drink it/get used to it.  Different than what I am used to, but I can dig it.
very bland, not offensive, masks the alcohol well. For a mainstream doubledock to fills its role well
Very tasty beer. It has a nice amber color with a medium head. The beer has a tasty caramel flavor with a touch of figs or other dried fruits coming through. Smooth finish. A very tasty Doppelbock.

Flaske 50 cl. Karamelfarvet hælde med stort off white hoved  med middel holdbarhed. Aroma malt, lys karamel, sukker og noget frugt. Smagen er forholdsvis sød, og bære præg af varmende alkohol. Farin og lys karamel dominere smagen.
En smule bitterhed opleves i slutningen, men varmende alkohol og sødme dominere.

Pours clear bubbly reddish-copper with loads o’ foam.  Surprisingly light colour, really.  Big sugary sweet thing.  Touch of caramel but mostly just big sweet cereal malts.  Tastes fantastic.  Thick mouthfeel.  Warming alcohol.  Nice.

Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom 

No seriously a nice dark doppelbock. Big malty notes with some dark fruits in there.

Bottle 50 cl. Pours an amber brown with a medium but fading off-white head and an aroma of malts, and caramel. The flavour is sweet, with lots of dark malts, caramel again and overripe fruits. The mouthfeel is soft and the finish is a tad bitter. A really nice bock.

A - little hazy dark orange with average head
S - first it goes with sweet malt, then followed by apples, figs and dark fruits
T - solid and creamy taste of caramel, malt with well balanced hoppiness and little tangy, but very compact. You can recognize dark fruits in the taste (raising, dark grapes, figs, etc.)
M - medium to high body with medium carbonation
D - nice and easy to drink, especially the curiosity to find other tones of the dark fruits in the body

16.9 oz. bottle from Woodman’s Madison

Ar: Dominated by malt, no surprise.  Toffee, caramel, a bit of burnt sugar and some wood.
Ap: Pours a hazy amber with a 2" pillowy manila head that sticks around forever.  Good lace.
T: Very sweet malt up front.  Lots of caramel, toffee, a bit of wood on the finish.
P: Sticky, chewy body.  Thick and filling, a good winter filler.

O: I really enjoyed this.  These are great for the cold winter months.

One of the most frequently rated beers I haven’t gotten to yet, I had this on draft at Vito’s in St. Louis while waiting for a pizza to go. They had a whole Paulaner tap system. Pours a cloudy but bright amber color with a very small off-white head. Aroma of Caramel and Bavarian-style malts, banana, brown sugar, toast, nuts, and clove. Flavor of caramel malts, toasted brown sugar, nuts, and sweet bread. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, malty mouthfeel. I don’t mind my doppelbocks a little more toasty and roasty than this one, but this is still a fine beer and one of the standards for doppelbocks, so what do I know?
Very characteristic doppelbock alcoholic malt bomb.  Pretty intense, complex caramel malt flavor, definitely a beer to savor and, most likely, not one overindulge in.

Világosbarna hab és szép vörösréz szín ami nem teljesen tiszta, nagyon enyhén ködös. 
Illata aszalt füge valamint édes, pörkölt maláta. 
Nálam már súrolja a túl édes határt, éppen, hogy bele fér. Befejezése száraz kesernyés.
Jó. Vajon csapolva milyen lehet?

Vöröses, világosbarnás szín, piszkosfehér habbal. Illata könnyed, malátás, gyümölcsös és enyhén karamellás. Íze is ezeket rejti magában, főleg a malátás vonulat a meghatározó, aszalt gyümölcsös és karamellás édességgel, a végén egy finom komlóadaggal. Keserédes, testes sör, az alkoholtartalom is érződik, de csak lazán megmosolyogtat és felmelegít. Nagyon finom, egészen különleges sör, régi barátok vagyunk.
Clear dark amber with a huge and lasting off-white head. Aroma has sweet caramel, malt, yeast and a little dried fruit. Quite full bodied with a malty and light alcoholic finish. 110111

330ml bottle sample purchased at the LCBO. Pours a cloudy orange/ brown, no real head to speak of. Aroma is of plum and other fruit. Taste is also of fruit and malt and maybe a little of spice. Decent.
Pours hazy orangish amber with off-white head and some lacing.  Notes of maple and grass.  Well balanced taste with a tang.

pours clear orange-rusty with a creamy off-white head. sweet caramel, intense maltiness, bourbon, toffee, vanilla, fruits with a some good backbone hops - slightly grassy, providing a smooth medium finish. average carbonation, full bodied. a classic - thanks for inventing the style!

Tap. Poured a light copper. Nose is light, if anything a touch sweet and metallic. Full bodied beer with rich malts a hint of alcohol which seems to add some sweet notes. Rich malts And sweet abv carry the finish. Quite good

Old rate. This beer is noteworthy specifically because I tried it while it the far reaches of China (Chi Fu outside of Guang Zhou). I had been in the country for a week and was desperate for a decent beer. Lo and behold there was a single local store that imported good beer and this was one of them. Brown colour, big bubbly head. Strong bitterness, roasted miexed flavours of herbs, spices, malt or maybe even caramel. Extremely rich taste, drinks awesomely well. Great doppelbock. Given bonus points because of the location? Perhaps...but great nonetheless.
Amber brown color.Disappearing white head.Smell wood,wine must,caramel,sweet.Taste sweet,wood,caramel,alcohol,light metallic,bitter for the ballance.
Amo tantissimo questa birra, è una delle mie tedesche preferite. Con quell’aroma di biscotti, e con quel bel corpo e gusto pieno, che la fanno apprezzare in inverno.
500 ml bottle a brown colored beer with a white head aroma sweet malts spices caramel dry fruits taste sweet malts spices caramel dry fruits and some hops

Pours a cloudy amber color with an off white head.Its got the light aroma of sweet malt with a tiny note of hay.The flavor was a water down malt flavor.The was medium at best with little aftertaste.Overall it was okay at best.

330 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a slightly cloudy deep copper/orange with only the tiniest white head.  Aroma is solidly malty with sweet caramel, bread and slightly sour fruit.  Taste has lots of sourish fruit (cherry/plum), caramel and wood.  Rather flat carbonation.  Good, not great.

500ml Bottle.  Pours a opaque dark brown with little head.  Aroma is strong with sweet malts and dried fruit predominant.  Flavors are also dried fruit on the front end with some caramel as well.  The taste is quite sweet but it also has a nice grassy hop finish.  It is a full-bodied beer that sits heavy on the palate.  Excellent Doppelbock and worthy of the title of Original.

17-dec-2010
50cl bottle at home. Redbrown beer with a beige head. Pretty sweet doppelbock, a little less balanced than the Andechser I had earlier that evening. Nevertheless, a pleasure to drink this beer!

50cl bottle from mein-biershop. Poured reddish brown color with a thin beige looking head. Aroma is very off atleast in my nose, at first dark fruits and some malt, as it got warmer, more gluelike aroma. Flavor is much better, caramel malt, plums and bit yeasty. Some alcohol detected as well. Sweet finish.

Mild notes of rich, dark malts on the nose with a deep, reddish sunset-like glow.  Full bodied, though I feel it could stand to be thicker.  Rather dry with a pleasant bitterness, with a rather "grown-up" taste.  Sweet bread and licorice on the palate.  The overall experience sums to a really enjoyable rich lager.  I personally prefer it to Optimator.

WOW i love this beer. I am partial to brown beers, but this one I could drink anytime anywhere for any reason! Love this beer, its especially great at the Paulaner Restaurant because of the amazing Bavarian style with the Oktoberfest touch.  Awesome, if your in southwest germany go there!! Love this stuff, thinking about bringing a case back to US when I come back!

Bottle: pours a peachy light brown, thin persistent white ring. Looks dense and opaque. Nose- fruit, apricot, orange, grapes, caramel malts. Taste- roasted malts, fermented fruit, a bit of alcohol, medium bitterness. lighter bodied than expected and lively carbonation. An old recipe that perserveres! salute

At the Doppelbock Width Tasting in Shachar’s house, thanks Oren, bottle, pours amber with a head that dissipates quickly, banana, nut and sweetish aroma, caramel and chocolate flavor, slightly bitter, and overall a palatable beer.

On tap at Wildeman in November 2010. 

Slightly hazy amber. Aroma of malt, caramel and dark fruits. The same in the taste. I liked Salvator, it was not as sweet as other Doppelbocks. Easy to drink.

Just had this with a nice Roth Case Gruyere... what a great food beer.  Pours orange-brown, with a nice, slightly off white head.  MALT!  Hear me again, MALT!  The alcohol content was very underplayed, maybe it  was the cheese.  Finishes with a nice roasted barley character, subtle hop hint (?).  Good Beer.

A: The pour is a dark copper color with a fizzy sand colored head that quickly fades away.

S: The nose starts of bready and mildly sweet with some slightly overdone toffee. There’s a bit of sweet banana as well as a subtle spice (clove) character.

T: Toffee is again the primary contributor of sweetness with a surprising amount of bitterness for a doppelbock. There’s a fair amount of (spiced) bread and an underlying earthiness.

M: The body is medium with a medium level of carbonation. Fairly smooth on the palate.

D: Not my favorite doppelbock. As it warms the alcohol begins to become more noticeable, but it’s still good enough.
Not bad.  The color is a little cloudy which throws off my palate but otherwise not too bad for me.
Simple molasses aroma. The taste is similar to corn syrup followed by burnt almonds. Leaves a bitter after taste.

Tasted on tap at Cafe Berlin in Denver, Colorado.  Hazy dark red-orange appearance- not much head.  Caramel and malty aroma.  Great sweetness with the thick malty flavor.  Caramel thick flavor.  A good doppelbock.

Bottle. Pours a hazy amber with fizzy tannish head. Almost looks like apple cider. Aroma is fruity plum, raisins, sweet malt, bran muffin and a tad bit of alcohol. Great malty sweet flavor with hints of raisin, prune and nutty grains. One of my favs for sure.

Tap. Decent head, with an awesome texture. It’s like silk, very tiny bubbles. Lasts quite long as well. Color of the head is a bit tanned, while the body is orange and clear (does not seem to match). In the aroma I find something like autumn leaves, sand and some honey. Taste is a bit disappointing, quite plain, a bit sweet and some bitterness, with the sensations of the aroma recurring. The body however is decent. Overall, not my bock, but worth a try.
Pours a reddish brown.  Aroma of sweet malt and maybe some plums.  Taste of malts, bread, and alcohol.  Very nice.

Le liquide est ambré.  La mousse est inexistante.  Au nez, les arômes du malt sont dominants: pain, caramel, chocolat, fruits et alcool se manifestent à des degrés différents.  Le goût me semble très riche, très gras, avec un malt sucré qui écrase tout.  L’alcool est bien présent et se révèle par une chaleur posée.  En bouche, le liquide est moyennement dense avec une effervescence délicate et une texture liquoreuse.  La finale est maltée avec une présence chaude de l’alcool.

bottle, very specific malty aroma, hazy, amber, brown foam, medium bitterness, medium to heavy sweetness, full body, slick feel, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, bitter, awesome beer
update 2012: nice strong cherry and dark fruits tones in aroma. rich ruby colour, brown head, warmy taste a bit alcohol i can feel but maltness is dominating, long warmy finish , good stuff and drinkable i would say

Bottle. $1.99 for a single. Pours a slightly opaque carmel copper color with a minimal white head that collars around the glass. The nose is fruity, caramel, toffee, and a slight biscuity. Almost has an artificial banana smell as well. Medium mouthfeel. Now, this is a pretty sweet beer, maltwise. Caramel and biscuity tasting with a slight bitterness to it in the end. For 7.9% the alcohol is pretty hidden but as this warms you get a slight warming effect in the end.

Bottle. Hazy mahogany with a small dense off white head that fades to practically nothing. Aroma of caramel, dark fruit, bread and light alcohol. The flavor is very malty, lots of ripe fruit, bread and some caramel, no alcohol taste. Medium body with mild carbonation and a smooth, soft mouth feel. Not as good as I remember but still a nice beer.
Sticky, bready, complex yeastiness, expertly malted, subtle dried fruit and honey spice undertones. Delicious.
Pours from bottle a hazy amber with little head. Smells a bit fruity, tastes like a fruity, wheaty bock. Not bad.

Bottle:
Beige to light brown foamy head, disappears quick.
Clear amber orange colored beer.
Smell malts, caramel, honey, spices, brown sugars, hops.
Taste spices, toasty malts, sweet, grassy, caramel, bitter, light sour and bit dry.
Like a bit of a viscous mouth feel.

500 ml bottle purchased 15 months ago at BevMo in Mission Valley ($2.19).  Pours a burnt red hue with orange-ish highlights and two full fingers of beige foam which quickly dissipates.  Aroma is sweet with notes of dark caramel, honey, wheat bread, and ripe dark fruit (candied date, fig, raisin, cherry).  Flavor is similarly sweet and contains mostly what is found in the nose: rich caramel, honey, molasses, and dark fruit (cherry and raisin stand out).  I am surprised by the lightness in the body for a relatively big beer.  Good stuff.  (1672, 405)

cloudy orange amber pour with a thin offwhite head.  Aroma is bready as fuck, sweet toasted malt, mouthfeel is medium and a bit creamy.  flavor is rich malty goodness.  A classic doppelbock bursting with rich layers of malt.  YUM
12oz bottle pours cloudy amber orange with a thin khaki head. Aroma is sour cherries, yeast, caramel. Taste is similar to aroma with hints of wood and vanilla, light spice. Nice.
Yeasty, sweet, but not overly bitter.  Medium body, nice aroma.  Goes down smoothly.
This liquid bread is deeply filling and satisfying. Really enjoyed the bready maltiness throughout. Excellent for fall.

Bottle.  Pours dark amber with a small, dense off white head.  Aroma is lots of caramel and roasted almond/cherry.  Flavor is caramel, sweet malt, almond/cherry, raisin, a little smoke, a touch of licorice.  Finishes sweet and bitter.  Palate is slightly oily.  An excellent doppelbock.

Key Food, flatbush ave ($10.50): Pours a muddy light brown with a beige head. Fruity and slightly boozy aroma. Tastes of licorice, kind of sweet. A little bit of hops. Quite malty and a tad roasted in those. Fruity and such. Does not feel like it has 8% alcohol most of the time, but is actually rather easy to drink (unlike some doppelbocks that are just boozy as all hell).
Amber color, no head and almost no lace at all. Sweet malts, crisp, bitter, slight carbonation, very refreshing.

16.9oz bottle.  Pours a copperish amber with almost no head and a large amount of sediment floating in the glass.  Aroma consisting of sweet toasty caramel malt with toffee overtones and the inside of a lawnmower bag while the engine is running. Flavor is caramel, tin can, toffee sweetness, bread and metallic.  Not a huge fan of the style.

From a bottle.  Pour is amber in color with a small white head.  caramel in aroma with some fruitiness.  Flavor is strong caramel and bread.  Slight metallic flavor especially in the finish.  Not bad overall, but that strange off flavor really is throwing me for a loop.

500ml bottle thanks to largadeer.  Pours a clear amber color with a nice large yellowish head that leaves a foam.  The aroma is nice, with sweet caramel and good fruity notes.  Simple but good.  The flavor is caramel and toffee, plum and fig, and slight toast.  Tasty stuff.  Smooth mouthfeel with medium body.  Solid doppelbock overall, if not a standout in the style.
Amber pour with a white head. Aroma of caramel, sweet. Flavor is malty. Tons of caramel mixed with alcohol. Sweet finish. Pretty strong.

I liked how it looked with its darker copper-amber tone and two inch head.  The head never quite went away.  The aroma is definetely malted up with some noticeable yeastiness in the background. The mouthfeel is rather bold.  The taste has this sort of molasses-like character along with the malts and a sharp bite at the end.

Pours dark amber/ moderate brown with virtually no head or sediment. Nose is rich and brown sugary. Flavor is similarly sweet with a good helping of brown sugar, maple, and a touch of cinnamon. Hops are very subdued and barely noticable. Alcohol is present, especially on the backside. A decent brew and a good example of the style but a little too sweet for me.

Strong sweet malt aroma.  Brown sugar. Maybe some fruit. Very nice. Appearance is a dark brown with a hint of orange. Taste is sweet. Very nice. Not cloying. Earthy herbal hops present. Hint of banana maybe apple. Slight roastiness. Palate is medium. Nice malty sweet with a bit of roast and hidden fruit lingers nicely with excellent aftertaste. Overall this is a very nice beer. Great drinker even at this ABV. The best of the style IMO.

One of the best Doppelbocks in the world. It is really smooth, but not one of the the very sweet kind, like animator or andechs doppel bock dunkel. Its rich and dark and with a really strong palate.

If you like doppelbock you have to try it!
Bottle, Blarney Stone, Menorca. Dark red, heavily malt flavoured beer. Very strong alcoholic taste, bordering on acidic, but in a good way. Vineous nose, with a hint of spirit about it.
This was a nice traditional German doppelbock. The taste was very smooth and I enjoyed it.

Bottled. Pours dark orange/brown with a frothy offwhite head. Aromas of chocolate, malt and brown sugar. Flavors on the tongue are the same. The beer finishes nicely, but leaves you wanting more. Overall a very well balanced beer, with a decent finish.

Appearance: light for a DB; coppery orange with a short, tan bubbly head that quickly dissipates; no discernable lacing.  Aroma:  again, on the light side for a DB; maybe some white raisins/grapes to go with the typical roasted malts, molasses and brown sugar; a bit of ginger snaps in there too.  Taste:  rich and sweet, with loads of malty caramel; a very faint hint of medicinal bitter hops.  Finish:  rich and sweet, with loads of malty caramel; a very faint hint of medicinal bitter hops. Notes:  I love a doppelbock, but this wasn’t my favorite.  Flavor was pretty good, but the mouth was very oily, and the finish was not nearly as dry and crisp as I prefer.
Pours a nice copper like color with a small but noisy head (lots of bubbles popping).  Taste is very malty, feels slightly viscous in the mouth and finishes slightly bitter.
Pours attractive dark orange to brown with lightly creamy head; smells rich, sweet; taste mix of bock malts, caramel, sweet

A-pours a cloudy dark amber, notes of orange edges with a brownish center, the head is very lightly tan in color and creamy in texture.

S-the nose is large, bready caramel and brown sugar in abundance with  hints of molasses, notes of yeast lie underneath, a touch of banana and a good bit of green apple.

T-the taste is a  bit of a malty mess, burnt brown sugar and caramel, lightly bready, a much stronger presence of molasses and hints of chocolate seem to not fit well with the poorly burnt sugars up front.  the yeast and esters have faded and are almost an afterthought from the nose.  light alcohol present in the back with a touch of grassy tea like hops in the finish.

M-this is thick and syrupy, too thick and syrupy.  its rough to get down and the carbonation isn’t strong enough to help curb that maple syrupy like texture.

D-the nose lead you to believe a much more yeasty estery beer, the flavors are a blend of burnt malts and dark sweet flavors.  it just doesn’t seem to work well together for me.
Pours amber with a tan head.  Aroma is caramel, florals and some citrus.  Taste is sweet with some woodyness.  Extremely smooth mouthfeel.
Pours a muddy amber color with a small white head. The aroma is sweet caramel, nutty, with a strong malty backbone. Bit of hop bitterness on the tongue, but mainly rich, sweet malt. Very drinkable.

16.9 oz. bottle- Pours amber to red, slightly hazy, a little too thin head and poor lacework, aroma is caramel malt and has that European aroma. The flavor is brown sugar malt and some hop bite actually, if it weren’t for the appearance I would like this beer alot more, I keep looking at my glass and it looks flat, but it doesn’t taste flat. Carbonation is medium, body is full, overall an ok beer.
Doppelbock de 7.9% avec moût de 18%...goût d’alcool très intense...très peu houblonné, mais très sucré...lève un peu sur le coeur...goût qui ressemble un peu à la Schloss Samichlaus.

Bottle: Pours an amber red with an average off white head. Has a nutty aroma. Flavors are caramel malt, mild dark fruits, and mild spices. Seems to have a bitterness here , be it from the hops or the alcohol is beyond me. I would suggest that this brew feels fairly simplistic - It was good to be sure, but I wouldn’t say much else.
Bottle - Pours dark amber with small off-white head. Aroma: caramel, nicely carbonated. Taste is burnt malt + caramel + a bit nutty. A very nice warm doppelbock.
Alla spina al Paulaner’s di Lubeck; colore rossiccio, schiuma poco persistente, è molto spessa, corposa, seppur ben bilanciata con il buon sapore del malto. Non va giù agevolmente, ma è buona!

Bottle pour gives dark amber color with medium off-white head that recedes after a minute.  Aroma faint caramel and a bit sour, doesn’t really match the taste which is quite powerful with caramel, malts, slight dark fruits and spices.  Bit of a sweet aftertaste with mild bitter hop finish.  Palate medium-thick and a bit sticky.  Alcohol readily apparent but not overwhelming.

Would drink again, a good one.

bottle.  Pours a murky amber color with small beige head.  Aroma of caramel, burnt vegetables, clove.  Smooth and creamy, almost silky, nice palate, very drinkable.  Flavor presents sweet caramel, burnt toffee, some light spices.  This is very nice.  It has an earthiness, almost cellar feel to it that conjures images of monks brewing in cool, dank basements.  Good to sip on by the fireside, or whenever really.
Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours a dark amber with small white head.  Aroma is caramel, nicely carbonated, and lightly lacing.  Taste is toasty malty caramel and a hint of nut.  Good.

330ml bottle. Pours a clear black-brown, with a creamy off-white head, which dissipates quickly, leaving good lacing. The aroma is not the strongest, yet does contain a quite pleasant mix of sweet malt and plum notes. The flavour, similarly, sneaks up on you. Initially there is a moderate grassy hop bitterness, tempered by some sweetness, yet as it moves back some plum characteristics appear, with the slightest hint of coffee mingling with sweet fruit in the finish. A very easy-drinking beer for its strength, and very enjoyable.

I truly enjoy this beer - yes, it does have an alcohol flavour character to it...to my tastes a cognac like alcohol flavouring which I find addictive. Closer to a biere du garde from my experience. This is a 9pm by the fire type of beer.

I’m kind of upset. I have been teased with so many amazing Porter’s and Stout’s, that I can not longer truly enjoy another beer. I guess Lager’s still give me a thrill, and Wheat’s are alright. Anything else though, Pale Ale’s, whatever this is, just don’t do it any more.

Dark orange, off white head.  Huge malt aroma, toasty and earthy - quite pleasant.  Taste is slightly sweet like an Imperial IPA, but without the bitterness and plenty of malt flavor.  The finish has more malt flavor - not quite toast, but something stronger.  The only downside to this one is I seem to be able to detect the alcohol in it.

12oz bottle. Pours a nice hazy copper-gold with a head that’s surprisingly tan. Nice to look at. Nose is packed with caramel and accompanied by nuts, spices, light hops. Flavor is predominantly sweet, of course, with a nice little hint of toastiness in the backdrop. A clean finish, malty just like the rest of it, with a little bit of alcohol present. Palate is full and warming. An enjoyable classic, once that lives up to its reputation - not a crazy or strange beer, just a good one.

330 mL bottle from the LCBO, served in a snifter. Pours hazy orange-brown with a frothy tan head. Head fades but leaves some lace. The aroma is big and malty, with caramel, grain and nuts, paired with fruit and herbs. The flavour is moderately honey sweet throughout with a touch of bitter. The finish is fairly clean. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a thick, syrupy texture and light carbonation. On the whole, this is a nice example of a doppelbock. It is singlemindedly malty with a nice toasty sweetness. The alcohol is very well hidden. Would make a great ’winter warmer.’ 2010-07-22

Avery 
Ellie’s Brown Ale
Pours deep ruddy brown with a minimal whitish head and ok retention. Pleasing aroma of brown sugar, caramel, malt and a slight hop tinge. Semi sweet flavor with a nice caramelly malt flavor. Alcohol is hidden and very little bitter. A bit understated, but well balanced and easy drinking. Would serve at a party to everyone.

Pours a rich, deep red with a fairly thin white head. It has mild effervescence. The aroma is of charred malt with a hint of fruit. The taste is of very charred rye, yet slightly fruity (from the esters) with a hint of hops bitterness. This wasn’t a bad beer at all, but it was fairly forgettable.

Pours clear dark amber with nice fluffy off white head. Aroma of caramel, malts, dark bread. Sweet, some yeasty and malty refreshing flavor. Round, lean and sweet crisp on palate with some alcohol notes. Finishesacidy bitter but also sweet.
I didn’t like this from the first sniff. I will just say this. MALT LIQUOR.  Everything about it reeks of it. Over the top sickly sweetness. Drain pour.

I had this beer with some thai leftovers- it helped put out the fire! Full bodied, not very hoppy. Molasses notes with a crisp finish. Not very much of a head out of the bottle, but i’ve had it on tap and it was even more scrumptious.
Amber coloured, small dense head, beige. Aroma:malts, some hops. Taste is full, smooth, barleywine like, reasonable bitter, long finish, nice.

Sampled from their 330ml brown bottle. Poured a dark amber-ruby with a foamy head that did not last long and pretty much no lacing. Aromas were of sweet caramel malts and molasse, with the alcohol (being a high alcohol content). Taste were rich in malts, caramel, dates and other fruits. This brew had hardly any carbonation, and you could not taste the alcohol. Had a syrupy mouthfeel. This, being one of my first Dopplebock, is a pretty good experience, but I still am a lover of their white beer.

0.33l bottle from the LCBO.  Appearance is amazing, beautiful cloudy orange/amber color, very opaque.  Head is almost non-existant and whatever is there disappears within seconds.  Smells of some kind of dark fruit and something a little funky.  The "quick references" at the side of the screen mention barnyard, maybe something like that.  Taste isn’t very funky but fruity and sour.  Not bad, but I prefer the hefe-weisse..
A very good beer,with a strong taste,yet with a fine aroma pouring.One of the best Doppelbocks,but with a too sweet tone...
Great dopplebock. Not overly sweet like a lot of dopplebocks. Great caramalization and overall taste.

Pours a reddish brown with an off white foam head. Aroma is of dark malt and biscuits. For a doppelbock this beer is fairly well balanced. The malt character does not dominate like in other doppelbocks I’ve had. Will recommend as a starter doppelbock for people who may not be ready for the maltiness of the others. Solid beer.

Poured into a pint glass.

A: Dark orange. Poor head retention. No lacing to speak of.

S: Grapes and hamster (I’m not sure that’s what they were going for, but it’s definitely a new smell to me and I actually like it). Really though, it smells alright.

T: Wood chips (as in the kind used for hamster bedding), orange peel. Again, not too bad though it should be.

M: Smooth. Carbonation is there, but isn’t overwhelming.

D: Didn’t enjoy this one all that much and wouldn’t want another one.

By the way, I cleaned the glass I used by hand (like I always do) and don’t have a pet, so I didn’t in any way taint the beer with outside hamster flavors.

Serving type: bottle
50 cl bottle in München. Deep red and coppery colour. Sweet but turns more to bitter in the end. Starts good but doesn’t last until the end.
espectacular... de las más ricas que he probado... sin ninguna duda!!! un sabor exquisito!!! y un color espectacular!!!

Clear amber w smaller white head, slight retention, minimal lacing... very malty aroma, slightly sweet, seems like its gonna be sticky, some dark fruits present... moderately lively, not very sweet, lingering warming sensation, full bodied as a result... malty flavor, almost a touch bland... decent, but not my favorite doppelbock...
Pours brown with good head. Nose and taste is caramel, breads, toasted malts and dark fruits. Rated 7/2/02
Bottle 350ml.Color dark red with small head. Aroma caramel, bread, dark fruits. Taste sweet caramel, bread, roast. Great beer.

On tap. Pours orangish brown with small white head; aroma is malty sweet, caramelish and slightly bready, and also quite fruity; flavor is also malty sweet and slightly fruity with a gentle hop touch in the finish, but also quite sharply alcoholic and not quite as full-bodied as I like my doppelbocks to be. But not bad overall.

bottled, light brown viscous pour with tan head, sweet malt aroma with lots of spice and dark fruit notes, tastes of sweet malt without being cloying with light roast and spice notes, full bodied with light carbonation with residual spice and roast on palate
sweet & malty aroma. Pours amber with a thin tan head.  Rich & warm in the mouth. The malt sweetness cries out for a salty, roasted chicken. Very delicious.
Murky red pour with thin white head. Slight scent of malt. Taste is nuts and bread, not as deep in flavor a Celebrator, but good.

Bottle.

A - Clear amber garnet color with an average sized foamy off-white head with average retention and a good layer of foamy lacing.

S - Sweet caramel and apple malt with some bready smell. Some nutty smell and a subtle touch of alcohol. Lots of sweet malt.

T - A lot of sweet caramel malt. Also a good amount of apple, pear, and dates. Some nutty flavors, but it doesn’t really bring an earthy taste along with it. A touch of spice is also present (mostly cinnamon like). Toasty flavor in the middle of the sip. Finishes with a slightly tart berry/dark fruit taste. Also a touch of warming alcohol on the finish.

M - Slightly above medium body with moderate carbonation. Quite smooth and fairly refreshing.

D - Good drinkability. Of course it is a touch sweet and pretty malty, so you have to be in the mood for that, but it is fairly balanced and not cloying. Easy to drink and although there is a slight alcohol warming, the alcohol taste is hidden quite well.

Notes: Solid doppelbock. It didn’t necessarily blow me away but it was very nice. A lot of malt and sweetness. Definitely recommend trying this, especially if you are in the mood for a full, malty beer.
Pours a clear caramel color with a quickly disappearing off-white head.  Aroma of bread, caramel, and dark fruit.  Flavor of dark fruit, caramel, bread and a touch of hops.  Heavy and quite smooth.

Paulaner Brauerei Munchen--Salvator Double Bock

1997 16.9 oz. Bottle.  7.50% ABV.  (2.25 / 5.0)  Doppelbock--Crystal clear thin amber red color. Fizzed over on opening.  Minimal aroma, but hot sweet malt body.  Lager fruit flavor dominates thin texture.  Lingering hot finish with strong alcohol bite.  Sampled 4/14/1999.

1999 16.9 oz. Bottle.  7.50% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Doppelbock--Clear deep copper red color. Rich and smooth with dry muted fruit body.  Medium textured.  Rich dry finish.  Sampled 10/5/1999.

2002 12 oz. Bottle.  7.50% ABV.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Clear thin amber red color.  Light head.  Rich cherry fruit malt front.  Rich sweet smooth lightly toasted caramel cherry body.  Thick and spicy.  Smooth malt spice mild hop EtOH end.  Rich, smooth, big and tasty.  Sampled 11/10/2002.

2006 Spanish 11.1 oz. Bottle.  7.50% ABV.  25 IBU’s?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Mild head.  Clear rich dark black cherry red color.  Toasted mild hop front.  Rich sweet toffee caramel cherry fruit body.  Smooth mild EtOH mild hop end.  Rich.  Sampled 1/16/2006.

Salvator--2007 0,33 l Bottle.  7.90% ABV.  25 IBU’s?  (4.5 / 5.0)  Mild lace head.  Clear thin cherry amber color.  Smooth floral cherry malt mild hop front.  Mild creamy delicate cherry fruit toffee body.  Clean hot EtOH hint mild hop easy clean end.  Dangerous malty balanced brew.  Sampled 9/26/2007.

Salvator Double Bock--2007 12 oz. Bottle.  7.90% ABV.  25 IBU’s?  (4.5 / 5.0)  Doppelbock--6-Pack $7.99.  Light lacy head.  Clear bright thin rich amber color.  Mild black cherry malt hop front.  Lager creamy smooth rich cloying sweet mild toffee fruit caramel cherry body.  Mild hop touch hot smooth lingering malt end.  Rich Smooth Tasty Classic Doppelbock!  Sampled 4/25/2008.

330mL bottle.  Pours hazy gold-amber with a small white ring.  Aroma of banana, a little toast and alcohol.  Quite sweet with some bitterness too.  Medium bodied, average carbonation that comes out on the palate and is slightly creamy, with a bit of a bitter finish.
caramel, toast, sweet,kobber color,clear, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,
On tap. Sweet malt and nutty aroma. Color,  cherry red color, tiny creamy head. Bitter, wood and fruity taste with bitter sweet finish very warming beer, excellent in cold days.

500 mL bottle.  Pours hazy burnt orange with zero retaining head into a stem glass.  It looks completely lifeless, but the color is good, meh.  Familiar doppelbock nose: raisin sweetness, brown sugar, bready malt.... its really very sweet off the nose, almost nectary.  This is a very simple doppelbock, akin to the nose.  Lots of raisin, dates, overly sweet caramel.  The base flavors are good, but it ends up being like hyper concentrated dark sugar, but thin.  Light to medium bodied with a fizzy mouthfeel and a medium level of carbonation.  Chewy with way too much residual sugar.  Ok, but not that good.

Bottle, 330ml. Pours a reddish/copper colour with a small off white head, medium carbonation.  Aroma is grassy, lots of herbs and some sweetness. Taste is heavy and robust, notes of caramel and roasted malt domain, with a really nice alcohol backbone and bitter aftertaste. Extremely good.
.33l Bottle. Pours a bit more muddy brown than I’d expect, herb spiced nose over sour dark malts. Sharp and robust, nicely complex. Body is balanced, to the light side. Great doppel

Pours amber with a beige head that fades rapidly to a coat. Big noseful - smells of figs, prunes, raisins and treacle with some fruit-cake spices. Taste is sweet, but lighter than the aroma suggests. Balanced and round with a quite lifting dryness at the end. Even for a German beer this is beautifully balanced.

Bottle from Whole Foods, poured into stem glass. Appearance is a deep copper/red color with a generous off-white head. Really a nice looking beer. Aromas of hand fruits, spice, and caramel. Tasting helps evolve these flavors; baking apples, dates, toffee, clove, and probably some others I’m missing. Pretty good.

Bottled.  Pours a very clear dark, orange amber with a large white head on it.  Smells of bread, raisins, dates, sweet caramel.  The flavor also has that "bread pudding" quality I associate with doppelbocks, with rich sweet malts and dried fruit flavors.  Hides the alcohol pretty well.  A little thinner than I’d like, but overall this is a good beer.

330ml bottle. Copper and mahoganey colours in the glass with a crackling modest head. Looks solid in the glass with strong spiced fruit aromas that invite you in. Port like flavour gives a warming sensation that lingers on the palate.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours a clear chestnut brown with a beige head which doesn’t stick around for too long. Sweet, malty aromas of toffee, caramel, treacle, marzipan, baked apple. Flavours of butterscotch, caramel, toffee, cloves. Dry, malty mouthfeel. Sweet, malty finish with a slight alcohol burn. Nice.

Large creamy off-white lasting head and a clear amber-brown body. Heavy aroma of malt, caramel, grain and nutty. Heavy alcohol and wine like feel. Full body, oily texture and average carbonation. Warming. Moderate/heavy sweet and moderate bitter.

Beer has a nice golden color and smells pleasently of malt and spices. 
It is a highly drinkable beer despite its heavy malty body. 

Hops are nice, but don’t forget the malt y’all!

Another one from my Montana beer run. Pours light orange with yellow highlights. The aroma is malty with roasted malt, honey, and spicy hops. The flavor has caramel, violets, spice, and chocolate malt. Would drink again in a heartbeat.

Finally! Bottle from KaDeWe, Berlin. Thick, lightly tanned head, slowly fading to a thin layer of foam.  Lively, amber-shaded, red body, with good clarity. Smells nice; Fresh bakery, barley grains and nuts, and a whiff of  honey. Surprisingly light-bodied. Medium strong, sweetish malt foundation, light peppery/herbal, with a caramel note, and suggestions of  dried dark fruits. Evident bitterness, earthy, only for balancing. Soft and easy on the palate, healthy body. As good as I expected. I like!

Very good german beer, which is quite rare to be noticed. Ruby clour and mellow attack. Predominance of caramel, thick creamy. Could have been proposed in a smaller format because it is a bit sickening in the end. As many german beers a bit shallowness, but despite this lack of subtlety, efficient and tasty beer. Good compromise between "thirst  beer" and "Tasty Beer"
Hazy amber-brown in the glass.  Fruity, malty aromas.  Predominantly malt flavors on the palate with some dried fruit notes.
(12oz bottle) Clear medium brown, taste and nose of dark dried fruits and cream. Smells phenomenal, wish it tasted just like it smelled. Still a good solid German Doppelbock.

0.5 l-es palack.
Színe vörösesbarna/mahagóni, tetején egy szépen telt vanília színű habkoronával, mely viszonylag hosszú ideig - és egy vékony fátyolt maga után hagyva - megmarad, szénsavassága élénk.
Illata karamellás, melaszos, alkoholos.
Enyhe csípősséggel indul, utána válik érezhetővé édes, cukorkát idéző, gyümölcsös, karamellás íze., mely selymesen terül szét a szájban.
Aromája karamell malátás, füves, a befejezése fűszeres, alkoholosan melengető és száraz.
Teste azt nyújtja, amit egy duplabak-tól elvár az ember, textúrája enyhén ragacsos.
Ez bizony finom volt!

Beer poors a dark foggy amber with a slight white head.  Aroma is of raisin, fig, and alchol.  No hop aroma.  Aroma translates in to the flavor presenting the palate with dryed fruits, and a sligth sweetness.  Roasty notes are present on pour and bitterness balances the beer but not in hop aroma or flavor.  Malts are the star of this beer.  Palate is dry with and alchol presence is apparent in the mouthfeel.  Overall, this dopplebock is very nice.

rated 03/15/2010 - A rich, dark golden-brown, plenty of malt, with hints of caramel, almond (or maybe hazelnut), and a definite taste of alcohol.  Excellent for cold weather, a bit heavy for summer.  07/18/2017 - I’ve had this fresh, in Germany, several times now, and that tips the balance to a perfect score.  Strong caramel malt, for sure, but so well done, and so well-balanced.  High recommendations

Bottle. The Salvator has a deep amber, very good looking body with a dense white head on top. Smells of yeasty caramel. On the palate it appears smooth and almost oily, quite to my taste. Flavor is intensely malty, with notes of burnt almonds, booze and grapefruit in the aftertaste. A feisty blend. Alcohol could have been better hidden, but otherwise a very nice, strong doppelbock.

Poured a slightly hazy medium amber/orange with a tall creamy light tan head. There was a good sweet aroma with some bread yeast, caramel and a hint of tart cherries. The initial taste was slightly dry followed by a good mellow sweetness of caramel. The finish was rather mild and left the sweetness lingering for a short while.
The aroma is full of corn, much like a good pilsner like Urquell, flavor is similar the corn is very much present.
17 ounce bottle .A caramel brown murky pour- tan head that dissapates rather quickly .Taste of caramel, nuts, woody. A really sweet dry finish.A subperb beer

Bottle 330ml. Great beer. Crisp aroma, with caramel, butter, and alcohol. Taste is sweet, and long-lasting. Palate is velvety, and medium bodied. Amber colour, with a head that doesn’t last all the way.
Bottle. I love doppelbock beers and this as good as it gets. Dark amber color. Large head that disappears quickly. Malty, sweet, raisin, slight alcohol. Really good beer.

Bottle. Pours brown/amber, with a thin white head, spotty lacing. Nose is orangey/spicy malt, plus alcohol, peaches and cream corn, mild vegetal note. Rich toffee notes in the mouth, soft and boozy, not the equal of Celebrator, but okay.

pours clear brown with a light and quickly disapating head. Aroma is bold and malty. Strong malty flavour a nice Dopple bock but not the best Dopple bock I have ever had. I can’t believe this beer is 7.9 %. You sure can’t taste the booze. Not bad at al. P
Pours a dark amber/brown with a small white head. Aroma of wheat, caramel malt and dark fruit. Flavour of sweet caramel malt, with a bit of smoke.
Nice beer. Pours a dark amber/medium brown color with a light brown head. Has a sweet smell and a strong sweet caramel taste. Very stout.

My favorite local shop beer, no doubt about it. Tastes great, nice bitter chocolate taste with a bit of smoke. Drank from the bottle, subtle aromas of coffee and chocolate. Goes down extremely smooth. Will be a favorite of mine for some time to come.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange-brown with small beige head. The aroma is sweet and grainy with notes of honey, caramel, birch, and wood. The flavor is caramel with a spritzy lemon note up front, followed by the sweet graininess I recognize from the aroma. The finish is very clean with a little bit of an herbal hop tinge. Tasty beer.

12oz bottle.  Poured amber with white head.  A faint aroma with hints of fruit.  Good smooth taste and goes down nice and easy.  Hints of fruit in the taste.  Easy beer to drink.  Like it but not a great beer.
12 oz bottle  from Liquor Barrel in Circle Pines.  Caramel color pour with a small white head.  Aroma is faint, slight notes of caramel and malt.  Sweet & malty flavor with a bit of an oaky finish.

ies others taste but Amber. Fast, creamy head. Aroma: Malty caramel, wheat. Flavor: Caramel malt, syrup, sweet, dry. Bitter/sweet finish.  The best Paulaner I have ever had and somewhat underrated at that.  It hides the alcahol burn well for the first half of the bottle.  I don’t get the berries others taste but  I did sence floral notes.  Nice example of a 
true German Dopplebock.

12oz bottle.  Auburn brown pour with a thin light tan head.  Sweet butterscotch aroma.  Sweet yeasty bread taste with hints of caramel and dark fruits.  Crisp palate with little noticeable carbonation.  Even finishes up a sweet with a tacky bitterness at the very end.  Decent beer to have now and again.  Little sweet to drink a sixer though.

12 oz Bottle. Pours a nice copper and amber blend. Frothy off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt quite evident. Dark fruit, nearly chocolaty taste. Only the slightest hops detectable. A nice dry finish. I was impressed with this fine offering.

The bottle I had is actually aged for almost 2 years (2008 release). I’ve had this beer fresher, and I’ve got to say it has improved with age.

Reddish-brown body with a thin creamy light-brown head, just a little cloudy.
The taste is more complex than before, it is quite woody, with strong hints of vanilla, toffee, and an intense breadiness. I even tasted a good amount of fruit notes, like cherry and plum (the latter is very pronounced). There is some nice sweetness both in the taste and the finish.
Nice and crisp on the palate, medium-to-full body to it. The alcohol is fairly masked, for a 7.9% beer. Drinks easily.

All in all, this remains one of the original and best doppelbocks. I highly recommend aging it for a year or two (disregard the best before date), it’s worth it!

Light brown coloured beer with no carbonation and a rather samm white head. Light malty hinted sweet fruity touched aroma. Medium to full palate. Finish is ligth bitter sweet with some malty hints and some very light alcholic yeasty touches. Nothing to special

Pours a light brown/caramel color with a thin tan head that dissipated quickly. Subtle malt and caramel aromas at first, but as the beer warmed these aromas became stronger and I was also able to pick up a hint of cherries and alcohol. The flavor started off very sweet, German malts and caramel. In the middle there is hops, cherries, and alcohol (almost like cough syrup but in a good way not like medicine). The finish is dry with almost no aftertaste. This beer is thick, full-bodied, and rich. The warming alcohol effect makes it a nice after dinner drink on a cold winter night. I thought this was very enjoyable, drinkable beer.

Bottle as gift. Malty, toasty, fruit-like (prune) aroma & pours amber with low carbonation and a low white head that dissapated quickly. Medium full body, rich malty flavors with melanoidins & sweetness from the malt. Low to no hop flavor, rich & smooth with some alcohol warmness. Long malty finish. A nice beer for a cold January evening.

Pours a cloudy cream soda.  Quickly dissipating head.  Thin mouth feel, not much carbonation.  A little watery even.   Pleasing malty flavor though, if a bit too sweet.  Like the caramel.  A smooth easy drinker, but nothing to write home about (but something to write ratebeer about evidently).  My third dopplebock, and not at all what I was expecting after the Thomas Hooker Liberator and Ayinger Celebrator.  I found those two much more like each other than this ... and way better.
Poured a slightly cloudy, deep copper with a smallish off-white head. Doughy malts up front with some bitter hoppiness. A real mouthful. Well crafted beer.

Bottle. Appearance is reddish brown with light brown head. Aroma is caramel, molasses and alcohol. Taste begins with strong caramel and roasted malt flavors along with cocoa, spiced dough, toffee and raisins. It finishes dry and malty with a warm alcohol burn. This is a thick, sweet and malty Doppelbock that would make for a nice dessert beer.

500ml from Goody Goody.  Beautiful clear, dark amber body with a quickly dissipating cream colored head.  Aroma of caramel, stone fruits and heavily malted barley.  Taste is same malted barley, raisins, plum and medium caramel sweetness.  A bit cloying.  Medium body with an almost creamy smooth mouthfeel.  ABV is present, but in a nice moderately warming way.
Very good work on this doppelbock. Aromas of caramel,fruits,coffee and malts. Taste is the same fruity with caramel and chocolate. Medium to full body. Long lasting aftertaste.

A wonderful example of doppelbock.  Pint bottle to lager glass.  Pours a slightly cloudy reddish amber with creamy off white head, which for obvious reasons disappears quickly.  Roasted, bread, malt and dough is first impression.  Slight caramel and coffee, and a nice quick bitter finish.  Alcohol comes through loud and clear.  Right amount of carbonation and very smooth, but full, such a great feel for a strong beer.  A favorite of mine, for good reason.

Aroma is floral, light caramel, malty sweet, light alcohols, & slightly doughy.  Appearance is from a 3 to a 5 depending on the bottle I get, some crystal clear, others not so much.  Lovely orange hue with decent dense head and small lacing.  Flavor is very clean & malty, perfect for style.  Well bittered for a dopplebock, more so than other examples.  Slight grain/cereal flavor on the finish but dominated with smooth caramel munich grain flavors, malt bomb with lots of alcohol at the end.  This is one of the better biers available from a mouthfeel standpoint, simply silky, viscous, think big IIPA but with malt in terms of mouthfeel.  Viscous yet very drinkable.  Overall this bier is a favorite, goes great with many many meals, it’s well balanced though I tend to prefer less bitterness in a dopplebock.  The knock is that it’s simply too alcoholic in flavor.  Very good example of the style, love the bier, but it’s just a bit too alcohol forward.

Bottled - World Market - Nice malty nutty aroma.  Amber with thin brown head.  Very nice nutty, coffee, carmal and other conplex flavors.  Low hop flavors but bittering hop on palate.  good overall and balanced for high alcohol beer.

Translucent, more red than brown with a quickly dissipating off white head. A sweet scent of alcohol and malts resound. Mild sweetness, roasty malts, subtle coffee notes, mild mouthfeel, light carbonation. A pleasant brew but not something outstanding.

50cl bottle: Syrupy, malty aroma with clean notes of whiskey-ish alcohol and caramel. This beer is characterised by its assertive, crisp and straightforward malt flavours - toasty, bready and a little bit roasty or chocolatey. All other components are kept subtle and merely attempt to balance the sweet maltiness. Soft and full mouthfeel from the residual sugars but not cloying, the alcohol is definitely noticeable. Copper red in colour. Simple and good winter warmer.

Cpr-lct, no head, med co2, full body, smooth.

sweet-malt aroma.

^malt-sweet T1, §hop malty §alchl T2, §fruity §hoppy diacetyl alchl T3, same thru.

better at colder temp to limit malty-sweetness.

A clear amber colored beer, with a thick beige head. The aroma of little burned malt with fruits like berries and citrus. The taste is some bitter with sweet caramel, a little dry. The aftertaste is bitter with some sweet.

Lot’s of warm, dark roasted flavours in this one, from nose to mouth. Burnt chocolate, mexican coffee beans, beef stew and simmering mild cider. Palate is smooth and sweet with a nice warm caramel and malt finish. Nothing over the top at all.

Bottle thanks to Gregg.  Pours a nice dark brown with a thin tan head.  A little bit of yeast floats atop the head.  Aroma is roasted malts and a bit of chocolate.  Notes of dark fruits, allspice, and burnt malts come out as well.  On the palate, it is a little sweet and a bit chewy.  The finish is a tad bit dry.  I was really impressed with this beer and hope to have some again.
This beer is amazing. Pours dark brown with tons of head. Tastes like applejuice, lots of apple and sweetness. Goes down easy with no alcohol flavor. Would (and will) drink again.

Bottle. Deep amber color. Rich caramel malt aroma with honey and dark fruit. Soft, rich, luscious dark malt flavor, with caramel, honey, chocolate and some dark fruit. Alcohol works to balance. Thick, round, soft, slightly salty. A fine bock.

Bottle. Pours clear mahogney/red with a 2 inch creamy tan head. Aroma of strong caramel, toffee and dark fruits. Taste of  caramel, heavy malty intence body, no detecteble hops here, just lots of sweet delicious malt

Bottle. Good looking light brown pour with a nice white head. Sweet sticky malty fruit aromas, lots of brown sugar too very dopplebock. Taste is also very sweet, brown sugar like litterally no hop presence. Decent mouthfeel, I guess this is sparkling by dopplebock standards.

Pours a lovely iced tea brown with a creamy beige head. Chunky hunks of yeast float atop the brew even after the head fades. Nose is of malt, caramel, bubble gum, penny candy, and something else I can’t put my finger on but like anyway. Caramel and spice flavor with roasted cashews. No hops detected, some malt but not a lot. Only a little alcohol detected. Has a coffee ground taste in the background that I don’t care for, and it affects it’s overall score
bottle - hazy amber brownish beer with almost no foam. Malty aroma with some hay and traces of caramel. Flavour is sweet and malty but has still bitterness, some honey. Alcoholic.
16.9 oz bottle  nice red/brown color, very nice aroma.  Rich flavor with good body.  This became one of my instant favorites.

Poured from tap into half-liter mug.

Rich orange-red with thin head.

Aroma of strong caramel, toffee and dark fruits.

Caramel, toffee, plum, some spiciness but no noticeable hops. Tastes like a regular bock but with a slight alcohol taste.

Moderate carbonation, chewy heavy body.

Nice overall, but a basically a boozy bock.

Nice amber fizzy body and a diminishing fizzy head. In the aroma caramel and some fruitness is present. Then when i taste it, i was surprised because of the  harsh alcohol, my tounge was numbed. I think a more thick body was expected from me. As you wait a bit, the caramel note becomes stronger and stronger.
