On tap; RE-WRITE; Ok, I am re-editing this as I tried this beer again and had a much better experience. Pours a nice brown color with a sweet aroma. Taste was mild in body but with caramel and brown sugar notes ... the alcoholl % was not noticeable. A great beer for sure ...

12 oz bottle.  Pours a hazy amber with a frothy white head that quickly goes to a thin film that leaves a little lacing.



The aroma is sweet caramel and toffee with some dark fruit and a little alcohol.



The flavor is sweet caramel and toffee and nuts with a little fruit leading to a lightly grassy bitterness in the finish.  The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with smooth carbonation.



Overall, a good example of a doppelbock.  A little too much on the sweet side for me.

Pours cloudy dark brown, with a nice white head that laces out nicely.  Very malty aroma with a hint of alcohol.  Sweet, malty, smooth yet complex with a hint of hops on the finish.  High in alcohol, yet it doesn’t show in the taste.  My only complaint is this is a "knock your socks off" type of beer.  Goes down smooth and after a couple...

A clear amber color with a frothy medium off-white head and good lacing.  It has a sweet malt aroma with grain and hint of fruit.  The body is medium with a sweet taste and finishes with a soothing alcohol warmth.
Pours reddish orange with a light, tan head. While you can taste the alcohol, the malt is there too. Sweet and quite drinkable, all in all a ’thumbs up’.
Wow, another one that I didn’t like that much and it’s rated 91%.  Either my tastes are going bad or I got into several bad bottles.

~Strong malt aroma with some alcohol, low fruitiness.
~Pours an amber color with small white head.
~Rich malty sweet flavor with some alcohol, no hops.
~Full bodied, moderatly low carbonation, sweet toasty finish.
~ A bit sweet for me. True to style, just not my style.

I tested it for the first time in 2003 and now, 6 years later, decided to refresh my memories. As I remember it was malty, strong, filled with portwein, caramel and plum notes. Now, the palate is more simplistic and alcoholic. The colour became lighter. But, anyway, it is still quite nice brew.

This is a very good doppelbock. Pours an attractive reddish brown. Rich aroma and sweet, deep flavor. Medium bodied. Decent alcohol content I would expect from a doppelbock. The flavor is well-balanced and complex with grain, malt, nuts and fruit coming through. This is one of my favorite widely available dopplebocks, along with Spaten Optimator.

Reddish brown pour with a one finger white froth. Quite effervescent. Aroma is quite fruity- almost bordering on vinous. Oaken woodiness prevails up front with a deep caramel dark fruit character coming through with some molasses in the back. Flavor is quite sweet with caramel, slight roast, molasses, grape, plum, and apple. Palate is medium to full bodied with a slight roasty dryness and a lingering smacking sticky sweetness. A slight alcohol warming comes through near the end, but never acts in an intruding or deterring manor. I was quite impressed.

Pours a chestnut color with a decent white head. Aroma holds lots of apple, pear, and grape, with almost a vinous quality. Also some bready notes, and a bit of wood up front. Flavor holds tons of malt, not nearly as fruity as the aroma, though apple, pear, and plum are definitely still present. A spice kick hits near the finish, with notes of wheat and caramel coming through as well. Really a tasty doppelbock, and the 7.9% is a good warming quality for a chilly night. Good stuff.
Bottle. Hazy orange body with a medium off white head. Fruity and malty aroma with some caramel and wheat. Heavy malty flavour with some alcohol and fruit notes.

Bottle (in NZ). Pours a dark amber with a rusty head. Biscuity malt on the nose with stewed fruits and medicinal alcohol. Yummy palate. Heavy malt palate full of fruity flavours, touch of spice, and that 7.9% bite. A lingering cloying finish that makes you want to take another sip.

Bottle. Pours amber with a creamy beige head. Rich aroma and flavour of toffee, dark fruit, caramel and nuts. Great balance in this beer. No hint of the alcohol. Smooth and bitter finish. Very nice - one to sip and savour.
Nice beer.  Taste is a little nut, toffee with a small bite of alcohol.  I enjoy the entire Paulaner line.
One of my choices among the Paulaner line.  What can I say that hasn’t been said among 1500 ratings except that I’ve had, I liked, and will drink again!

500. Pours a crystal clear very dark amber with loose white smear of foam across the top. Dates, nuts, a little campfire smoke, and some dry leaves on the nose. Watery, light body. Toast, nuts, a little smoke, and faint hints of fruits on the mid-palate. Probably a subtle accompaniment to food. Mild nutty finish.
Dark pour, roasted malts and fruits.  Finishes very nicely with just a hint of alcohol burn.

Pours copper brown with medium sized beige-white head with some lacing. Caramell with raisins and dried prunes in aroma. Flavor is very sweet and full of toasted caramell and dark fruits. Lovely thick body with a long lasting warming aftestaste and bitter finish. Perhaps a bit too sweet to get a better score.

Clear dark amber with a biege head.  Nicely balanced, some sweet malts and some darker malts as well.  Very malty, like drinking bread...with a nice yeasty alcohol twist in the finish.  Medium body, feels like 5.x% ABV, not ~8%.  Warms as it hits the belly and cheeks.  A very, very nice doppelbock &#40since it’s the granddaddy of ’em all&#41 but not quite as perfect as Celebrator.
12 oz. Bottle. Light to medium head. Pleasant aroma. Amber coloring. A decent beer.
Pours a lasting ring of beige head and a clear, copper body.  Smells of ripe fruit and dough.  Flavor is banana, dough, caramel.  Some bitterness on the finish.
Have had from a 12oz bottle and on tap.  A nice rounded and balanced double bock with a sweet finish.  One of the best examples.
Bottle at German restraunt-Very light and easy drinking. Yet, it packed a punch. Golden in color with medium head. Great malt flavor. Highly recomended by Coloradomatty!
A really nice beer, with a good, foamy head and a gorgeous amber colour.  Aroma was fabulous &#40the malt?&#41 as was the taste.  Rich, and almost sweet in taste, this was a treat to drink.
Bottle. Pours with a nice golden copper color. Aromas of caramel and butterscotch. Flavors of dark fruit and caramel, with some nice buttery malt finish. Has abit of alcohol hotness in the finish.

Bottle pour with a nice, dark tan head that dissipated fairly quick. Very clear, copper red color. The flavor was not what I expected.....it had hints of some sweet, but slightly spicy flavors, maybe from the alcohol content?....kind of a brown sugar with maybe some cinnamon, nutmeg, clove? Not malty or hopsy at all. Palate was medium, lingered on the back of the tongue with a slight fizz. I think for comparison purposes, I would really like to try this beer on draft. I liked it, and was really trying it based on the ratings of other members. Just another foray outside my comfort zone.

Bottle. Pours amber with a fluffy beige head . Malt and honey stand out on the nose which is also a bit woody. Flavour has touches of brown sugar, malt, toast and caramel and while it is a little on the sweet side it is nowhere near cloying. Very decent beer, almost too easy to drink.

Beautiful burnished copper in the glass. Toasted nuts and caramel on the nose. Toasted bread, roast chestnuts, toffee and caramel, with a whiff of cinnamon perhaps? Some spice I just can’t quite nail. It’s been a long time since I’ve had this beer, and I had forgotten just how great it is.

I expected a lot more out of this, I know it’s supposed ot be the original, but it is really weak once compared to others like the Celebrator or even Tommy knocker butt head. Hardly sweet or malty, This thing dries the hell out of your mouth. Bottle at Gulf Liquors.

Bottle, poured into a glass stein mug. Reddish-amber, with light fizzy head that goes away pretty quickly. Nose is heavily malted, with some caramel. Brown sugar lingers on the palate, with a slight dark rummy undertone. Solid sessioner, and will buy again, but not really anything to get stoked about.

The Paulist monks, or Paulists, in Germany during the 18th century created a stronger, richer, heartier version of the then available bock style beer which had been brewed since 1634. Seeing as how the scriptures conveniently did not include beer as a forbidden fruit during their time of fasting (lent), the Paulists thus enlightened and revitalized their minds and bodies with their liquid bread; the doppelbock. Thusly named Salvator, at first all doppelbocks that followed were also called Salvator which led to some confusion as it became a name for the style in general. That changed not too long after as the Paulists claimed exclusive rights to the name Salvator for their doppelbock, though the “ator” stuck and since then the large majority of doppelbocks have “ator” at the end of their name.




She arrived at my side full of glamour and sparkle and grace, decked out in a breath-taking gown of deep amber while rubies glimmered and sparkled in her spotlight. Sporting a soft scarf of blanched copper, she swishes and swirls with seductive aplomb, offering a whiff of her forbidden lace which my eyes make sure to note. As we draw closure, I am able to steal a deep breath of her fruit. Sweet with caramelized sugars and moist dark breads while prunes and raisins are drizzled with maple syrup and a sprinkling of nutmeg. Weak in the knees I gather my will and lean in for our first kiss. No fireworks per say, but instead I am slowly drawn into her sublime embrace of spice and warmth which lingers on our breath even as she lightly coats my mouth with her liquid temptation. Maple melts into soft breads while moist prunes and raisins lead into a snap of lemon crispness in her finish that tingles on top of my tongue. Not too heavy, she balances my desires perfectly, and as my palate dries slightly, her lingering warmth hints of dry brown spices and rum. As I wholly surrender myself to her charms, she leaves me with one final kiss of sweet dark fruits, robust dark breads, warmth and spice, with a playful nip of lemon.




While the Paulist monastery and brewery are now separate locations, the Salvator is still just as tied to the Paulists today as it was hundreds of years ago when it was first brewed. Paulaner Salvatore is available year round, a blessing in and of itself. Good thing for six packs because I think I shall have another.
Caramel color, warm well-balanced flavor. Medium body. Would recommend with food or by itself.
Dark amber orange, light tan head.  Aroma is bready, sweet, light spice of alcohol head.  Taste is the same sweet malts, fruit, toffee, caramel, bread, light alcohol finish.
Tiny white head. Sweet yeasty aroma with caramel and malty notes. Sweet fruity flavor with caramel and mild hoppy notes, a real deal beer.
A caramel color beer with a 1 finger head. Aroma was very sweet. Taste was sweet, caramelly, bready, & slight banana. Too sweet for my liking.

Bottle.  Pours brownish-amber with a robust off-white head.  Aroma of good, solid malt.  Flavor is malty, slightly grainy, and some caramel.  Not bad at all.  Slightly thick, which is good in my book.
Amber pour with solid ivory head that left spotty lacing.  Tons of malty goodness; caramel, toffee, molasses, and honey.  Alcohol noticeable but not distracting.  Medium mouthfeel.  Solid brew.
Pours reddish copper with a big offwhite head.  Nose is malt and alcohol.  Taste is sweet, with notes of malt. molasses, and alchohol, with bitterness in the finish.  Flavorful and satisfying.
TAP: clear amber pour, malty nose, sweet taste with a grape/wine element, yeasty. I didn’t really like this one.

Aroma/Malty-toasted,
Appearance Head/Initia-huge, Head/Color light brown,
Body/Hue-murky,
Initial Flavor-bitter light
Finish Flavor-bitter light
Palate/Body-medium to full,
good beer

re-rate 03/15.. it’s bock season so wanted to try again.   lowered from 3.4.............not overly hoppy but I don’t like the hops in this and the malt beginning is not my fave. so pass.......................................Solid; very malty in aroma and taste.

Taste was too sweet and slightly too much alcohol.

Good palate, would drink again.

cloying malt aroma, decomposing apples mostly, with an alcohol tinge. surprisingly mild body and flavor. malty and too sweet, with overripe fruit and obvious alcohol. body is much too thin. 
this isn’t very interesting, and whatever flavors it does have are a bit off.

Bottle 500ml. Pours translucent mahogany, with none-to-little head. Rich aroma of dark and sweetened malts, and treacle. Similar on the palate, with roast molasses and yeast. Quite light bodied for a doppelbock, but none the worse for it.

Pours a dark amber with a thin layer of creamy beige head  .... aroma of sweet nutty roasted malt, caramel malts and orange ..... taste is of orange, molasses, caramel malts, roasted and chocolate malts and slightly nutty with a slight bitterness on the palate, creamy/soft mouthfeel .... finish has lingering caramel malts, a light bitter bite, and some orange .... not too heavy and a very nice balanced beer. Sessionable and smooth

0.33L bottle, smallish head vwith big bubbles, dark orange colour leaning towards amber. Aroma of honey and vanila with some herbal notes and a touch of candle wax. Flavours of caramel with some scenty floral notes with a strong bitterness and a alcohol presence which is a little to noticable, buttery texture reminding me of oaked chardonnay. sour dried figs aftertaste and that buttery chardonnay sensation again. Intriguing beer.

Bottled.
Brown withh white head. Aroma and flavor of malt and caramel. Some fruity notes.
Very enjoyable. Smells of roasted malt, nuts, and caramel. Pretty much tasted the same. Really felt creamy throughout the mouth. I will definately drink this again.
500ml bottle. Copper pour with a pretty short lasting white head. Malty, slightly toasty aroma. Flavor is pretty much the same, pretty good, but could imagine it being alot better in Germany.

No: 748

Rated: 28.06.2009

Bottle brown, 500 ml,18.3 P

Appearance: Pours beautiful strawberry red to opalized dark orangy, shiny and perfectly clear body texture, body carbonation is seemingly not very vivid but there is a moderate beer saturation, head is initially big, frothy, pillowy, beautiful in its regularity of texture, off - white with interesting orangy shades, firm and slowly decreasing to small, there is a nice lacing. All in all beer looks wonderful in terms of colour.

Aroma: Oily, alcoholic, fat malty, quite a grat deal of sweetness, cognac, coocoo candy, all in all is very malty and alcoholic oriented, in terms of fruit there is plum and cherry going upfront, very noble malty profile, apart from choisest malt ther is a gnetle hoppy touch balancing the malty sweetness of the beer, strawberry, prune, slight touch of red grapes, hoppy profile may seem leavy but is hard to tell.

Flavour: Front is robust with honest fat crispy fresh toffee like malty background being given a great character of spicyness of hoppy origin and leavy touches going together with quite strong alcoholic background, great warmth on palate in the aftertaste, kind of mineral saltyness, stronger in alcohol towards the end with slaty bitter touches on a tongue. Finish duration is long with notes of fruit, especially red fruit  such as plum, prune and toffee.

Palate: Body is full, texture is almost oily, carbonation on palate is moderate, finish feel is strongly alcoholic, moderately astringent with a spicy - alcoholic warmth.

aroma of toffee crunch, some pit fruits and more caramel.  flavor is deeply nutty with caramel.  booze makes an appearance but its not offensive, it actually melds well with the caramel notes to make a warming brew.  this is a beer i would revisit even amongst a style that somewhat disinterests me.

Dark amber/ruby por with a large off-white head that quickly faded. Slightly hazy.
Loads on clean sweet malt aroma with caramel notes. Some chocolate hints and creamy alcohol.
Similarly malty flavour, quite sweet. Smooth alcohol presence. Low bitterness. Once you’ve got used to the strong sweetness and alcohol (or rather, the lack of balancing bitterness) it makes for quite an easy drinking beer.
Quite full body, low carbonation. Wouldn’t have thought this would work with the sweetness but somehow it doesn’t seem out of place.

Rich dark orange in colour with a fast dissipating head. Aromas are sweet citrus and nutty with underlying grassy notes, touches of caramel too.
Medium bodied with a sweet, malty, soft and creamy mouth feel, bread dough, marmalade, malt, grilled nuts, mild bitterness and fairly good length.
While there will be many who enjoy this style, but if you are top-fermenting fan it may not suit.
Bottle: malty, biscuity, some bready notes, some chocolaty notes, dried fruits marmalade, some caramel and honey notes, nice bitterness in the finish, some alcoholic notes, very nice beer overall.

Lots of flavors, none overpowering. I tried this side by side with Boont Amber, and compared to that the flavors seemed mild. Anyone who likes 1554 should love this. I’ve been buying Salvator by the 6 pack for 3 years,  bought a 6 pack recently that tasted bad! In every other example I would rate it at least 4 out of 5!
Chestnut and lime nose with a touch of smoke. Amber with a medium yellow head.Medium body, alcohol evident. Dried leaves, grass, and horehound. Not overbearing, but not terribly flavorful either.
Sweet,  aroma with notes of figs, plums and other fruits. Flavor has hints of caramel, berries and a very faint hint of hops. Mouthfeel is smooth.

Rerate: Deep orange to red, aroma of caramel, butter cookies and toasted bread, flavors of caramel, brandy, fruit cake and dough, spicy peppery bitter finish that lasts long, medium to full bodied, winter drink.

From bottle, @BeerFest Israel, bronze to Orange color with medium off-white head, nicely carbonated, aroma of biscuit malt simple and pleasant, flavor of malt liquor with some coriander clove and pretty much alcohol, bitter finish, medium complexity, nice beer.

12 oz. -> pint glass.  Pours a fog machine auburn, with a thick head of almond-colored, marshmallowy whip, which melted quick.  Malty, slight apple, spice, soap, and grain aroma.  Tastes of balanced malt - not overly sweet, but not hoppy either.  Taste the apple and spice on the back end.

Aroma - great aroma of prune-like fruit and malty nose

App - rich but clear brown color, tan long-lasting head.

Flavor - malt forward, delicious dark fruit flavors, hops in the background

Palate - medium carbonation, body is just right, alcohol perceptible but not overwhelming

Overall - wonderful beer that’s hard to stop at one!  You can’t beat the aroma and flavor.

50cl bottle poured into a dimpled mug.  Pours a beautiful amber brown with one finger tan head.  Aroma is caramel, licorice, a bit of vanilla, and a hint of alcohol.  Flavor is maple syrup, licorice, slight citrus, a bit of alcohol, and some hoppy bitterness in the end.  Heavy and filling.  Well balanced.  A complex and interesting beer.  Delicious.

Bottle. Poured turbid ruddy amber with a thick foamy tan head. Aroma was bubblegum, licorice, maple syrup, fig, and somewhat grassy and floral at the end. Flavor was orangey sweet, maple syrup, molasses, licorice, honey, and finishes nicely spicy and hoppy. Palate was robust and had a nice finishing burn. Overall reminded me somewhat of rum.

Poured a deep rusty orange with an off-white head that died - leaving only a bare minimum residue clinging to the glass like a sugar coated margareta rim. A good ammount of minute particles are suspended within the beer. That being said, this is a really clear brew. Malts, caramel and weak molasses dominate the aroma with some over-sweet fruit hiding behind that. Quite complex in flavor it tasted like a weak tawny port with the usual well done yummy malts. Combined with the alcoholic strength is a soft rum taste. All the hard work that this beer does to keep you more than interested goes for naught if it warms too much - don’t let it happen. Enjoy, but enjoy at a steady pace.

given the other recent ratings, maybe i either wasnt in the mood for this tonight, or i just got a bad bottle. but i found it kinda blah. it pours dark ruby red with a decent ivory head. aroma is nicely spiced and malty. put the flavor didnt have much profile other than some malt flavor and a little alcohol burn. just not that interesting. not bad just ok.
A solid doppelbock.  The color is right on and so is the pour.  The taste wasn’t what I expected, but nothing skunky or bad about this beer.  A good drink overall.

bottle poured a caramel brown in color with a one finger foamy off white head. aroma has rich malt, light spiced yeast, dark ripe fruit, and a touch of sweetness. mouth feel is surprisingly light with low carbonation. dark fermented fruit, yeast, sweet malt, and a hint of bitter hops. interestingly rich for being so thin.

This pours deep amber with a fine white head and has a sweet & vinous nose full of raisin and dried plum scents. Initially tastes sweet and full-bodied, but as the flavour develops the sweetness is balanced by a nutty hop character, lots of malt, a hint of roastiness and a dry alcoholic bite. The finish is dry and gently bitter

Dark- red , beautiful colour and very nice taste. Strong alcohol percentage along with a bitter finish give this one a good advantage to other red beers. Classic german taste with red beer sweetness. Perfect match!

Pours a clear dark red-brown with a tan head. Flavor of caramel malts, fruit, hint of alcohol. Flavor is similar, with a surprising, although slight, bitterness in the finish. Wasn’t too thrilled about this one. Diggin the 7.9% though, a bonus point.

Bottle, 50cl. Pours a orange beer with a yellow/orange head. The aroma is malt, alcohol and fruit. The flavor follows the nose, but without the alcohol. The palate misses a little body. Overall a good beer.
Bottle poured to glass.  Clear copper colored brew.  Very malty nose with notes of licorice.   Small ring of off white head.  Soft carbonation.  A little alcohol in the flavor of the palate.

Smell is sweet and rich with hints of caramel. Colour is a clear reddish brown. Flavour follows the nose - rich, creamy, pleasing effervescence on the tongue. A great beer - try it paired with pulled pork BBQ, pork sausages, or roast pork.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear amber with a small white head.  Aroma is semisweet with caramel, apple, and a hint of cherry.  Flavor is moderately sweet with lots of caramel and biscuit.  A little green apple and hops are in there as well.  Reminiscent of a Belgian dubbel in some respects.  Crisp palate.

Hazy dark orange pour with thin white head. On the light side for a dopplebock. 

Nose is a whiff of alcohol with holiday pie, maybe some caramel. 

Palate has a fair amount of alcohol warmth with those little chocolate covered orange wedges. Malty to caramelly sweetness mid palate and then finishes with some dry chocolate and orange on the finish. Again, alcohol warmth. 

Even with the alcohol detected it remains fairly drinkable somehow. Not a turnoff at all.
Bottled. Pours dakr brown with a tall brown head. Aroma is sweet with notes of hops and alcohol. Taste is also sweet and very malty. Roasted malt. Full body with lots of alcohol. Thick and full body

Draft in Singapore ... not exactly where I expected to have this first.  Good nose of malts and chocolate.  Appearance moderate brown, small head, tanner head and lighter body than I expected, since my standard for this beer is the Ayinger.  Ditto, smaller mouth than I expected.  Taste of sweet malts and caramel and floral hops, with, maybe a touch of coffee, but none of the huge roasted malt coffee and chocolate bitterness of the Ayinger.

Bottle.  Pours light orange with a medium head.  After head dissipates, this brew is downright ominous with its bright apricot body and no carbonation!  Aroma is copper, caramel, and peat.  Flavor has caramel, ripe peach, milk chocolate, and cocoa.  Mouthfeel is slick, but finishes a touch dry.  Not sure I am completely satisfied with this beer (I am a hophead by trade), though as a Doppelbock I can appreciate it.

Pours rich amber color with an inch thick tan head. Aroma is alcohol, plum, raisin, and other dark fruits. Bitter alcohol taste, cherry, and roast characters. Good creamy texture and a sturdy bitter finish.

500 ml bottle. From Germany.
Reddish amber colour with tiny tan head.
Malty and buttery aroma, more like Czech Dunkel than Bock. Malts and some alcohol in flavour. Warming. Quite strong.

Bottle.  Pours a bright amber with a full foamy head.  Aroma is bread and raisins.   Taste is malt and caramel.  Sweet and smoothe.  Middling carbonation gives it a richer feel than the taste itself does.  Pretty consistent throughout.  It’s alright, but perhaps not my taste.
(bottle). Pours a copper color. Medium size light tan head, which diminishes quickly. Sweet malt aroma.  Malt and caramel tastes. Smooth finish, with light alcohol taste. Moderate carbonation.

Dark red-amber, it has a small creamy light tan head that shrinks very slowly, leaving a hint of lace.

The aroma is strong and rich with fermented and caramelised raisin, some plum, fresh whole wheat bread.

The taste is rich, sweet but with balancing bitterness and a bit spicey with a light bite and with a dryish, slightly bitter-zesty finish. It has rich, caramelised, fermented whole wheat bread, raisins, hint of burnt caramel building near the finish, and a hint of pepperiness.

Appearance:  Pours a dark auburn, with a tight knit layer of foam at the top.

Aroma:  A fruity mixture of banana and bubblegum. There are also scents of bready grain.

Taste:  Sweet and fruity malty flavors, bready yeast , bread crust, and a modest amount of bitter hopping in the end to balance out the sweetness. Also a hint of booze.

Mouthfeel: Thick and full bodied.

Overall:  Exactly what I look for in a Double Bock/ Doppelbock! Not too sweet. You know its strong, but its not overpowering with booziness.

this beer is slightly darker than your typical amber and has a fluffy head.  the aroma is malt, sweet, and slight hops.  the taste is malty, with a sweet flavor, bitter at the front and ends sweet. over all this is very smooth and pretty good

Bottle 50cl. Colour is very nice and red / amber. The taste is almost similar to some Irish Red Ale but with more sugar and alcool. We can detect the typical caramalt aroma as well as german hops also. The beer is quite bitter with some spices flavours, it goes well with this kind of heavy beers.

wow. This beer just took me by surprise. Simply wonderful. It had a nice amber color with a nice creamy head. the head don’t last, but that hardly mattered. It had a nice malty aroma, with a slight confectionary trace. and the flavor was almost the same. very pleasant malt taste, with toffee undertones. it went down very easy., and overall just very pleased. jumped up to one of my top favorite beers, out of over 300 I have had.

This pours a nice reddish brown with a good head and some nice lace. The aroma is sweet and fruity and the flavor follows with good cherry and apple character. Rounded out by a mile roastiness and tons of caramel. Very nice.
Aroma is sweet, with some light hints of dark fruit, caramel malt and alcohol.  Appearance is fair, but I do really like the dark amber hue.  Taste of roasted malt and noticeable alcohol.
Dark amber pour with a white head. Aroma is fruity and malty. It had a creamy taste that seemed to coat my mouth. Sweet tasting and you can taste the alcohol. Very tasty beer.
The Paulaner Salvator with its strong,typically malty taste is the original Paulaner.

Served as cold as ice in Korea with no glass, haha. Someone needs to brush up on their beer drinking. Tall tan head, clear amber body. Smell of smoke and wheat, citrus and grains. Taste was nutty, with toffee and a well balanced hoppy finish. Sharp palate, medium filling. Amazingly refreshing even at 7.9% - I was expecting it to have more weight. Excellent beer.

From a 500mL Bottle.  Mostly transparent, dark honey amber color with a thin layer of small bubbled, off-white head.  Intense Munich malt aroma, brimming with notes of raisin, plum, and grapey melanoidins.  Hintes of toffee and cherry gumdrop.  Medium-full bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a rich, chewy maltiness.  Melanoidins.  Lots of Munich malt.  Liquid grape beer juice with lots of gumdrop and raisin.  A noticeable alcohol warmth comes through in the finish, and while it isn’t hot, it prematurely shortens up the malt melanoidin parade that lingers on the palate in the finish.  A classic doppebock.
Another German beer I’ve really been enjoying lately. Nice smooth drinker with a very creamy malt mouthfeel only interrupted by a nice nuttiness. Maybe a slight bit of hops in the finish. Good stuff.
Great doppelbock.  Nice malty roasted barley flavor. Caramel, coffee flavor with a creamy finish.
Extremely smooth on the palate, with cream flavors remaining on the aftertaste. Excellent beer.

I had mixed feelings when looking for a new beer today, but I went with this based on it’s description. Well, unfortunately I succumbed to great marketing, as this was less than great. It has a watery mouthfeel, and some slight sweetness on the finish. It’s slightly dark, very German, and at best a decent brew. Oh well.
Bottle. Great beer. Pours a darker amber color. Thought it would be darker but no. Decent sized head. Aroma is sweet malts, roasted caramel and chocolate. Taste is nuts and some alcohol. Very good

Poured Dark Amber Color, wasnt expecting that. 1 finger head that went away quickly. Really nice aroma, kinda nutty, kinda sweet. Lots of flavor in this one for sure. Getting more of that nutty flavor, some bitterness but well balanced. Not getting as much chocolatey flavor as im use to with a double bock, but this one is still pretty darn good.

Overall this is one solid brew. And if im using a value scale this one I would give it an A+, but take price out of the equation and this is a solid b+ maybe an A for me!

...bottle.  Poured a nice looking darkish orange amber, with a small white head that for some reason didn’t last.  On the nose was lots of caramel malt, hops, and a little hint of spice.  Flavor was mainly malt, with nice nutty overtones, and the hops.  Very well balanced, and easy to drink.  Body seemed medium, went down well and had that nice Paulaner consistancy.  Very low carbonation, finished dry with hoppy notes, and just a hint of alcohol.  Was pretty damn good.
Pours a clear dark amber, very thin head. This was very very sweet big caramel, brown sugar taste, with a very nutty and malty aftertaste.
A very easy Doppelbock. lightly carbonated, toasted malt, toffee and spice. Rich and nice.

Poured clear brown with a dense one-finger head, ok retention and minimal lacing. Strong malt notes on the nose, featuring toffee and caramel. Taste is similar, with a hint of bitterness toward the end. Medium to full bodied, lightly carbonated, and a full toasted malt aftertaste.
Amber colour, off-white head. Aroma of toasted malts. Flavour has roasted malts, toffee and spices. Alcohol well noticable. Ok beer.

Bottle into Sam Adams Lager glass. 

Pours clear, dark amber, with a creamy off-white head that fades into a thin cap. Very translucent, and a bit off from what I’ve come to consider as the norm for the style. 

Nose is very malty, lots of toffee and caramel notes, with a big, fruity presence too - caramel covered apples, only with a bit of a toasty, molasses-like lightly bitter presence in there as well.

Taste is generally caramel sweetness, some lightly toasty bitterness in the back of the mouth that never emerges entirely from the malty sweetness, and resembles, again, molasses, or slightly-burned caramelized sugar. Toasty at points. A lightly fruity presence on the finish, which like the nose, comes across as caramel-covered apples. The nose and the taste with this one seem to mirror each other quite closely. 

Mouthfeel is a bit syrupy, low carbonation. Sticky. Maybe a bit undercarbonated.

Certainly not my favorite dopple bock. To me, this one almost comes across more as an English Barleywine. Still, It’s a pleasant beer, and I wouldn’t turn one down - there are just a number of examples of this style I’d pursue first (Curator, Korbinian, Celebrator, Troegenator...).

12 oz. bottle.  poured an amber/orange with an off white head.  aroma of caramel malt, spices, and some orange zest.  flavor was caramel, spices, alcohol and a nice bitter.  medium body with high carbonation.  i was surprised this was as good as it was.

Aroma- Strong malt aroma, modest toasty, minimal hops, no diacetyl, low fruity esters of prunes and dark fruit, moderate alcohol
Appearance- Dark amber hue with orange highlights, good clarity, minimal off-white head quickly dissipates, minimal legs
Flavors- Rich and thick caramel flavors, significant melanoidins and moderate toasty flavors, clean lager yeast, no diacetyl, light essence of dark fruits, light alcohol smoothness near the end, slight hop bitterness, sweet finish
Mouthfeel- Full-bodied, moderate carbonation, very smooth texture
Overall- The prototype doppelbock style, rich and sweet malts dominate throughout with a smooth and creamy texture, very clean and crisp flavors, easy-drinking as the alcohol is well masked behind the malt profile, no discernible flaws here
More of an amber to yellow apeparance. Forms a medium tan colored head. Easy taste that doesn’t cause a smirk. Goes down smoothly with no bitterness.

Although I am not a huge fan of the dopplebock style, this is definitely one of the better representations. Nose is fairly complex, a bit floral, hints of spice, slightly sourish. Decent lace when poured from the bottle into a glass. Subtle chocolate and cofee undertones, molasses and raisens also come to mind. Very easy to drink, spicy and malty, not much hops presence though (one reason I’m not a regular dopplebock guy), high abv well hidden but the slightly metallic aftertaste takes away from the overall experience. Nice warming sensation which helps make this a great winter beverage, pairing nicely with standard German fare as well as spicy Thai (which was the case with myself prior to this writing). All said, a fine and classic brew from the Munich brewery which has been around for over 360 years. Makes me proud of my German heritage. And did I mention the 7.9 abv?
Pours reddish amber, with thin slightly tan head.  Caramel flavors with a yeast finish.  Aromas of bread dough, toffee, and oatmeal.  This is a beer to drink when its cold, not too bad.

Pours a clear amber with a creamy beige head.  Aroma shows some raisins, toffee, caramel, and is somewhat lactic but is too subdued.  Weak lacking flavor is similarly toffee-ish with some raisin followed by a slightly bitter toasted finish.  Sweet all around.  This is ok, but there’s an emptiness to the flavor that bothers me.

12/3/08 From the bottle. Aroma is warm and caramel malt forward with light dark fruit and no hop character. Appearance is clear gold with a well maintained off-white head. Flavor is rich and candilike with low earthy bittering and some citrus. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a moderate carb texture. Overall, rich but not overwhelming, lacks a little of the overly rich character one might expect.
Amber brown in color with a good sized tan head. Aromas of malt, toffee, caramel, toast and fruit. Tast is the same with a nice alcohol warmth.

Aroma de malte e toffee. Coloração caramelo avermelhada, lembrando whisky. Espuma densa. Sabor acentuadamente maltado, com predomínio de açúcares no início e amargor no final, sobrando um pouco de álcool.

12 oz bottle. Pours a thickish light tan head, over a clear dark amber body......nose redolent of layered malts, yeast, breads.....tastes of complex heavy malts with a lightly sweet finish....mouthfeel is chewy and heavy. A lovely thing.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Very sweet malt nose.  Flavor has more of a scotch ale profile, but it’s a doppelbock.... Aight, that’s cool.  Nice and smooth, not spectacular, but thankfully no poop.

Bottle dated 06/08 but I figured it would still be good so I bought it anyway. Nice reddish color, smells and tastes bready, grainy, some sweetness, raisin bread. Overall a tasty and easy to drink dopplebock. I need to start drinking more of these German beers!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-24-2009 03:11:52
Pours a clear amber with a nice bready malt aroma. Flavor is rich malty, some breadiness, and  dark fruit.

A nice amber color with an attractive dark fluffy head that formed.  This was a very good doppelbock, highly recommend it.  It had a big malty flavor along with a fruity finish.  Noses of fruit, malts, and some slight hops.
Pretty good, about what I was expecting. Not overly sweet which is a problem in many doppelbocks. Fruity malts, especially grapes, dominate the taste. Sweet finish. Dense taste, light carbonation.
Amber colored brew. Malty aroma. Flavor is fruity, malty, watery, en some burned malts.

500 ml bottle in Germany. Nice brown head it was not exported so it had a nice head but went quickly. What can I say other than this is proof that Macros can brew fantastic beer. Unlike most Macros in the USA. Slight aftertaste a bit metalic. Still a great Bock.

Brownish orange color out of the bottle with almost no head.  Big sweet nose of caramels and alcohol.  Thick creamy caramel and toffee sweetness with some rich bread and dark fruit.  Hot on the tongue.  Nice double bock.

(bottle) pours a ruby-amber colour with a creamy off-white head. aroma of caramel, sweet spices, strawberries and brown sugar. flavour is fruity, with notes of apple, strawberry and peach, caramel, yeast and alcohol. heavy-bodied with medium carbonation and a rather dry finish. a surprisingly good bock!
Slightly metallic on the nose, with toasty roasty malts, patchy white head.  Slight iron in the flavor, with sweet malt, some milk chocolate, bitter, with significant boozey flavor.

Appearance: Pours a clear, dark, deep amber body with a medium-sized, though dense, off-white head.

Smell: Sweet-smelling, lightly nutty nose of dried herbs, honey, pears, and even sugar-coated figs.

Taste: Lightly toasty, lightly nutty malt flavor with a definite sweetness, but it’s kept in check by an herbal spice character, the certainly noticeable alcohol, and the bitter hops. Rum-soaked fruitiness. Still though, it finishes bready and sweet with warming alcohol presence.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: A fine, respectable doppelbock, but, truth be told, it’s bit boozy for me.

Amber body with a lasting beige head.  Deliciously sweet aroma of malt and candy.  The brew is smooth, sweet, and very satisfying.  Caramel, molasses, and red licorice.  There’s a bit of alcohol warming at the end.  A very good beer, and surprisingly easy to drink considering the alcohol content.
500ml bottle, 19th Nov 08. Very, very malty aroma, malty taste. Decent standard doppelbock.

Bottled version. Nice authentic label. Amber brown, ruby- orange color. Medium, frothy head , quickly fading. Sweet fruity malty aroma. Medium to full bodied. Sweet caramel, molasses  with a hint of warming liqueur feel in the end. Good.
Bottle. Pours a brown body with a tan head. Nutty sweet malt, hints of licorice, and alcohol latent fruits.  Good with a nice warming to finish.
Draught at Brics Inn Jyväskylä. Mild syropy nose. Malty syrupy slightly sweet taste. Mild hopppiness. Slightly grassy taste. Slighyly coppery yellow colour. Pale beige head.
Bottle. Poured amber in color with a very thin off-white head. Aroma of a sweet malt. Smooth and thick on the palate. Flavor is sweet with an alcohol finish.

Bottle poured a darker amber with an off-white head.  Light barley and malts with a bolder flavor as the beer warmed.  Better than your average Doppel and I would have again but falls short in comparison to Celebrator.

Pours a beautiful clear copper with a small off-white head. Aroma is red licorice. Taste is also red licorice with some maple syrup and molasses. Not too thin on the palate but not heavy. Very different from the typical dobbelbock. 7.9% abv is perfectly hidden. Very good.
Definetly caramel aroma and flavor in this beer. I think that this beer is a great after dinner beer, or a great beer to sip on a cold night around a fire.
12 oz. bottle - Poured amber copper color with little head. Aroma is malty and sweet. Flavor is also sweet, reminded me of a cough drop. Boozey on palate
Aroma is caramel. Small frothy, white head. Fair lacing. Fully diminishing longevity. Clear orange body. Heavy sweet flavor with notes of caramel, and a long finish duration. Medium to full palate.
very bold flavor thoughout and finishes strong at the end. a pretty good brew

(Draught at Hilpeä Hauki on 2008-11-07) Deep amber and clear. Small white head. Sweet malty nose. Full bodied palate with lot of carbonation. Malts, hint of roastedness, some alcohol, boiled vegetables and bitterness in taste. Sweetness and bitterness in aftertaste.

Pours a gin clear amber with a super thin off-white head.  Some carbonation..no lacing.  Aroma is fruity, with hints of bitter-sweet chocolate malts.  Flavor is consistent with the aroma, with a touch of alcohol (brandy/port).  Palate is light-med bodied, slighty water and slick.  Overall a very enjoyable, highly drinkable dark lager.
Bottle from Carringtons, Manchester.  Bit too thin for a Doppelbock for me.  Other than that, not a bad beer of its type but not exceptional.

Pours brownish amber with tan head.  Smells like burnt grains, sweet mollassy.  Tastes sweet, roasty, starts bitter with the burnt grains, followed by some fruity sour/sweetness.  Hints of honey or molasses and some cocoa. Not to my liking.

Draught. Sweet malty and molassy nose, little fruitiness, syrup. Slightly toasty, but there ain’t much hops. Flavor is sweet syrupy malts, sweet pear and alcohol. Almost closer to European strong lagers, than ”proper” dobbelbocks. A bit thin palate, with soda like carbonation. I remember this being a lot more chewy and warming from bottle, should probably re-rate that way sometime.
Great maltiness as expected from this style but not overly sweet.  Beautiful brown color with well balanced hops.
amber coppery colour. medium head. sweet, malty aroma. Very bready, malty taste but not too sweet. still well balanced. A very solid doppelbock.
Bottle.  Pours a clear amber color, thin off white head, very malty, fruity, and flavorful.  Not a huge fan of doppelbocks but this is worth trying.
Bottle, R$ 10.00 (US$ 4.55) in Bompreço Iguatemi, Salvador, Brazil. Very nice beer.

Bottle from the LCBO
A more detailed description will follow on a second tasting
I have misplaced my comments for this beer

Bottle; pors an amber/orange color with a small, off white head.  Aroma of caramel, fruit,dark fruit, and sweet malt.  Very quaffable flavor.  Balanced and blended nicely.  Caramel, bread and dark fruit blend well.  Moderate sweetness.  Light yeasty elements with a solid bitterness.  Lingering flavor.  Very enjoyable stuff.  Can’t believe I haven’t rated this yet.

Pours translucent amber in color with a light tan head. Straightforward sweet malt aroma, with some caramel and maple syrup. Flavor is also sweet malt dominated, with some bread and toffee. Nice and warming going down. A good example of a straightforward doppelbock, but not quite on the level of the more complex versions like the Celebrator.

On tap, Flying Saucer-Cordova
Served in tulip glass, a deep amber.  Flavor was deeply malty, a very satisfying beer.  The alcohol further adds to great mouthfeel experience.

Pours a dark amber with a small head. The nose was reaking of sweet caramel and with a hint of dark fruits. Flavor was malty, caramel sweet with a tough of dark fruits.The alcohl and complexity was hidden well.

Bottle pours dark amber with thick, beige head. Uber-malty nose with tootsie-roll, molasses, maple, caramel candy, toffee. Flavor has that sweet-malty center, with a touch of sour breadiness, going into mild bitterness for good balance. Bittersweet aftertaste. Nice all-around flavor.
Pours amber with carmel frothy head. Not a big fan of double bock style but this isnot too bad. Have another? If you goget it for me.
Bottle.  Pours brown/red with little head. Aroma is sweet and malty.  Flavor is sweet with dark fruits and malt throughout. Little hop in the finish.

avoided for reasons i cannot explain....too bad, this is a nice doppel raisiny and sticky sweet it is full of malt and has an interesting full aroma as well. spicy (and yes burnt ryan) and true to form with a light yeasty and pleasant mouthfeel. i would encourage all to try this one. alcohol nicely recessed. i should lower several doppel scores in my profile as this is clearly a superior brew.

Pours red-orange, unfiltered and bubbly with little head. 

Sweet aroma, sweet and spicy flavor with plenty of malt and bread flavor. Distinctive flavor, but not overpowering like a few other dopplebocks.
Amber, sweet, syrupy, creamy, caramel, bready, malty, little spice, little fruity, little alcohol.

Pours dark, clear red, thin to middle sized head that dissipates quickly. Looking diagonally into this beer -- it’s red as Mars. Nice looking brew thanks to the color. Syrupy, sugary, slightly alcoholic, malty aroma. Taste... Syrupy caramel malt, a bit of breadiness, a tad alcoholic. Tingly carbonation, slightly watery, but not drastically so. Solid, solid effort. Thumbs up.

Great aroma, it is almost enough just to smell this stuff. The appearance of this beer reminds me very much of Spaten Optimator. Not as fruity as Optimator, more "burnt" flavors on the tongue, nearly spicy. More complex than expected, every mouthful is a new delight. I really enjoyed this brew, I would go out of my way to find it if need be.

Love the colour of this beer...an invigorating burnt hazy brown-tinged orange sepia deep mahogany rose. Smell of malts, apricot, rum. Mouthfeel is smooth; almost creamy on the tongue and leaves a faint sweet tingle on the edge of the lips (in an almost pornographic sort of way). Taste falls intot he spectacular range with hints of ham, toffee, buttered carrots, brown sugar, caramel, spices, barley, and malt. Aftertaste is well rounded with some slight bitterness and cognac0like sweetness.

Dark amber body with a frothy tan and stable beige head. Mildly, buttery aroma of malt, fruity yeast, moderated hop, caramel. Complex flavor, smooth mouthfeel with caramel, sweet and fruity malt and nice bottom fermentation. Well balanced, roasty and liqueric aftertaste.
he Paulaner Salvator with its strong,typically malty taste is the original Paulaner
Dark orange. Very sweet, malty and syrupy. Butter, caramel, chocolate. First thing that popped into my head was ’tootsie roll’, and I feel thats pretty accurate. Delicious, but very sweet

Dark orange color with a thin white head.  Sweet malty aroma with notes of honey.  Malty flavor with an almost syrupy taste and feel to it.  Crisp citrus finish with a slight bitterness and alcohol flavor.  There is either more to this beer than I can pick out, or it teases me into thinking so.

On tap in our hotel in Garmisch.  Pours amber with a small head.  Smell is light with a little sweet and spicey aromas.  Taste is wonderfull, starts sweet then turns dry and bitter and ends with a slight alcohol flavor.

Pours a nice amber with frothy tan head.  Mildly sweet aroma, some nice fruit notes in there.  Lots of caramel in the flavor above the expected maltiness.  Balance is wonderful, extremely pleasant to drink.

Pours a copper amber with a thin off white head. The nose is sweet, bready, grainy, light alcohol, grassy, malty. The flavor is sweet, grainy, bready, caramel, fruity, light alcohol. Sweet mouthfeel with a little alcohol showing through.

The first thing that hits in the aroma is spicy and flowery hops and some sweet maltiness and warm alcohol. As it warms, it wofts dark fruits like prunes, raisens even maybe strawberries! Has a thick but fleetung creamy tan head. This great beer pours a clear darker amber. Tastes much like the aroma. A great beer indeed.
Nice deep rich color and has a sweet dark amber-brown. sweet buttery syrupy taste yet has kind of a thick full flavor. this is a good beer and I give it two thumbs up.

12 oz bottle. Nice brew, smooth and tasty! Light copper hue and small head and some lacing. Aroma hints of molasses, herbs, honey, ripe pears, and vanilla. Starts sweet but a swipe of alcohol cleans the palate. Fruity taste and aromatic german hops are detected as well. Full-bodied with a oily and soft mouthfeel. Moderate alcoholic feel is present. Overall a solid beer.
Deep, rich color, pours nicely. Sweet yet complex. Strong but smooth. Incredibly good, one of my favorites.

Awesome fall beer.  This sucker screams to be nurtured while watching a good football game next to a fire.  The pairings are endless with this beauty but it is so damn tasty on its own.  Supple off-white head gives way to a deep copper, light brown tweener that reminds me of drizzled maple syrup.  Smells like french toast with buttery syrup and just a touch of alcohol bite to it.  Taste is a malt heavy creaminess that almost induces sleep upon contact, let this sucker warm up a bit and it’s like caramel on your tongue, sweet and bready in the finish.  Smooth full body and a lack of carbonation makes this  beer a total comfort food. Awesome.  12 oz. bottle. 2008.

small frothy offwhite head. fair lacing. mostly diminishing. clear sparkling dark-amber body. aroma: caramel, heavy nutty malt, dark bread. initial flavor: moderate sweet light bitter. Final flavor: moderate sweet bitter; long duration. palate: medium body, watery/oily texture, lively carbonation, metallic finish. good attenuation and drinkability. tasty. 50s

sep18,2008Sua belíssima aparência é composta por uma espuma inicial de aparência pequena, cor marrom-claro e virtualmente nenhuma formação de colarinho. A longevidade da espuma é reduzida, seu corpo tem densidade rala e tonalidade âmbar. O aroma é moderadamente maltado, com presença de pão escuro, melado, caramelo e mel. O sabor inicial é levemente doce e amargo, adquirindo moderado amargor no final, este de longa duração. O corpo da Salvator é médio-leve, com textura seca e oleosa, de carbonatação suave e sensação metálica e levemente alcoólica. É bem maltada, com amargor de lúpulo bem presente. Muito agradável no paladar, com a presença caramelizada no paladar mascarando bem o teor alcólico.

Little head retention. Watered-down amber color. Nose of almondy caramel malt. First sip is more of the same. Mouthfeel is medium with soft German malts balanced by a hoppy presence I’m not used to in most Bavarians. A mild Winter seasonal but very tasty and good balance. Alcohol content is a shocker. I would have guessed around 5%. Could drink every day.
dark amber-brown. sweet buttery syrupy. ok and tasty, but a little watery taste. although almost medium bodied.

Dark red color, brightly clear, nice light head that dissipated quickly, with nothing left.  Deep roast scent.   Malty and strong.  Flavor is mild and smooth.  Crisp in the mouth with a late bit of bitterness way in the back.  Can taste a bit of alcohol in it.  Nice light and flavorful brew.  I like this one.

Bottle. Dark amber colour with a very small head. Sweet malty aroma with hints of some fruits. Taste is sweet and malty with alcohol. Medium bodied brew with a sweet aftertaste. I was expecting more from this beer, but it was still quite drinkable.

Interested in a delicious malt bomb?  Look no further than this amber pouring maltfest of a beer.  Always good.  Paulaner makes some damn fine brews folks.  Lost of caramel, yeast, and some hints of fruit in the nose.  Flavor is yeasty, caramel malts, sweet...I liked it.
Aroma of caramel, orange brown body, sweet flavour, a little strong the presence of alcohol but an easy drinking beer.

Aroma is sweet and fruity plus a hint of alcohol.  Pours a clear dark copper color with a bubly head that disapears almost immediately.  Taste is once again sweet and fruity; raisins, a bit of plum, plus some caramel and toffee.  Finishes with a smooth, dry flavor of nuts and smoke.  Smooth and very drinkable.

Round, malty and caramal flavors. Enough hop bitterness to keep it from being cloying. Spiciness in the finish. Very nice. Goes well with steak and sharp chesses. doppelbock the others are comparing themselves to.

I loved this beer.  12 oz bottle poured into a stem glass.  Poured a clear dark amber color with a huge foamy tan head.  Aroma was of caramel and some dark fruits, maybe plums.  Flavor consists of sweet malt, caramel dark fruit and honey.  Medium/heavy bodied with average carbonation.  I was pleased with this beer.  Bought as a single, because I am skeptical of some imported Germans.  Will purchase a sixer of this on my next visit.
What can I say, I love German beer! Appearance of an amber brown with a thick creamy tan head. Slight hoppiness with caramel, maple, and fruit. Nice beer to have on a cold night, belly warmer.

draft, tasting, biergarten, tivoli. aroma not quite strong enough. sawdust, dark fruits,  pours clear brown with nice head, flavor is burnt caramel, honey, alc - a little strangely balanced, but all the flavors that are present are great.

Bottled.  Very easy drinking doppelbock.  Pours a clear bronze colour with a tan head, no lacing.  Big aroma of caramel and molassas (and I swear to God corn tortillas).  More molassas in the flavour plus some rock candy and rich malts.  Enjoyable.

Bottle.  Pours a medium-thick, creamy, off-white head which tops off the clear, bubbly, deep orange-brown body, little lacing.    Sweet aroma of leather, peach, grape, and barley.  Velvety, not as thin-bodied as most lagers.  Leaves a bit of film on my tongue.  Complex flavor, rich, malty and peachy with some high notes at first, but a little too sweet.  Fades into a pleasant bitter, dry finish.

12 oz bottle...pours amber brown with a fluff, mostly diminishing off-white head...no lacing. Aromas of maple syrup, caramel, spices, the dark malts and some alcohol. Flavor is sweet, and dry with notes of the above , but the alcohol is persistent and warming. Palate is thin, dry, with low levels of carbonation, and a moderately bitter sweet finish. Not overly impressed...
Sweet, a bit fruity, dry and nicely malty. A bit too sweet maybe but I do dig it.

(Bottle).  Aroma is sweet caramel with distinct alcohol.  Color a beautiful dark red.  Head is small and whitish.  Flavor sweet caramel and malt, but with way too much alcohol taste intruding, leading to a disturbing imbalance.  Overall, an ok doppelbock, but nowhere near the Celebrator (or even Optimator) class.

This pours deep amber with a fine white head and has a sweet & vinous nose full of raisin and dried plum scents. Initially tastes sweet and full-bodied, but as the flavour develops the sweetness is balanced by a nutty hop character, lots of malt, a hint of roastiness and a dry alcoholic bite. The finish is dry and gently bitter.

Bottle in a train - going to Sunes birthdaysparty - shared with Mette & Lars. Clear dark red/brown - white head. High malty, raisins, brries, fruity, caramel, amber malts, roasted, nutty, light hoppy. Finishes with a alcho-bite !!!
Poured an amber brown with a medium off-white head. Fruity and malty aroma. Quite flavourful with hints of caramel, malts and fruit. Medium bodied with a slightly bitter aftertaste.

2008 Bottle.  Light aroma of caramel and malts.  Gorgeous appearance: dark amber with hints of orange and a light off-white head.  The flavor and palate could be fuller and more complex, but this beer is robust nonetheless.  Quite malty with a dark, alcohol taste as well.  Very good beer.
Amber color, medium head, tasted cherries on the first sip, malty not bad I really liked it ,

Bottle, Carringtons, Chorlton. Poured a dark amber/brown with a large, dissipating off white head. Aroma packed with malt and some spice. Flavour was sweet and sticky and on the rich side of the scale. Brandy sodden dark fruit, roasted malt, nuts and some hop in there. Certainly smooth and flavoursome, but lacks balance to its detriment, and the finish wasn’t quite there either which knocked marks off what nearly could have been quite a high score.

Oh yes.  I do love doppelbock.  Sorry that I avoided grabbing this for so long.  Nice brown pour out the bottle with a better than average head.  Smells of malt and fruit.  Tastes of biscuit, caramel, and even a bit of licorice.  I can’t imagine how good this is on tap.

Clear golden color.  Small white head that quickly disappears.  Aroma is very sweet.  Malts and Caramal.  Failrly good palate.  Starts off sweet, some spice and finishing with a taste of alcohol and some hops.  Not bad overall but I do think the alcohol is a little to prevalant at times.

On tap @ De Geuzen en Café Gollem, last winter. Amber colour, big creamy head. Aroma of sweet malts, caramel. Flavour is sweet and malty, dough, caramel. The first few sips are very sweet, afterwards the nice soft bitter finish comes out. Very nutricious and tasteful beer.

22 oz bottle.  Nice caramel, malty aroma.  Strong, musty tea flavors overpowered the caramel malty and slight brandy flavors.  Maybe I had an old bottle in the States but the flavors seemed out of balance.

Off white full lasting head. Dark anber colour. Aroma is malty, fruity (raisins) with light caramel, wooden and alcohol notes. Flvor is malty too with dark fruits, honey and caramel tones, ending in a more balanced, slightly fruity finish. Medium bodied.
Dark amber colour and clear. Has a golden head, mostly lasting. Aroma is sweet, caramel. Flavor is heavy sweet. Syrup texture.

Man this is the best German beer I have ever had. Carmel flavors work with lively carb to mask the heavy alcohol. makes this smooth and easy drink. lt has an amber colour ... which is pleasant surprise because one would expect a really dark colour if you where sipping this out of the bottle before you poured it. Good stuff. .

(Bottle) Pours a reddish brown with a small creamy off-white head. The aroma is medium malty/syrupy and light hoppy with tones of caramel, syrup, dark (rye) bread, vanilla-ish marshmallows, light honey, light marzipan, light toasted almonds, and flowers. Some dried fruits and brown sugar in the undertones. The flavour is medium to full malty and light hoppy with tones of caramel, syrup, dark bread and flowers alongside a light touch of dried fruits. Some alcohol is present in the flavour. Medium to full sweet and light bitter. The mouthfeel is somewhat creamy but too clean/sterile with a light sticky touch. The finish is light numbing from the alcohol with some earthy bread-like tones lingering. Medium to full bodied.
bottled. Nice chestnut brown color, beige head, no lace. Aroma has malts and is flat. Flavour has malts and fresh bread. Alcohol is well hidden. not a beer for late July

Pours clear brown with a decent sized tan head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malt.  Taste of sweet malt, dark fruits and a bit of alchohol in the end.  Not bad.  Not too cloying, but sweet.  Hey Grim, I bet you rated this higher then me!
0,5 l tap at Ølgrotten in Tivoli, København. Brown color, off-white head. Aroma is caramel malt. Flavor is fine sweetness from malt and fruit. Hints of alcohol.
Bottle from 2006. Brown pour fizzy head. Caramel roast aroma.  Slightly oxidized flavor combined with dark fruit, malts, and yeasty

12 ounce bottle-  poured a rich amber-gold with a fair, but short-lived head.  Aroma was dried fruit.  Taste was dark fruit and very slightly floral.  Very nice.  Big points for the silky smooth palate.  A good one.

Bottle. Dark ruby, dissipating head. Sweet aroma of burnt sugar and caramel malts. Sweet spicy flavour of dark fruits and dark sugar with a distinct alcohol sting. Very nice cookie dough finish. Like a less refined Belgian, but great value for money.
On tap @ Ølbaren. Clear and deep amber coloured with a medium sized wihte head. Ok balanced - a bit to the sweet side - notes of bread, caramel, metal and hops.

Bottle from By The Bottle in Vancouver, WA--Poured a dark amber-brown body with a fluffy two-finger off-white head.  Fruity, sweet, malty, nutty, roasted, and chewy.  Sweet, acidic, tart, sweet, mildly cloying, and boozy.  Nice clove and banana spice hints.  Complex and dessert-worthy.  Very good beer!

22 oz. bottle.  Poured amber-red with some beige head that quickly dissipates.  Smells of tart fruits, molasses, nuts and alcohol.  Tastes sweet and toasty... honey and dried fruits with notes of malts and almonds... a little tart, and some definite alcohol presence.  Not bad, the flavor of alcohol was not masked enough for my tastes, but I should have expected that at 7.9%.

poured an amber-red hue with a quickly fading white head.  No carbonation present.  
A rich malty aroma sweet caramel and bread notes some alcohol.  Flavor was a sweet with both caramel and a sweet bread note.  Nice smooth drink, mild but noticeable alcohol presance .
thx 4 great tasting Kimjohansen, formely known as Beljohansen :-) amber, short head, notes of malt, toffee, chocolate and fried fruit. Sweet taste

Bottle, Large Creamy white head with some lacing.  Clear body with an amber/red color.  Aroma of molasses/carmel and almonds.  Decent palate with a medium body and light carbonation.  Sweet flavor.  Does not even compare to Celebrator or even Tucher.
Bottle.  Dark amber pour with a beige head.  Sweet malt aroma with hints of banana and spice.  Nice malt flavor, mildly toasty and more bananas and spice.  Pretty good.

Appearance: Redish brown, little head.
Aroma: Honey, malt.
Taste: Bitter, malty, sweet, complex finish.
Info: 500ml bottle, 18/11-2005, 54/300, 34/500

re-rated 2020

cream-beiege head with amber red body, lots of carbonation visible. intense malty aroma, light coffee, sourdough bread, caramel, brown sugar. taste is alcoholic, dark toast/coffee, bready, little apple, not sweet at all, darker flavour than colour lets on. body is full and frothy.

more complex than i remember, but highly drinkable. i thought it might let me down after many years not having it, but didnt at all. would get again.

341mL bottle from LCBO.  Pours dark orange amber, with a small reducing white head.  Nose is of sweet malt and honey.  Flavour is of honey, toffee’d malt, and scorched sweet nuts.  Thick, appropriate mouthfeel.  Delicious.

THOUGHTS: A nice beer. This may have been the first doppel, but others have perfected the style. It does get much better as it warms. Very nice, but not as complex as some doppels or as intense as others. Bonus point for creating one of my favorites styles.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a medium copper with an average-size, off-white head that mostly diminished. The aroma was nice but weak. There was some grain and molasses along with apple, cherry, tobacco, slight alcohol and maybe some red wine. The initial flavor was lightly to moderately sweet and lightly acidic; while the finish was moderately sweet, lightly acidic and moderately to heavily bitter with an average duration. There was caramel malt, red wine, cherries a little alcohol and some apples as well. The medium body was creamy then dry in the back with lightly fizzy carbonation and a light astringent and light to moderate alcoholic finish.

Fantastic beer...had the pleasure of enjoying this one on tap at the Yard House in Las Vegas, Nevada.  Tremendous, rich, malty flavor with strong notes of fruit.  Some alcohol in the finish, but still ends on a sweet note.

nice clear golden brown appearance, thin non-lasting head. Begins with a sweet malty taste which is quickly overshadowed by a chemically alcohol taste that was all that lingered. I drank half of it and poured the rest out. It was one of the least agreeable beers i’ve tasted.
Clear amber pour with a small foamy head.  Rosted caramel malt aroma.  Sweet malty flavor with a bit of spicy hop on the finish.  Pretty standard.

(GERMAN) Pours a orange / amber color with a dissipating white head. The aroma is of caramel, honey, and figs. With a mild malt taste that hides the 7.9 % very well, and leaves a nice warm finish. Pretty good, But not quite what i expected.
this is a malty dream.  spicy and caramelly, very little hop presence at all.  far too easy drinking at almost 8%.

Bottle pours a nice dark reddish-brown with a light tan head that quickly dissipates. The aroma is malt and a caramel sweetness that is intoxicating. Nice sweetness and creamy mouth feel, with malt and hops and a slow bitter sweet warming finish. To be savored.

Dark brown color. A nice malty aroma which follows to the strong flavor. Not my favourite style of beer, but it’s quite good as what it is. (737313)
(170916) It’s good but the score was OK already.

I love this beer. My wife says it tastes like soy sauce, and it is May and it says it’s a seasonal. I wonder if it tastes different because of this. Nonetheless, with sushi or without, this beer is great. Does taste salty, though...

Recommendation: drink this beer at room temperature (not fully cold anyway). Taste it!
Small, quickly dissipating head, pours amber. Sweet smelling aroma. Slight smoky flavor, smooth. A little too bitter, somewhat unbalanced in my opinion.

Alot like the Optimator, but way more fragrant. Aroma of honey, fig, and caramelly malt. I think I smelled a little sandalwood in there somewhere. Rich, sweet malty flavor of caramel, figs, grain, toast and cola. Softer CO2 would have for a better palate. Finish is a little less dirty than I had hoped for, but overall this is a solid doppel.

330 ml bottle. Pours a reddish-brown color, low head. Aroma has some notes of dark malts and blackcurrant leaves. The taste is  a fairly good mix of sweet, juicy malts,  molasses and hop bitterness. Slightly watery texture, fairly light body.

One of my staples as a young, beginning beer drinker... surprising that I’m just now rating this.  Lovely amber-orange color that gives you a visual peek into its sweet, slightly-strong taste.  Aroma is sweet and malty.  Flavor is strongly sweet and just a little spicy/nutty - just enough to balance out the sweetness.  Comfortable body.  Enjoyable to drink.

Red-brown with a small head that disappears quickly. Smell is sweet, with mild hops and raisins. Flavor is winey and kinda watery. Palate is thin and flat. I suspect that this is just a bad bottle. Well, okay, it’s not that bad. I just think that this is normally better.
Amber colour, medium bodied. Semi sweet taste with a creamy thick body, and a tan coloured head. Pours pleasently- aroma is reminiscent of fruit, nuts and caramel.

A great brew! Nice caramel aroma with a hearty amarillo taste. Pours dark and thick with a minor slightly darkened head. Bubbles of flavor attack the senses with a punch of sweetness and bitterness perfectly balanced. I’m recommending this for a try.
Dark Ruby color, light beige head, decent lacing. Nose is caramel and nuts. Palate is caramel, malt, sweet, nutty, brandy. Not too bad.

Copper-gold pour with little head.  Aroma is bready, nutty, spicy and lots of caramel malt.  Rich caramel malt flavor that has notes of bread, brandy, nuts, spice, and dark fruits.  Sticky medium body with soft carbonation.

A very orange beer on pour into a pint glass. It smells of sweet malts. It tasted of sweet malts. A very good beer that is very well balanced. 

Second take: I really didn’t get bowled over with the nose on this one after pouring it into a pint glass. It had a small head with a dark amber body. It is smooth and creamy and you don’t pick up the alcohol levels at all. All in all not a bad as it is very smooth - but nearly flat .
ADDED A POINT

This beer pours a deep copper with some head.  It has a very sweet, malty aroma.  The taste is also very sweet and malty....almost syrupy.  The body is medium-heavy with low carbonation.  This is a good beer and a fine example of a double bock.

Bouteille de 330 ml. La bière se présente avec une couleur cuivrée et une légère mousse qui laisse rapidement place à un vide total. Au nez on découvre des arômes de jus de pomme, de céréale, de poire et de fleurs. En bouche le corps est moyen et les flaveurs sont : les pommes rouges, les poires, le caramel, les fruits rouges murs et le sucre.
I was expecting a bit more body to this doppelbock.  It is good nonethless, but a bit too smooth for the style.  Pours almost pure black with a nice head.

A very bready beer that had a generally pleasing flavor.  The main problem i had with this beer is in the palate which i just found unpleasant.  I may try picking this up again to see if i like it any better

35cl Bottle . Very beatiful amber color with a big and low duration head. Toasted malt and caramel aroma. Full bodied and low carbonated. Sweet and toasted malt flavor with notes of caramel, alcohol is not perceived. It’s a very balanced beer !
Deep amber with medium beige head. Sweet malty aroma with caramel notes. Sweet flavor with notes of roasted malt, caramel and bread.
dark amber with a small white head that leaves little to no lacing behind. smells like a brown ale but with a spicier taste of clove mixed in.

I love this stuff. My favorite place to drink this is at the Rathskeller when Polka Boy is playing. 
It’s smooth on the palate, high in alcohol and well balanced all the way through. It’ not the best Double Bock I’ve had, but it’s one of the tops.
Nice thick head and dark in color. Full of malt, carmel and bread flavor.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with nice beige head. Aroma and taste of sugary malt, fruit and berry, bread and caramel. Very balanced with medium carbonation. A great classic.

2008 Bottle - Pours a beautiful amber with a small tannish head.  Aroma is powerful yeast, sugary malt and dried fruit.  Flavour is drier than the aroma would suggest, but still is a bit cloying. The profile is pretty simple and leaves a weird feeling on the sides of my mouth,  Also, there is a metallic nuance that I thought would go away, but stuck around and made this pretty hard to drink...
Light colored beer.  Easy to drink. semi sweet, and refreshing.  Smells sweet medium carbonation.  ok beer.

A- Pours a deep reddish copper color with a small, brownish off-white head.

S- There is a subtle sweet smell. Hints of dark fruits. Very laid back but pleasant nose.

T- Tastes of darkened wheat, with an almost candy-like sweetness.

M- This brew has fairly light carbonation however it is somewhat thick. It leaves a syrupy coating in my mouth that feels a bit unpleasant.

D- This is fairly easy to drink taste wise but because of the way it coats your mouth i’d have to say drinkability suffers.

50cl bottle.   Clear dark red-amber with a big fluffy head.   Smells a little doughy with some breadcrust, caramel, and light metal.   The flavor is big malts with lots of plum and caramel.   Very clean and crisp, with no apparent alcohol.   Full bodied with small, crisp bubbles.   A little boring, as I tend to find the style, but very clean and drinkable.

Bottle.  Pours a clear copper with a one finger tan head.  Nose is caramel malt and dark fruits.  Palate is sweet – caramelized sugar and prunes with a slight dry alcohol finish.  Creamy mouth feel.  Not my favorite style, but this is a decent spokesperson for it.

12oz bottle from 12/07.  Pours surprisingly light (for the style).  An amber color with a small white head that quickly drops to just cover the surface.  Aroma is sweet, clean, with some nice hot melted caramel smell and candy.  Like a subdued barley wine.  Slight breadiness.  Taste is moderately sweet with some subtle dark fruits and a quick finish.  Medium bodied.  Easy to drink.  I am not a huge fan of doppelbocks but this is pretty good.  It’s no Celebrator though.

deep amber. smells coppery, malty, oaky. taste is a whole lot more interesting. carmel, raisin, hops disguised as bourbon, nutmeg. for its robustness i expect it to last longer. could be softer on the tongue. flavor steals the show.

12 oz bottle from Total Wine in Jacksonville, FL.  Bottle marked "made on 10/07" on lower right of label.  Pours a nice light copper color with a small head.  Aroma is robust with malt; taste is rich and full, and delivers a nice doppelbock taste.  Great beer.
Light amber with thin diminishing head.    Aroma of sugar, caramel and bread.  Taste is more of the same, overly sweet.  Light notes of fruit in the finish.

keg draught at Gallows Bird Espoo
Taste:sweet,malts, bit hoppy. short aftertaste. Too sweet for my taste
Full malt backbone. Not too much carbonation with lacey pour.  Low bitterness. A flowery sweetness in the first sip. I like it, and always have.  A model of consistency from year to year.

6-pack from Total Wine, River Edge, NJ...bottle pours clear copper with an off-white head...mildly sweet aroma, kind of like candy corn...flavor is mildly sweet too, malts, bit of a metallic aftertaste...kind of reminds me of the "Old Speckled Hen" but better...this is the fourth Doppel I’ve rated (not OSH which is an ESB) and they’ve all been drastically different...keeping me honest...

Pours with an off-white foamy head that goes in about 45 seconds. Clear amber body. Aroma is of metal and amber malts. Taste is sweet malts and a bit of salt. Syrupy mouthfeel with nice lively carbonation.

Clear amber pour with small off-white head.  Loads of malt on the nose.  Sweet, but not overly so.  Really lovely aroma.  Taste is sweet but not cloying.  Mild fruit taste... apple, golden raisin, more malt, a little yeast.  This is a pleasant brew.

Had this one bottled in Stevens Point, Wisconsin, thanks Slothgar!  An outstanding dopplebock, probably the best I’ve ever had. Dark orange pour with a bubbly white head, sweet, molassasy nose, very clean taste, sweet and uncomplicated, raisin, apple and allspice.  Strong finish yet very highly drinkable.  Outstanding.

Bottle. Moderate aromas of light bread and nutty for the malt, light notes of herbs and earth for the hops and yeast, and a background of toffee and a hint of alcohol. Head is small, fizzy, off-white, with good lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is a clear reddish brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and finishes moderately sweet and lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is light to medium, slightly creamy and has a lively carbonation. It finishes lightly alcoholic. An excellent beer to accompany a german game type dinner.

Sweet, heavy aroma of caramel and roasted malt.  Solid amber, clear pour.  Full mouth feel with a long finish.  Heavy malt taste with little hops.  Hints of grape and black pepper, and something bourbon-like, almost like it has been cask aged.  It is smooth and easy to drink.  Salvator, the Savior, is to have been the beverage that got monks and/or priests through Lent and periods of fasting because of it’s bread like filling effect (perhaps that was before Paulaner took over its brewing).  Now that I think about it - there is a certain rye bread quality to the taste.  One of my favorites.
Molasses and fruity sweetness with a subtle banana clove yeast smell.  Thick body, chewy, hearty, alcohol burn on the way down.  Finishes smooth and fades quickly.
Amber color with a nice looking head.  Smell is of the malts, caramel, and sweetness.  Not quite thick in the body but a little sticky.  Taste is sweet with some good malty flavors and caramel.

Bottle. Pours deep orange with a beige head. Sweet aroma with notes of toffee, caramel, apricot and alcohol. Medium body. Flavor is sweet woody and earthy, with notes of caramel, brown sugar and plum. Quite good.

This one comes with the weight of expectation--in my ten years of legality, I have somehow not imbibed this epitome of the genre...lighter brown orange effervescent body... white head is thin but bubbly and symmetrical...sweet, malty aroma with a lesser sense of soft hops... a soft palate with warming effects around the tongue--little fiz--surprisingly drinkable for a doppel... malt is pleasant, not intrusive; in fact, astonishingly tastes like a full-bodied, trumped-up lager... crisp and clean, with sugars appropriately placed... the name may precede itself, but the taste follows through--and I saved this bock sample for Good Friday... "liquid bread" indeed, and a little bit of soul food after a chocolate-free Lenten journey...
Amber with a white head. Sweet caramel flavor matches the sweet aroma, almost like a soda at first. Starts out much better than it finishes, but still a satisfying beer.

Re-rate 5/23/08. Pours a amber color with a decent off-white head that settles down to patches. Aroma is floral with a little perfume, light fruits, and some malt and molasses. Ditto on the flavor although it all seems too light. Finishes a little sour and bitter with the rest of the flavors rather bland. It’s okay but it all seems light and a little unbalanced.
Brown with a low head. The aroma is dominated by caramel and spice, while the flavours are intensily sweet, with malts, syrup, wood and alcohol as main notes.
bottle, gorgeous amber color with nice nut brown head, has a nutty malty body with a fruit finish that is very smooth,
Nice ruby-amber color and relatively light head of a tan tint. Strong fruitcake flavor and aroma from all that malt, with the slightest amount of hops on the finish.
Bottle from BottleTrek.com.  Pours a clear amber with a hint of red.  Aroma is sweet and the flavor is mainly bananas and caramel malt.  It is very rich in flavor. Not bad.
A Clear lightly beaded beer, Sweet Aroma, Slightly Astringent, I just don’t love this beer, I know alot of people who do but I’ve had better.

Pours a deep red/brown, with a dense head. Aroma is big malts with some alcohol undertones. Drinking it is like drinking a big malt ball thats been held together with alcohol and bananas. A very good beer in small amounts.
Pours a dark amber color, with an off-white head.  Flavor:  Slightly sweet, with a hint of caramel.
This is close to the definition of beer for me. A nice deep red and malty smell. A little sweet and a lingering but nice finish. Will definitely be picking this up again.

Pours clear amber with a small cream colored off white head.  Aroma is a nice strong caramel malt smell, very malty, very sweet.  Taste is also big caramel and dark malts with some sweetness of course too.  I really enjoyed this.

Clear Amber.Off white head,fleeting.Malty aroma,caramel apple.It has a pear apple kind of fruit juice sweetness to the flavor,some bitterness.Lighter in body than I expected.Nice balance,the alcohol is not very apparent in the flavor.Slightly bitter-dry finish.Pretty good.

0,33l bottle. Nice dark amber color. Malty and slightly smoky aroma. Malty sweetness in the flavor combined with the strength from the alcohol provides a round entity. Some hops. All in all a bit of a disappointment.

Bottle poured into my trusty stein- poured transparent dark amber, light carbonation, off white head formed and stayed awhile.  Aroma of malt and weak sweetness.
