Hits the mouth with a medium body, mild notes of sweetness throughout, has a small element that makes it stick to the sides of your mouth, finish is very slightly acidic.  Interesting take on the style.
pours clear copper, small head.  smell reminds me somewhat of apple juice.  thick and malty, not really any hops.  not very complex but it tastes pretty damn good :)

This was one of the most beautiful beers I’ve ever had the pleasure of viewing. It was a deep ruby red that almost seemed to have an light inner glow. 

The smell was nothing special, and in no way impressive. A light hint of hops to it, but otherwise unnotable.

Taste was slightly above average, hops dominating the mouth and little else making itself known.

Was a little bitter in the mouth, and I felt that it was slightly over carbonated.

I would not call this beer particularly drinkable, as I found myself really nursing this one.

All in all, not a bad beer; extremely appealing to the eye but not so much to the mouth.

Serving type: bottle

Clear amber with good, foamy beige head / Very sweet, malty nose / Medium body, a touch watery, with sweet, sticky body, minimal hops, and decent finish / Simple, sweet spun sugar flavor with a light citrus note / Fine, but rather one dimensional.
Good beer. head into clear amber body. decent lacing. aromas of sweet malts (mostly caramel) and light hops

Bottle.  Very clear amber pour with a decent head.  Sweet malty, caramel aroma.  Flavor starts pretty sweet and malty, then has a slightly bitter aftertaste.  Medium body, slightly carbonated mouthfeel.

Poured from a 0.5L bottle purchased locally. Deep amber, clear, off-white rocky head, has legs that coat the glass. Aroma is malty, a little sweet, and a little raisin fruity. Malty, rich, a little toasty. A slight raisin fruit flavor from the malt. Just bitter enough to cut the sweetness. Thick, full, but dries fairly well in the finish. The flavors linger, but not heavy.
Overall, a great example of a classic Doppelbock. I love how drinkable this beer is. It is very thick and rich, yet it dries out and is very smooth.

On draft, this was a bit of a learning experience.  I’d never thought of a doppelbock as a German barley wine, but that was the case here.  This might have been a little oxidized (sherry-like melanoidins), but it still came accross as a less fruity, less bitter barley wine.  Drier and a little less malty than what I’ve had in most other doppelbocks in the flavor and mouthfeel.  A nice beer and even nicer with some spatzle and gravy.

bottle.  small khaki colored fizzy (quickly and mostly dissapating) head into clear amber body.  decent lacing.  aromas of sweet malts (mostly caramel) and light hops (also some light spices present).  alcohol is also present.  flavor is sweet into bitter that last for approximatley 1 minute.  overall pretty good beer.

Bottle. Strong smell of malt and alcohol, very sweet and dark. The head is white and fizzy and disappears fast. Started a little bit sweet, then it gets bitter. Dry and a little bit oily, medium body, flat carbonation. Not as good as the Aventinus.

Not bad, but I think the board has overrated it a bit.

Pours a deep brown with a red tint, small off-white head.

Aroma is malty and sweet, with hints of apple and caramel or toffee.  The taste is much the same, though the fruitiness gets turned way up and the caramel fades.  Initial taste is pleasant, but the sweetness lingers and becomes almost overbearing.  Very malty, but no hoppiness is present at all.  Not a heavy finish, but not particularly clean, either....and the sweet stickiness lingers.

330ml. brwon bottle

bought at the SAQ for the rediculous price of 2,25$CAD

A: copper - amber colour, some head, 
S: a lot of malt, some hops, caramel
T: nice malt flavour, some spices, alcohol, 
M: roud, full body
D: some alcohol, nice winter sipping beer.

Flaske. Mørk ravfarvet tydeligt filtreret øl. Meget smuk. Sød duft af en lettere vinøs karakter. Klart bedst frisk hvor karboneringen og den meget diskrete humle giver modspil til den kraftige sødme, ellers er der en lille tendens til for meget sødme over i den kvalmende afdeling. Men ikke i aften.

Brown pour..translucent with a slight reddish tint.  Malt sweetness in the nose....taste is quite the same.  Fruity...like raisins with maybe a tinge of caramel-malt in the flavor.  Meh....not bad but not anywhere near the quality of Celebrator or the Detonator.  You don’t have to put this one on your "must have" list.
Bottle. Pours deep ruby brown with thin creamy tan head. Nice carmel aroma, nice body, no taste of alcohol. A fine bock.
12 oz bottle  deep amber pour , decent white head . sweet caramel and fruit nose.  very sweet on the palate, like a caramel candied apple .smooth ,medium bodied and finishes suprisingly dry .

Re-rate from Bottle. Faint caramel apple aroma. Clear medium brown, with small tan head that disappeared quickly. Tasty sweet & sour caramel malt. Too sweet.
Had on tap at Beer Bistro in Toronto and wow, what a difference. Aroma, Taste, Flavour way more intense than my bottle rating. Much maltier, caramel, apple. Great doppelbock if you can get it on tap.

12oz. bottle into a mug.  Poured a nice amber color with a nice white head.  It smelled of sticky caramel and sweet malts (smells almost like apple juice).  The palate was very average and unexciting.  The taste was unique and very sweet, almost candy-like.  Lots of malt, no hint of hops, tastes very much like alcohol flavored apple juice.  The sweetness was overboard and unbearable to me (almost like a Smirnoff ice of something where the company adds so much sugar that you can;t taste the alcohol).  The flavor points are purely for uniqueness, because I have never really tasted a beer like this, but I had to force it all down.  The sweetness was nauseating.
Sweet and strong malty aroma. Light amber color with a small tan head. Sweet beginning with a tangy middle and finish. Light body.
Pours brownish-copper color with a small energetic head.  Tastes of roasted malt with caramel, cinnamon, honey, and complexity.  Nice occasional beer.
Eccellente Doppelbock. Riesce a essere dissetante e gustosa allo stesso tempo. Meglio degustata in Stein o bicchieri simili.
Bottle. Thanks to a buddy. Poured a very maroon color. Aroma is malty maple. Taste is sweet with a malty finish.

The pour is medium brown, with small white head.  The nose is yeast, malt, with hints of floral yeast and honey.  The flavor is complex yet smooth while following some scents of the nose.  A well rounded brew.
pours medium brown with reddish hue smells of roasted malts taste of  choclate and cinnamon this is one of my favorites in this style had better but very good

bottle brewed nov/07... pours a rich amber shade with an off white head. this smells like cooked grains, bread, molasses, light fruitiness, earth and some how dry. the palate is not too sweet. it’s combined with flavors of grain, raisins, caramel, cinnamon/spiciness and a fruity banana like yeastiness. skunky finish and aftertaste. medium body. creamy carbonation leads to a soft mouth feel.

At the trinkgut in kleve germany, dark amber colour, thin head, my bottle says 7,9 % alc, very overwalming one like those bad supermarkt  Malt Liquer’s , can’t vind any character in it, maybe i wil gife it a re-rate next time
Tasted 2008-02-24. Fresh bottle. Pours clear, dark amber with off-white head. Aroma: Fruity, nutty, malt, sweet. Flavour: Fruity, slightly bitter, a little sweet. Medium body. Fine beer!

Poured from a dark brown 0.5 liter bottle with a best by date of 12/08 (L361740), and rated at 7.0% ABV. Poured a dark amber with a very short-lived head. Had a sweet malty aroma with maybe a trace of molasses. The flavor was sweet and malty with a light hint of caramel, but well balanced by hop bitterness and the warmth of alcohol. Though Spring is nearly over, this has become my favorite bier in Germany, at least when it’s below 50 outside! I’m focused on developing a recipe for this one so I can clone this one when I return to the states.

Pours copper/red with a frothy white head that disappears quickly.  Aroma of toffee and caramel.  Taste of roasted malts with a finish of cherries and light hops.  Full mouth feel.  Very nice Dopplebock.

Bottle.  Recommended by BevMo employee when I complained that they were out of Celebrator.  Poured a dark ruby brown color, with a light white head that quickly left.  Nose of malt, maybe lightly roasted.  Tastes pretty good, lighter that I would like, with a medium body.  Finishes well, but leaves me desiring more.
Pours red/brown weak head good carbonation,aroma spicey malt,flavour bitter tender roasted malt flavour,coffee,chocolate,tang on the tongue that is bitter,finish bitter malty goes down very nicely.

Bottled 50cl. 7.9 ABV. It pours a deep amber beer with a dissapearing white head. The nose is of berries, eucalyptus, smoke, caramel, carrots, syrup and wood. Very well balanced and rather strong. The taste is syrupy with hints of caramel, candy, smoke and hop. Good balance. Some figs. Lots of alcohol before the finish which is of caramel. Hints of marmite, grass and aniseed. Rerate: Interesting stuff I wrote back then :-) I enjoy this beer more lately. Very pleasant. Staying with the initial rating.

A nagyböjt idejére főzték a Pálos szerzetesek a malátában gazdag dupla bakot hogy átvészeljék ezt az ínséges időszakot.Borostyán színű,kemény habú alkoholban erős lager ez.Fűszeres,gyümölcsös,karamellás ital,aminek az utóízében ott akellemes száraz kesernyésség.Alapmű!

this beer was  once one of the best dopplbocks on the market. For some reason the turned it into a weak crappy bock and now call it a double bock. The color is wrong for a dopplbock, the alcohol content is too low and it tastes like a Lienenkugel’s Big But.
Bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville.  Pours a reddish copper with small but persistent head. Aroma of caramel and a little hoppiness. Texture is thin. Taste is caramel and sour cherry.

bottle same as image.  Fruit nose: apple and faint citrus, caramel and slight alc mouth (not a fan of this), little hoppy.  While its got a good deal going on, all in all its a bit forgettable.  Extra .1 overall for alc content.

Draught. Beautiful oak-amber color with absolutely no head. Aromas of copper, caramel, wood, and citrus. First sip brings caramel and oak with a smoothness that demands a second. Cherries in the aftertaste that define the second sip and a mellow hop finishes it all off. Thick and chewy palate. Complete, balanced, wonderful.

12oz bottle - clear medium amber color with small quickly dissapearing off white head. Aroma is full of light cherry, toasted malt, light caramel and vanilla, hint of lemon, slight roastyness. Flavor has fair amount of chewy malts, light caramel, subtle but notable alcohol presence, with a level of bitterness that is somewhat surpirsing considering the sweetness of the aroma and flavor.

Draught: Copper liquorish and citrus aroma.
Amber Brown no head. Great appearance. 
Black Cherry flavor fallowed by grain and alcohol aroma. Rough Palate: It’s biting from the tip of my tongue to the back of my throat. But a very well balanced beer.

Any time I can get my hands on something referred to as "liquid bread", with a ABV of 7.90%, I’m going to be happy... 

This dopplebock poured into my large tulip glass with a rich amber color. The glass I used allowed for a great, light tan, rich foamy head. It stayed around for enough time to really aid the great nose of malt and lingering streaks of toffee. Had a wonderful heavy malt taste, with slight bits of toffee, and fresh wheat bread with honey. This beer, for being so substantial, really had a very drinkable, medium bodied mouth feel. This beer is pairing great with my aged white cheddar, but don’t rule out the schnitzel. Never rule out the schnitzel. I’ll leave the fasting to the Monks...Enjoy

This double bock is a medium body, slick feel, soft carbonation, clear and red. This beer has little to no Aroma which was a little disappointing, but overall an excellent Double from Germany since 1634.
Deep brown with a nice but disappearing head. Sweet malty, fruity, somewhat earthy or floral. Quite cloying in the end.
Amber color.  a good dopplebock!  malt flavor little bit of a lingering aftertaste.  Dopplebocks are fantastic and this is a good beer!

Dark amber with a very short lived head. Sweet malty aroma with a trace of molasses. The flavour is also sweet and malty with a light note of caramel, this sweetness is quickly balanced by a decent hop bitterness and a good deal of alcohol. Medium to full bodied.

Pours a rich caramel, with a light-caramel tinted creamy head.  Aroma of fruity, caramelized malts and nailpolish.  Rich sweet malt flavor, alcohol burns a little, really poorly presented.  Odd bitter aftertaste.  I dont know if I’d call this superbly balanced.  Who am I to argue with "world-renowned" though...

Poured amber with a creamy head.  Nose of sweet malts and caramel.  Taste is very malty and sweet.  Didn’t realize this beer was 7.5% when drinking, very easy drinker.  Medium bodied with plent of carbonation.  Not my favorite style, but pretty good.

12oz. Bottle:  Sweet aroma.  Smells very malty with hints of oak and caramel.  Poured amber in color with a medium-sized, dense, creamy, tan head that lasted throughout.  Flavor is sweet and malty.  Tastes of malts, caramel, wood, and more malts.  Medium body.  Slick texture.  Soft carbonation.  Malt finish.  Overall, way too malty, and not "superbly balanced."

Poured brown amber with a slight head that disipated quickly.  Smelled maple, malt a twinge of alchohol.  Taste maple brown sugar and caramel... slight alchohol taste.  I enjoy it and would get it again.

Dark amber pour with a thin white head. Molasses, caramel malt aroma. Thick body. Taste is very heavy on the malt, especially the caramel, with a big alcohol hit. I find it a pretty easy drinking double bock, if there can be one. Be careful of the alcohol, though.
Beautifully balanced beer.  Reddish hues with a deep dark balanced alcoholic structure which keeps on giving.  Powerful grip.  Excellent.
Thick body with fruit and slight wine like aroma.  Alcohol taste is evident but not distasteful.  I’d buy this beer again but wouldn’t go out of my way to do so.

12oz bottle (thanks Thermo1223)- pours a nice amber color with a quickly disappearing head. Very clear looking brew. Tastes of honey and caramel noted with the alcohol well hidden at 7.9%. Fairly rich taste and heavy but enjoyable and easy to drink. My first Paulaner Doppelbock  and a very good one.

16.9 oz bottle-A medium amber body with a small ring for a head and an aroma of roasted malt and caramel. Taste of the same with a faint alcohol taste. Not bad but I don’t think as well overall as Korbinian .

Smells a little earthy and sweet with some caramel malt stuff.  Clear reddish brown with a small tan head. Tastes bocky with some honey sweetness and non obtrusive alcohol.  Alcohol is well hidden, the bottle says 7.9%.

Bottle - Pours a deep amber/coppery.  Aroma is sweet malt, alcohol and dried apricots.  Flavor is similar all sweet malt up front, a bit bitterness with some dried fruity notes, hint of sulfur and a tinge of alcohol on the finish.
Pours a deep copper red like little mermaid’s hair. YUM taste, smell, feel. Really good doppel bock! On tap at the Ginger Man. YUM.

Pours a copper color with a small white head.  Aroma is of alcohol and caramel.  The flavor is sweet malt... caramel.

12 oz. bottle.
Pours auburn. No head. Dried fruit aroma. A touch of chocolate. Flavor is very similar. Very fruity. Sweet with a touch of bitteness. Pleasantly warming. Good stuff.
Very good aroma. Impressed by the sweetish almost deep taste. I enjoyed this one a lot. Would buy again
Had a sweet smell and poured a dark amber with many aromas.  It was a heavy drink I though but was very satisfying.
Sweet, malty and with a great aftertaste. This is the original doppelbock and one of the best I’ve ever had.
Smelled very sweet and malty.  Poured a dark amber with very little head to speak of.  It tasted just like it smelled with an alcohol finish, and had no real body to it.
Poured to an off white thin head, amber colored. Aroma of yeast. Initial taste of sweet and yeasty. Not much body. Alcoholic finish.  Good tasting beer.

My favorite German brewer here.  

Pours dark amber color.  Not as dark as the Celebrator but still a nice color.  No head to speak of.  

Smells very malty and sweet, just like a doppelbock should.  

Very rich malty taste with a hint of sweetness and a trace of alcohol as well.  

Very good example of the doppelbock style.  I don’t think its as good as the Celebrator but there aren’t many beers that are.  Probably my second favorite doppelbock.
Bottle-Good solid beer, full amber color with a small head.  The aroma was malty with caramel.  The taste followed in the same manner with some sweetness bordering the malts.  Produce place 1.79
Sweet, heavy malt - very hefty drink. Myriad of flavors and aromas. Warning; do not pair with smoked salmon dip. Bad times.

Pours a clearish light brown color with a an airy off-white head. Smells of sweet brown sugar and malt. To me this brew always tastes of sweet potatoes and brown sugar. Malt as well.
Thinnish with just ok carbonation. Great brew if you’re in the mood for a sweet, brown German brew.
Bottle. Pours a orange/red/amber colour. Aroma of malt, hints of fruit and berries. Strong but simple flavour, sweet.

Best beer I had so far in my life. Incredibly rich and full flavor, of course malty and sugary-sweet. Beautiful dark reddish color. I was utterly amazed how easy it was to drink this beer, no trace of the high alcohol content, just pure taste.

Bottle. Orange/red color with almost no head. Nice aroma of dates, sugar, and bread. Flavor mixes fruits and dark malts with little alcoholic burn. Not overwhelming, but a really nicely balanced brew.

Pours a dark copper color with virtually no head and no lacing, color was pretty nice though. Smell is pretty nice, strong smell of burnt caramel, molasses, and some dark fruit. Much of the same in the taste but with a pretty strong alcohol presence. Taste would be higher with less alcohol apparent. Very sweet, but a small, but seemingly correct amount of hops come through in the taste. Low carbonation, full body. A little too much alcohol warmth to have a lot of this, but it is still very tasty.
Interesting Dopplebock. Generally mild flavor, smooth and full feel on the mouth, and nice malt (bready) flavor. Slightly sweet, with a little sugar.
Moderate bitterness in initial flavor, finishes sweetly/smoothly. Has a great caramel, bread aroma. Excellent dopplebock.
Wow, what a beer. The bottle looks great and the beer is the same. tastes fine sweet-malty, very balanced and long finish. Incredible good!

Can I blame my behaviour on this drink? Wasn’t that strong but that’s my fault for being on a works do, getting home after daft amounts of cheap rubbish and trying to rate it. It does taste strong which isn’t a good thing for me right now. Bit sweet, not that impressed but do not want to give the impression I don’t like it. Not educated enough to put my finger on why it’s a bit...I don’t know.. Smells great, a real lung full like my dinner this evening. Hmm average? I’ll try it again.
Filtered redish brown beer, not much head, lots of caramel aroma, very malty, sweet, but balanced. A very good bockbier

0.33l bottle. Pours a clear golden brown with absolutely no head. Lots of carbonation. Smells very strong, mostly of malt. Palate is very smooth. Tastes strongly of malt and alcohol with hint of caramel. Taste becomes quite sweet with a hint of fruit.

bottle. pours clear ruby with thin white head around the rim but that didn’t last 5minutes. the aroma is syrupy cotton candy sweet, with lots of molasses. flavor is sweet, syrupy, molasses and toffee. slightly toasted and nutty. body is really thin and the carbonation is fizzy. pretty sweet, straight forward beer with a bad mouth feel. i expected more because this is barely drinkable.

Pretty tastey....nice use of what appears to me crystal malt and roasted malts. Terrific use of flavor and aroma hops. Rich tan head with good retention. Feels great on the pallat and on the nose. Nice relaxing beer for speacial occasions. Would purchase again.
Bottle, Amber color with tan head. Aroma and flavor very sweet of caramel and nuts and little roasty. Medium carbonation and a bit alcohol finish with sweetness.

Poured from a 12oz bottle and served in a Bell’s dimpled mug.  This dopplebock poured a clear, caramel color with a ton of carbonation dancing inside the glass.  A one-finger thick head of beige foam lasted throughout.  A touch of slippery lace was left behind.  The aroma of the beer consisted of lightly roasted caramel malts, bread, and nuts.  The flavor was made up of caramel, vanilla, sweet ripe fruits, and a mild noble hop note.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied with a good dose of aggressive carbonation.  A straightforward beer.  Very well crafted and to the point.

Pours a nice copper color with a lot of foam that quickly settles down and stablizes to 1 inch that lasts a while. The brew smells great like its been brewed very slowly, LOL. The taste is sweet and bland malty. The finish is very clean.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Boca Raton, FL for $1.79 Very good!
Bottle: Poured a tea brown color with a off white creamy head. Aroma is fruit with sweetness. The tatse is fruit with a rich malty finish.
Bottle. Amber colour with a off-white head. Aroma and flavour of fruit, caramel, hops and malt.

0,33l. Beige head, diminishes fast.Orange-to red colour. Very sweet aroma: bananas, apricot, vanilla. Flavour is also sweet, little bit bitter on the end. Raisins and banana. Little bit mouldy flavour.

12 oz. bottle pours a clear ruby color with a tan head. Sweet cinnamon roll smell. Lightly carbonated with a rich, creamy mouthfeel. Mildly sweet taste of milk chocolate, molasses, spices. Finishes with a spicy alcohol tang. 
This brew smells way better than it tastes.
jan 2001

500ml. red/amber color pours with a brief sandy head. loads of malty sweetness and caramel with a hint of musty hops. clean and malty. brown sugar, earth and a touch of toast that appears just before the finish. noble hops come through to make the finish crisp. very different from most other dopples i’ve tried. it’s the closest to a regular bock. just beefed up. not my favorite but still good.
Pours a light brown with a thin bubbly head that fades quickly. Aroma is of malt. Taste of carmel a little roasty. very smooth, nice. A little too much carbination. Finishes well.

330 mL bottle purchased from LCBO in Toronto.  Pours a clear reddish gold with a decent but quickly diminishing head.  Strong aroma of malt and alcohol.  First taste is sweet and powerful.  The alcohol feels noticeable through the sweetness.  I can’t say I drink many doppelbocks, so I suppose my review will end up being more of the style in general than of the specific nuances of this beer witihin its style.  Too sweet for these tastebuds.

Clear bronze appearance with a medium size  off white head and good lacing.  Aroma is sweet caramel malt and red licorice with a hint of soy sauce.  Earthy, fruity taste, some molassas, slightly nutty, modestly hopped.  Full bodied with moderate carbonation.  Finishes with a lingering sweetness.

Bottle from GM liquors, Bakersfield; Produced 06/06; Nose of fruity malt, roastiness, and light vanilla; hazy rust clor with a small beige head; flavor is alcohol, (not well covered), raisins, toffee, a little sweetness, and caramel. Pretty good, but I think overhyped!

Had this beer on 5/5/1999.  Color is a bright amber with good carbonation and light head.  Aroma is a heavy sweet malt scent.  Taste is sweet and strong.  It starts with a full medium body that goes down with a sweet malty feel.  This malt flavor gets strong as the finish comes on with a sharp feel and a medium bitterness.  Very tastey brew.

Rerating. Pours copper with small head that dissipates quickly.  Scent of pumpernickel & molasses. Low carbonation, medium thickness in mouth .  Flavor starts smoky & sweet roasted malts.  Ends with a bittersweet chocolate roar which resounds for quite a long time.

Bottled. Nice caramel brown color into my glass, small head that faded quickly. Flavor has a definite caramel and oat like malty vibe. Very nice! (in my best Borat voice). A really good beer even though its not my primary style.

This is the most beautiful DB I’ve seen, having more of an amber copper hue than the usual deep brown. The oatmeal colored head disipates quickly. The nose is typical DB, with malt, smoke, and soy. The flavor is subtle and smooth, sweet from malt, very little trace of the soy, and a dry, smokey finish. Not my favorite style of beer, but in that catagory, one of the best I’ve had.

wow! pours a huge overflowing three finger, stiff, fluffy, light tan head. aroma is lightly toasted sweet caramel malt, toffee, and a touch of black licorice. has a medium body with good lacing and just the right amount of carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma. it is sticky on the hands and lips, and is probably one of the better bock beers i have had to date. very nice, surprising, well done paulaner! as it warms there is a little alcohol aroma and flavor. i guess you could say there is a little raisin in the aroma and flavor as well.

This beer seems to have gotten lighter over the years at the same time, I think it’s become more of a session beer at the expense of character. Has good malt and some roastiness with a bit of hop. Superb body and finish. Perhaps a bit hard on the carbonation.Great beer! This one is a draft at Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse, WI. They have bottles too.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear copper color with minimal head.  Aroma is sweet malt, bready with raison.  Taste is sweet bread with raison; malty with little hops.  My taste preferences must be changing because I used to like this beer more when I was first getting into craft beers.
A good beer with a strong caramel character which gives it a unique taste - kind of like a blend between an Octoberfest and a dopplebock. Better than Ayinger’s dopple, but far behind Spaten’s

330 ml bottle from LCBO, served cool in a tulip glass.



App.:  Reddish-orange copper, clear, small light tan head.
  
Aroma:  Massive amounts of brown/burnt sugar, molasses, toffee, figs, dates, raisins and anything else dark and sweet; some wood, some herbal notes.
  
Palate:  Medium-full body, soft carbonation with some effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Tons more of the sweet, syrupy malts and associated dark and sweet flavours, more herbal than the nose, a touch of wood, a touch of alcohol, a touch of esters; on swallowing, it is a bit sweet, but not cloying, more alcohol shows, lingering burnt sugar/molasses.



Huge and malty – a great sipper.

Pours a hazy golden brown with minimal head, though thin layer of foam does hang around a while.  Nose is strong and sweet, with brown sugar and pitted fruit (date, raisin, fig) notes.  Bready and nutty flavor; aroma components more subtle than expected on palate.  Mildly bitter and barely astringent finish.  A touch of alcohol fire to warm the belly.  Very nice, although a tad cloying.
Very tasty brew! Very smooth going down. Very quaffable. Sweet tasting and not very hoppy. A long lingering aftertaste that’s very pleasant. I wish i bought more than one bottle.
Dark amber color.  Sweet bread and dark candy smells and flavors.  Some molasses and dark fruits as well.

old rating:
6/3/7/3/14 - 3.3 ( 12/24/2007 )

pours a semi-cloudy orange-brown with a medium size beige head, and a little lacing.

smell is of sweet malt, caramel, some roasted nuts, and hops way in the back.

taste is of caramel, malt, a roastiness comes through, grain, and a little sweet, ends nicely thick.

Figured it was about time for me to rate this.  Poured crystal-clear coppery orange with about 3/4" of creamy beige head sticking around.  The aroma picked up sweet, toasty caramels, floral notes, and lighter herbs.. sweet overall and quite enticing.  The flavor was definitely on the sweet side with toasty caramel, molasses, and brown sugar representin’.. bitterness was light and complimentary.  Medium-bodied and syrupy on the front of the palate with moderate carbonation pushing it nicely across the palate.. smooth with a shorter, but enjoyable finish.

Sampled @ GDBTF.  Pours a lovely garnet red with very little head.  Rather strong toffee, caramel on the nose. Rich on the palate, crisp malt sweetness. Hops are minimal until the finish, slightly woody but well complementing the malts. Pretty good doppelbock.

500 ml bottle dated 11/06, so this one has been around. Pours a gorgeous, crystal clear red-brown. Decent tannish head. Aroma is of caramel maltiness. Very nice full body with small-bubble carbination. Taste is malty, some caramel and perhaps molasses, but its leavened by the hops which keep it from being too sweet. The back end has a shot of alcohol too it.
This was a slightly red beer that had a fairly decent flavor.  A little sweet, but also hoppy.
Pours a dark brown with a light tan head.  Smells of raisins, pepper, some licorice.  Tastes of caramel, some chocolate, dark fruit, some pepper, some banana like hints.

12 oz bottle from The Rock...Amber colored with a quickly disappearing head. Aroma of caramel and toasted malts, slightly hoppy. Flavor is the same, caramel malts with a slight hop backbone. Alcohol presents itself as it warms, but not in an unpleasant way. Well carbonated and not too thick on the tongue. Not as complex as a I was expecting (first dopplebock I have tried) but very good overall.

12oz. bottle while in Munich for Oktoberfest. Pours deep red with a super thin white head. Aromas of malt and caramel as well. Flavors of sweet caramel with a sharp alcohol finish. Very smooth, full mouthfeel. Very good brew.

Bottle bought at the Oktoberfest in Munchen. Oaky brow with some head. Sour nose. Oaky, sweet like toffee and caramel. And then gets a bit sour at the end. Superb lacing. Alcohol taste a bit too strong though.
I’d expected more from this double bock. The color is nice amber but with very little form. The palate is thin and the taste rather sweet, with the alcohol coming through.
nice amber color on the pour with no head. it looked mighty tasty although in the bar i couldn’t smell it at all.  very hoppy taste in my opinion that i didn’t really care for at all.

I’ve had this one many times, so I thought I should finally rate it. It may be the first authentic doppel bock, but nowhere near the best out there. Pours a nice amber colour with almost zero head. Has a sweet molassas, carmel smell that comes through on the taste. Body is thick, and alcoholic strength is evident. Way too sweet for me overall, but an interesting beer.

Pours beautiful amber red. Little head, giving the carbonation it has.

Sweet molasses, and caramel smell. 

Tastes like a carmel candy bar. Very sweet. Maybe the sweetest dopple I have yet to have. 

Finishes with a hit of liquor.

Not something I would like to have more than one of, at a sitting, but, a very good--but different dopple.

EDIT: just noticed the "produced date" is 11/06. A year old beer.

0.33 l bottle, 7.9 %. Dark amber color with diminishing head. Very malty, caramelly, toffeish and berryish aroma with hints of alcohol. Rich sweet and malty flavor with caramel, warming alcohols and berries. Chewy mouthfeel. Nice and complex warming alcohol note.

i must have had a bottle that went terribly bad. Tasted in Oct. 07, probably meant for Winter of 06, there was not much i enjoyed about this beer. I will try to re-rate next winter. But i don’t think i’ll ever enjoy this better than the great Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock

One of my all time faves, the standard by which all double bocks are judged.

Malty candy like citrusy aroma. Amber color with minimal head. Taste is intense bready maltiness with hints of toffee. Palate is chewy and complex.  Finish is incredibly smooth hoppiness.
I like the body and flavor of this beer. I have been wanting to try this beer for months and finally found it and have not been let down. A very great tasting beer

Unbelievable I have not rated this beer.  Aroma is bready malty with plent of molasses and dark fruit.  Flavor is also bready and lots of toffee.  Alcohol does make an appearance but nothing to over the top.  A solid dopple and something every beer drinker should have at least once.
Pours Ruby Copper with an offwhite head. Aroma is nothing to brag of, but this doppelbock has a sweet malty flavor with a nice balanced palate.
Poured a deep amber, with a small head,and  a real nice fruity aroma. It has a nice bite of alcohol and surprisingly smooth palate. I actually enjoyed this while eating supper. Very good Beer!

bottle -   tried this two years ago and was disappointed.   revisited and clearly the problem was me.  this beer is very nice.  pours a nice copper colour with a just off white head.  I believe the aroma makes this beer - very sweet/floral with alcohol.  nice body thats not too carbonated.  excellent after dinner beer.

0.33 l bottle brought from B&H. 7.9% ABV. Poured great clear deep reddish brown colored body with small brownish head. Aroma of some sweet caramel and alcoholic. Alcohol is felt a lot in the flavor, too. It is sweet and dry. It is not too complex, with maybe just some hints of some fruitiness inside. Finish dry again, sweetish. Good beer for colder parts of the year maybe now the heat ruined it a bit but I’ve expected more from this one...
From a bottle pours dark amber with a fair amount of head.  Big flavor with citrusy malty flavors coming through.

Rust colored with medium to weak head.    Nose a good mix of floral hops, fresh grain and the whiff of yeast from opening a bag of bread.  Fruit flavors predominate, from citrus to summer fruit to a candy apple finish.  Palate full with some fizz, but a unpleasant caramel feel.  This beer is complex with much character, but a bit sweeter than I like.

Pours a deep amber color with very little head and no lacing. Low carbo. The aroma was sweet with possibly a hint of apples. The taste was also sweet with almost an apple cider like taste to it.  This was an easy drinking beer, but maybe after the the two stronger beers had that night it was too subtle, or my senses were starting to degrade a bit... I will try this again to get a better feel for it, but it was very drinkable.
I am not a fan of double bocks at all but I was very impressed by this beer. This is an exception. It is a very sweet and crisp flavor.

This Doublebock was awesome.  At first I was hesitant because I had the Samuel Adams Doublebock and, even though I am a Samuel Adams fan, I didn’t like it.  My only problem was that we wanted a glass to drink it out of but the bartender didn’t hear us so I drank it from the bottle.

Bottle conditioned and courtesy of the LCBO. Poured a wonderful mahogany, with high levels of carbonation and a steady stream of bubbles breaking the surface. A sweet malty aroma with a metallic edge. The flavour was sweet and bready. My first dopplebock...and not my last!

Pours a deep amber color into the dimpled mug.  There was an inch of creamy head and a small amount of lacing.  The scent was of cloves, spice, malt and fruit.  The taste was syrupy sweet with some hints of fruit, cherries, malt and hints of bready notes.  A solid doppelbock.
copper brown tan cap of head dark malt nose odd fruit in there too, kinda bready flavor with again a slight sweet fruit flavor, good beer
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.

Bottle, from the Dodgy Deli on Cowley Road in Oxford. Red brown, smallish tan cap of foam. Dark caramel malt aroma, along with a healthy dose of cherry flavor. Not actual cherries, more like the cherry syrup that goes on ice cream. Not a bad thing as all. Sweet, plummy malt, a bit of dark bread. Lingering chewy sweetness. Medium bodied--to my taste feels like it would be more satisfying a little thicker. Overall, a very nice drop.
Bold red colour. Strong aroma of malt and caramel. Flavour consists mainly of malt sweetness. Texture is rich and smooth.

Bottle sampled. Pours a dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of caramel, molasses, dark fruits, and toasted malts. Flavor is moderately sweet and full bodied with toffee, caramel, brown sugar, and a hint of raisins with a clean and crisp finish
Excellent.  The first doppelbock I ever drank several years ago, and one I return to often.  Great appearance, and flavor -- the molasses in the aroma transfers over to the flavor.

[i] Bottle, poured picked up from the Dodgi’ Deli, Cowley Road, and supped whilst steering a narrowboat on a merry course down the Thames 15-09-07 [/i]  Dark amber in colour, nice chocolate and coffee on the nose, these aromas unsuprisingly appeared in the taste which was really glorious, bit sweet but there was bitterness as well and other flavours zipping around molassess, nuts to name but two, wish I’d have had another couple of these!

I agree with everything that matt (below me) has stated.  I love the malty aromas, with a bit of caramel as well.  The color was very pleasing to the eye.  For this type of beer, I thoroughly enjoyed it.

330 ml bottle. poured red/amber/copper with one finger of tan head. great roasty malt aromas; caramel, and candy. also some lingering bitterness. flavours are candy sweetness followed by a great bitter finish. very well balanced with perfect carbonatiion. this one surprised me, i wasnt expecting it to be this good.

Poured a clear, bright red, with a tan head that vanished quickly.

The aroma was red candy licorice, alcoholic notes, molasses, and grain.

The mouthfeel was a bit too watery and much lower carbonation than the usual.

The taste is red licorice (which I feel is the combination of the malt and grain flavours combining with some cranberry esters).  The beer was slightly warming, but not noticeably high alcohol.

An enjoyable beer, but one best served late at night to enjoy alone.

Bottle, 50 cl. Thx to Leen.
Red amber color, with a off white head. Armoa a bit sweet caramel and malts. Medium body. Taste caramel, biter hops, malts. 
Not so great beer.
a good full flavored beer with a nice aroma. very little head. a nice Dopplebock

Bottle.  Poured a nice dark golden-brown with a small head.  VERY malty aroma that smelled like caramel, molasses, and a hint of coffee.  The taste was also intensely malty.  It was a smooth palate though and the sweet flavor was not saccharine.  A pretty good doppelbock when looking for something malty.

Draft, Edelweiss Restaurant, Staunton VA. Bright, reddish brown with offwhite head. Aromas of brown sugar, nuts, caramel, and some light fruit. Flavor is balanced between sweet and bitter, with notes of fruity apple, raisin/grape, toasty caramel malt, and a clean finish. Really tasty stuff.

Nice carbonation. Elements of molasses, caramel and syrup, hints of dried apple and  oak. Goes well with the winter season.
Old Stein Inn, MD

Bottle. Pours a deep brown wtih disapearing tan head. Aroma is malty sweet with notes of molasses. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately bitter, with notes of brown sugar, alcohol, and a light woodiness. Roastiness is present throughout. Full in body with medium carbonation. Finish is lightly bitter and a little too sticky sweet.

500 ml bottle from Bevmo. Pours a translucent mahogany red-brown with a small off white head that quickly fades to nothing. Armoa is light with sweet caramel and biscuits. Flavor is complex without being overbearing--I note anise, caramel, burnt toast, biter hops, almonds and a touch of butter. Mouthfeel  is undercarbonated and syrupy. Finish is long, slightly biter and sweet with caramel. Overall this is an interesting offering, I could see myself ordering up a dozen or so of these at Oktoberfest in munchen.

Bottle. A delicious world-class doppelbock with a smooth mouthfeel, carmelized apple aroma, and sublime lingering aftertaste. Those who donï¿½t appreciate the style wonï¿½t appreciate the beer; those who do most certainly will even if the socks don’t get knocked off.  Amber, clear, lighter than expected with a slim tight head. Yeasty thick rich cakey aroma. Smooth velvet palate makes it dangerously drinkable. Smooth boozy finish has rich, strong rum cake with some cherries.

This beer confused me. It poured far lighter and had far less rich sweetness and fruitiness of any dopplebock I’ve ever had. It certainly is worlds different from Celebrator or Maximator or even Optimator. This tastes and looks more like a regular bock than a dopple. As a bock, I’d give it high marks, but it gets bumped down some for just not living up to the style. I find it hard to believe this is #6 in style. Anyway, the beer poured a golden brown with a slight amber hue, crystal clear with moderate amounts of head. The beer smells like a bock and tastes like a bock. This beer could use a bit more carbonation, a bit more hops and a bit more depth...a bit more of everything. It’s good, but nothing to rush out and buy again.

Mahogany with a nice head. The aroma has notes of malt and hops. The mouthfeel is smooth. The initial impressions in the flavour are sweet and malty with notes of dark fruit, but then comes a nice bitterness along as a good counterweight. It’s a smooth and nice doppel-bock, and my husband is very fond of it.
Extra heavy malt, a bit too sweet - only one of these at a time.  Pleasant but a bit too much.  Nice on a cold night, but only as a single.

Re-rate 8/22/10: Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks Oren. Clear amber. Malty alcoholic nose with caramel and a bit of fruits. Sweet malty flavor. Silky mouthfeel. 7/3/7/4/14=3.5



Draught at Paulaner im Roten Ochsen in Cologne. Amber beer with a slow-diminishing beige head. Malty aroma with some caramel. Flavor is sweet with firm maltiness and caramel. Medium to full body and a somewhat syrupy mouthfeel. Very nice beer. 7/3/8/4/15=3.7

Date: 09/08/1996

Mode: Bottle

Source: Chevy Chase, DC



dark redish amber, whispy head and a touch of lace, strong malty aroma with slight floral hop accents, heavy body starting with strong malt flavor followed by earthy hops and then a powerful esterly character, dry malt finish

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: 05/15/2002



sweet carmel aroma, rich malt flavor, not the hop character seen before

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: 12/01/2004



sweet toasted malt aroma, light malt flavor with a nice touch of hops, light bitter finish, 



Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20

Rating: 2.8/5.0
Score: **/4

The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

This beer has less flavor than the other doppelbocks I have tried, but it is well balanced.  It is very smooth and dangerously drinkable, and I would really like to try it on tap. I put this one about even with the Optimator, but a peg below the Celebrator or Aventinus.
carmel, malt, chocolate, wheat, lemon, ginger, and clove.  very rich carmel color with thick creamy beige head.  touch of butterscotch and bourbon.
Nice sweet malty aroma, nice copper colour.  Bit of a hoppy finish, but more malty overall and some mild spice.  A decent Doppelbock.

[i]Bottle from Toom Getränkemarkt in Kasierslautern, Germany[/i]. Clear copper red with a small creamy beige head. Roasted, nutty and toffeish malt aroma, a slight alcoholic touch. Very smooth and creamy with light carbonation. Very well balanced with a long moderately bitter finish. Good but not in the same range as Andechser Doppelbock.

.5 L Bottle:  Consumed from Stein.  Pours a deep amber with a large bubble head that settles fast.  Sweet consuming aroma of hot wort.  I mean sweet like the ass of a homecoming queen /cheerleader.  Maolt overpowers the hops but hops are there for the enjoymnent of those who appreciate them.  Brown sugary body that quits and let s som spice end it with the hops.  Nice.

Pours a dark amber and has the aroma of malt, alcohol and perhaps some fruit. A great smooth taste of sweet malt with a little bit of bitterness, and a nice alcohol bite. Quite well balanced and well done.
sweet smell and start. hopsy notes. mid is malty as the end. a typical doppelbock. not enthusiasting but very drinkable.
Has typical tastes of nuts, spices, lots of alcohol. Finished smooth though.

Pours a deep copper/brown with a dense, fluffy head and a delicious aroma of caramel and malt.  Tastes slightly bitter at first with a caramel and toffee taste, finishing with a balanced malty aftertaste.  Prost!
If you are into really strong beer with a great dark and rich taste, this is what you want. Coming again soon to a Rodney near you.

12 ounce bottle from a six pack I bought.  Amber with a small off-white head that doesn’t last long.  Smell is caramel malt and notes of fruit and toasted malt.  Taste is sweet, but not too sweet - caramel and brown sugar.  There is a slight hop bitterness finish, but this beer is really all about the malt.  The mouthfeel is nice.  It is full bodied and smooth, but without being syrupey, which I don’t like.

Bottle - Amber color, caramel and cherry aroma, Taste of caramel with slight hint of cherry. Very palatable with a smooth finish. Expected this to be stronger due to being a doppelbock but didn’t expect the feeling to last as long as it did. Drink a few of these in a short time span and expect to fell it for a few hours afterward.

Clearish reddish amber colored beer with off white head.  Smell is sweet, sour malt, kind of like a maarzen or heller bock style smell.  Taste is deep strong malt, a touch of bitterness and a definite noticeable alcohol taste that really detracts from the beer.  Alcohol is more noticeable as it sits and really makes it less enjoyable.  I was dissapointed by this beer.
Bottle. Clear amber colour with medium frothy white mostly diminishing head. Malty aroma with fruit and caramel. Nice sweet nutty flavor with hints of alcohol.

Alla spina al Kapuziner di Arquata Scrivia. Curiosa - e, a quanto pare, storica - doppelbock della Paulaner, colore rossiccio intenso (ma al pub era buio), aroma abbastanza intenso, sapore pronunciato, non una birra da mandare giù come un acqua frizzante di culo. Però è buonina e non fa dispiacere se la bevi col tagliere. Sono ciucco.

Bottle date of June 2006, Sampled August 2007

Hugely aromatic, with amplified malt character leaping from the glass as I pour this brew. Caramelization, Maillard components, toffee, hints of light molasses, toasted malt, browned-rustically-crusty bread and even something like a concentrated fruitiness (though not the kind contributed by ale yeast).  The beer is topped by a frothy, initially two-finger thick tan colored head that sits on top of a brilliantly clear, cranberry hued, dark amber colored beer.  I don’t know why, but the malt focused aroma of this beer, at this moment in time, is hugely satisfying.  Complex in its malt focus, it makes me seriously think that this is still a decoction mash, or at least they fake it quite well.  The malt aromas are just so concentrated and enticing, it is almost pavlovian in the instinctual response that it generates in the olfactory portion of my brain.



Sweet, though not cloying; rich though not syrupy.  Above all it still has that deep, rich, malt character that I was really craving.  Flavors of caramelized brown sugar, and somehow a fruit character that has been unsweetened, yet still reminds me of dried figs and prunes.  This beer is clearly all about the malt character, though there is a touch of hop here, noticeable as a trace of bitterness and perhaps an ephemeral phantasm of herbal notes.  I really like how this beer is somehow not too sweet or cloying, despite clearly having a hefty level of residual malt sugars; chalk that up to the malt / mash / boil character.



I probably prefer the aroma over the flavor as it was just about perfect to me in this moment.  This is still quite tasty & over all this is just a great Doppel Bock.  I have had this beer a few times over the years and I don’t remember it being so striking, but such is the nature of beer, sometimes you just have to be in the right situation for a beer and this happens to be one of those.  This really captures that meaty malt character that I really like to find in a Doppelbock.

First rating
Initial Rating Date: 8/5/2007
(Bottle served into a "Stein" at Paulaner Nockherberger "Keller" in München) 
Since it was served into a stein it was difficult to tell the color, though it had a tan head. After a while when the head settled the look of the beer is rather dark. Malty, grainy sweet scent. Huge sweet grainy and alcohol taste, also some chocolate and husks. Full mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Fresh aftertaste.
7/3/7/4/14=3.5

Rerate
(50 cl bottle brought home from Germany by a friend)
BB 11.08
On September 21, 2008
Clear pale copper color, fluffy cream-colored head. Sweet malty, lactic and alcohol scent. Sweet, malty, roasted, lactic, alcohol, nutty taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Metallic, nutty and alcohol aftertaste.
6/4/6/3/12=3.1

Bottle -- Ruby brown with a smallish, dense off-white head with not much retention or lacing. Aroma is sweet malt. Flavour is all about malty sweetness with the tiniest hint of bitterness, supported by a too blatant alcohol warmth. A very good beer just the same.
Very good beer.  I didn’t like it at first taste but it quickly grew on me.  It has an interesting cherry smell to it.  Definitely worth a try.

Rated 8/4/07.  Fairly clear, dark amber, cider-like color.  Starts out with a cream colored head with unique orangey highlights, but it recedes quickly leaving nothing behind.  Aromas are sweet caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, and cherries.  Flavor is dominated by the caramel malts, but everything else in the aroma is detectable on the tongue.  I also picked up some peppery spiciness on the finish, and maybe a little dark rum as well.  Very little hop character, as is to be expected.  Sugary and sweet.  Not my favorite style, but pretty decent nonetheless.

500ml bottle. Middling brown with a long-lasting, off-white head. Aroma of toffee and preserved fruit. Flavour began with sweet caramel. This beer tailed-off severely: there was a nasty-metallic edge and the alcohol was a bit harsh. Unbalanced.

Bottle. Caramel aroma for this one. Amber body if held to light and biege head not much of a head ok thin. Vanilla chocolate flavor with some carbinated cola in the mix. Smooth and one of the better doppelbocks I’ve had in a while.

the pour give little head. The dark brown caramel color with tiny carbonation bubbles. The smell gives way to caramelized malt. the flavor is bursting with caramelized malt and molasses full body a bit nutty, oaky hint of coffee, vanilla and alcohol. Has a bitter finish. Not too bad for a doppel bock
Poured from bottle.  Didnt get much from aroma, but flavor is bursting with burnt malt, caramel, clove, banana, a hint of hops.  Nice finish.  Great beer.

Pours with a thin layer of an off white creamy head, but quicky vanishes. The beer is a beautiful amber colour which is quite pleasing.

This dopplebock leaves a bit to be desired on the nose with a strong hint of burnt caramel and yeast. Something seems a bit off.. 

The taste is not very surprising since it follows through with the smell quite nicely. It definitely holds it own in complexity and lingers for some time. 

I recommend trying this beer!
Bottle. Been such a long since I’ve tasted this doppelbock. Full body. Beautiful amber. Very nice.

Pours a caramel/brown color...not all that much carbonation Sweet malty aroma with bananas, clove, and some breadiness.  Flavors were very sweet and very bready with hints of the yeast, raisins, caramel, and a tiny bit of clove and anise (and some alcohol).  Full-bodied, lightly syrupy mouthfeel... pretty good stuff overall but I’d probably just go for a Celebrator.

Paulaner Salvator was a quality doppelbock. It had a pleasant caramel taste to it with mild carbonation. It was a reddish brown with almost no head. Overall a decent brew, but it was overhyped at my local beer store.
500 mL bottle. Pours a gorgeous ruby/amber color with a small white head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma was a fruity and malt. The taste is smooth with a very sweet finish.
Dark amber color with a sweet malty aroma.    Malt body with a faint roasted character and an alcoholic bite.
bottle.  amber with somewhat sweet aroma.  Decent flavor but nothing spectacular.

Very beautiful red beer with a medium head. Aroma is strongly malty and sweet, some red currants and syrup. Taste is malty and quite sweet, some roastiness and overally taste is quite simple. Full bodied and nice to drink. Appearance promises a lot, but flavour is too simple and alcohol in the end spoils the enjoyment. This beer is better to enjoy cold, when warmer it is too sweet and alcoholic.

Poured amber with 1 cm of tannish head. Decent lacing trails. Nose is chocolate and malt. Flavors are amalgamated well with the cocao malt ever-present within a slight cidery backbone. Medium/full body and medium carbonation. Good brew.
This beer was rich. A dark brown/amber color and an off-white head. Heavily malted beer with a strong, sweet finish.
Amber colour with a medium off-white head. Taste is quite sweet with roasted malts, brown sugar and chocolate. Alcohol doesn’t come through too much but it’s still there, leaving a nice warm feeling.
Dark pour with a strong nose of molasses and caramel.  Full bodied and smooth with a hint of yeastiness.  Overall, a pretty good example of the style.

Bottle. Pours a nice reddish-brown with a large tan head. The aroma is somewhat sweet malt, with both dark and lighter fruits, brown sugar, and a bit of alcohol. Flavor is richly malty, with caramel, fruits, and yeast, getting sweeter towards the middle, and with a tinge of bitterness and alcohol in the finish. Full-bodied and smooth mouthfeel. Not the most overpowering or intense doppelbock, but a very well made classic (and tasty!) beer.

I tried this on July 5, 2007 after purchasing from my local LCBO store.  It poured a beautiful translucent reddish into the glass with very little head.  The aroma was that of malts and fruits (apricotish).  The mouthfeel is full-bodied, very smooth and crisp with a hint of carbonation.  The taste is smooth with hints of yeast, malt and some sweetness and goes down very well. One of those beers that tastes better at the finish than it does at the beginning.  Nothing overpowering.  A very nice beer.

Clear dark amber color, not much head on this pour.  Figgy malt aromas are prevalent, but there are also suggestions of toffee, alcohol and pine.  Very smooth character, with a malty/toffe flavor, with roasted caramel notes as well.  The alcohol is definately present and leaves a warming tinge towards the finish.

Bottle... Beautiful auburn (ish) color with a nice brown (ish) head. Wonderful aroma. Perfect bitterness (which I adore) and a bittersweet finish. This was my first try and it’s already an instant Top 10 for me. On second try, I decided to rate it higher. Double Bock is simply fantastic!

Clear, auburn body with a medium-sized, beige head. The aroma is light with berries, vienna malts, caramel and cookie dough. The flavor is lightly sweet with cookie dough, caramel and light berry. Medium body is soft but a bit thin with light carbonation. Decent.
Reddish brown color with a adverage sized head. Aroma and flavors of malts and caramel. Too bad I only brought 6 home with me

12 oz, bottled 03-07. Clear, dark copper with a small head that lingers a bit. Nose is caramel toffee with light alcohol. Flavor is caramel, sweet corn and pepper, with alcohol in the finish, all covered with a slightly earthy smoky tinge. Medium body starts fairly smooth, thick and syrupy, then finishes with a slight astringency.
Clear rubi color. Small off-white head. Smocky aroma, alcoholic at the back, fruity of molasses and hoppy. Smooth flavor, bitter, strong, very alcoholic. Light body.
Good. I felt the amount of alcohol  too much, maybe the rest of tastes are no so well balanced. I expected a little bit more of it.
Bottle.  Cppper-red with creamy head.  Sweet maltiness with a little bit of a metallic taste.  Taste the alcohol on the finish.  Ok, but maybe this just isnt my style.

**Re-rate of a bottle produced on 12/06". Not surprisingly, this beer is noticeably better with a "newer" sample. Similar descriptions, but my initial assessment of the astringency (found in my earlier sample) being due to the beer’s age was accurate. This "fresher" bottle displayed none of those qualities and was quite clean in its finish. NOW I understand why this beer is regarded so highly, by many.

Bottle labeled "produced in 11/05; I bought it last week. Pours a clear reddish brown with a frothy, beige head. The nose is almost candy sweet with notes of caramel and prunes and a faint alcohol in the background. The mouthfeel is medium-full bodied, creamy and soft with a slightly sour, astringent finish. The flavor is a sweet caramel and prunes with a woody backing and a roasted, lightly sour finish. There is a hint of alcohol on the exhale but nothing significant. A tasty beer, but I have to think the sourness I was pulling from this bottle might be due to its age. I’ll see if I can find a fresher source and re-rate it in the future. [Original Rating @ 7/4/4/3/14=3.5]
500 mL bottle.  Copper red with a creamy white head.  Aroma of malt.  Thick syrupy palate.  Sweet malty taste and a hint of alcohol in the finish.

330 ml bottle - pours almost a glowing copper-red with a short-lived off-white head.  Rich, sweet aroma filled with honey, dark fruits, and sour grapes.  Lots of quality dark malts.  Mouthfeel is creamy, thick and smooth.  Lots of sweet dark malt in the full-body and a port-like character.  Slightly alcoholic finish.  Wonderfully balanced.  Excellent sipping brew.
One of my favorite styles of beer.  Creamy honey aroma.  Dark amber in color, slightly sweet full bodied brew.  Will definitely drink again.

Bottle.  Pours a deep amber with an off white head.  The aroma is full of honey and wheat?  Has a nice thick mouthfeel.  There is a strong sweet honey flavor and a malty aftertaste.  It is almost too sweet like a maibock.
Orange brown pour with thin head. Malty taste, hoppy finish. Very good beer.

a cherry orange color with a thin fluffy head. has a sweet soy sauce aroma with notes of dark fruit. nice thick body with light full bubbles. has a strong salty malty flavor with maple, toffee, raisins, and a light roasted quality to it. very full and well balanced

12 oz bottle. Poured an orangey/ruby color, clear body with very fine carbonation, and a super fast disipating head that only left a slight bit of white foam scattered about the top of this beer. Aroma was sweet, with notes of brown sugar, raisins, caramel and a very slight hint of alcohol. Flavor was actually better then the aroma and came across with loads of sweetness, especially in the aftertaste, hints of raisins and caramel and a nice complexity. Mouthfeel was rather full but yet creamy. Very nice beer, probably would be better on a cold day rather then in the middle of a summer afternoon.

330ml bottle.
Rich reddy brown, thin tight head. Smells a bit lagery, thin and perfumed. Taste, however, has much more body - a very full bock.Robust sweet maltiness, nicely burnt, with very dry hoppiness filling the back of the mouth, and providing the finish. Covers the 7.5% well.
- - 
Keg - - Opus K, Lohja - -
Sweet malty aroma. Soft bananaey palate, full of esters, sweet, soft carbonation. No hint of 7.5%. Full, malty body, not as almondy as normal. Subtle fruity hops too. Lovely quaffer, could session this, despite the strength.
Dark amber color, cream-colored head that lingers and leaves a lot of lacing.  Tastes of dried fruit and honey, chocolate - sweet and malty.  Alcohol is well hidden.

dark ruby color, small head. aroma is dark malt, and caramel. flavour is robust, and thick. Malty with big caramel, and grain overtons. as this warms is get very very mealy. THis beer is quite satisfying, its like a meal. very nice stuff.

On tap.  The pour was crystal clear, pale amber with a one-finger tall white head.  Decent lacing.  The aroma was brown sugar and nutty.  The flavor was brown sugar, caramel and nuts.  Middle of the road in terms of body with the alcohol completely hidden and the finish a nicely lingering bit of sweetness.  Not as aggressive in the spice dept. as Optimator, but this beer is very drinkable.  Nice.

Good beer for the price.  Looks a lot like ice tea in the glass.  reddish brown amber with an almost non-existant head.  Not much aroma but tastes nice.  A little bit of chocolate and sweet caramel.  Not bad.....not great.
Dark amber smells like juice.  Disappaiting head with little lacing.  Syrupy and sweet on the tongue.  Alcoholic finish.

Bottle pour.  Amber-brown with little to no head.  Has a very rich, rock candy, caramel, and malt aroma to it.  Thin mouth feel of caramel and candied sugar with a subtle malt taste. Good double bock that I’m glad I can find anywhere.

On draft at the Saucer.  Poured into a tulip glass with a ruby body and off-white head.  Incredible malty aroma with hints of cherries, toffee and vanilla.  Taste is equally malty with just enough hop bitterness and alcohol to balance it out.  Much better on draft than out of the bottle.
Great bang for the buck on price. Tastes like a dark midas touch IMO. Thick rich chocolatly tastes with low hoppiness. Very good and the alcohol is well hidden.
Although lacking the bock complexity typically seen, this is a good brew.  I would purchase again.

Pours a fairly dark reddish amber with a respectable off white head.  Aroma is bread dough and spice.  Sweet smooth malt flavor along with some maple syrup notes, even some cinnamon and pepper.  Very good example of the style.

330 ml bottle. Amber coloured with some head. The aroma is very fruity and with some bitterness. Actually the taste reminds me first of a normal bitter but the palate gives it away as a bock. Later on the taste sticks in your mouth (probably because of the sweetness) and you get the bock character. Overall a nice beer for chilly (Scandinavian) summer evening or cold winter days.

impressive for its price. Poured a nice dark red amber color. Little head but big fruity/carmel aroma. alcohol taste is hidden although it stands at 7,5%. Not all that heavy for a double bock. Overall, a good winter beer.

500ml bottle, $2.59.  Aroma is pleasant malt and  dark dried fruit.  Small off-white, fully diminishing, head left no lace.  Medium-dark nut brown body had lots of medium sized particles.  Flavor is moderately-heavy sweet and lightly bitter with an average duration.  Palate is full and creamy with a flat carbonation.  Nice sweet malty brew.  Mouth feel was better than others describe and very drinkable.  I really don’t like this style but I found myself really enjoying this beer.  Would recommend.

500ml. Bottle
$2.29
Health Mart
Produced on 3/06

Salvator poured a perfect caramel brown into my pilsner glass that sines with a reddish hue. Many tiny carbonation bubbles rise from everywhere to the small cap of head. The off white head started off about 1 finger on the pour but quickly fell down to the thin cap it’s at right now. The clear caramel body really makes this beer attractive.

For me this was unexpected but the first smell I noticed was tart green apples. There’s a solid caramel maltiness in the back but the apple really sticks out. Lightly toasted white bread shows up in there too. Fairly simple but unique and enjoyable.

The caramel shows up first in the flavor but drops to the background quickly and lets doughiness step up. This doughiness shows up mid-palate and is then taken over by the tart green apples and a hint of alcohol. As it warms the caramel gets deeper. Again, simple but very effective.

Body is medium with a thinner mouthfeel that actually compliments things nicely. Beer moves slowly through letting each flavor show itself. Small alcohol heat on the swallow.

This is definately an easy drinker. The body really helps this along with the simple flavors. The alcohol is a little too high to drink a lot but I could drink a few pretty easily.

Salvator is a quality doppelbock. Unique with the simple but interesting flavors. Good on this cold winter’s night. An easily enjoyable beer that’s also easy to find.

2/16/07

Bottle. Beautiful reddish dark amber colour. Good sweet and malty aroma with notes of apples. Flavour is sweet and malty  along with an alcohol presence and a lightly bitter finish. Nice!!

Cerveja com uma cor âmbar escura. Aroma doce com umas notas de maça. Savor adocicado e maltado dá pra sentir a presnça do alcool e levemente amarga no final. Boa!

Bottle, BWS, Alfred Cove BBE: 07/07
I suspect this may have not fared well in its trasport and handling, as it was very poorly carbonated and nealing its end of shelf life. The malt its very enjoyable, but a little more freshness and carbonation woudl have made for a much more inspiring experience.

TOTAL RE-RATE: I really love this beer. Pours a beautiful mahogany-orange colour with a small tan head, that diminishes fast. Too bad it doesn’t have much of a head, but the colour and small champagne-like bubbles make up for that. Aroma is just amazing. I could sniff this for hours. Malt-tastic. Caramel, toffee crunch, some booze but not at all in a bad way. The flavour is more of the same, in a completely delicious way. Malty, toffe caramel crunch candy bar, with some nice alcoholic bite in the finish and aftertaste with a nice slight dry astringency which helps balance out the sweetness. Absolutely awesome stuff. Dopplebocks are seriously growing on me.

Malty vanilla aroma.  Foamy tan head with a clear deep amber body.  Flavor is strong carmely malt.  Bitter up front with sweet accents and a roasted malty finish.  Fairly thick in the mouth but not overly carbonated.
wow...excellent brew, one of my favorites. nice light brown pour, full of flavor, balanced, excellent
Had this one bottled at the Taco Mac in Suwanee GA.   Served cold.  Disappointing as I was expecting more out of this brew.  Overwhelming licorice flavor.  I have had more enoyable doppelbocks.
really sweet beer, nice amber brown color with good carbonation, alcohol is hidden very well, overall a great bock.

Nice color, somewhere between deep golden and amber.  Nose is fruity, mild malty sweetness, Mouthfeel is smooth and round, taste is slightly but pleasantly bitter, the hops last nicely on the finish.  For me the alcohol sticks out a little bit and detracts from my overall enjoyment.  Still, pretty complex, I get peach or apricot hints and the bitterness reminds me of lemon rind.  Nice long finish.
It is a great bock.  If Optimator isn’t available, then this is the beer to have.  It is awesome.  What else would expect from Paulaner, makers of an outstanding hefe?

Rated 1/3/06:  I must admit after I poured this into a glass I was expecting a darker, heavier looking beer. One taste and I knew that looks are deceiving. This dopplebock is chock full of flavor. It tastes like a liquid sweet bread with overtones of figs and almost a "rum like" flavoring. This one is hard to explain and at 7.5% the strong alcohol taste is non-existant. Can’t wait to go back and get some more!

Pours a crystal clear dark-brown with an off-white head.
It has a malty and slightly sweet taste that is very refreshing.  A very good doppelbock, but not quite in the same league as Celebrator (a bit too sweet IMO).  Highly recommended.

Bottle. Hazy, copper-brown color. Not much head. Aroma of sweet, roasted malt. Flavor slightly sweet with the flavor of those roasted malts. Also, a kind of dark fruit flavor, maybe cherry or raisins. Good mouthfeel. Very good.

Amost pure crimson in color with a white head. Aroma has a very fruity presence that is match in the taste.  A medium-bodies brew with an alcohol content that is strong but hidden.  I’m not a big fan of the doppelbock flavor itself, but this wasn’t a bad brew.
Dark reddish color.  Sweet, roasty malt aroma with cinnamon.  Flavor is sweet and malty, roasted malt, cinnamon, hint of raisins, well balanced. Quality.

Pint bottle, pours very nicely, crystal clear red-amber color, would have been a 5 on the appearance I think if the head was more developed. Aroma gave hints of warm alcohol, sugary molasses, roasty malts, some cinnamon, and yeast. I was very impressed with the balance on this beer, considering I dont try too many doppelbocks. Sweet at first, with flavors of plum and raisin with brown sugar, with a smooth malty middle fade, that ends in a nice crisp hoppy bitterness with adequate carbonation on the tongue. I was impressed with the palate, very nice mouth feel, thick and silky. A good rich brew. Nice.

330ml bottle. Pours a dark red/orange color with a nice tan head that disappeared within 30 seconds of pouring. Aroma of candy, malt, honey and some yeast. The taste of alcohol was the first thing I tasted, but it was smooth and not overwhelming at all. Also detectable were notes of citrus, malt and some honey. A good doppelbock (although its my first).

12oz bottle. Pours a dark amberish body. Aromas of sweet candy, yeast, malt. Flavor backs that up with some citrus notes as well. Finish is crisp and medium length. No bitterness, just a pleasant, not too sweet finish. I enjoyed this much more than their Hefe.

I really liked this brew. It was spicy and sweet. Alcohol taste was present but smooth. Nice palate, bitter, full body, deep amber in color, moderate head. I tasted a very faint chocolate/ nutty flavoring. I would recommend this beer for the style.

The Doppelbock is a dark amber beer with a small fizzy head.  The aroma is malty, roasted, with other hints bread.  Initial flavour mildly sweet with a hint of brown sugar and finishes moderately bitter.  The finish stays in mouth for a few seconds to leave a lasting impression.  Overall a full bodied doppelbock with a fizz.

Bottle: Pours a brown/amber color, small beige head that dissipates quickly to a ring around the edge.  aroma is malty, smells of honey butter.  Initial taste is sweet with a hints of heffeweisen surprisingly.  Finish is lightly bitter, but mostly honeyish..again with the buttery tones.  Very satisfying beer, it is in no way dull.

(Bottle, Monk’s Café, Stockholm, 20 April 2007) Dark amber colour with short beige head. Malty, roasted nose with dried fruit and raisins. Malty, roasted taste with dried fruit (raisins, prunes) and notes of brown sugar. Lots of spicy hops in the finish. Balanced sweetness throughout, smooth body. Very nice balance.

Dark red coloration. Beige, consistent and persistent cream. Aroma of nuts, coffee, chocolate and clove. The palate folloies the aroma, with advantages. An absolutely SILKY beer, full bodyed. Excellent!....................................................................PORTUGUÊS: Coloração vermelho escura. Creme bege, consistente, persistente. Aroma de nozes, café, chocolate amargo e cravo. O paladar acompanha o aroma, com vantagens. Trata-se de uma cerveja absolutamente SEDOSA, bem encorpada. Ótima!

Cerveja diferenciada da Paulaner - garrafa pequena. Coloração vinho, bonita. Espuma densa, presente, ambar. Cheiro gostoso, traços de alcool, lembra bananas. Amargor pronunciado, cerveja densa e encorpada, gosto frutado, forte. Não é refrescante, não sevindo para climas quentes, muito encorpada, fez bem em vir em garrafa pequena.

330 mL bottle.  Pours a dark amber with quickly dissipating head.  Aroma is fairly malty with a very sweet fruity honey-maple smell.  Flavour is surprisingly bitter with strong caramel maltiness.  Bitterness tails off in the finish.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but not bad.
bottle. metallic amber color. medium head. sweet aroma. sweet malty alcohollic taste.
Bottle. Redborwn with pale brown quickly disappearing head. Aroma of malts,alcohol and bread. Taste of malts and sweet with some bitterness. Long finish.

[255-20070408] 330mL (c/o tuqueboy). Boozy vanilla and toast caramel malt aroma has sweet characteristics. Clear, dark red orange body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Flavour continues toasted caramel malt and vanilla with yeasty booze and a sweet finish. Medium body. Though boozy, this has a nice roundness.
Pours a nice dark color with a nice thick head. Smells malty and is pretty good and smooth for a double bach.
Bottle. 12 fl. oz. Golden, amber color with small, diminishing head.  Fruity, floral aroma.   Smooth palate.  Flavor is sweet with a light bitter finish.  Good brew.
Mine says 7.9% ABV. Sweet malty brew that really is not all that interesting. Although, the nose is fantastic. A good intro to Double Bock kind of beer.

in can 500 ml.,
Brown color, with some red sparkles. A big and clear head. The aroma is a very good malty, well!. Good and heavy body, with an initial flavor well malty. Then it comes slightly sweetly, the sweet; to finish in a slight bitterness. A very good bock. (It is necessary to have it in house).
Amber color with small head that disappears rapidly.  Moderately sweet decent beer.

Bouteille (11-07). Arome fruité, alcool, malté, caramel. Couleur rouge-brun, mince mousse avec lacet qui reste. Goût très malté, caramel, fruits, épices, alcool, finale en alcool. Effervescence moyenne, corps plein.

1000th rater. 12 oz bottle, produced on 10/06. Poured into a Delerium snifter glass gifted by JoeMcPhee to my girlfriend.  Pours an orange/red copper with lots of clarity and no head.  This cant be a bad bottle b/c I have kept it in my fridge for about two months now.  I only had this once before but it was a long time ago and I do not quite remember it.  But this smells like lagered fruitiness with estery bananas but not in the good way.  Lots of past its prime, old,  tea.   Taste is earl grey tea with lagered meatiness.  Its weird.  Low bitterness, very German and not too good.

Careful with this beer, it’ll sneak up on you.  As described to me, "Salvator" means ’savior’ to the monks who originally brewed this ’liquid bread’ during times of fasting.   Gotta love the monks! 
It has a great flavor for a beer high in alcohol that I usually can detect.

Ok, I’ve been sittin here, smelling this beer for the last 5 minutes and I still can’t place my finger on what it is that I smell. I’ve read other peoples reveiws, and the only thing I can think of is Juniper Berries, because it’s the only thing I wouldn’t recognize if I smelt it. Also, notes of toasted malts, and caramel. Flavors of caramel, malts, alcohol, and hops. The palat is solid, with just the right amount of carbonation, not watery at all, impressive. Well done. Would buy again.

bottle.  copper pour with great clarity.  rising bubbles to thin off white head.  floral hops and roasted malts dominate this sweet aroma.  sugary. sweet mollasses, roasted malts, nice hop balance.  very crisp.  peppery bitter finish.  nice.

A ruby colored ale, with a loose fizz head,  with a roast malt honey malt deep tones,

 Tk2 Ruby colour ,Good body, fruit malt some honey and a tinge of something not so nice. Think this btl on the turn so leaving at 3.9

Garrafa, 330 ml. Coloração âmbar avermelhada, com creme bege não tão persistente. Notas de fermento, malte torrado e caramelo. Consistência cremosa, suave, sedosa. Álcool e amargor presentes, mas bem harmonizados. O paladar deixa um final amargo. Carbonatação baixa. Bom retrogosto.

An aggressive pour into a snifter glass produced crystal clear beer sporting a creamy two-finger head that fades slowly and is reluctant to return.  Held to the light the color is a stunning ruby red.  The aroma dominated by a crisp caramel malt note, with accents of smoke and sweetness.  Flavor follows the aroma profile closely.   Head retention is modest.  The palate is a full-bodied, and a little creamy with a moderate level of carbonation.  The finish is balanced, alternating between sweet malt and bitterness.

50 cL bottle. Pours amber/orange with creamy, but short lasting light brown head. Aroma is wheat, caramel, honey and traces of yeast. Taste is caramel malt, sweet and a touch of flowers. Finish is dominated by malt notes without being sweet.

A very deceitful beer. Between the ABV and taste this beer will knock you on your ass.  For me the prefered DB as this is balanced in all aspects, unlike the Ayinger example.  Rich, full bodied, yet not too sweet.  Vey good yet deadly in its afteraffects.
Draft, .5 liter.  Pours dark brown w/smallish head.  Sweet and balanced but not quite enough kick for me.

Medium brown body with amber hues at the edges. Small tan head, somewhat well retained. Sporadic lacing is neither pleasant nor ugly, just happens to be there. The beer does have a pleasant glow. Quite a complex aroma, though far too shy. Notes of oak, anise, juniper, caramel malt, chocolates, alcohol, smoke, brown sugar and plentiful sweetness. Flavor expands on the aroma, malty and lightly bitter. A very satisfying amount of the aforementioned, though it seems to be missing the spicy punch that defines a memorable dopplebock. Finishes sweet and with lingering caramel and mild hints of juniper and alcoholic warmth. Palate is average, medium to medium-full bodied, smooth and with an off kilter acidity/sourness. For many the quintessential bock, for me it’s just a tasty dark beer that’s easy to score.

dark amber apricot color this smooth, sweet double bock has a well deserved reputation.  A strong winter bock and it’d should’t be the first beer you drink when starting out,  but its pleasent balance and dry finish helps the medicine go down.  Well made bock.  The Bavarians do it again

This has an aroma of raisins and caramel.Small disappearing head.Color amber.palate was quite sticky and smooth.It has the flavor of malted raisins and honey.medium body.Is sweet tasting somewhat with a dryish and bitter finish.I don’t really care for this style,but it’s fairly good for the style.

This was the first beer that made my jaw drop.. about 2 years ago. I still love it! Caramel, malt, perhaps a bit of citrus, spicy (ginger, coriander), perhaps salty aromas. Flavor is strong caramel, lightly spicy, heavy malt, perhaps a hint of soy sauce. Alcohol hidden quite well (7.9 %). Very fairly priced too, I might add ($1.99/ 22oz bottle). I’ll say it again, I LOVE THIS BEER!
Amber with creamy white head. To sum up this beer in one word - caramel. Okay body. Malty caramel. Medium sweet with an easy alcohol feel. Moderate bitter end. Pleasant and drinkable!

Poured a light amber with big frothy off white head. Very sweet aroma up front of fruit and bread. Taste was sweet bread, very malty, some raisins, perhaps. The sweetness lasted in the finish with this one as well, which I quite enjoyed! This was very drinkable and very good indeed!
