Pour is a clear amber type color, seems like a light color for a doppelbock, but still nice.  Aroma of malt, nuts, caramel, and dark fruit.  Flavor is sweet with malt, caramel, nuts, a little dark fruit, bread,  and a some sourness.  I nice german beer.

Bottle.  Pours amber with lasting small white head.  Not much lacing.  Has the sweet malt bock beer aroma.  Lekker malty flavour with a sweet/bitter finish.  Lovely bock from the country that invented it.
Bottle, Pours out a very nice clear amber/tan. topped with a very small light tan head. Some sweet and malt on the aroma aswell as in the tast. Not bad.

This may be the original dopplebock but it is nowhere as good as a Celebrator and I think it is a little to sweet in the finish but I will drink more of these in my life. Page 355 of Michael Jackson’s Great Beer Guide and only 297 of his 500 Classic Brews to go.
Bottle.50cl. Malty aroma with alcohol note, no head and i did try to get it, with no luck. Malty flavor and strong alchol,
A nice brew. Pours nicely with an amber tint and a thin lacey head. Amora is mild with a hint of hops. Mouthfeel is smooth and flavor is sharp with a mild aftertaste. A nice german beer.
Caramel malts and dark fruits are in the aroma.Pours a murky medium copper with a medium off white head.Dark fruits dominate the flavor.Thin to medium mouthfeel with a sweet finish.

Yeasty, figs, and heavy caramalt make up the aroma.  Slightly hazy copper iwth very little head.  Medium palate with low carbonation.  The taste is heavy malt and earthy flavors. No hops at all.  Lightly sweet, this one finishes clean.
caramel, amber, hazy, frothy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light sweetness,

Bottle - Pours a dark cloudy amber with not much head to speak of (at least from this bottle).  Malty, grain, biscuit dough aroma.  Complex spices and flavors - biscuit, prunes, dates maybe, caramel, wine-like alcohol finish.  I didn’t pair this one with food, so I may buy/drink again to get a better prospective.
Bottle-Memphis. Tan head on dark amber body.  Aroma is complex and sweet.  Palate has loads of flavor.  Damn it, I wish I had a decent palate!!! Best I can do: it was good.

Pours a clear amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of caramel, fruits, toffee, yeast, and a slight hint of alcohol.  Flavor starts off with caramel and toffee that gives way to the fruits and yeast.  Has a slight alcohol warming on the end but not very much.  A pretty decent doppelbock.

Sweet aroma, flavor is mainly sweet aswell, balanced by the high alchohol%.
Solid but not too complex.
One of my favorites.  This has a good German malty taste with very little bitterness.  A malty nutty-caramel taste that finishes clean  and doesn’t disappoint.
This dark amber ale poured with a substantial tan head. The flavor is dominated by caramel malt and treacle with a sweet fruity finish. This is one of the better dopplebocks.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass, amber with a thick tan head, which disipated quickly. The aroma was light with hints of malt and fruit. The taste is of sweet caramel and malts. There is a nice alcohol bite, some bitterness and a nose something like dark bread in the finish. Excellent beer.

Bottle. Clear deep amber colour wityh a nice big creamish white head. Aroma of sweet malts, some toffee, fruit and alcohol. Flavor of caramel, some bit roasty sweet malt, bit chocolate, fruity, sweet alcohol. Dry bit sweet dry finish.

Bottled, 7.9% ABV. An amber beer with a light head. The aroma has strong notes of caramel and is very malty. There is some alcohol presence, but doesn’t disturb me. The flavour is sweet, with again much caramel, molasses, malt and little hops. The body has enough power to balance the alcoholic strenght. Not strong bitterness. Sweetish and medium long finish. Well made beer.

Pours a clear mahogany with a healthy, persistent tan head. Aroma is sweet with chocolate and caramel. Flavor has dark fruits like plum and raisins. Very smoky and slightly alcoholic. Pretty nice dopple.
Really good. Molasses dominates the aroma. Very smooth feel and warming on the way down. A little sweetness hides the alcohol. Just a hair behind my favorite Doppelbock, Troegs Troeganator.

Never had doppelbock before.  First impression: Excellent.  Fermented malts along with sugar cane to the nose.  Dark amber in color with slight quickly dissipating head and not much lace.  Flavor is rich on the malt(s) side with a very distinctive sweetness.  Caramel, molasses, sugar cane offset by a very subtle saltiness.  Velvety smooth mouthfeel.

Nice relaxed aroma of molasses, sweet bread, nuts and caramel. Clear dark amber appearance with nice foam, though this fades away quickly. Strong taste of alcohol blended with caramel, nuts and toffee. Slight hop bitterness present. Nicely carbonated with small bubbles - suits the beer well, good mouthfeel, medium body though appears thin. Good beer -  above average.

Fantastic dopplebock. 
appearance: a dark amber with a very thick tan head
smell: a little hops with a little sweet like mollases and breadines
taste: A good balance of hops and sweet with some dried raisens or other spice.
mouthfeel: A nice smooth initial taste with a kick of hops and spices to follow, a little thick but not overpowering

Pours a clear, dark copper-amber color with a less-than average, somewhat creamy, off-white head; head is mostly diminishing leaving no lacing.  Nose is faint and fairly bready noting rich milk chocolate, maybe some grape or raisin, light earthy hops, and toasted/grainy breads.  Taste is much better; rich choclate, malted caramel, toasted whole grains, light anise and raisin, and a touch of earthy bitterness.  Palate is medium, moderate, and round, slightly viscous (pleasantly so).  Finishes with chocolate and toasted bread an a little earthiness.  Nice rich, hearty, malty bock with well hidden alcohol content.  Certainly one of the better everyday dopple from Germany.

I am not fond of the smell of this beer at all.  I am hesitant to say it smells like rotting malts.  The colour is nice, deep, clear, head is a little on the weak side.  Taste is surprisingly smooth, malty, oaky,  Plug your nose and guzzle it down!

16.9oz bottle: Golden red in appearance, some bubbles.  Whitish smallish head, lasting, good lacing.  Malty aroma, earthy dark fruit aromas.  Grape.  Fresh taste, lively, woody, dark fruit on the aftertaste.  Some alcohol, smooth balanced flavor, not real malty.  Letting it warm up a bit...a little more malty flavor, but still well balanced.  Some taste of flowers.  Overall not too bad a beer.  One of my first dopplebocks, so not sure what to look for.
Not a bad beer but nothing special.  Malty and caramel colored.  Classic doppelbock, but it has nothing on the Ayinger.
This beer has a flavorful taste with a perky malt flavoring. Not the smoothest beer I’ve had, but went well with Papa John’s.
A really solid, yeasty taste, that lingers on the palate. A dark red pour and a small head that disappears quickly. Lingers nicely. Very malty, with a soft alcohol burn
Bottle. Aroma-quite fruity and pleasant. Appearance-dark and reddish. Flavor-Alcohol predominates and masks the subtle flavors. Palate-Bubbly. Tastes like a bock with the alcohol raised, simply.

reddish amber clear pour with an average bubbly head, slowly eroding.  toasted aroma hinting at caramel apples, mmm.  also butternut and/or toffee in the nose.  medicine-like, maple syrupy taste, but with a caramel malt and amaretto flavor as well.  truly interesting and complex.  not too savvy on the hoppy side of life, but nonetheless it is a good beer to enjoy every now and then.

This is a nice, warming beer great for a cold winter day.  Pours an amber, red color, with little to no head.  Nice aromas of hops, floral, and caramel.  The taste was very maltly and slightly bitter.  A good sipping beer but not something I’d drink everyday.

Reddish brown copper color with a thin beige head that did not last much. Nice smell of fruits and malts. Great taste of malts, fruits, and a bready finish with some hints of hops and caramel. Nice syropy mouthfeel but very low carbonation. Very good finish and a nice aftertaste. A pretty good beer. I will have more of this.

15-Dec-06	500ml bottle in Munich	Malty, sweet aroma. ..	Dark orange, clear with whitish head. ..	Malty & sweet with a hint of hoppiness. ..	Smooth, not much carbonation to get in the way. ..	Not as impressed as what I’ve seen in the states.  Try another with a fresh palate.
My first double bock and so I do not have anything to compare it to.  There was no head.  The color was red medium brown.

Poured a medium-dark brown with no head. Aroma quite stunning! What IS that? Plum? Very fruity, sweet & sour aromas, confusing and inviting. Wow, flavour is just as intriguing. Raisin bread, yes, overripe (rotting) pear & fruit, and crisp but full-bodied hops. Mouthfeel thick and syrupy, but lacking in carbonation. Overall, a very interesting and thought-provoking beer. I’d be curious as to what I’ll taste in it a year from now, after tasting more beers.

Reddish brown with little to no head. Aromas of raisin bread and caramel. Sweet chewy malt with a sweet bready finish. 
Awesome doppelbock.
6 pack. very dark, can taste alcohol content, feels heavy. feels almost sludgie. If your not into double bocks this one won’t get you into them.

Super  dopplebock (double bock)-- I normally do not like this style at all but this is the best I found. Great roast bread fruit aroma. Nice balance with the malt, carmel, spices. Nice driness in finish. Great flavor but a bit too sweet for me. Most dopples are much sweeter. Easy drinking smooth for 7.5%

500ml produced 06.06 - Small head over copper liquid.  Creamy woodiness on nose.  Very light carbonation.  Sweet maltiness fading to raisins with alcohol clearly present.  OK, but I’d opt for the Ayinger here.

Pint bottle... poured ruby red with a white head that diminished quickly.  Spicy, malty aroma. Well carbonated palate and flavors of sweet malt, fruit and perhaps caramel with also a light alcohol presence. I was really excited about getting this one because I have had great experiences with the few Doppelbocks that I have had, but this one was mediocre.

12 oz. bottle, one of 10 "winter" beers in a variety pack sold by my local retailer. Boy, was I disappointed with this! No head to speak of, although it had a nice color. There was little flavor, not at all what I would expect in a doppelbock, and not at all what I was expecting based on reputation and the reviews here. (Most of the reviews I’ve read here have been in line with how I would rate the beers I’ve tried.) I will probably try this again, but I’m not expecting much! Not a very pleasant experience.
Good pour(Nice amber) Sweet Malt taste but not overly done. This is a brew and quite enjoyable
Gorgeous ruby colored beer, beige head. Flavor is yeast, alcohol and sweetness. Quite malty. This beer has some depth, though. Herbal flavors come through, as well as carmel and some hops.

This starts off with an aroma of sweet and spice.  There is virtually no head or lacing to be seen, but carbonation is visible through the dark red color of the beer.  The flavor is strong and complex, I’m able to pick out some hints of chocolate and plum, with a mild hop finish.  Not my favorite style, but a very drinkable beer.

Bottle pours light brown/ dark amber with a fair offwhite head.  Aromas of caramel malts, a little raisin, and some toasted malts.  Flavor is caramel, raisin, toasted malts, a touch of toffee. Sweet throughout even in the lingering finish.  Smooth medium body but a tad to the watery side.  A little alcohol warmth on the back of each sip.  Not bad.

[Sampled at Carsten Bertelsens Ølrejsen.]

Very nice goodlooking beer with an amber appearence. Aroma is sweetmalty with the flavor of caramel combined with some malt and hops are in balance. Good aftertaste!
good dark beer, alittle to hoppy and bitter for my tatse but all in all a good double bock
Nice orange amber color with a big off-white head.  Aroma is crude malt and not much else.  Taste is fairly bold, and malty with grapes. Alcohol is only slightly detectable in the finish.  $2.25/12oz
12oz bottle-pours a diminishing light tan head and copper color.  Aroma is medium malt-sweet.  Taste is very sweet-medium malt, faint hops, dark fruit, bananas, alcohol.  OK carbonation.

Bottle:  Attractive head that doesn’t last long.  Clear Amber body, malty, nutty, aromas are mixed in with the alcohol in the nose.  Hops present as well.  Good balence.  Nice bitterness in the finish.  Spicyness lingers.   Starts with malty sweetness &grapes, alcohol.  Not bad in body.  More hops than expected.  Ver good beer, enjoyable even though I’m crazy about the style.

pours a crystalline amber with honeyed highlights, medium light tan head which dissipates fairly quickly
Aroma of caramel, some figs and melanoidin with a faint noble hop aroma, alcohol notes come thru as the beer warms up
Palate: medium-light bodied with a medium-low carbonation which seems prickly diminishing the smooth palate. The finish is dry and yields to the prickly carb
Taste: Dark Caramel, some nutty qualities dried raisins and melanoidin notes play high notes with the a spicy hop bitterness is restrained and keeps the beer balanced. As the beer warms up the alcohol warmth seems more noticeable and diminishes the finish
Overall: a great welcoming appearance, warm aromas and flavors unfortunately the carbonation makes this beer un-necessarily sprightly on the tongue detracting from its enjoyability. A very good doppelbock with too thin a body or high carbonation. I am a tad disappointed with this since this is considered one of the standards for the style. If you are seeking a great doppelbock a must try is the Ayinger Celebrator

33 cl bottle, Shelburne. Deep amber, soapy head that clings to the side of the glass. Caramel aroma, strong malty alcohol flavour. Long finish, warm and sweet. Thick in the mouth but thin finish for the style.

A medium orange coloured beer with a fizzy and quickly diminishing head that is a light brown colour.  There are distinct apricot and grapefruit aromas and flavours.  There is an initial sweet burst of flavour with a moderately bitter and lightly acidic finish that is short in duration.  It is a medium to full bodied beer that is a great tasting and smelling winter brew.  It left a little to be desired on the palate but the flavour makes up for it.

7.9% 0.5L bottle. Raspberry jelly-red body topped with dirty suds that dissipate quickly. Densely chewy mouthfeel. Thick and simple, but a grower. Nutty malt and raisiny booze in the snout. Opens sweetly with a mouthful of caramel and figgy fruit, finishes with a surprising nibble of bitterness. Pleasantly bready afternose. Lingers with a thick liquid licorice bitterness. No spice, no hops, very little alcohol. In the mouth at least. Really developing some boozy fruit now it’s warmed up a bit, but I’m still not convinced it’s anything more than a turbo-charged Alt.

A delicious winter seasonal that I could drink all year ’round.The aroma is is fruity and sweet. The taste is thick and caramelly with spices and roasted nuts in the finish. This would be the beer they were drinking in the scene on Dumb and Dumber when they are in their holiday sweaters and Jim Carey ignites a fart. Delicious....(the beer)

Newly tapped at Barley John’s.  Copper in color with a fleeting yellowish head.  Aroma is of prunes, nuts, caramel.  Flavors of raisin, toffee and hot whiskey.  Initially dense mouthfeel eventually recedes into a flattened, thin semblance of itself.  Fruity and subtley spicy character.  Wasted, in small part, by an aggravating emptiness that expands as the pint goes down and the carbonation withers.  A rare brew that in this case may have fared better from the bottle.

Very, very thick off-white head that dissipates rather slowly.  The lacing disappears quickly.  The appearance is beautiful; color is a copper amber.  Scent and taste of caramel, spices, fruit.  Light-bodied.  The aftertaste is bittersweet (literally) and not 100% pleasing to the tongue.  It is also dry but not at all metallic.  The alcohol is evident at first taste but like many other beers the full flavor of this one truly comes out as it warms to room temperature.  It may be hard to refrain from downing the beer because of its inviting appearance and great taste, but try to drink it as slowly as possible in order to get the full experience.  Perhaps leave it out of the cooler for a while before consumption.  A very good brew.

Bottle produced on 08.05. Poured a deep red-copper color with a thin off white head that fizzed off quickly. Very nice aroma of fruits and a spice background. The flavor found sweet fruits with a chocolaty malt hint. Medium to full body that was creamy and smooth. Very nice!

Wonderful aroma of malt.  Melinoidens galore, something that I has a homebrewer have never been able to attain.  This is a nice mug to sip on when the weather is cold.  The alcohol is well in hidden in the layers of malt that reflect toffee and raisin. The finish is somewhat spicy and dry with a lingering note of caramel.

I love this beer. It has a very beautiful color, a nice head, and a subtile but rich aroma.
Wonderful flavour of caramel, spices, malt, with a nice sweet/bitter balance.
A great beer in one of my favorite styles...

pours hazy medium brown, creamy off-white head.  Aroma is heavy malty; molasses and moderatly yeasty; rasin and dates.  Flavor starts heavly sweet and malty and lightly bitter. finishes moderatly sweet and lightly bitter with an average duration finish.  medium bodied, creamy and softly carbonated.  Nice.
Bottle. Ok head with medium duration. Nice aroma of fruit and spices. Taste is rich with caramel and alcohol.

330 mL bottle.  Translucent reddish brown with creamy beige head that doesn’t last.  Aroma of alcohol, dark fruit, spice, and whiskey.  Taste is more balanced than expected; there is the alcohol and the brown sugar sweetness, but there is also evidence of hops.  Still, a little too sweet for my taste.
A nice beer strong taste, I find a little like whisky. A rather orange color. Nice bottle motive too. But completely my taste it is not.

Aroma is very nice; roasty, roasty, fruity, and bready.  Pours a see thru amber.  Wow, nice bitter, malts that carry a sustaining complexity; Head fades.  Overall an excellent bock that’s worthy of it’s praise.

Pours deep red-brown with light tan head.  Smells sweet and fruity with just a hint of apple.  Taste is strong and a bit sweet, almost too sweet.  Finishes easy though.  Bottle marks 7.9%ABV, not 7.5, but its close enough.
pours a deep brown with red highlights creamy off white head.aroma of choco and carama.taste is syrupy and almost cloying sweet.overall ok just too sweet
One of the sweeter doppelbock’s, quite high on alcohol, but it doesn’t stick out. Very pleasant winter evening warmer. At the time of rating, you can get this from Finland also.
Pours a dark amber, thin off-white head.  Sweet aroma, malty and yeasty.  Flavor is strong and biting, very sweet and malty, just a teensy bit cloying.

12oz bottle. Poured a medium copper color with a huge sized off white head. Aromas of fruitiness, toasted malts, caramel, and a little bready. Tastes of caramel, brown sugar, some dark fruits (raisins), and fruity. On the sweeter side. Alcohol content well hidden. Some lacing left on the glass.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a beautiful light brown mostly lasting head. Plenty of malt in the aroma and a little hint of sweet caramel. Flavor of malt and dried fruits (raisins?). Good finish.
Very nice taste. Great amber (almost reddish) color. Medium head. Great fun.

This beer is tasty but the almost 8 abv kinda sneaks its way through, its a bit cheeky... nice and woody, no lacing head, good aroma that is quite strong at the crack of the bottle, i honestly don’t think i’ll be having this again, well, if i can get it on tap then for sure!!
Rerate: WOW, my first review was quite harsh on this poor old dog...This must of been one of my first doppels, because this beer is very nice. The taste is decent when looking at the 2.50 price tag, and this beer goes down clean, quickly and smooth......Another!

Great red color with a quickly diminishing head.  Smells of malts and yeast.  Malt flavor carries into the taste, which also has bits of fruit and alcohol.  Has a medium-big body which compliments the taste well.  Great aftertaste also.
Amber with a firm off-white foam. Fruity and malty notes. Full bodied with a sweet finish.
Pours a clear bronze.  Caramel, toffee flavorings with some alcohol warmth.  Clean finish with great smooth taste.

Aroma very stron malt some melanoidins, light caramel, low fruity plum and or raisin. Deep dark gold ruby highlights. Slight alcohol in flavor, strong rich maltiness seems its from Munich malts, no fusel alcohol but some warmth due to alcohol, excellent in richness malts. Perfect example

Pours a clear and beautiful dark ruby red color. Medium white and frothy head. It stays for some minutes until it leaves a small lacing.
Ultra-malty aroma, full of enticing notes of caramel, toffee, molasses and some plums/prunes. Some roasted sugary traces. A herbal note gives a fine counterpoint. Excellent.
Flavor is sweet, caramelly. It’s full, bold with notes of caramel, molasses, roasted brown sugar complemented by overripe red and dark fruits. Delicious!
Body is medium, oily texture. Fair carbonation. Long sweet finish, caramelly aftertaste. An awesome german beer....I want more.



Bought in Mendoza, Argentina

Bottle shared with Lilith and nigredo

Aroma: Strong sweet Munich malt aroma, toasty low hop nose
Appearance: Copper brown with tan head. Beautiful belgian lace lasting to the bottom of the glass.
Flavour: Rich full malt character. Luscious sweet maltiness with toasty malt flavour. Finishes very clean.
Mouthfeel: Medium full bodied with creamy carbonation and mouthfeel.
Overall: Starts sweet and malty but finishes dry with lingering toasty flavours. Alcohol character compliments the malty aspects but doesn’t overpower the flavour. Very rich and slightly warming.
Bottle.  Pours bright red, without head.  Nice malt flavor, but that’s all.  Not much else to it. Alcohol is all there is.

(Bottle BBE 09/07; ABV 7.9%) Caramel, sweet, toffee, slightly roasted and slightly alcoholic aroma. Amber colour, clear and average size, light brown, more or less fully diminishing head with fair lacing. Caramel, malty, slightly fruity and slightly hoppy flavour. Lively carbonated, alcoholic and mediuml-bodied palate. 08/10/06
Pours a light reddish brown. Aroma of sweet toffee and caramel. Very sweet flavor, candyish.

Pours clear bronze with a nice tan head.  The aroma has lots of bready toffee that is rich and smooth.  Medium rich body with only a small amount of carbonation.  Starts with the bready toffee and caramel - very rich and smooth with a touch of astingency.  The finish has a light bit of spice, but mostly still malts.  Thick breadiness sticks around on the tongue for quite a while.  A solid doppelbock.

500ml bottle. Pours a small tan head that quickly fades. Very dark orange almost brown color. Smells of sweet malts hops and alcohol. medium to full body. Sweet very balanced tastes . goes down great!

bottle from my local indy beer seller. dark orange almost brown in appearance, not much in the way of froth and what there was went really quickly leaving just a faint wisp round the edge of the glass. quite sweet on the nose, almost caramel but quite different because it’s not too sweet once it gets onto your tongue. malty finish, quite bitter too but nice length to the beer, hides its alcohol quite well

Smells like a candy stick, rootbeer perhaps. Orangish brown in my steelers glass. Leaves a bitter impression on my tongue.  Almost flat.  A little too syrupy but not overly sweet, if that is possible.  I could barely detect any sweetness at all.  Bitterness prevails, but is not overwelming, on the finish.
Good overall.  A very sweet beer.  Too sweet for my usual tastes, but with a complex palate that mostly makes up for it.  Still a tad over-rated.
Rich carmel color.  Foamy head dissipated quickly.  Sweet, hoppy aroma.  Taste is the same, sweet with a  little metallic aftertaste.  Good beer, but not a great one.

Pours a rich brown with a tan head.  Elements of maple abound in the aroma, very candyish.  Flavour is rich malt with vanilla down the throat.  One definitely gets the alcohol presence.  I am sure this suffers from the travel and the age on the shelf.  It is still a nice doppelbock.

Pours a earthy looking light brown with a fading tan head. Thick roasty malty aroma, chocolate & cinnamon. The flavor is creamy, as well as the body. Rich & viscous character, with a chewy malt flavor of maple syrup, slightly chocolatey, cinnamon and alcohol presence. The finish is long and slightly nutty. Decent flavors, but not all together balanced. Seems a bit syrupy and sweet in my opinion, overrated.

Well, this is weird.  I haven’t rated this beer, I wonder how that happened.  Well good!  I needed something to do.  It’s a sweet tasting beer.  Really no yeast or fruitiness since it’s a lager.  No hops to speak of.  Candy like.  It’s a little sticky sweet, especially the last half of the glass.  Not bad, it’s not as good as Celebrator.

Re-rate 12-07-2007 Large creamy like beige head that mostly lasted. Clear sparkling body with a mahogany color. Good display of lacework. Aroma was heavy bread, nutty, toffee, light fruit, almost a hint of liquorish, somewhat toasted malty notes as well. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and somewhat thick texture. Lovely moderated to heavy sweet malty base, maybe a hint of bitterness. Rye bread sweet and lingering finish. This beer is just so drinkable. A really solid Doppelbock. 

Strong taste and long bitter finish. Red/brown appearance with a lot of malt and nutty aroma.6-3-7-3-14 (10-03-2006)
Clear cherry red colour, tiny vanilla head. Sweet malt and nutty aroma. Has a nice bitterness at the end which balances the sweetness.
Good body and not overly sweet. Doppelbocks just don’t have enough hops for me.

Pours a rich ruby-hued amber with a big but dwindling offwhite head.  The nose is sticky sweet with malt and just a bit of something tannic.  This is well rounded in the mouth with gentle creamy  carbonation and a bit of body.  The flavors are a bit of disappointment given the malt in the nose.  A bit on the watery side.   Sweet and sticky, with some light tannic sort of hop flavors providing more balance than the nose would suggest. Bready biscuity flavors come out, with hints of toasty aspects, especially as warming.  A lingering bitterness is a little on the unclean side, but still, this is a decent brew.

Looks great, it has a deep orange/ color with a medium sized fluffy white head (large at first, but turns thin fairly quickly).  Sweet malty, rich aromas, which include caramel, vanilla, pepper.  The flavor is disappointing compared with the aroma, mostly because it is watery.  There is a lot of bitterness.  Some of the sweet caramel is still there though, and maybe even some fruits which werent present in the aroma.

When I found this at my nearby wine store, I quickly snagged a six-pack.  Afterall, I love Paulaner and I love doppllebocks.  Fortunately, the salvator provides just what you’d expect.  The body is nice and full, delicious caramel and malt with a bit of complexity from the bitterness and astrigency. Unfortuantely, for the Salvator, I have a couple other dopplebocks on hand that are a step up.  Still, for the price, this is quite good.   I’d agree with the previous poster about serving at the correct temperature maybe 60°F.

330ml Bottle: I wasn’t familiar with this poorly labeled beer so to find it was a doppelbock was a pleasant surprise.  Poured ruby red with thin head that had 100% disappeared very quickly, leaving it to resemble red wine.  Aroma is excellent; sharp caramel candy malt sweetness with oak, very pungent and interesting.  Flavour cold was bitter sweet malt with alcohol and cherries.  Let this one warm, it only gets better, adding in subtle tannin and grape flavours to a rapidly enhanced flavour profile.  Quite complex and good.
Amber body with a head that falls very quick. the flavor is very nice hopps good malt finish. A slight burn on the way down.

1 pint 9 oz bottle.  Pours a murky amber with minimal tan head that fades quickly.  Medium activity carbonation.  Smells slightly of bananas and earthy grains.  The taste starts out with nothing recognizable, then explodes with a slightly citrus-driven hop that instantly fades to a long-lasting very malty finish.  Slight alcohol taste and burn after finish.  Decent but non-spectacular mouthfeel.  This beer gets better the closer it reaches room temperature.
Bottle:  Copper in color with almost opaque head.  Extremely malty smell with hints of caramel.  Taset is same as aroma with an alcoholish finish.  Nice overall.

Bottle from Hy-Vee Liquors poured into dimpled mug - Pours red orange with a quickly dissipating 2.5 finger beige head; Sweet malts and a hint of caramel to the nose (stupid allergies won’t let me smell much anything else); Lots of caramel and a little bit of a hoppy malty mix on the initial taste; Molasses with a slight hop pressence on the backtaste; Not incredible, but not bad at all. I prefer Paulaner’s hefe to this, but it’s still a good beer. Does get slightly harder to drink as it warms though. Shouldn’t be that way. Might take another go with this one after a while.
Bottle.  Pours copper, with a thick, fizzy, brown head.  All I can smell is malt in the aroma.  The body is heavy, with an overpowering taste of malt and molasas.

Bouteille de 330 ml acheté à la LCBO (Ottawa, ONT). Arôme: Odeur de céréale rôtie et de petits fruits confits. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée foncé avec une très faible densité de bulle. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de mélasse et de torréfié. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence d’alcool chaleureux avec une pointe de fumée en arrière goût. (Rating #637)
Amber pour with light head.  Aroma of light caramel.  Flavor is much the same with a touch of molasses and toasted malt.  Finish is clean and to the point.
Bottle. Pours orange red amber. Off white head. Aroma is molasses, malt, and caramel. Flavor is caramel, raisin, malt and pine.
light brown body with not much head.aroma is a mix of butter,caramel malts,and metal.flavor was mch of the same.not bad but pretty typical for a doppelbock.

Dark color, flavorful candy-like aroma with a taste to match. A Strong drink but it’s expensive to buy where i live. Nice to have a couple of these in a day also something i would drink maybe twice a month. Would not make this my regular beer of choice because of the price

bottle.Pours very dark with a short lived head.Aromas of roasted barley, sweet malts and a hint of hops.The taste is fairly smooth and not too off balanced with the sweet malt coming through first then the slight hop finish.A nice brew.
descent notes... overall taste, blah... overpowering alcohol.. i don’t think ill get this beer again. not for me

not as dark as i was expecting.  deep amber, translucent.  1/4" head, fairly normal, perhaps a little light-colored.  wow, tons of dark fruit aroma.  very sweet, almost molasses/candyish.  a bit creamy aroma too.  creamy tasting.  not as malty as i was expecting based on nose.  might be slightly underpowered actually.  well-bodied.  good dopple.
Bottle.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a medium sized white head.  The aroma is of sweet malts.  The flavor is full of the sweet malts, but it has a nice lightly hopped finish.  Excellent beer.
I am not a huge fan of this style , but it was pretty good.  Very malty, i will try it again in the winter time.

Dont normally like malty beers this much, but it is very good.  Good bitterness to back up the body, which seems  a little dry for the style, but i like it that way.  Good caramel and dark malt flavor.  head disappears quickly.
Bottle. Color is deep reddish amber with a white head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Flavor is dominated by sweet malts, sugary and doughy. Some detectable hop bitterness.

The rating issue comes to a head on this one.   It seems to me that this is perhaps my least favorite style.  When I look at my ratings I don’t want to fool myself into thinking I liked it. But, as I can see from the existing ratings - the consensus is that this is an excellent beer in the style. 
To me this tastes like burnt sugar mixed into carbonated water. It is so sweet as to be just about undrinkable. I hate this.  I can’t let it go. I can’t rate this highly given such a one-dimensional character. Smells sweet, drinks sweet, ends sweet. People, drink something else.

Nice sweet malt aroma. Golden copper amber color, and a tan? head that disappeared at once. Starts with sweet malt, a bit of bread and alcohol in the middle, and some hop at the end - but the sweet malt never disappears. Medium mouthfeel. A bit of mouth pucker after a while - indicates it’s not all sugar in there. Maybe a little coffee shows up. Enough balance that a West Coast hophead can enjoy it.

Color is deep reddish amber with a white head. Aroma is sugary and malty. Flavor is dominated by sweet malts, sugary and doughy. Some detectable hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is a bit syrupy. Flavor of alcohol is nil.
Pours dark reddish-brown, full tan head.  Rich malty aroma, very little hop bouquet.  Deep roasty, malt flavor.  Somewhat unbalanced.  Metallic finsih.
Dark amber with very little nose. No head, Bitter with carmel overtones. smooth finish
Amber with thin head little lacing.  Aroma caramel and alcohol.  Smooth mouth.  Flavor rich caramel with a sweet dry alcoholic finish.  DEcent beer for a German.

500ml bottle from Cask & Glass, Tonbridge. Clear russet colour with lasting beige head. Strong dry malt aroma., almost to the exlusion of everything else. Smooth in mouth. Lots more dry malt on the finish with some herby hop. Coo, didn’t realise it was 7.5%. Nice, but a little one dimensional i.e. lots of dry malt. Some dry choc towards the end, like a cheap supermarket own brand plain chocolate bar.  Herby hop on end lends a bit of balance.
Brown colour, big bubbly head. Strong bitterness, roasted miexed flavours of herbs, spices, malt or maybe even caramel. Extremely rich taste, drinks  awesomely well. Great doppelbock.

Bottle 0.33 l.
Heavy malty (cereal, toasted, hints of caramel) aroma; spicy notes with alcohol in the background.
Dark amber body with average light-brown creamy head; mostly diminishing with a fair lacing.
Flavour is dominated by the sweet of malt and spices, maybe with some bitter note at the beginning.
Medium body with a creamy texture; flat carbonation; moderate alcoholic feeling in the finish.
Beer for meditation; maybe a bit too sweet beacuse of malt and alcohol, but never nauseating. To taste.
Bottled. Pours a lovely dark, golden brew with no particles. Lovely cocoa scent. Salvator had a very strong fruity taste with hints of burnt caramel. Not bad.

17 oz bottle from local grocer. Medium size head, dissipates very quickly leaving a little lace. Reddish brown color, not as dark as some dopplebocks. Nice malty carmal smell with a hint of fruit. Very nice smooth taste, perfectly balanced between the malt and hops. Full bodied with a bit of sweetness, perhaps caramel. Nice aftertaste that could stand to linger just a tad longer. THis is a masterful brew that does a nice job showing why dopplebocks are my absolute favorite style of beer!

Powerful malty aroma, with hints of caramel, honey, roastedness (if there is such a word), alcohol and even a little grassy freshness. Dark amber colour with off-white big head that has a texture like whipped cream, but unfortunately doesn’t last very long. The taste is very malty with very little bitterness. The little bitterness that is sensed is probably more from the alcohol then from hops. The body is a little on the light side, and the lack of carbonation makes the alcohol sweetness a little bit to dominating and thereby stops Salvator from being one of the greatest beers in the world - now it is only extremely good.

(0.5L Bottle) Pours brown with medium sized head. A pretty good beer, but not as good as it is rated on this site. Sweet toffee and caramel tastes fade to a slightly bitter ending. Pretty average mouthfeel. Alcoholic taste from start to finish.

The nose on this is so comforting... immediately there is caramel and thick toffee that permeates the bouquet.  These accompany the flavor in the front palate.  After the intial sweetness, there is a small alcohol note on the back palate that permeates to the finish.  Mid-palate offerings are of honey and molasses.  The mouthfeel is medium, but for the bouquet and flavors at work, feels like it (the body) should be a bit more thick/syrupy.  A good brew here, and one that goes down well enough, just a bit unbalanced.  If the mouthfeel were a bit thicker, this brew would be one of my faves.  As it stands, I’m afraid that it may turn into a good beer that may be forgotten shortly.... and that’s unfortunate, given my rating.

Bottle:
Red colour, with a nice foam.Aroma of maltyness,chocolate.Smouth mouth felling of maltyness and bitter hops in cimbination, who make this German dark bock nice on a dark winter evening.
Medium finish, full body!

Bottle, dimpled mug 54F.  Malty notes are very dominate, a bit of roasted notes as well, maybe a touch of chocolate.  Clear light amber color, with a moderate tan head, minimal lacing,  Rich strong malt flavors, with decent amount of slightly bitter hops. Not too sweet but slighty sweet not very cloying.  Definitaly sweet start with a slighty bitter finish,  Finish fades a little quicker than I would like, notice a touch of straw.  Medium palate with a medium carbonation, mouthfeel is decent but not looming, nor does it really last long. It is good not as good as other german dopples but better than some american attempts.
Bottle. Creamy lightbrown excellent mostly lastinfghead. Wonderfull orangebrown colour. Very malty aroma. Malty alcoholic flavor. Average fijnish. Oily palate.

Pours amber with no head. Malty bready aroma with underlying fruit rind. A bit of caramel comes through as well. Taste is of malty chocolate with some caramel. A weak taste with an average palate. Slightly vinous alcoholic finish. Good, but not great.
Bottle. An amber coloured pour with a small head. Aroma of sweet malts. The taste brings more sweet malts along with honey and strong alcohol. A sweet, alcoholic finish. Not bad at all.
Big Foamy head that is beige in color.  The body is clear brown.  The amora is very malty.  The flavor is full, there is a sweetish malt present.  The finish is a bit on the tart side.  Good Beer

Consumed while watching the second half of the match Germany - Portugal on TV. My bottle (Alc. 7.9%) was bought at a supermarket in Stuttgart in April. Nice label design! Pours a dense, off-white head over a deep and clear brownish coloured content. Robust aroma of roasted malt and tart fruit. A pleasant plummy fruitiness dominates the flavour with hints of caramel and yeast. Bitter ending. German enjoyment in both bottle and at the Gottlieb-Daimler stadion.

It took a while to find this one, but it was worth looking for. Bottle.   Poured very dark amber with a tan head.  Big aroma of mails with carmel.  Some fruit appeared in the taste.  Very smooth considering the alcohol content.  While it was good in the mouth there was just a little bite.  Nothing wrong with this at all.  Like all great brews it somehow seems to come down to balance.  This one has it. I liked this brew.

Bottle. Pours a nice amber colour with an off-white head. Sweet malty aroma with some hints of caramel. Has a sweet smooth malty flavor with some hints of caramel. Sweet malty finish with some hints of bitterness.

Pours a semi-transparent reddish amber.  Creamy off white head that slowly fades to a thin film.  Little to no lacing.  Sweet, buttery aroma.  Super smooth, almost velvet like texture.  Taste is also sweet and fruity, but with significant alcohol.  The warming alcohol gives the beer a bite that finishes with a mix of sweetness and tangy bitterness.

Bottle.
I did not like this brew at all which is a shame becasue I’m a fan of dopplebocks. Very pungent sour smell and taste. Maybe my bottle was bad? I couldn’t not finish this one.

nice yellowish colored head
dark redish amber
caramel smell, plum smell, some alcohol,even some hidden citrus
smooth carbonation
dark, roasted caramel taste, bitter taste,malty but not too sweetish,some hidden citrus behind
aftertaste caramel, plums, nice hop bitterness, warm, not harsh alcohol
nice beer!!seems less strong than it is!

really excellent

a pleasure to the senses.

My score does not really reflect its quality, but I can’t up any of the ratings. 

Seems to be a case of the whole being greater than the sum of its parts.
Excellent Beer. Amber Colored beer with semi white head. Has a nice caramel smell...taste is fairly complex but very good

Light amber color with minimal white head. Aroma is a mixture of Munich malts and sweet caramel type malts. The flavor has a nice mixture of a couple types of malts to create depth. Very light hop influence. There is also a hint of yeast fruitiness. Very nice beer.

Bottle. Crystal clear, brilliant amber color. Nice average sized head. Rich, malty aroma with slight smoky caramelized character. Sweet caramel and roasted malt flavor, hint of molasses with mild alcohol warmth. Very smooth, very drinkable.
A good pour of dark amber with a good amount of off-white head.  Has a generous malty sweetness and mild hop bitterness.  Has little carbonation.  Overall, a very good beer.
It poured a dark honey color with light head.Caramel flavors balanced with mild hoppiness.  Has a molasses sweet after tase. Gives a nice toasty feeling after a few sips.

(Bottle ("produced on 1/06, 02663") via trade with Degarth, thanks Joe!) Pours a medium-dark burnt orange with about 1/2" of yellow-biege head that eventually recedes off. Rich aroma of malt, hay and honey. No real lacing. Mouthfeel light, a touch thin, very lightly sticky at end. Flavor is malt and honey sweetness, restrained and good, in no way harsh. Sort of an earthy quality as well. Decent doppel, probably most reminded me of Andechs in flavor but not quite as good.

Extremely chewy beer -- if H&H made a  darkwheat and raisin bagel, it would closely resemble this beer. It is nice to have a beer that can be sweet while still being light on on its feet. If only all Germans were so flirtatious! Really a lovely and important standard for this difficult style.

Poured an amber, slight orange color with a satisfactory initial head that did little after a few minutes. The aroma was caramel-like malts, very rich, very sweet. The flavor was obviously sweet and malty with a bitter finish and some definite spicing flavors. Some doughy flavors also present. Mouthfeel was smooth and moderate to thick. Not my favorite doppelbock, but not bad.
Clear brown ruby colour, nice lacing ecru head, intense aroma of bread, molasses, caramel and malt.  Lovely palate, sweet flavours of malt and toast.  Wish it didn’t have such metallic aftertones!
Clear dark caramel color with a small creamy off-white head. Aroma of sweet caramel and some molassas.  Sweet caramel flavor.

A darkish copper with a small head. Aroma is pretty big malt, molasses, caramel. A nice sweet malt flavor with hints of caramel, roasted nuts. Full bodied with a light bitter finish. Very nice overall.

Bottle, 500ml. Oh sweet mother of mercy, or whatever the German equivalent happens to be. The dark ruby colour, something which I’ve never seen before, fits with the blackberries in the aroma just perfectly. No foam just makes your mouth wet even more. Sweet taste, with an aftertaste even stronger. After a couple of minutes, a smokey tone appears at the back of the tongue. Wonderful.

Smokey caramel nose, with slight overtones of vinegar and wood. Cool label, vibrant orange/rust color with chainmail head which transforms to an inch of spongey foam which persists. Substantial mouthfeel, with an acidic aftertaste. Caramel and slightly metallic flavor, but I may come back and re-rate this on a cleaner palate. Paulaner again comes through with a crafty brew.
Malty and sweet, with understated hop profile.  Higher ABV noted only in the sweetness.
Slightly thick and syrupy sweetness. Very smooth and warming, ABV is not noticed except for the belly warming goodness.

Reddish copper, nice foamy head. Really enticing aroma - caramel, fresh toast, and even a touch of cognac. , perhaps some pumpernickle bread thrown in, as well. Nice, lively palate. Rye, pepper blend nicely with smooth, caramelly malts. Finishes with a touch of whiskey, and, uh, I’m gonna say walnuts, maybe?

Reddish brown. Excellent clarity. Fine tan headed diminished quickly. Malty, bready and yeasty flavors in the foreground with some rich melanoidin flavor. Some hop bitterness, spicy hop flavor and alcohol in the background. Medium-full body (gave a lighter impression due to carbonation). Warm finish from alcohol.  Very nice beer.

<!-- b -->Bottle:<!-- /b --> Red amber color with a light brown fizzy, bubbly head that dissipates pretty quick.  Strong sweet alcohol and malt aromas along with a hint of ripe bananas.  The taste is better than the aroma, but still malty.  You can taste the higher alcohol, but not too bad.  The body is full and rich -- smooth going down.  It is easy to see why this beer holds an overal 90% even though it is easily purchased in most locations.  I am glad to give the Salvator its 825th rating on the site.

In short: A well balanced and peppery twist on the Doppelbock style.  Highly drinkable, borderline session beer.

How: Bottle 330ml, many many times.  Consistent beer from batch to batch and year to year.

The look: Beautiful clear redish-copper body with a medium creamy white head.

In long: The malt is dominant (expected for the style) but is very well balanced by some pleasant peppery hops.  Caramel/toffee, brown sugar, earthy notes and ending on a grassy and peppery note.  I even tasted some strawberry although I seem to be the only one.  I especially liked the way the malt and hops flavours fused together instead of malt followed by hops.  Very mild bitterness, the finish is more earthy and peppery that bitter.  A very good beer.  To Germany I say, make beer not war.

Pours a dirty penny copper with a tiny light tan head.  Aroma of raisins, brown sugar, nuts, and a tiny bit of alcohol.  Taste of brown sugar up front, caramel and toffee malts, raisins again, into a slightly sweet finish.   Alcohol makes another small appearance.  Full bodied, light carbonation.  Very good beer.

A great surprise! I don’t know what I was expecting, but this was excellent. Orange-brown, light brown head that fades quickly. Sweet brown sugar aroma, along with something nutty or woody, I’m not sure. Sweet caramel flavours, woody/earthy, vaguely fruity. I’m not sure how the balance is accomplished, but this stayed delicious and enjoyable to the end despite its sweetness. Not as complex as Ayinger’s or Weltenberger’s, but excellent nonetheless.

From the bottle, (by itself) I would have given this beer a 5 on appearance if it hadnt been for the small head and almost no lacing. The color was beutiful like orange rust or a deep orange red sunset, the mini head was white with hints of caramel. The nose on this brew is delicious much more than the taste of it. You can sniff out Toffee, brown sugar, raisins and sweet oranges and bananas. The taste is a bit subdued buy the strong ethanol, but its still very nice, sweet and bitter, bubble gum, bannana, alchohol, toffee, raisins and something else maybe a little pine. Its complex and fun to savor, the finish is warming and medium bitter but not lasting a tiny astringent aspirin aftertaste lowers the score. The toffe and sweet caramel explodes when the bock warms up.. Excellent beer overall one of my favorite sippers.

0.5l bottle courtesy of a friend from Germany (thanks Daniel !)

 I’ve been looking for this one for ages now. Ever since I bought a 0.33l bottle of this in the El Corte Ingles in Barcelona instead of some old Chimay Blue that was next to it, and then never got to taste it because a classmate I shared my room with broke the neck of the bottle accidentally (in retrospective, I shouldnt’ve left it on the floor). I got a taste, but then I spotted shards of glass floating in the glass I poured into. Not enough for a rate. Well, a year and eight months after that, here it is. 

 This poured a very nice deep(ish) red colour with a big fluffy tan(ish) head that went down at a medium pace leaving absolutely no lacing. Strong aroma of honey with some hints of alcohol. Nice. The flavor is interesting. Not as cloying as I thought it might be. Malt, of course is the key word here, and it’s quite pleasant, some hints of caramel can be felt from time to time, maybe even some fruit - something like weak lemon gum candy, and alcohol. As most people have noticed it gets relatively cloying in the end, with a crude hoppy bitterness, that’s not that compatible with the nice maltiness. Weak, but persistent hoppy aftertaste. This is a nice beer, no doubt about it, but not as good as I thought it would be.

Difficult to rate, since although it has definite objective qualities, I didn’t really like it that much. Very pretty to look at and clearer than I’d expected, and the aroma is interesting and makes you want to taste it, but when you do, its overwhelming sweetness really ruins it. Way too much candy for my taste, and not bitter enough. Lots of interesting notes (lots of caramel, a bit of smoke etc.) makes it worth trying, but I for one will leave it at that!

Reddish, rusty brown pour with an offwhite head that dissapated quickly.  Taste is rich with malts, roastiness, brown sugar, and nuts.  Solid flavor throughout the beer, nice smooth finish with a sweet/roasted touch.  Nice brew.

Bottled. Rubyish red colour, mediumsized beige head. Sweet plummy aroma with hints of honey, nuts and malts. Flavour is sweet plummy and fruity with some hints of yeast. Pleasantly balanced brew, Mainly alcohol and malts in aftertaste.

Pours clear red with a one-finger off-white head that disappears rather quickly. Excellent aroma of caramel, toffee, honey, toast, and a bit of smoke. Very smoky, toasted flavor with a lot of the caramel coming through. A small amount of alcohol is perceptible. The finish is almost nothing, but it does leave a sweet, roasty aftertaste.

Dark red-amber with a thick head. Deep malt aromas of fruitcake, toffee and honey. Rich, sweet,  biscuity malts  combine with molasses and apple flavors to make this strong and filling. Sweet, chewy finish is checked by modest bittering hops. Thick and memorable.
Deep amber color with a light off white head.  A wonderful light toasted malt aroma.  Sweet caramel malt flavor.  Not much hops detected.   Medium body.  Not a bad beer.  Worth a try.
Pours a lightish brown with minimal head.  Sweet and malty.Caramel/toffee/brown sugar.  Slightly bitter finish.

made by monks like way back in the day? whoh. anyways... pours a ruddy-amber with a medium sized tan head. pick up an immediate texture and taste of molasses back in the throat. a bit overkill on the sweet malts. pick up some alcohol too. too sweet but o.k.
AMber with a good thick head.   Good aroma.  Good malty flavor that resinates in the mouth.  Suprisingly clean finish for a double bock.
Bottle 330ml. Appearance: amber with thin white head. Aroma: caramel, malt, alchool.  Flavor: caramel,  sweet malt, alchool.

50 cl bottle. No yeast at the bottom. Amber clear colour with a small head. Light aroma of caramel and quite malty endeed. Sweet malty flavour with notes of caramel, toffee and alcoholic. Not the best doppelbock I had.

Bottle: Salvator has a amber/ruby body. The head is pale yellow/white and short living. The nose is of sweet caramel, alcohol and with notest of nuts. The flavor is full of sweet toffe and alcohol. Nice sweet/ bitter finish
I would say this beer is a bit over-rated.  It is a fine German beer but not a "90."  I guess the Style percentile is a bit closer to the truth but for a German Dopplebock, I certainly expected more.
Not the best doppelbock around. Brownish colour with a small creamy white mostly lasting head. Aroma of sweet malts. Taste is dominated by the alcohol. Go for the Paulus at the brew pub ...

My first doppelbock. Hopeful not the last. Its a completely different style than anything I have had before. The aroma contains Carmel and Malt. The flavour is sweet with carmel. The hops really add to this beer. Thanks to Mrmanning for getting this one for me.

Bottle.  Poured a pristinely clear ruby caramel color with a thick, light tan, creamy head that would leave some pretty lacing.   The aroma was rich sweet malts, very inviting.  The taste was a mouthfilling sweetness, just borderring on too sweet with hints of dried fruit, currant.  The sweetness is rescued by a nice light bitter finish that is present briefly before being washed away by a now slightly diminished thick sweet tartness.  It is rich and smooth in the mouth with a gentle warming sensation.

Nice ruby-amber color and relatively light head of a tan tint. Strong fruitcake flavor and aroma from all that malt, with the slightest amount of hops on the finish. Seems more like a beer to have along with cheese, crackers or some other snack food. Quite cloying on the palate, but with food this wouldn’t be as important.

500ml bottle: poured brilliant orange with a small beige head. The head disappeared quickly and left absolutely no lacing of any kind. I was expecting something a lot darker. Big aroma of malt and a touch of brown sugar. Flavor is of course malty with a lingering sweetness. Alcohol is well hidden. Fairly thin body. Call this a bock instead of a doppelbock and you have a nice beer. This just doesn’t seem like a doppelbock to me.
Bottle.  Light brown creamy head. Beautiful dark red body showing the carbon dixide bubbles. Aroma of berries. Pleasant flavor with both sweetness and bitterness. Notes of caramel.

Cobber red with fast disappearing yellow/light brown head; Almost no nose, very little malt; Very simple, very full, quite sweet body with medium carbonation; Long simple sweet finish with any real taste. Very boring, very sweet beer.

Cobber colour with a thick sticky off-white head. Aroma is of bitter berries and malt. The taste is a bit unorthodox and gives the beer a sweetness through a lot of malt in the taste. Not much carbonation.
Very surprised with this beer.  A little more sweet than I expected, but not a bad thing. Nice tastes of red fruits, and alcohol was hidden.

I liked the looks of this, with its deep color and thick head,.  However, for me the aroma and finish were much too predominantly chocolate or toffee....seemed too sweet. This beer just did not do it for me.
Pours out a deep amber color with some hints of brown.  Aroma is that of sweet malts.  Flavor is very nice with a caramel note.

bottle - Pours a reddish brown color with a thin head.  The aroma is of roasted caramel malts.  The flavor is moderately sweet with caramel notes and is nicely balanced.  I notice a little alcohol in the flavor and finish, but it’s mild.  The finish is of roast malt and hops with a pleasant warming effect.

Pours an amber copper with a thin ring of light tan head.  Aroma of sweet caramel, dark fruits and wood with a roasted malt undertone.  Flavor of roasted malts with a nutty dark fruit finish... very little alcohol presence.  Delicious!

Red copper amber bock with a thin creamy off white head. Sweet caramel aroma, with fruity and vinous notes. In mouth, a sharp malt, with lots of nuttyness, and smooth alcohol. Note as sweet as remembered. Rich and viscous mouthfeel. Fresh from LCBO. 1.90$.
Bottle: Impressive, intense aroma, fruity, notes of red fruits, wood. Taste is rich and complex, good balance with the alcohol level.

On tap at Everybody’s pizza.  This one was tasty.  I am liking this style.  Pours a brown color with red hues, big white head.  Smells spicy and caramely.  Tastes smooth and malty.  Full bodied and easily drinkable.  Get this one again.
this brew reminds me of a sunny day, but there are clouds with a little sun, but the sun shines through, but the clouds are pretty big.

Bottle: Amber to copper coloured, smaller off-white head, slowly diminishing; sweet (toasted) malt, mainly molasses or liquorice in the aroma, (port-)vinous traces detectable, hops in the backyard; sweet-malty flavour, full bodied; mild, shorter sweetish-bitter finish, wine, raisins and alcohol, again. A rich, well balanced, warming brew, but a world-classic.................?

Draught at 42nd Street Oyster Bar in Raleigh, NC. Murky reddish brown color with thin off white head. No lace. Malty aroma full of dried fruit and alcohol. Flavor is rich and complex including figs, port, caramel, and brown sugar. Sweet, very slick and oily with a warm alcohol effect at the end.

(Bottle) Pours amber with disappearing white head. Nose is malty with fruity notes. Taste is nicely balanced between sweetness and bitterness. Notes of dried fruits, toffee and spices are present. Well done!

Clearly the archetype of all doppelbocks . Pours out a ruddy amber color with very little head. Aromas of dried apricots, prunes, and a pleasant sweetness. Flavors of prune, flavored tobacco, cassis, and port. Perfectly balanced with just a touch of sweetness. Great for dessert at the end of the night.

Brown bottle, 330 ml; expiry date: 10.05; eye: little head that disappears quickly, copper in color with light caramel reflections; nose: caramel, bread (from the yeast), floral hops; taste: after the initial sip, nothing but then an explosion of caramel in the mouth, lightly bitter and even more lightly sweet, the sweetness prolongs itself, ho, a hint of alcohol and then sweetness again, sweentess and alcohol then dances together

FRANÇAIS
Bouteille brune, 330 ml; date d’expiration : 10.05; oeil : très peu de mousse qui disparaît rapidement, cuivrée avec des reflets caramels, clair; nez : caramel, pain (levure), houblon floral; bouche : après la première gorgée, rien, puis une explosion de caramel en bouche, légère amertume, très légèrement sucré mais le sucré se prolonge en bouche, pointe d’alcool, puis le sucré et l’alcool danse ensemble

Clear copper pour with thin, off-white head that quickly disappeared. Pleasant, sweet aroma of caramel and molasses. Hints of pastry dough. The flavor was sweet malts — brown sugar, caramel — with a lingering bitterness. Thin approaching medium body, but with some rich, syrupy qualities in the finish. In general, smooth with little carbonation, reminiscent of a barley wine.

A nice hearty dopple to warm thy belly. Sweet ruby red auburn, rather clear. Head is  a smallish albeit creamy off white. Nose is all sweet caramel malts and some light bitter hops. Maybe a bit of cherries in there as well. Taste is more of the sweet malt, toffee, and some yeast and spices. Ends bitter. Dry hopped. Alcohol not evident.

A deep amber orange coloured beer with a very weak head. A strong liquorice nose, sweetness, an almost Sherry aroma with hints of orange, chocolate and malt. An effevescence on the tongue, a refreshing citrus taste immediately belies its strength. Followed by a rich, smooth sweet maltiness.

(bottle) Clear copper colour with a firm foamy beige medium head. Intense but moderately sweet malts-accented aroma with toasted notes, caramel, liquorice and light herbal hops. Sweet malty flavour, full bodied, almost oily texture; full malts accented (toasty and slightly fruity) taste with caramel; moderately sweet malty finish with a distinctive and slightly sharp alcoholic note with a bitter and herbal hoppy blend. A good but definitely not perfect classic Doppelbock.
Very well done. Beautiful amber in color w/ slight malted nose. Perfect ballanced flavors w/ a touch of sweetness. Alcohol is well hidden. I highly recommend.
this nigga means business, and demands respect as a doppelbock!!! I have been enjoying for a while/

bottle. Very cola-like appearance with a bit more red tints. The nose is thickly sweet of cola and caramel. I was a little afraid to take a sip, but once I did I was quite relieved. There’s more spices evident in the mouth: some nutmeg and cloves, even a bit of bark and raisins. It is predominantly the sweet caramel taste, but it’s not as overbearing as the aroma cautioned me.

Great beer.  Malty and sweet aroma.  A mix of malt sweetness, dark fruits, candy sugar.  Very pleasing.  The appearance is a nice copper red, also very appealing.  The flavor is sweet, malty, bready, fruity.  Enimently enjoyable.  Nice thick mouth feel, as one would expect from a double bock. I can see how monks once brewed this beer to consume in lieu of food.  The finish is perfect, a crisp hop bite.  BTW, this is a re-rate, I love the beer more now than I did before.

Nice deep red color, small white head, and a slightly sweet aroma (though not much).  Excellent malty flavor with an excpetional mouthfeel (smooth, medium-body).  I really enjoyed this Paulaner doppebock -- it stands up to Paulaner’s reputation.  I highly recommend.
pours a clear copper with minimal head and lacing.  caramel, malt, and spice in the aroma.  taste is malty with some sweetness and light hoppy finish.  liked it, didn’t love it.

Very nice drinkable 7.5 beer.  Huge and powerful malty nose with spices and alcohol -- easily the best part of this beer.  The res is well above average, but nothing terribly noteworthy.  It’s just a nicely done malty german beer that tastes a bit like an arrogant bastard type american strong ale minus the hops... which may or may not be a good thing, depending on who you are.
Amber color with a small white head. Caramel/malt flavor, some carbonation and mildly hoppy. A bit complex and hard to pin down, but a good beer.

Whoa - Molasses! Nice pour. Tan head with lace that comes back whenever you swirl it. Malty. Kind of sweet and as mentioned...molasses. Very nice, but the sweetness can get to be a little much after 2 bottles. Nice kick at 7.5% abv,but it’s evident.

Appears dark red with a bready beige head.
A bitter sweetness, a bit sticky.  Buttery thick, soothing taste with a hoppy finish.

Øl (50 cl) købt i Tyskland.

Øllen er klar rød, og har næsten ingen hvidt skum (falder hurtigt). Virker meget sprittet fra start, men bliver bedre efterhånden som den bliver varmere.

Smagen er bitter-sød, og maltagtig.
Great frothy head that stay for the duration. Full body with a lot of flavor. A very good specimen...

Great doppelbock from paulaner brewerie.  Although it is quite rich and full, it is not overpowering.  Lasts shortly on the palate, and the flavor is somewhat spicy, but less than some of the other German doppelbocks.  The color is not too "cola-like" either.
Bottle. An excellent Doppelbock. Not too sweet, but very malty. Clean tasting. Quite rich. Nice copper color.

Bottle.  Pours coppery mahagony with a tall foamy tan head and sticky lacing.  Medium roasted caramel malt (meal) and yeast (sweat, earth) aromas with dark fruit (prune, plum) and port notes.  Moderate bitterness and acidity, medium sweetness and malty flavor, fruity hop and alcohol round out the flavor.  Warm and full bodied, spicy palate.
Bottle.  Darkish red colored pour with a small head.  Smoked cherry wood, spicy kinda sweet flavor.  Not bad, but I didn’t enjoy it as much as I thought I would.  May have to try this again later.

This beer has lost some character over the years. Clearly this beer has been re-formulated to reach a larger audience. Its still VERY well made, but the magic for me with this beer, has slipped. What was once a stellar example of dopplebock, has become a very good one, but a shadow of what it once was. Salvator pours to a bright, deep caramel color, with a thick, white head, and a good bit of carbonation. The nose as some good sweet malty, nutty, and toasty malt aroma. The body is firm, with some good sweet malty, and toasty malt flavor. Finishes clean, with good sweet and toasty malt, with a slight, alchol burn. Still an excellent dopplebock, but once had much more depth in malt aroma, flavor, and character over all.  10 years ago this beer would have been a 5.
love this beer hints of licorice and brown sugar liked it because it was easy to drink for being 7.5 ABV give it a try.
Pours a clear dark amber, very thin head. This was very very sweet big caramel, brown sugar taste, with a very nutty and malty aftertaste. Very different from other dopplebock’s I have had.

Medium offwhite creamy head with larger bubbles. Dark red body. Deep aroma of licorice and bread and deep firm malts. Intense grainy sweet hoppy taste of corn, alcohol and caramel. Harmonic. Oily. A fantastic beer.
Nice rusty red colour with a foamy head.  Malty armoma.  The malt continues strongly in the mouth.  Slightly thick.  Warm aftertaste.
Extremely malty, almost to a fault, but very drinkable nonetheless.  A little light on the palate. A nice double bock that is easy to find at local grocery store.

Ah, a double bock that lives up to its billing!  Pours a deep amber from the bottle, off-white head that dissipates quickly leaving thin lacing.  Aroma is full malt, nutty with some hops.  The flavor is outstanding!  All of the flavors (malt, nuts) come at you at the same time, but subtly.  The palate is medium, syrupy, silky.  Just a hint of hops and alcohol in the aftertaste.  What a way to celebrate my 100th review!
Pours a copper colour with a big beige head. Bready aroma, nice malty character. A very fine bock.

This a great beer........  It pours a copper red color that is very nice and it’s aroma and flavor are unmatched in the doppelbock area.  It has a silky smooth taste that is well balance leaning towards the carmelized malts!!!!  This is one of my favorite beers anytime of year!

Bouteille de 330 ml, acheté à l’SAQ de Centropolisse (Laval), rebu ce soir. Rousse caramel, presqte pas de collet. Arome de malte caramelisé, un peu de scotch doux et une petite sensation d’alcool. Goût de caramel anglaise alcoolisé, malte sucré. Bien faite de l’avoir rebu!

One of the true Dopplebocks out there. If you have an opportunity to purchase this "liquid gold", then don’t hesitate to do so. The pour immediately produces a medium-sized off-white head that dissapates fairly quickly. Notes of caramel, chocolate are pronounced in the aroma. A rather sweet, strong malty flavor and an EXCELLENT example of how a dopplebock should be. There is little alcohol taste and a stong sweet aftertaste. This one is ALWAYS stocked in my house, it’s usually easy to find and it goes well with most foods, especially Italian food.
Pours deep amber with quickly dissipating head.  Very little carbonation.  Caramel notes.  Sticky malt flavor.  Quick, sweet finish.

Review No. 100: I’d been saving my first bottle of Salvator for a special occasion.  It didn’t disappoint.  Ruby brown / amber pour with little and soon no head.  Lots of carbonation.  Super strong aroma of caramel with a touch of toffee.  Alcohol was also clearly present amidst that almost sickly-sweet malty aroma.  Has a bite!  Sweet malty start on the tongue, a bit smokey, smoked wood.  Herbal bitterness in the finish, and a bit of a disappointing, lingering off-flavor.  Well-balanced between the hops and malts.  Thick and syrupy texture, left my lips sticky.  Warming.  Despite the excessive sweetness, a good one, though I still prefer the Andechser. [3.5]

Update: Just getting around to this six pack of 0,33’s.  Immediately hit by a rush of grape aroma, can’t believe I didn’t notice it the first time around.  The last bottle was certainly more vinous than the first ... wlll have to "research" further. [3.6]

"Poured an orangey color with an average head which disapated quickly. Aroma was of caramel, and smelled very very sweet. Tasted sweet with some kind of spices and yet slightly bitter as well. Good beer. but not the best "

This is one of the best beers I have tasted.  Definetly high on my top ten list.  The flavor was excellent.  The alcohol content is excellent without any alcohol flavor.  Price was 1.95 U$S dollars in Utah.  Would be a perfect score if it was around $1.50 a bottle.

Pours dark amber with a large tan head.  Aromas of wheat bread, raisins, molasses, caramel, plum, macademia nuts, and apple.  Slightly sweet taste with a nice bitter complexity.  Has a nutty bread taste and is excellently balanced.  Starts of sweet with caramel notes but ends with a hoppy bitterness.  Has a good presence on the palate but there is an odd aftertaste that I can’t quite place - it’s almost metalic.  It takes away a lot from the beer.

Bottled. Alcoholic aroma, apple, malty. Dark amber color, beige almost creamy head, very nice lace. Sweet, light bitter to pretty herbal bitter in the finish, apple, alcoholic, very sticky, soft. Pretty standard bock in the non-roasted style.

(01.12.06)  One pint, 0.9 fl oz brown bottle purchased from DiCarlo’s, Mundelein, IL.  7.5% ABV. Bottle label states that beer was produced on 08.05. Lot 21753. Clear reddish amber double bock ale having a large long-lasting white head with good lacing. Soft carbonation.  Aromas of malt, bread dough, and caramel.  Full bodied with smooth and creamy texture that starts with light malt sweetness and caramel flavor.  Finishes with a light sweet malt and slight metallic aftertaste.  This is a smooth drinkable beer but its odd aftertaste is a turn-off.

orange color, tan head, sweet rich and malty tasting.  not bad, very easy to drink.  my beer was gone quick in anticipation for some others.  not a bad one, and something i have wanted to try for quite some time, glad i found this one.  nice brew.

When I ordered this deep red doppelbock I misread the menu and called it the salivator.  It could almost be called this.  Very smooth with some fruit and other crisp notes.  I liked this one a lot, but not as much as the optimator.

330 ml Bottle, 7.5% a/v
Pours a gorgeous ruby red with a dense off white head. Smells of plums and other fruity notes. Tastes of sweet fruity tones as well. A tad spicy but VERY well balanced. Thick aftertaste which is wonderfully delicious. 
Definetly going to get another few bottles of this!

Good, even very good.  Heartier than others in this category it had a rich fruity taste.  Deep color, little head.  Not the best in the land but it was damn good.  Will order again.  Would have been cooler had it been named the Salivator...(like a Celebrator or an Optimator.)
Pours a lovely reddish color with a thin white head. Light plum and raisins in the aroma with a hint of wood. Deliciously sweet and malty with more raisins and plums. Thick mouthfeel. Very enjoyable.

I wanted the bottle, but with the cap, anyway, they did not give to me. The flavour is sweet, but a little tiring after a while, a little spicy, and looks like a dark cedric. PErhaps it is unfiltered.

Pours a reddish amber, a little lighter than expected. Head is tan, thin and frothy. Nose is sweet toasty malts with hints of alcohol. Flavor is sweet and crisp, with roasted malts gettin’ in there. Has a nice affect on the tongue.
Amber coloured, thin tan head. Woody, citric, sugary, raisin nose. Spicy flavour with notes of brown sugar and chocolate.

Pours amber with a foamy light tan head. Aroma of rich caramel, extreme maltiness, raisins, and slight breadiness.  Taste is chewy bready malts. It is sweet without being cloying, strong without the alcohol being noticable. Instead you are left to enjoy a thick, sticky beer with a heavy mouthfeel and mild carbonation. A standard, solid example of doppelbock. Still, this pales in comparison to Celebrator or Maximator.
rich, creamy, sweet, and mellow.  has a carmel flavor with good feel...good carbonation level and great aroma...great sweet after dinner beer.

Molasses, alcohol, raisins in nose.  Dark orange color with fast-disappearing off-white head.  Sugary, caramel, sticky then hoppy palate. Could be my favorite beer ever?  Love the perfect simplicity of the classic German beers.
amber body with small head...aroma is full of chocolate, toast, spice, sugar, and raison....flavor is heavy in chocolate, toast, nuts, cherry, and molasses...nice palate, and a great beer

Bottle poured a clear copper with a lasting amber head. Aromas of raisins, molasses, and a hint of spices. Palate was medium bodied and slightly syrupy. Flavors of sweet malt, molasses, and a hint of dark fruit with a sweet, lingering finish.
Pours a beautiful golden amber. Nice high sweetness with aromas of lots of sweet malts, fruits (plums & prunes) and a hint of nuts. Very full, very filling.
Smells sweet and malty.  Tastes:chocolate malt.  --Extremely-- smooth, as smooth as beer comes to hot chocolate.  Sweet malt.  full mouthfeel.  Warming, filling, and good warm.

Poured a deep copper color with an offwhite head.  Spicy, bready, malty caramel aroma.  Nice malty backbone, some spiciness in the middle, mildly hoppy finish.  This gets much better as it warms up.  Medium mouthfeel, slightly warming.  A solid doppel.  Merry Christmas!
Lovely amber color with a diminishing head.  Light yeast boquet, with an aroma and flavour of honey.  The palate is thin and slick, finishing up with a mild hoppy bitterness.

A deep muddy brown ale color, with not too much of a head.  Has roasted aromas, with notes of sweetness.  The taste however was overpowering with sweetness, though it was a touch too malty, but had some cinnimon, clove, tastes a little.
Pours a nice deep dark amber.  Aromas of caramel and dark malts.  Flavors a molasses, fruit and mild hopping.

Deep amber with a large tan head that slowly fades away leaving beautiful lacing.  Aroma of rich sweet malt.  Full sweet flavor with a nice spicy hop finish for balance.  The original and one of the best.
Pours amber, light head with lacing on the glass. The balance is exceptional, with a bit of sweetness followed by a hoppy bitterness. Alcohol is hidden very well. Excellent beer.

I’ve had a few times, pours clear amber color with a small head that dissipates quickly.  Nice malty aromas with a touch of hops coming through.  Taste is also malty, but not oversweet.  This is a good choice, but it is still not a Celebrator.

Its tough to rate another doppelbock after when the first one you ever had was a Celebrator.  Pours is clear amber with a medium head.  Malty aroma with some fruits and yeast.  Taste is more sweet than bitter, like there is a pale ale hiding in there.  The alcohol is masked well.  A very good beer, but definitely not a Celebrator.

This beer pours a deep amber color with a small tan head.  It has a very malty breadlike aroma almost spicey.  The flavors are bery deep and malty like dough.  very rich beer.  One of the better, if not the best, paulaner beers.  Cheers!

Pours a dark amber with a decent one finger head that faded away pretty quickly and left a good ring with lots of lacing.

Smell; caramel, apples, bread dough. Smells really good. In fact, I think it smells better than it tastes.

Taste; malts, honey, apples, caramel, followed by little hoppy bitterness. I can’t really taste any aolcohol. It goes down really easy at first, but after a while it almost becomes to sweet for me. Mouthfeel is medium/full with just enough carbonation.

my second fave-o-rite dobble bock. nice dark roasty raisiny smells and colors. tastes even more so. really warms up the ’ol insides. nice head that stays with ya down to the last drop. these are good to have around when your trying to add wood to your smoker in a snow storm. just had one last week....no snow,but who cares!
this is the original but doesn’t have the complex layers that Celabrator has, which isn’t always a bad thing.
A very nice dopplebock.  A slightly fruity aroma to me.  Definitely tasted and felt the alcoholic. Extremely good.

500 ml bottle, bought in Bier Spezi Hamburg. Reddish amber colour, large orange to light tan head. Surprisingly alcoholic aroma, elements of molasses, caramel and syrup, hints of dried dark fruits, port wine and oak. Flavour is also rather alcoholic, malty sweet (a little too sweet for me) with plenty of caramel and molasses, a herbal spiciness and moderate hops in the finish. Not nearly as good as the much darker Weltenburger Kloster Asam Bock, but still a very powerful beer in any way. Definitely a "winter warmer".

Hmmm. Perhaps it’s just that my first bottle of Celebrator was old or something, but I’m finding Salvator to be a much richer beer. It poured a deep, reddish amber with a thin, foamy head. Aroma is nice: malty with a touch of caramel and maybe dark cherries/plums. Flavor is sweet and smooth, malty with a subtle bitterness on the back end. Extremely good.

Pours a clear brownish-red with little or no head.  Sugary aroma with a malty undertone to it that is quite pleasant.  Warming mellow first taste with toffee notes and subtile alcoholic taste with a sugary palate.  Definately a blood warmer.  A fine brew!

Maybe it isn’t fair to make comparisons, but life isn’t fair, or I wouldn’t have had a summer’s worth of drinking (temporarily) underpriced Ayinger Celebrators before I had my first Salvator. So, the negative: Salvator doesn’t have the richness and  layers of flavor that border on Belgian-depth that Celebrator has. But Salavtor is very good, and 25% cheaper, so I’m thinking this will end up being my stock doppelbock. To the beer: Even with the sniffles tonight, I get the strong fragrance of compote and similar dark-sugary aromas. It pours a beautiful red-brown (more red than brown) with almost no head. A hit of carbonation yields to a medium-bodied, sweet sip that finishes with a pleasing soft sourness and refreshing bitterness, which cuts the sweetness. I love just swirling the glass and smelling it. Found it for $9 per six-pack at store on Addison and Leavitt.

Thanks to gputty for sharing this with me on a Friday afternoon! Coppery pour with a decent head. Nose is sweet malts, molasses, breadlike, gingerbread-ish really. Flavor is sweet, gingerbread, molasses/brown sugar. Mellows as it warms, drops back to a toffee and malt flavor. Pretty rich, sticky, but not in an unpleasant way. Good in front of a fire on a chilly night!

Bottle from Florida. Pored a hazy brown color with an average creamy light brown head that diminished slowly. Heavy fruity malt aroma. Medium to full body with a rich sticky  texture. Full flavor with a long pleasing finish.

Amber-brown color, with a tan-colored head, with an extra malty nose, with caramelized malt, fruity, nutty, sweet roasted malt and toffee aromas follow through on a medium-bodied sweet palate with an expressive malty character, sweet toffeish accent, hint of butterscotch, roasted malt, caramel malt, leading towards a sweet note but showing a shy hoppy finish.
The problem with this stuff is it tastes too good, and at 7.5% that can be a problem.
