This is a mild doppel.... sweet, yet balanced.  Smeels like bread dough.  Fills up your mouth.  Smooth like movie star skin. Re rate:  After a few more ratings I must give this a higher score,  It is far better than a 3.5, in my opinion.

Came out of the bottle copper colored with a light tan head on her. I get a sweet bready hop aroma. With a sweet bready hop taste. Some of the hops stick around for a while but don’t over stay there welcome.  I’m enjoying it but I liked Spaten’s Optimator better. It has more malt flavorings

Bottle.  Poured a nice bold copper color, cloudy with a decent tan head.  The aroma was a nice blend of malt, apple cider and apricot.  The flavor was rich with apricot, caramel, yeasty bread, and malt with a bit of a bitter finish.  Very complex, very nice.  Nice and full bodied on the palate, well textured.  Great beer for the fall, I enjoyed it.
Pours a nice bright amber brown with a white head.  It is malty and sweet like honey in the nose and has similar taste with some nutty darker flavors.  A very smooth and solid beer.

This is said to be one of the most legendary beers in the world ... once poured you can see why ... the sheer beauty of the amber-garnet colour is mindboggling ... the smell is full, butter, malt and candied fruits ...
the taste is of almost barley-wine like strenght with dominating english toffee and darjeeling ending in a long moreish light bitter finish ....

This is truly a great beer, albeight not for the uninitiated ...

as it is a seasonal beer for spring I’ll try another one in 6 months (and let you know) ....

Bottled (BB 02/2006)

Dark copper brown, big creamy brownish head, lace. Malty, ryeish, shapr, almost metallic aroma. Malty, burnt sugar and bread in flavor, some brown sugar and burnt molasses. Quite industrial dubbelbock. Hides alcohol quite well. (4/4/4/3/11 2.6)

Re-rated, bottle (BB 10/2007), alc. 7.9%

Clear amber color, decent off-white head. Toasted malty, slightly sugary aroma. Very balanced malty with notes of toasted grains and rye, light fuityness. Light tickling alcohol, malts and sugars in the aftertaste. Warming and balanced. (6/4/7/4/15 3.6)
All taste critiqing aside, this beer is fun for those of us that like occasionally going on power-trips.

Aroma: Fruity, with notes of apricots and caramel. ... Appearance: Dark amber, with consistent head. ... Flavor: Reminds me of dried apricots, finishes hoppy and dry. ... Palate: I found the after taste a bit too dry and bitter for my liking.  Overall: A unique and solid selection, but I wouldn’t go out of my way to drink it again when something better is around.
Bottle that must of been old!  Not what a excepted for such a high rated Doppelbock. The finish was a little bit smoky. Will try again.

A lovely clean copper with vibrant oranges and a creamy full tan head.  The aroma is big sweet carmel malts and a somewhat sharp fruityness is very presant.  Tangy and very full flavor.  Carmelt taste and feel coats the mouth.  Residual fruityness and a bit of alcohol head covers the tongue.  Plesant doppelbock, this obviously fits the style since it originated it.  It is a very nice beer.
chocolate malt, coffee, and hops aroma.  surprising amber color.  carmel malt flavor.  not as rich as i expected.  sort of bland.  very malty and boring.

Bottle. Dark amber with dense beige head. Sweet, malty aroma. A bit warming too. Balanced flavours of malt, caramel and some alcohol. Aftertaste is caramel, malt, alcohol and a light bitterness. (051004)

A tasty Doppel, this one pulls no punches in its flavor, but is still more drinkable than some others in the style.  Although lighter in color, its taste is a complex mix of toffee and raisins, with an underlying malty sweetness.

Bottle: Clear walnut colour with a nice-looking yellowy head. Initially the aroma was tangy, vinous, and sherry-like, with some ’red’ toffee notes. As it opened up some earthy sap-like qualities (that worked) emerged along with a touch of sticky date.Flavours of smokey caramel and burnt sugars dominated. In the first few minutes there were some mettalic cardboard flavours evident. However, as it come to room temperature this was rounded out with some nice complex dried fruits. Again the initial mouth feel was a little harsh but developed nicely. Very well structured.
Aroma reminds me of chocolate. OK, there is little head, but who cares (at least not me)? Just the fine malty aroma you would expect from a Doppelbock.
Deep amber color. Malty aroma. Sweet taste of caramel, raisins but not oversweet. Very enjoyable actually !

Dark orange/red in color.  no head to speak of.  Sweet, caramel malt aroma.  Not exactly a lot of stimulation on the nose.  Sweet caramel malt flavor also with a bit of dark fruit maybe.  The flavor is more interesting than the aroma.  Definitely drinkable and worth trying to form your own opinion.

Maple syrup and pancakes on the nose. Nice pour from a bottle with short head and some lacing. Reddish brown, clear color. Very appetizing and I have not even taken a sip yet. The first sip is malty sweet with notes of bourbon and a slight candy nut flavor...maybe caramel with some pecan. Finish is smooth with minimal bitter. Nice, easy beer with lots of maltiness all the way down to the bottom of the glass.
Bottle.  Taste is almost all malt.  Really malty.  Nice full mouthfeel, the alcohol is not very noticeable, which is nice. A sweet beer.  Not my fav, but not bad.

Pours a stunning clear deep amber, with a nice fluffy off-white head. Aroma is sweet slighty burned caramel, very little hops or anything else notible. The palate is full bodied, but not overpowered by alcohol. Similar flavours to the aroma, burned caramel, brown sugar and rum, with a low bitterness. There is some alcohol present in the finish, and a little lingering sweetness. Overall... fantastic

Not much on the aroma.  Some malt, some caramel maybe,  but the flavor was quite another story.  Right off, it was nutty and roasty.  Then it settled in to revel the alcohol, and a nice bit of dried fruit.  Not bad, but I’ve had better.
good winter beer - can’t taste the alcohol at all.  Smooth as silk nice aroma and color.  Another good product by Paulaner

A wonderful tasting beer with a warming alcohol finish. The aroma is both good and bad. It is sweet and caramel like but it also has a basement (maybe its the yeast) like smell. The appearance is a red brown with a nice head. The Flavor is sweet but not overly so. It has lots of caramel taste, raisins, and toasted malt. The aftertaste is like brown sugar. Highly recommended.

Decent orange pour with a small, pretty thin head. Aroma was the highlight, with a good malty fullness and a bit of a sugary, vegetably touch. Flavor is similar but browns out early with little if any noticable hop and pretty much aftertaste. Creaminess on the palate is good and promising but still feels thin for the most part. This certainly is no Ayinger Celebrator DB, which is easier to find, cheaper, and better... I don’t like to mention other beers in reviews but this one seems pretty blatant. Variety is certainly always good though.

surprisingly smooth. not much head but decent burnt caramel color. a little malt a little raisin a little taste alittle alcohol on the swallow. drinkable but i was expecting mucgh more flavor from paulaner.
Pours a brown body, almost no head. Aroma is sugary and malty - caramel and raisiny. Hint of alcohol. Flavor is the same, easy drinking - but lacking complexity.

Big caramel, sugar, malt anr raisins in the nose.  Brownish red color.  Yeasty, pale malt flavor.  Also toffee notes.  Smooth and delicious.  The savior delivers once again!  Granted, there are dopllebocks that are better, but for the price, I just keep coming back.  Its a great beginner dopplebock that sometimes doesn’t require an evolution.
Poured thin. No head. Was looking for a little more. Not a strong paulaner product.

Poured with a very decent sized and moderately lasting creamy head on top of a clear deep amber/copper coloured brew. The nose is toffee and loads of malt, and some raisins. Slightly bitter, with some of the raisiny sweetness coming through at the finish. A good doppelbock, and a good beer for that matter all round
Big malt, somewhat complex flavors, alcohol is evident in the aroma.  Not my favorite style of beer but this is one that I can drink more than one of.

Bottle: Coppery caramel, fairly clear, large off-white frothy head, thick pancake batter like lacing, few streams of heavy carbonation.   Heavy bready nose, slight fig/date, seems like it will also be fairly sweet.   Definite whole wheat bready aspect, slight apple skin, some fig/date or otherwise dark pitted fruit, yet not too sweet.   Malty, big time.   Big body, moderate to full mouthfeel.   Big finish, sweet, yet with an unripened fig/date like flavor near the finish.   Probably one of the better easily available Doppelbocks.
Robe rouge cuivrée très claire surmontée d’une mousse fugace. Arôme de sucre d’orge très prenant. Saveurs de malt, d’alcool et de caramel.

One of my favorite beers, honestly, although I’m partial to the style in general. Only moderately inferior to Celebrator, in my opinion, and arguably better by simple virtue of being much more inexpensive. Full bodied, deceptively strong, sweet on the entry, and just the slightest hint of hop on the finish. A beer I point people towards to define Doppelbock. (If they don’t want to pony up extra for Celebrator)

Bottle. Pours a clear ruby with a spare off-white head. Aroma was too sweet, all caramel malt to my nose. It smells O.K. but it’s dull. The flavour is malt, malt, malt & malt. There’s nothing else there! Others mention hops but I couldn’t taste any. The aftertaste is a bit harsh. On the plus side it hides the 7.5% very well. Quite mediocre.

From the bottle.  Thick rocky head that stuck to the side of the glass.  A sustaining brew with a rich and creamy mouthfeel.  Sweet at first with fermented apples and vanilla.  Finished with a peppery alcoholic flare.  The more I drank the smoother it went down.
Pours a dark copper color with a good amount of head.  Big malty nose.  Sweet taste and alcohol isn’t very noticeable.  A little bitterness in the aftertaste.  A solid beer, nothing great.
Big malt and light hop aromas.  Clear garnet read with a big creamy head.  Big caramel malt flavor with some roast and hop bitterness.  Very full bodied with pleasant carbonation.  Outstanding.

Bottle (330ml).  Poured a startling brilliant ruby-orange, hazy and bubbly, with a very quick diminishing off-white head, absolultely no lacing.  Aroma ligthly malty, some sour wine, strong orange juice, some yeast, ash, wood and leafiness.  Taste is fairly woody and fungal, with more strong orangey maltiness and some hops to make it less sweet - a bit of sourness, tannins and burned candy too.  Extremely flat and lifeless mouthfeel knocks it down a peg or two.  Not really a summer beer.

12 oz bottle( November 2004 vintage): Poured a leather brown color and had a fizzy head that broke up leaving the beer naked. Aroma had a strong breaking point of sweet malt, while also maintaining a fig and cigar like scent. After having a drink, i found a striking resemblance to a old barley wine style or perhaps a barleywine in the English style. Notes of cookie dough, vanilla, fig, tobacco, and minor tasting of malt in the background. Overall, i figure it unbalanced and having a poor carbonation level which makes this a mediocre doppelbock in comparison to others.

A nice golden brown color with a light brown head.  A caramel aroma and a hint of floral.  A light hop bitterness at first but quickly becomes sweeter in taste, somewhat light syupy.  Despite the alchohol content the presence is barely apparent.  A very nice warm finish to the beer.
Tastes malty, with a hint of caramel. Almost has a sweet sense to it. Definite alcohol warmth, but you don’t taste it. Smooth finish. Overall, a decent beer. Well worth a try.

From the bottle: pours an attractive reddish copper with a fizzing tan head that fades quickly. Aroma is a ripe fruit and  alchohol with some sweet malty and floral  tones . Smells quite decadent (reminds me of a light tawny port)
Flavour is not dominated by the alcohol as I thought it might be. Quite malty with a sharp persistent carbonation.  A caramel sweetness works well and the overall impression is a fine beer that has some depth to it’s character but finishes smooth and well rounded with minimal aftertaste
my first dopple bock. Intresting, particularly malty. Il need to have this again as i was quite drunk when i had it, but seemed good stuff at the time.
[bottle from magic_dave6] pours dark brown with a quickly collapsing head. nose is very malty sweet notes of caramel and fruit. decent body , a little sickly.

Bottle. Pours ambergolden with a thick off-white/orange head. Sweet, malty aroma with notes of rye and hops. Becomes more wine-like as it warms. Flavour is fruity with rye and well-balanced alcohol. Faint perfumy note in the aftertaste, though. Smooth, soft palate.

A rich and clear caramel hue evinces malty sweet delectation awaiting.  Creamy and off-white, the head is not mountainous, but it matters not.  A simple aroma of dark bread, boil caramelization, honey and dried flowers belies the commercialization of this beer.  A robust sweetness and tender bitterness are frustrated by malapropos acidity.  Unfermentable sugars furnish a copious body and glutinous texture, but the mouthfeel is set back by aggressive carbonation.  A go-to grocery store beer but it’s soul has been eviscerated...

pours a dark amberwith an off-white medium head that doesnt hang around, this beer has a good blend of fruit and sweet malts in its aroma, taste is sweet, perhaps a little overkill but still drinkable and enjoyable with some bitterness to finish, decent body, this is a solid beer, very drinkable
Dark brownish-red appearance with quickly diminishing head.  Little to no lace.  Somewhat doughy taste with molasses flavor present.  Overall a decent beer, although I’ve tasted better in this style.

A failry bready/rich Doppel which has oodles of sweet malty expression and decent balance for the style but perhaps is not as nuanced and hay-like as my favorite, the Welterburger Asam. Excellent quality though so one or two points overall for it being a good, widely marketed beer with such good form.

A wonderful amber color and a creamy head.  The smell is a bit fruity, with bread, and sweet yeast.  It is a very classic dopple bock taste, deep rich flavors that continue to intensify the right after one swallows, and transitions into a full range affter tastes ending with a slite bitter taste and a dry sensation at the back of the throat.  It may not be what it once was, according to most, but it is still a very fine beer, that has depth and character, and I would reccomend it.

"The first authentic dopplebock," the original recipe of which, since its creation over two centuries ago, has survived the French, the Austrians, the Allies, and the Russians.  It could not, however, survive the Dutch.  Once the epitome, the very essence of what a dopplebock should be, Salvator in its present incarnation is nothing more than a gutted shell of its former glory.  A glass of which through you could barely see a bright light, the aroma and flavor of which could stop you mid-thought just to savor it, this legendary "liquid bread" has been bastardized by Heineken’s marketing machine in a transparent attempt to appeal to the great unwashed masses.  It’s not even close to what it once was, and I’m personally boycotting Heineken products until they wake up and smell the wort.
ok for me, but a little too sweet for me, I’d like it more if it were more balanced, overall I enjoyed it, but nothing special for me

Pours a transparent amber red with a small amount of white head.  Aroma is extremely potent: loads of fruity sugary sweetness, almost like candy.  Flavor is very malty almost molasesy then with loads of tart fruits and smokey undertones and a slightly dry, bitter finish.  Overall, I found this to be a decent beer but nothing that truly blew me away.
I though this beer was really terrific until I tasted ayinger celebrator, and realized what a truly smooth, rich doppelbock tastes like. Still pretty good.
Dark amber brown. Syrupy brown sugar sweetness. Good, but didnt really hit the spot.

Bright red-amber with a fuzzy, peach coloured blanket.  Cereal grains, fruity caramel, and melanoidins produce a rich and inviting aroma.  The flavour is a pleasant blend of pumpernickel, peach, toffee, noble hops, and then some grain, followed by a little more fruit and then a little bit of barley husk.  Warming from the alcohol, but not alcohol-tasting, with a medium to full body and medium carbonation.  Very nice.

Aroma is light, grainy, malty.
Pours a beautiful amber with an off-white mostly diminishing head.
Initial taste is somewhat bitter, slightly sweet. Nice combination.
Aftertaste is sweet with a nice bitter hoppy finish.
Palate is oily, but pleasant.
Overall very nice balance, good brew, not great.

Pours a clear mahogany with an inch thick lacy tan head. Smells of fruity malt, caramel. Earthy and touches of vanilla and raisin.

Tastes...like a dopplebock. This was my first doppelbock ever and when i think of doppelbock, this is the taste I use as the standard. Very malty with caramel and molassess, tart fruitiness and earthy. Woody. A lightly smoky and woody aftertaste. Velvet smooth and very drinkable. 

One of my all time favorites. Can’t believe it’s taken me so long to review it.
poured a nice amber color with the typical bock aroma....taste was very hoppy for a bock... with a bland after taste...all in all....a decent beer

Aroma of raisins, dried figs, roasted caramel, yummy.  Cloudy amber-brown color with a tall off-white head.  Flavors of dried fruit, roasty caramel and noticable alcohol.  Warming and smooth.  Lightly creamy, very lively mouthfeel, dry finish.  This was pretty good.
(Bottle 50 cl) Salvator is THE classical doppelbock. Nutty brown with a disappearing head. Very dry and malty (three malts) - some caramel. Excellent, sweetish bock although better are found. 311099

orange/caramel colored body with a cream colored layer of head that laced the sides of the glass.  aroma is yeasty and malty, sweet with lots of caramel notes. alot of caramel malts up front backed up by some moderately bitter hops, which is the lingering aspect of this brew.  definitely not as good as a number of dopples that ive had

Bottled at DBF 2005.
Orange colored with a lacing off white head.
Aroma of malts and fruits with notes of caramel.
Sweet flavour with lots of malts and caramel.
Like fresh fruits and honey.  Very good quality, refreshing.  From the bottle, drank illicitly in a youth hostel.

Pours between a light brown and a dark amber with a nice tan head.  Aroma is malty sweet and complex.  I get a bit of spiciness in the flavor.  Slightly thin in body.  A very good beer, but this is not my favorite.

Red-orange with brown tones. Dense beige head.
Fruity aroma with notes of apple, banana, fudge, spungecake, ryebread and spices.
Peppery flavor with notes of alcohol, fudge, vanilla, butter and some sweetness. Fruity. Low bitterness.

After all the reviews I’ve read, I was expecting this to be some kind of nectar. Hmmm, well, it wasn’t. I’ve got five more bottles to drink, and I hope to have my initial impression changed by them. From a doppelbock, I had expected more complexity, more depth, and a denser mouthfeel.
Malt and hops dominated the aroma and the taste, pleasant enough, but it was nothing like the rich roasted darkness or chocolate-spice-raisin taste you might expect from a much touted d-b.
Mind you, this is a nice-looking, very drinkable beer. Indeed, it is really pretty in the glass -- nice light-tan head, though not very long lasting, and a lovely red-brown color.
Really easy to drink as well but too hoppy and light-feeling to stand with its superiors. This is a "light" doppelbock!

Pours reddish orange, the 1" camel head stays around for a while then poof! it’s gone. No lacing. Pungent honey, caramel apple, and tobacco aroma with nuances of cumin, chalk, and bleach. Flavors of sweet nutty malt, spice, graham crackers, and faint lemon zest. Slight bakers’ chocolate bitterness. Palate is full, rich, smooth, perfect. Strange rubbery aftertaste. Very nice, yet lacks intensity.
beautiful red/brown with a tan head. smells like fruit. taste a bit like honey, malt and spices. sweet and bitter finish. full/heavy and sticky/sweet palate. nicely done! #30

Orangeish off-white head which dissapears almost immediately.  Orange-red in color.  Malty scent with something displeasing.  Interesting scent but not something that I’m digging.  I like the taste more than the scent.  Tastes a bit bitter, with a little aftertaste.

Thanks Chuck!  The appearance is a clear copper body with a thin white head.  The aroma is like a peaberry candle that my ex-roommate left at my place.  Sweet malty floral hoppyness.  Smells kinda like some women’s perfumes.  The flavor is much like the aroma but maltier.  The palate is typical. 9, 3, 7, 3, 16 = 3.8



Rerate: pours to a clean bronzed orange body with a thin white head.  The aroma is sweet and caramelized plantains or bananas with a unique yeast and apricot and pear that’s muddled into the background.  The flavor has a metallic caramelized bock malt going on with a sweet strawberry seed compote.  The palate is sweet and lingering and surprisingly light. 7, 3, 6, 3, 13 = 3.2

a copper hugh w/ a nice white head that dissapates quickly and laces fairly well.  scent is sweet & malty hints of alcohol a little floral sugary.  Palate is pretty creamy coats pretty well not to much carb.  Tastes very sweet a nice thick carmel malt a little dougy floral farily simple flavor but done well.  Overall pretty good.

[bottle - 16.9 oz] Clear copper pour with a fizzy and quickly dissipating tan head. Aroma is slightly sweet with hints of malt, sugar and some vegetables. Very mild flavor with a malt beginning and a middle of brown sugar, malts and alcohol. Very warming on the way down. Not as flavorful as most doppelbock’s I’ve had though.
Thsi is an excellent double bock brew from paulanar. very smooth flavor with a hint of sugar in the taste. not overwhelming but still an excellent beer

Bottle into tasting glass.  Clear, medium brown with a bit of glow, creamy off-white head that totally diminishes.  Not as dark as my favorite doppelbock.  Bready, somewhat tangy nose.  Warm dark fruit and port flavors, very nice, with great malt sugary body and flavor.  Warming alcohol that’s unnoticable in the mouth.  Not much breadiness on the taste, which was disappointing.  Tangy finish was unexpected and not entirely enjoyable.

Couleur rouge rubis, abondante mousse blanche concassée, pleinement diminuante.  Arômes très alcoolique, presque de cognac, nous dévoilant plus tard ces raisins secs, pruneaux et malt caramel.  Les flaveurs portent essentiellement le grain pour ensuite en venir aux fruits séchés foncés et à l’alcool.  Corps moyen, carbonatation légère laissant place à  la brûlante sensation offerte par l’alcool.  Finale semi-sèche offrant une brève sensation d’amertume venant tenter de contrebalancer le sucre.  Bouteille LCBO Mai 2005.

The complex aroma hints at plum, sweet chocolate, apricot, peaches, cherries, loads of sugar and some alcohol.  The beer pours a transparent cranberry with little to no head.  Flavor is much the same as the nose, with cherries, plums and alcohol becoming predominant as it comes to temperature.  My only complaint is the thin, sticky mouthfeel.

Expected a lot more from the first mass marketed ’Doppelbock’. Many other breweries, jealous of the success, named their Doubles in honour of this one, but many of them produce far greater versions of the style. Poured into an ’Aventinus’ glass, a short off-white ring formed atop a clear gusset-amber body. No true head, but it did give a good lace. Woody and slightly nutty, burnt toffee and toasted malt nose. Spicy alcohol phenols gave it a pleasant warming balance in the aroma. Medium light bodied in the mouth, with medium carbonation, it took until it warmed a little to give it’s full character. Burnt toffee and husky grain flavours were dominant, with a treacle sweet front, malt, vanilla and plums across the tongue. Yeast and alcohol phenols came in mid-palate and followed long into the aftertaste, providing a good warmth. All flavours seemed a little subdued, though,  as if watered down, but it was still an unusually sessionable Doppelbock.

Sparkling orange, thick fizzy off white head.  Nose was toasty and bready, with notes of caramel, cherry, and hints of raisin.  Nice sweet caramel malt and dried cherry notes up front, but is backed nicely with a dose of German hops for balance.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, malty, caramel and cherryish finish.  Pretty tasty, but it certainly is not Celebrator...

The bottle poured a crystal clear amber liquid with a small creamy but persistent head that left nice lacing on the edge of the glass. The aroma was loaded with mega maltiness. There was little or no hop aroma to this beer. I also detected notes of plum. The mouthfeel was smooth and full-bodied. The flavor was intensely malty sweet and smooth with a great warming sensation that grew toward the middle and lasted well into the finish.

This poured clean and ready to be chugged. Was listening to some italo disco while ironing a shirt. Toffee’s, fruits, squeezed into a balance brew. Very enjoyable and smooth. I had an entire bottle of champagne last night after this, but can still taste the ol’ Salvie.

Bottle
Aroma is of raisins and maybe chocolate. Colour is dense ruby, opaque but clear ( hehe difficult to understand, i know). I guess that now i understand why "doppel", really warms although alcohol is not disturbing. An overall fine brew, maybee too sweet for a session beer, but fine to have a glass in a winter night.

Perhaps the most fruit in the aroma of any beer I have sampled, particularly raisins.   The aroma is a hint to the taste which includes toffee along with the rich fruit taste.  The beer is very smooth with just a hint of harshness to the palate.  Consistant throughout the pint.
It pours a nice amber color, but I expect it to be darker.  The aroma is mild, and good natured.  It’s essentially a beer that is not offensive, and I expect more from my dopplebocks.
Amber, tall beige head. Malty aroma. Soft carbonation. Immense malty sweet flavour. Roasted malts. Notes of smoke? Uncomplex but well balanced.

Attractive deep orange brew with a small, off-white head. Slightly hazy... lookin’ like a barleywine. Delicious, heady aroma of caramel malts and sweet, citrusy oranges. Then I had to ruin things by drinking it... not bad, simply too sweet. And a bit lacking in its claim of "heartiness". Malted flavor, but a bit weak and watery. Balanced hops, but sugars are dominant. Good, not great.


Bridgeview Liquors

Had on tap at a local bar.  Aroma is very sweet anf fruity.  Color is a nice amber.  Flavor to me is extraordinary.  Full of dark fruit and sweet malt.  Ive heard people say its too sweet, but its not for me.  One of my favorites

Pours a nice brownish copper color with a pretty good head that diminishes quickly.  Aroma is a bit musty and sweet.  Taste is full, almost thick... of caramel with nice spicy aftertones.  Slight alcoholic warmth.  Good, not great, as palate does not fully develop, which is really the only thing holding this one back.

Pours a light brown with aromas of bread yeast and sweet malt. Flavor is very rich in caramel/toffee malt and bread with hints of roastedness. A little light on the palate side of things but very enjoyable.

Deep amber body, medium off-white head. Fragrant aroma with caramel, burnt sugar and butter. Strong malt sweetness with notes of bread and butterscotch. Smooth mouthfeel, rich taste, long, delicious, slightly bitter finish. The original doppelbock and still one of the best.

On tap.  While this is better than most other beers, it is a disappointment when compared to others of the same style.  For a doppelbock (or even for a single bock) this is a somewhat weak, watery brew.  All the correct characteristics are there, just at about 75% of what they ought to be.  If for some unlikely reason this is the only malty beer on the menu it’s not bad, but if you have any other choices I’d go with those first.
Poured a mostly ruby color with a small off white head.  Malty aroma and flavors.  Fruity, raisins, caramel, and light alcohol.  Medium bodied with a smooth mouthfeel.

The original double bock makes a decent nightcap but it’s a little too sweet and coarse in the finish for my taste. Poured a burnt orange colour with a rocky 1.5 cm head that settled quickly, leaving a little lace. Aroma is of hard candy, toasted malt and toffee. Medium-to-full body with an oily mouthfeel. The flavour is malt-driven, with sweet toffee-like notes, some fruity acids and a big slug of rummy alcohol in the finish. Needs a cold night to be at its best. Alcohol is too prominent for my palate. (330ml bottle, best before April 2005)

Bottle, dated 7/04. Purchased at Walt’s grocery store, Homewood, IL. What else should one drink on Easter Sunday? Still very much the beer that sets the style. Pours a deep copper color, no haze, and a thin head. Has a heady caramel smell and taste, almost like a settled barleywine. Mouthfeel is a bit thick, with notes of maple, rum and plums. Just a little touch of bitterness on the tongue, otherwise a nice sweet, warming and drinkable Lent-breaker.
Beautiful clear red beer with a lasting frothy head.Malty aroma and taste,slighty bitter palate,but extremely delicious.Perfect Springtime warmer!

Bottle, at home.
Red with off-white head, quickly gone. Aroma of sweet bread. Flavor bitter of sweetness, light of hops. Medoium body, creamy, flat carbonated. Too sweet, not in balance.
Malty aroma, nice amber body color. Head lasts long and thick with a cream color. Decent lacing. Goes down smooth.

Nice ruby-amber color and relatively light head of a tan tint. Strong fruitcake flavor and aroma from all that malt, with the slightest amount of hops on the finish. Seems more like a beer to have along with cheese, crackers or some other snack food. Quite cloying on the palate, but with food this wouldn’t be as important.
Deep amber color.  Aroma is subtle and darkly sweet.  Thick and rich flavor.  Earthy and semi-sweet with slight coffee/caramel presence.  A bitter sweet finish that pleasantly lingers. [$7.99/6pk]
Bottle. Pours a bright amber with white head that leaves quickly. Smells of apples and cider. Tastes semi sweet with a bit of bitter in the end.
Bottle. Bright copper colored beer with somewhat shortlived white head. Aroma is sweet and bready, which is found again in the flavor, but with some alcohol. A sweet but tasty classic.

Fairly carbonated head has decent longevity; reduces to thin off-white head with medium bubbles.  Sparkling clear light amber color.  Attractive malty aroma- with slight alcohol scent.  Very smooth texture leaves mouth slightly velvety.  Well balanced doppelbock.
Malt aroma with a honey sweetness. Dark red body with off-white head.  Rich malt flavour with just a hint of hops in the aftertaste.

Instant caramel sweet aroma even from the bottle, a little thinner that I expected when poured.  Huge head that I wasn’t quite ready for.  I can barely notice any presence of alcohol, if this is 7.5% you could probably get a buzz quick because of the sweet inoffensive character of the beer.  Half way finished with the glass and I don’t agree with this cloying as it warms it’s just not thick enough to be overpoweringly sweet. There is a slight bitternes trying to fight through but it is quickly squashed on the palate by carmel malt.  I wish I would have tried this before I tried a Celebrator Dopplebock.  It’s like visiting Colorado after you’ve seen Alaska.  Still, this is a good beer that I could easily see buying/drinking again and could also be enjoyed by many who are not into trying and rating beers.  Too thin to be great.
Buena cerbeza de color tostado. Muy buena aunque tampoco es la mejor cerveza del mundo. jejeje

Bottle. Sweetish, rusty sunset orange offering from Paulaner. Definitely needs a good chill to keep the malty profile in check. Done deed, this is a pleasant, rich brew from the old weissbier guys at Paulaner. The 2006 bottle is way better than 2005 as I remember it -- in fact, superior to a degree that I had to rerate every single parameter. Last year, I found no reason to push this higher than a 2.4 total -- reaching a respectable 3.1 now, I’d say something remarkable has happened.
a nice drink and relatively cheap for a highly regarded german beer.  malty and very highly carbonated.

I can not belive I nver rated this, it was a daily drink toward the end of "04/ Poured amber with acreamy head, like whipped cream. Sweet/sour aroma of malts. Nice back bone of malted seetness, that improves as it warms. I really liked this, try this on double bock lovers, while no Celebrator, still very nice.
An amber hue.  nice to look at, nice to drink, by no means my favorite dopplebock. A good strong brew for a frosty winter night or a good frosty on a spring morning.

Bueatifully clear burgandy hue with quickly disappearing off-white head. Pleasant malty arroma, but still subtle. The taste is malty, clean, and lingering maltiness in the aftertaste Makes me want to have another sip.

Not nearly as dark as I expected. Nice malty enticing aroma. Flavor wise, extreme malt followed by alcohol is the first thing that comes to mind. Hardly any bitterness here. Somewhat creamy. Gets maltier as it warms. Even though I now realize that bocks just aren’t my style, I can recognize this is a good beer & would be quite enjoyable to those who are a fan of them.
one of those beers that suprises you when you first taste it.  a unique flavor that i would describe as flowery.  its slightly sweet with hints of caramel as well.  i was impressed.

Clear and light red. Syrupy looking with a thin tan head. Very appealing aroma of dark malt and raisens and caramel. Thick in body with a bit of an alcohol finish. Excellent malt and fruit and caramel flavor. According to one of the Paulaner Sales Managers,  Salvator is only available in the early spring for Lent in Germany. We are blessed with it year round. It varies from 7.2% to 7.8% by the year.

draft@paulaner, my oh my this is really nice! some floral caramel notes, the aroma gets very complicated when the heat gets higher. Candy sugar is quite obvious in taste, incredibly well balanced .... I had a few rounds of 0.5l kegs, I went to heaven .... NOTE this rating is bades on the draft version, I´ve also had this from bottle and it didnt taste nearly as good

Dark amber colour, clear, large head. Aroma of caramel and hmmm...old coins? Strange..
Caramel, malts, warming, bitter, some alcohol. Andechser is better, but this is still very, very good. I like Doppelbocks. Nein, ich liebe Doppelbocks!

Good example of a Dopple bock.. Aroma is malt heavy with toffee and carmel notes, No hops to style. Alcohol warmth and scent. 
Amber color with solid tan head...Flavor is much the same as aroma....Perhaps carbonation hig for style but not carbonic bite.
Full body.
Cheers

Lacks a strong aroma. Nice large ivory head. Clear red. Ultra creamy, excellent caramel and burnt sugar. Not too watery, smacks on the palate of apples. Finishes crisp. A little too much cheerios and sourness.
Excellent beer. Has a smooth warm taste with a very fluffy head. Nice rich medium amber color and hits fast and hard after a long day at work. Whoooooo! :)

Firstly, I’m an IPA guy...a "hop-head", if you will.  I generally dislike lagers, pilseners, and even most bocks because of their relative lack of flavor and style.  That being said, I LOVE this beer.  It truly defines the doppelbock...definitely one of my top five "desert island" beers.  PS...my character on FFXI is named "Salvator" (Ifrit server), which obviously proves my dedication.

I’m a doppelbock fanatic. My mouth waters at the mention of a Paulaner Salvator. Since this is an authentic doppel, I judge all doppels by this one. You can "crank ’em up" any way you like but for sheer great taste, the Germans still are the king.
Earlier Rating: 2/4/2005 Total Score: 4.3
Mein Got! Zis ist zo much ze autentic doppelbock. Americaner zhey brew fuller biers, unt darker biers, unt hoppier biers but zis be ze best style ov doppelbock. How can you be perfectink upon ze improvementz?

Pours reddish-brown with a thick beige head.  Malty, sweet, and maybe woody aroma.  Not as malty in the flavor as aroma.  I think that being well carbonated does help.  Good hop bitterness also balances out the malt.  Very well balanced.  Maybe some oaky flavor as well.

Crystal clear dark ruby/amber pour.  Nice creamy tan head which recedes.  Big sweet malt nose.  Flavor is sweet malt and caramel with a slightly hoppy, bitter finish.  Thick full body, and enough carbonation to keep it from being syrupy in the mouth.  Tasty and interesting.  Smooth and pleasant, warming alcohol on the way down.  A very high quality brew from Paulaner.  I got a sixer for $9.99 and will enjoy every last drop.  Nice!
Sweet and malty with a mid-sized light tan head, this brew is flavorful and warming. Distinct German malts make this is bready and smooth. A fine pairing with any wurst dish.

Apperance: dark amber, no head, minimal lacing
Aroma: slightly spicey yeasty sweet
Flavor profile: Very malty sweet, light with low hops, a touch of yeastish spiceyness. Very smooth and tasty. I like it.
Overall: Must try

I expected a lotmore than I got. Quite Pale for a Doppel. Smell is sweet like maple syrup. Very malty smelling. No hops. Taste is very sweet with a warming in the chest. Very displeasing as a doppel...

Bottled.  A mid brown coloured beer which pours with no head.  The aroma is sweet and a bit creamy and the alcohol comes through.  The taste is also sweet with lots of maltiness and again noticeable alcohol.  A tasty beer but I thought quite poor quality for a doppelbock.

Pours amber with decent off-white head. Sweet malt aroma with hints of caramel. Flavor is caramel malt,syrup or molasses with a little hops in the finish. Very full-bodied beer. Could easily be a creeper.

amber colored with a light tan head, lighter than most doppelbocks
butterscotch and ground malt aroma. Full to medium mouth feel, a malty beer 
with notes of Carmel and sherry …a slight hop bite in the finish
(26 Dec 04) Pours a deep crystal clear ruby with a creamy white fluffy head that doesn’t last long.  It has a big butter and malt nose and a warming mouthfeel that is sweet and alcoholic.
light brown.   nice malty flavour, full-bodied beer.   very smooth.  quite a good beer.

Red-Copper body, strong head.  Malt completely dominates the thick aroma.  Flavor is sticky-sweet malt that leaves a surprisingly bitter aftertaste.  Lingers on the tongue for a while.  Noticeable alcohol warmth.
Amber body, small off-white head, much rising carbonation, malty nose. Rich malty start, medium sweetness, mild bitterness, disappointing thin finish. Slight lingering bitterness.

Bottle. Clear light mahogany with a small cream-colored head. Nose: molasses, toffee, raisons and prunes. Taste: raisons, prunes, burnt toast, dark rum and honey.  Full-bodied and slightly sweet. Alcohol is noticeable in the aftertaste, but overall a good cold-weather beer.

Aroma:caramel.malt sugar
appearance:Red small white head
Flavor:caramel small bitterness,malt
Very good doppelbock
Bottle somewhere in Munich. Golden amber color and a big white head. Sweet fruity malty aroma and taste, medium to full body and a sweet finish. A bit to sweet for my taste.
Pours a dark golden light amber, with light head that dissolves quickly.  Aroma is sweet, malty and little chocolate.  Taste is spicy at first with caramel and a malt flavor.

Lighter in color and body than most current doppelbocks.  Quickly dissipating head from draught version.  Some bitterness also confounded me.  Tastes of maple syrup with a pinch of woody rum.  Sweetness dominates all the way up until the short finish.  It may be the original doppleback, but it isn’t my favorite.

Another one of those beers I was surprised to see I hadn’t gotten around to ever rating.  Well, not really.  It has been a long time since I tried it.  Just not a doppelbock fan.  Having said that, this beer wasn’t half bad.  Medium to dark amber, tinged just slightly with ruby, decent head at first, faded completely.  Aroma bodes poorly, soggy bread with a bit of asparagus.  Flavor is better, however, with the malt, although clearly the focus, not being sickly sweet.  There is also the faintest tinge of a smoky element that I found to balance and dry the beer out a bit.  It won’t be the first beer I will reach for, but it was tolerable.
Bottle. A very smooth malty buttery taste, not much in the way of hop bitterness. I like this type of beer, lots of alchohol and it goes down a treat.
bottle.  fiery tarnished copper color with a quickly disappearing tan head.  there is a rich maltiness throughout the entire spectrum of this brew.  quite smooth and enjoyable!

Light copper colour, very attractive.  Thin head dissipates quickly.  Excellent aroma -- dark with sweet notes.  High alcohol on the palate, but solid taste and very smooth finish.  A very enjoyable dopplebock.
Don’t take this bad boy lightly... This is one brew that demands your attention.  And it deserves every bit of it.  Nice one to enjoy on  a cold winter night.

Rusty dark orange - almost brandy like.  Big nose of chunky dirty malts and fruit. Very typical of the style.  Ripe fruits in the mouth and a little spice and heat to finish. The alcohol doesn’t show until very late. Thins out a little at the finish. Not as smitten as when I first tasted in late 2004 but still very good given the producer is very commercial.
Clear amber colour. no head blened malt nose. crisp clean malty taste. with having no head there was no lace either. I found it very average

(on bottle) Dark, clear and golden amber color. Besides the very dak malts, with it´s dried fruits and coffee, there´s a hint of rum too, very plesant indeed. The mouth is thick of malts and wood, he alcohol is mild, but there. Short warming finish.

(Bottle).  Large off-white head, mostly diminishing, fair lacing.  Clear amber-orange body.  Dark caramel, toasted, toffee, medium-high malt sweetness, molasse as well as some light tones of fruits in my nose.  In my mouth, medium-high to high malt sweetness first with toffee-like flavor.  Later, medium-light sweetness and a light-medium bitterness.  Medium body (a bit syrupy), soft to lively carbonation, light alcoholic feel toward the end.
Dark, red and intense color. Compact foam and of good persistence. Intense scent with an alcoholic aroma and of fruit. Good persistence.
Burnt toast.  Awesome burnt toast.  This is a thick, very heady 2xbock.  Her only flaw may be the the aroma being a bit too sweet.  Carmel and chocolate flavors make for a great meal.
Fine.  Doppelbocks taste a bit too rich for me.  However this was still a good beer because it is high quality.  If you enjoy Doppelbocks give this beer a try.  Not my style.

Draught at the White Horse, Parsons Green, London. During the festival. This was very red in colour, little head. Aroma is sweet, typical for the style. Sweet malt and syrup leads into a heavy grain character
Amber colour, good malt aroma.  This beer has a nice taste. Very well balanced, it has a sweet finish.
Reddish amber in color with little head and a  sweet malty aroma. Flavour is most of the same, full bodied and quite tasty.

On tap, Paulaner Im Tal, Munich, April 2006.
Crystal clear brass color with a spongy, anamorphic tan head.  Copper pennies, birchwood whetted from air drying doggies, some pecans stirred ceaselessly in Christmas tins and a slight touch of protruding caramel get the aroma going.  Sleek, steady stream of caramel to elicit bock smack.  Candy toffee cubes provide a flavor with only half of the requisite sugar.  Bready, semi-sweetened whole wheat bread.  Some butter-fried hazelnuts and liquefied golden raisins, and mulled apple butter with almond shavings.  Toned, nearly absent carbonation lets the ABV and chalky stream of alcohol protrude, though it’s absent, dactylically speaking.  Rubbery toffee controls the mouth feel with partial numbing.  Mixed nut tin finish, somewhat dry, and a prevalent cocoa graham flavor in the aftertaste.  It’s a good, solid doppelbock, just drier and less sweet than I noticed in one of my earliest ratings.  Still an amiable benchmark and thought provoker for brewers of the style.  

500-ml. bottle, November 2004.
Very good doppelbock.  When I poured this brew into my glass, it wasn’t as dark as I expected - it had a little bit more of an amber tint to it, kind of like Paulaner’s Oktoberfest.  This beer had a great consistency.  It was rich and smooth yet complex.  Very malty and a little chocolatey and spiced.  Great beer.

Love the taste,like the nose.

Pours a watered down cola colour...leaning to-wards red.Small tan head.

Interesting malt nose with some prunes in there.

Taste is very good,it has a strong taste to it,malt,prunes plum raisons...sort of reminds me of plum cake.

a far bit of carbonation and good body.

This is one of those “classic” beers that I have wanted to try for a while, and I wasn’t too disappointed with it either. In the glass it was an amber/mahogany colour with an off white creamy head, the nose was reminiscent of caramel, toffee, burnt grain, and rum and raisins, following through with a smooth, complex, palate and with a finish of roasted grains and chocolate with the result being smooth, dryish, and warming. Overall I was quite glad to have had it, and may even have it again (if there is nothing new)

Very nice amber body topped with a lasting beige foamy head. Good malty aroma with evident notes of brown sugar, toffee and dark berries. Taste is surprisingly mild and hides the alcohol quite well. Flavors are mainly sweet and fruity. It ends with an honest hoppy/bitter finish. Although I was expecting a little more character, this is a very good and well balanced Doppelbock.

Lots and lots of malt went into this beer. Many people try to describe the subtle tastes, but if you know what Munich malt is you’ll understand. Well balanced beer hides the alcohol well. Aromas are of figs, raisins, and dried fruit. Finishes sweet and clean. Dark orange color and tan head are pleasing to the eye. Satisfying.
Nice malty carmel aroma. Rich and pretty tasty. Love the density in  taste and color. Moderate/sweet after taste. Tasty is apparently the my operative term for this beer. Great buy (quality/price)

The traveller arrived in the village at sundown.  A brilliant orange sky lit up the street, and the sound of blacksmiths anvils ringing accompanied his step.  We sat late into the evening, talking of old times,  smoking our death in pipe tobacco.  Such good times could never last, we knew, but there is no great dearth of friendly strangers in this world.

This is a very well made, complex, wonderful fall/winter beer.  Pours dark amber with reddish edges.  Aroma of malt, dark fruit, toffee, caramel, and slight corn flakyness.  Tastes wonderful, complex, firm, dense, and solid.  Complex, balanced, and smooth at the finish, with a bit of a warming kick.  World class.

Available on tap at Everybody’s in Atlanta. Nice thick head, malty as all get out. Is sweetish, but that’s pretty much what a dopplebock should be, and it finshes nicely. Not in the same league as Celebrator, but then again, I haven’t had Celebrator on tap. Yet.

On draught at the Draught House in Austin.  Medium head with amber color.  Malty aroma.  Medium to full body.  Malt and caramel flavors with alcohol apparent.  Some honey flavor, too.  Slightly bitter aftertaste that keeps it from being cloying. Nice to drink on a cold winter’s night!!
Dark amber. Dominant sweet malts. Some yeast comes through as a bready aspect. As the weather turns chilly, it warms the belly nicely.
Bottle. Nice amber colour with a creamy, off-white head. aroma is caramel, malt and raisins. Taste is caramel, raisins and brown sugar. Full bodied, nicely sweet. A very good doppelbock.

Pours a deep amber with a thick but short lived tan head. Aromas of caramel ,malts, rasins and wood. Nice hints of caramel, raisins, kinda sweet but not overly so, mild alcohol burn. A good fall drink.

This beer is a dark brownish/red color with a moderate head. The aroma is excellent with some caramel, grapes, oak, brown sugar, and alcohol. The flavor is quite sweet with a nice punch of toffee, sour apples, molasses, and raisins. The mouthfeel is quite thick and syrupy. Some alcohol does show through with this beer. This one would certainly be a good one for a cold night. I can feel it, ooooh yeah!

Pours deep amber with a rapidly diminishing creamy tan head.  Nose is malty and nutty.  The flavor is complicated... malt, pecan nuts, dried apricots, coffee, baked apples all make an appearance.  Sweet.  The high alcohol content is apparent in the way the mildly smoky finish rushes towards you.  A good dessert beer.

Poured light brown with some reddish hues, a little lighter than I would like, with a large light-brown head.  Aroma is rich and malty.  Taste is malty and sweet while not overly sweet, with little bitterness or smokiness.  A smooth, very drinkable doppelbock.  Not the best I’ve had, but agreeable.

This must be one of the best looking beers I ever had. Nice reddish colour with fine off white head. Aroma is malty with lots of bread and some alcohol, it smells strong. Flavor is malty with hints of leather. Some alcohol in the finish.

Smokey caramel nose, with slight overtones of wood. Orange/rust color with rocky head. Substantial mouthfeel, with an acidic aftertaste. Caramel and slightly metallic flavor but very smooth, sweet and rich.

Tasted this beer on the Bockbeer festival in Utrecht, The Netherlands, on draft. Nice amber colour with a good head. Some smell of Citrus fruit. A nice flavour, you can clearly taste the alcohol in this beer, but nevertheless it is a fresh and easy drinkable beer with a nice sweetness. A good quality beer which I can recommend.
Clear amber liquid with a tight, light colored head.  It had a slightly sweet but pleasant taste.  Short lived aftertaste.

bleh. I don’t like this bitter, one-dimensional flavor at all!
Would not buy again. Try the hefe instead.
Rich malt, dark fruits, alcohol, soy, brown sugar.  Tart (sulfur?) at first followed by really rich malt, lots of plum and brown sugar/toffee.  All well balanced.
A rich, sweet, almost too sweet doppelbock, this is a good example of the style.

Red colored with beige vanishing head. Aroma has strong chocolate with sweet notes. Full bodied and syrupy mouthfeel, ends with biting, warming and also lasting alcohol with nice carbonation, excellent palate. Flavor starts caramelly and ends with lasting chocolate, alcohol makes ending mildly dry. Well balanced beer with nice character, excellent doppelbock!

A very nice orange-y copper colour. I didn’t get that great of a pour so the head was small and went away quickly. There wasn’t too much lacng, but the aroma was very nice. It was definatly malty, and the malt carried through to the taste. It was kind of sticky, which I think is related to it’s sweet flavour. It has a slight roasted favlour and you get a little hint of alcohol at the end. Overall, terrific.

A very thick, rich doppel.  It pours a deep copper color with a frothy tan head.  Sweet, sweet malty aroma with dark dried fruits.  Thick, almost chunky in the mouth.  Very malty flavoring, toffee, a yeaty fruitiness, and a dash of grassiness.  Left my face & hands sticky from drinking it.  Good stuff, if a tad bit too sweet for me.

I was very impressed with this beer, even beyond the expectations that come from the Paulaner name.  It had a defining doppelbock  aroma, and a very rich and thick, malty body.   This will definately get more playing time.

This brew pours such an intense red with a tall off-white head that leaves thick lacing. Sweet malt smell and taste in both the aroma and taste. Notes of caramel, fruit, and wheat, with a well balanced finish and malty aftertaste. Very smooth and medium to thick bodied brew.

Clear red colour, big, foamy head. Very malty, sweet and caramelly aroma.  Taste is also very caramelly, sweet, malty. Also slightly fruity, like figs and dates. An excellent Doppelbock. Medium-bodied and not as rich as the best doppelbocks, but still very good and complex.

Pours a dark copper with a nice head and a nice lace.

Nice nose! Big and malty with dark fruits, raisins, figs and apples, somewhat tart as well.

Very Very caramelly and unbelieveably malty. Pretty hoppy as well. Awesome for the style.

Sparkling clear ruby body with a lasting dense light tan head. Lacing is quite nice. The aroma is tons of malt, sweet caramel, molasses and hints of citrus The flavor is not as sweet as the aroma would lead you to believe. A good bit of bitterness and alcohol are also  in the mix. Medium full syrupy body with some alcohol in the finish. Once a staple of my beer diet years ago, I now see it for what it is, a decent but not exceptionaly dopplebock.
Light auburn coloration, thick off-white head.  Aroma is fruity (Pineapple, Peaches) with heavy wheat.  Easy drinking, but uneventful & bland.  Slightly mettalic, with caramel.
very caramel nose.  caramel taste also but hops and yeast invade.  end of the night beer for me this time around so theres some alcoholic influence.  still a delicious beer

Appearance: clear, gorgeous, deep garnet hue, with a fine, fuzzy cocoa-colored head.
Aroma: bready, yeasty, but soft, slightly hoppy and spicy, with some traces of fruit.
Taste: smooth flavor, but soon fruity flavors, derived from malt, dominate the palate. Tasty,. tasty, rich and malty, improving exponentially as we go!
Bright, shiny, delicious, with alcohol content eventually rearing it’s powerful head. Flavor feels burnished, roasted, still fruity, and let us never forget, delicious. A world class beer, a champion doppelbock, and surprisingly approachable.

Copper pour with an initially voluminous frothy head, which receded nicely.  Malty aroma with some earthy notes and caramel.  Very creamy mouthfeel.  Taste is malty as well and slightly sweet.  Nice finish maybe a bit of lingering alcohol.  I’m surprised how smooth this one went down.  Tasty

I don’t usually like the doppelbocks.  They are usually too sweet for me.  This beer however was quite delicious.  The pour was an amber with a thin white fizzy head.  Far drier than other dopplebocks I have had.  Absolutley delicious.
Love this beer - strong and satisfying - like a hefty chunk of chocolate cake.  Wonderful malty aroma, and luscious red-orange color pours thickly.

in the bottle.  amber red in color. thick beige head, lasting to the end. very malty aroma. pronounced caramel flavor.  nice tip-of-the-tongue bittering hops. I wish this would be  the type Oktoberfest beer we will be drinking in Munich, but I know it is not.  Even the burps from this beer are tasty.

bottle:  pours a nice copper orange color with a with head.  the araoma is much of bubble gum and fruit.  very sweet.  this is the second time i have tried this beer and i lkike it alot better on this go around.  the flavoir is veryu sweet/malty with a nice fruitiness.  there is a little hebal smokey flavor towards the end.  for the price this is a very drinkable good beer.

Poured a copper/amber hue with a thin white head.  Aroma was, to my senses, completely dominated by super-sweet maltiness.  Flavor was a bit more complex, still dominated by sweet malts, but accompanied by a pleasant crispness from tasteful hopping, somewhat herbal/spicy notes, and a noticeable alcohol bite in the finish.  For a primarily sweet beer, this one’s really good.

Pours a nice crimson with an off white dissapating head. Aroma is lightly malty with some dark fruit. Taste is syrupy sweet with notes of peat, caramel, roasted malt, smoke, toffee, raisans, plums and some tobacco. No bitterness that I can detect. Mouthfeel is full and round but could have been a little thicker. Alcohol content present but pretty well hidden. No head or lacing to speak of. Overall, nice brew- recommended.

Close to copper color/or strong tea with honey added. Malty sweet nose. Mostly oily mouthfeel with a bit of fizz at the end. Just a great malty/sweet hearty brew that is quite warming. Never noticed any bitterness on this one and I have been drinking it for years and is always a maindish in my fall/winter imbibing. SOLID!

Nice redish brown color with a malty smell.  It was slightly sweet to the taste but had a slight aftertaste that barely reminded  me of the higher alcohol percentage.  Very drinkable and easy to forget just a few could knock me on my butt.

Appearance: bright red copper color with light effervescence. A full fluffy beige head with limited retention and a sticky lace. The taste is very astringent with a sweet middle (malt, caramel) and a lingering bite. Aroma: Malt, spices, caramel and aroma hops. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, some effervescence and a lingering bite. IMHO: Too abrupt with the astringent bitterness. Not well balanced with other (sweeter) characteristics

Full thick golden head and a beautiful copper color. It smells rich and gummy like a good dopple should. The hops and malts are evident. A bit sour with a taste that fills the mouth with hops, fruit and roasted chestnuts. Pretty good, but a bit bitter at the end and a dissapointingly light stay on the taste buds. Celebrator still rocks my world.

dark brown, malt aroma with a slighty sweet banana flavor.  Round and full and delicious.  It does taste a bit different from other beers, but this is because it is my first dopple... can’t wait to try some more
Full of body and taste this is a classic dopplebock.Dark brown appearance with flavour that hits you hard.Needs to be treated with respect - a truely excellent beer.
This was one of the best beers I have ever tasted.  Did not have a lot of bitterness.  It also had a slight fruity taste to it.

Amber with a quickly dissipating head. Malty aroma with roasted notes. Fruity flavor, mostly plum, some spices, malt. Light bitterness at the finish. Round body, with mild carbonation, warms up the mouth. Bittersweet aftertaste stays long in mouth.
Sweet aroma.  Nice dark redish brown color.  Smooth tasting.  With hint of banana...  Decent medium lasting head.

Sample taken from 330ml brown bottle. Brownish red hued, fizzy head vanished quickly. Sweet malt in the aroma. Sweetish sticky body, caramel, some spiciness. Some bittereness and alcohol warming in the finish.
Very smooth, sweet, caramel flavor.  Stronger alcohol taste than other bocks.

Clear red body with a thin off-white head, sweet nose with hints of alcohol and fruit, complex sweet flavor that touches on over-ripened fruit, caramel and syrupy maple notes, concluding with with a bitter alcohol finish, I feel like kind of a jackass having this with hungry howies cheesey bread, but I’ve never clamed that I’m not a jackass, and this is after all just the pre-game for the celebrator.
Bottle. Powdery fruity malt aroma.  Light brown clear color with small tan head.  Bitter maltiness with chalk/astringent flavor especially while cold.
Bottle. Nut-brown/reddish colour, compact white head. Malty, peppery aroma. Very full-flavoured, malty and peppery. Oily texture.

Brown/red with a thin offwhite head which falls quickly.  Very fine carbonation.  Sweet raisin/malt/alcohol aroma.  quite a full bosy, but not as thick as was hinted from the aroma.  Some hop to balance, but it doesn’t meld right for me.

Bottled.  Big orange head is fully lasting, leaving behind some sheets of lace, sitting on top of a crystal clear, reddish-amber body.  Intensely fruity aroma, heavily malted, caramel, fresh berries, apples, light alcohol and yeast--very sniffable, very unbalanced.  Full body, lots and fair duration of very soft, slightly foamy, slightly silky, slightly dry carbonation, wet, kind of syrupy(so much malts...).  Flavor is intensely malty, caramel, toffee; highly alcoholic, not so much fruity flavor(prune, apple) until it warms some, lightly bitter(citrus, wood, toasty) finish that manages to dry the palate out somewhat after time passes...well balanced, not smoothe.  Would be better on draught as it’s nearly flat currently, but what carbonation it does have is lovely, but it needs more of it.  Alcohol flavor is too bold, carbonation is off...complex, warming and a sipping beer.
Pours a nice ruby/amber color. Smells of very smooth with very litttle carbonation. Has a slight carmel taste. Tastes kind of like a See’s candy coffee sucker. Good easy drinker.
Lovely color and nice tan head. Aroma is spice and malt and some others. Ok mouthfeel little to sparkly for my taste. Has a nice bittersweet flavor with a good long lasting aftertaste.

Aroma is sweet dark fruits and malt. Amber in color with a slowly diminishing, two finger thick, tan head. Fore is bready and malty, but has a slightly tinny note. Lots of caramel flavor. Has a hearthy and wholesome baked sweet bread feel to it. Finishes with warm bracing alcohol that leaves the throat dry and tingly.
Very malty, rich flavor.  Although I like this beer, I generally will only buy it if Celebrator is unavailable.

Pours a cloudy, orangey amber with a frothy, cappucino like head.  I hoped it would be as good as Celebrator, but was skeptical.  Nice malty, fruity, bready aroma with a hint of banana.  The flavor was the same with some apricot and some warming alcohol.  The palate was fair and overall typical of the style.  Finishes with a slight metallic twang.  Nothing extraordinary but all in all a nice offering.
Poured orangey amber, thin head...smells very sweet with a nondescript candy smell...definate alcohol in the finish though...
Great beer!  Nice body and wonderful after taste (almost toffee-like).  Amazing with burgers.  Cannot find in Nova Scotia
i could not finish this drink had to hand it over, too sweet for me.  had a nice orange amberish hue, malty aroma...not for me...it was ok.
A bit too sweet for my liking but it doesn’t it make it a bad beer. It poured and orange light color, with a sweet aroma, and light head. This is a decent one.

poured an almost orange/amber color, head was pretty thick but diminished rather quickly. a slight amount of alcohol detectable in the aroma, also in the taste, warm as it goes down. very malty and a nice mouth feel. i give it o perhaps two points over celebrator, it's also .75 cents per bottle cheaper! a very nice brew, i’ll have another.

Orange amber aroma with a thin fizzy head that was gone before I was able to put the empty bottle in the trash.  Aroma is very malty with a wood roasted grain tone that is a bit striking.  There were also notes of orangey hops.  The taste is robustly sweet, with a smoky peaty background supplemented by vanilla, apples, and oak.  The hops are floral and peppery, but are definitely playing second fiddle here.  The body feels a lot thicker in the mouth than the appearance first suggests.  The alcohol is apparent from the beginning, and detracts a bit from drinkability.  The father of the dopplebock style does not live to the initial expectation, as it has been surpassed by a more talented child (i.e., Celebrator).

Light brown color with a big tan head.
Very malty aroma with hints of bread and honey. Sweet and malty taste with just a touch of bitterness to balance it out. Heavy mouthfeel.

poured a amber color with a big tan head.aroma molasses, honey, choc. the good kind and as it warmed a light musty oder. flavor malts, choc, dark fruits could not pick which one a nice bitterness with a touch sweetness in the finish. not to bad
Pours thick with a large head; a dark-orange color. Smooth, malty smell. Rich, creamy flavor, clean with a slight alcohol taste. Very good.

nice clear,dark amber color,good head but faded fast.
 strong sweet roasted malt flavor like a stout..
a bit to much alcohol for my taste on the finish,,this would be good once in a while but not more than one.

Very nice molasses smell.  Orange-ish, brown color, not much head.  On my first taste I had only minutes earlier finished a chocolate bar, and the beer tasted quite like strong coffee with alcohol.  Not liking that, I waited a bit and tried again.  Much better...nutty, smoky, and chocolatey. Alcohol is noticeable in the finish,  but is not unpleasant.

Low, fizzy head.  Dark caramel coloring.  Tastes sweet with roasted malt, with chocolate finish.  Slightly spiced, warming effect, with minor finish of alcohol.  Pretty good beer for the price.  Not my favoritate style, nor my favorite of the style, but it’s quite drinkable.  Kinda thin for a dopplebock, but it's not bad.  I prefer Paulaner's excellent hefeweizen over most of their other beers.

Bottle Pours a medium redish brown with no real head a little lacing.  Stong aroma of honey, warm spices and malt.  Sweet and malty up front with honey, hazelnuts, prunes and a nice full smokey slant.  Plenty of carbonation and the finish is quick with a little bite that hangs around. If this is a typical Doppelbock, I’ll be looking for more in the future.

Poured a wonderful red/brown colour with virtually no head. The nose is malty with hints of bread. The flavour evokes caramel sweetness with spice notes.  Nice little hit of alcohol on the finish makes for a nice mouthfeel.
Draft. Rusty orange hue; cloudy. Where’s the head? Nice apricotty/bready  aroma. Like the malt presence & tartness on back of tongue. Roasty yet drinkable in quantities.
Amber Coloring.  Malty.  Caramel.  Had this one a year ago. Need to try again.
Amber colored with a toasted bread smell. Has a nice creamy malty taste with a hint of some syrup. Feels very nice in the mouth. Has a sweet aftertaste that isn’t overpowering.
Brownish color with average sized head.  Very sweet with little harshness that I usually expect from a doppelbock.  Another fine beer from paulaner.

Bottle.  A reddish-orange doppelbock that sits under a foamy, tan head.  Sweet, earthy, malty aroma with notes of toffee and dark sugars.  Medium body with a smooth, creamy, moderately syrupy mouthfeel.  Rich caramel flavour, with some rye bread-like maltiness present, as well.  A woody, earthy bitterness ushers in the dry finish, leaving a lingering, semi-sweet aftertaste.  Although this has probably undergone some changes over the past few years, it is still very satisfying.
Red brown colour with excelent head and lace. Huge sweet caramel and malt aroma. This is thick, sweet and absolutely delicious. Malt is king over hops here. Very much my kind of beer.

18 June 2004 - Lovely Fruit malty sweet aroma, lacing on the poor side, but head retention is a little better, red brown clear, but maybe it could be by beer. Smooth hoppy drinkable fruity brew with nice spices and finshes dry with a lingering hop.  ver drinkable.
dark Red clear colour with good head malt hop aroma. strong malt spiritus flavour with smooth finish. Could drink this one all night!
The defining modern example of the dopplebock style.  There is simply none better in the world today.

Pours with a two-finger head that fades slowly leaving some lace.  Deep, clear amber color.  Low carbonation.  Nose is malty.  Medium bodied. Starts sweet, very smooth, the high ABV is not noticable.  $1.90 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

very caramelly and malty.  although i was in a rather significant state of intoxication at the point of tasting, it was still pretty tasty stuff.  very syrupy but still a tad thin.  masks the 7.5% well.
amber with an off white head.  Malty, fruity aroma.  Tastes like caramel and plumbs; malty. A thin beer that finishes dry.

This one’s underrated. Actually reminds me of a more interesting Bass ale. Terrific mouthfeel and strong malt backbone, with a little fruitiness in there -  but we’re not talking about the Richard Simmons type.
I enjoyed this. Very solid body, good malt taste.  Little aroma, but long lasting head.  Great malty balance in taste. Well done.
Reddish brown.  Thick body.  Lots of malt flavor,  darker fruit, can’t put my taste buds on it, though it is not raisiny.
Pale doppel, it’s a dark tan, not really very clear. Good head. Almost prune aroma and flavor dominates with a sweet caramel backup. It’s not too heavy but packs a definate punch.

Not my favorite style but I like the lack of bitter hops. I admire the Carmel flavor and it has an atractive red color.I like this better  then Ayinger myself as it lacks the thich medicanal afteraste. I would drink this again without hesitation but I like Pauliners wheat beers much better

Poured almost a clear brown with a nice head that dissapeared pretty quick. Light dried fruit aroma and molasses. Taste was a bit malty for my liking but very clean and refreshing. Not bad and very drinkable for 7.5%.

Pours a good rich red with a slightly off-white tight head. The aroma is quite complex - fruity with rich malts. The flavour backs up the aroma featuring sweet malt, fruit, faint coffe notes on a backbone of alcohol (unpronounced). The mouthfeel seems too thin. This is good, but a touch one dimesional.
Poured a copper color with a medium off white head.  Sweet and spicy, bready, and slightly fruit aroma.  Sweetness and malt, some alcohol as well.  Mouthfeel didn’t strike me as anything special.
Strong aroma, creamy head, slightly bitter, with some spiciness. The alcohol is definetely present, but not overpowering.  Overall good, but a strange aftertaste.
Among my favorites.  Sweet, syrupy, blackish copper and has substance though not for eveyone.  A fantastic sipping brew especially good in the crisp fall.  Not for your Bud faint-of-heart types.

Boring aroma, mild caramel. But a beautiful and tempting apperence, but damn ugly label! Gives a sparkly feel in your mouth, and leaves a bitter taste. The taste is sweet with caramel and sharp with herbes. A beer worth tasting, but not worth lovin’!

Ok, so I do not usually like Doppelbocks (besides Celebrator), but this one is pretty good.  Fruity and sweet nose.  Deep red color, small white head.  Sweet and slight fruit/caramel taste.  Doesn’t taste that high in alcohol.  Pretty nice.

Malty, caramel and spicy nose......is that Play Dough, too??!! thick malty and slightly fruity palate; gives you an alcoholic prickle on the tongue, for sure, and a nice lingering sweetness, maybe a bit too much there..... My kind of brew, though.
This gives doppelbock a bad name. The appearance was a lot lighter then i thought it would be. This beer has a world-renowned reputation, my ass.

I was really excited to try this stuff when I saw it.  My excitment turned to disappointment when I tried it.  It wasn’t near as dark or as good as I thought it would be.  I feel like a real smuck for buying this shit, it wasn't even half as good as Leinenkugel Big Butt Doppelbock.
very sweet. a little too sweet for my taste. has a gorgeous pour. beautiful amber color. consistant fruity flavor

Nice fruity aroma and dark brown appearance. Lots of alcohol in the flavor, which is not something I’m a fan of with a fruity beer like this. Flavors of "just off" berries and apples, with some chocolate notes near the finish. Thick body. Not really to my taste, but it fits the style well.

Intersting aroma of malt and fruit. Superb balance between the fruit and alcohol flavors. Salvator is the pioneer of doppelbocks but better doppelbocks are available nowadays, like the awesome Celebrator.

In your face carbonation and over-the-top unique flavour.  High alcohol and not that greatly masked but liked it. Need some food to not have to crawl away. Nice brown colour and bubbles. Aftertaste made it nicely drinkable. Chestnut chocolatley toasted malt.
Slightly sweet, very mild hop flavour with a hint of fruit, not a lot to write about but is very nicely made, malty, smooth palate.
I have to say its one of the best doppelbocks I've had so far. A great reddish appearance with a darker thin head. Awesome flavor, hard to taste the alcohol. Something I'd like to try again.
Dark amber in colour wih a thin head. Aroma is sweet caramel, alcohol and wood. Flavour is malts and alcohol with a long sweet aftertaste.
light amber in colour with short lasting thin tan head. Nose is rich malty with hintof sweetness with some hops. Light malty with faint hops. somewhat thin bodied. Not all that bad overall.

Bottle. Amber color with a thick off white head that is fairly retentive. Nose is of caramel and malt. Taste is highly carbonated and slightly metalic. Notes of fresh bread dough, spice, a little  hop, and apple are present. Finish is slightly dry and there is a hint of pear/apple and black pepper that lingers after the swallow. This is not a beer that would blow you away, but it would be a great session beer. I think that tap would be much better, and may eliminate that light metalic taste. Overall, I would have this again. 
[br]
re-rate. Draft-ark amber body with a thin ring of bubbles. Nose-grape, malt liquor, frat house after a home comming kegger. taste-medium to high CO2, light grape, light metal, lightly floral, cherry Kool-Aid, light slcohol, medium to high sweetness. Kinda white fruit (lychee, grape, etc.), good use of hops, very drinkable even though it is slightly on the sweet side.

Amber red to copper colored body, with a big nice tan head, it looks very delicious. Flavor is very rich with notes of malt, some candied fruits, molasses and a bittersweet ending. Very drinkable and very nice!
Aroma is dough, malt, spicy and quite frutity.

Copper colour, crystal clear with an attractive tan coloured head that fades back to just a wisp of creaminess on top.  Rich malty smell, some black pepper and alcohol are present as well as some fruit.  Flavour is of zesty malt, with some traces of plum.  Finish is quite bitter leaving a trace of grass and hay as it fades.  Quite good, but carbonation seems a bit harsh for a beer with such smooth flavour characteristics.

Bottled: Bready malt aroma with hints of spice and citrus. Beautiful clear copper coloring. Toasty malts predominate the taste, but more hops than I was expecting follow. Very nice indeed - I do believe I'll take another.

Aroma is very grain like--almost like cow corn.  Malty notes in the nose as well.  Pour is a transparent amber color with a decent off-tan head that has decent staying power.  This tastes different than the doppels that I am used to.  Quite floral taste and lots of sweetness as well in the middle.  Very malty.  If this is the first doppel, then I should pay homage.

nice amber red with a thick head that dissapated relitivly quickly. aroma was of rich malt and plums with slight toastyness and a little spiced alcohol. Sweet rich malt, dark and light fruit present. warming alcohol and slight flowery hoppiness, and a bitter dry finish.

Often the aroma and appearance of this brew is less than I expect from the style.  Does not display a normal head retention for the style, although the carbonation is reasonably active.  The aroma goes missing.  Mild toasted carmel aftertaste.

Deep orange brown colour with a light tan coloured head. Caramel, honey, and bready aroma. Caramel sweetness dominates, with some cereal maltiness kicking in and a quick bitter bite on the finish to balance out the sweetness. Full bodied and rich, almost but not quite reaching  syrupy.

Nice reddish amber color. Has flavors of caramel malt, "dark fruit" flavors, alcohol, and some citric hop bite. Not as complex as I was expecting it to be, but still a respectable brew. Reminds me more Sam Adams Double Bock more than any other brew. I like Optimator

Wasn't really up to my exectations.  OK, so my first doppelbock was an Aventinus, so what?

Well, I just thought it lacked that complexity that I look for in a good high Doppelbock.  Malty, some vienna or munich in there, a touch of chocolate, hops were low bitterness and came through in a slightly spicy finish.   It was good but unremarkable.
Copper, amber in color. Thin off-white head. Nose of carmel, and malt. Nutty, carmel, taste, with light hoppiness. This beer is pretty good, no complaints.
I dont think there is anything I can say that hasn't already been said about this fantastic dopplebock. I have been a longtime fan of this beer and will continue being one.
Very malty, but nicely hopped so it's ok. Standard bearer of the style. Rich and nutty. A classic.
Poured a nice dark amber.Had a sweet malty aroma to it.Has a nice malty/nutty/carmel flavor to it.the finish was slightly bitter.All in all not too bad

Darker amber body with a thin orangey head that dissipates quickly. Caramel aromas are present, but not overpowering. Taste is subtle....caramel, malt, and candy. Pretty thin beer though, so it goes down easy. Pretty much average.

Previously, I'd sampled a bad batch.  This time, I really had my eyes opened.  Rich, orange-brown with a sweet caremelly taste.  A nice alcohol kick that didn't overpower the nice, and again sweet, aftertaste.  When fresh, this is a darn good beer.

Red with a thick head that laces up nicely. Very strong malt and caramel aroma. Flavour is initially half a metric ton of malt which is quickly nailed by enough hops to send a man to the moon. Thin palate. I like this beer.
Draft at Brownies Pub in Philly. Nice beer. Poured a nice brownish color. Had a very good malt flavor to it.
Very thin, wheaty, carmelly doppel. Hints of fruits, esp. cherry.  Honestly, my least favorite style, even less than American Standard!

Totally limpid copper hue with a small off-white head that is quickly limited to a ring. Honest malty aroma with a light floral hops note. Mainly geared toward caramel, white chocolate, cashews, vanilla and not so well-hidden alcohol. Very sweet palate. Hazelnuts and crème caramel, licorice and marshmallows. Interesting flavor profile, but that’s just because I love the style and this one doesn’t have any of the balancing elements (smoke, light bitterness) that top examples like celebrator can boast about. It’s all about the malt which can become rather cloying at the end of the bottle. Smooth creamy medium body displaying particularly low carbonation. 
 A 2001 sample proposed far fruitier malt, better defined mouthfeel, very soft, more butter traces. 
 A fresh 2004 sample offered a weird greasier aroma, leathery with notes of beans, mild butterscotch. Off-dry dustiness took on the aftertaste while the palate had this characteristic tart earthiness a little too expressive for me. Body was a bit more powdery and oily Surprisingly, aging seems to help this one although the 2001 was still way short of world-class imo.

Poured a crystal clear copper. Low effervescence. Creamy off white head that vanished surprisingly fast into a lace and ring.

Odors of sweet malt, dried fruits with a distinct smoke overtone and detectable alcohol wisp.

Starts slightly sweet then gets oily... full of malt, caramel, molassesm figs and nuts....like a plumb pudding... unimpaired by any detectable hop balance until the finish where the herbal bittering shjows up with the light smokey roast coming in.
