A good brew but a tad too sweet and unbalanced for me..this is the origina;l dopple and still the standard but I’m glad there are more balenced bocks around like Weltenburger.
Clear orange in color with a lasting head. Smooth malty flavored. Very good. Subtle bitterness.
0.5l bottle. Clear orange with a lasting tan head. Smooth, mellow malty flavor. Sweet and sticky. Slight bitterness at the finish.

Dominated by malt.  Reddish-orange color, big but quickly dissipating creme head.  Fruity and sweet, almost too sweet, but still good.  Slight bite at the end, but dominated by malt throughout as per style.  Although not great, it is a nice beer and I will drink it again.
Light brown/tan color, medium-bodied. Sweet caramel, malty, decent. Sweeter finish.

This is a style that I generally tend not to like, especially the bottled version for some reason +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle with a nice label this beer pours a reddish-brown color with a small tan head that lingers. There is a strong scent of vegetables. Smooth, malty flavor with a bit of a vegetable soup element.  Slightly biting aftertaste. I had really been looking forward to this as I have enjoyed a number of Paulaner products - but this really disappointed me.

Deep amber color with a small white head. Aroma is bready, malty with hints of plum and brown sugar. Smooth malty with hints of caramel, brown sugar and raisin. Light hoppiness in the finish.  Slight warming alcohol feel. A satisfying dopplebock.

Orange/brown body with a small offwhite head.  Rich robust sweet malt, caramel, toffee aroma with some buttery diacetal notes.  Malty/ bready taste with a bit of caramel sweetness. Very light bitter on the finish.  Wet and refreshing palate that fades to a long lasting after taste.

Solid, but not outstanding German doppelbock prominently featuring the usual sweet, carmely maltiness, with bitterness and hops definitely taking a back seat; Sweetness is perhaps a bit too sugary, but that's a minor flaw; The maltiness doesn't finish well and is on the thin side, with the sugary sweetness eventually bordering on cloying; Higher alcohol content is apparent and is very warming; The abundant aroma is wonderfully malty; Color is reddish copper; Good sized off white head on the pour has good retention and leaves a moderate amount of lacing on the glass

Deep copper color with an orange hue.  Little head but incredible aroma!  Sweet caramel malt with toasty/biscuit notes coming through.  Very rich caramel maltiness yet manages a crisp finish - not overwhelmingly sweet.  Fruity flavors linger on the tongue.

Man, was this a disappointment!  Super chemical-fruity nose with some caramel and sharp citric whiffs.  Very alcoholic when cold, when warmer, lemon and licorice flavors emerge.  Smooth malt underneath with a smooth finish that I did not find cloying.  But the flavor combo wasn't the best.

Pours lightly carbonated with a clear almost orange body and a gorgeous tapioca head that lasts long enough and leaves a web of intricate lacing. Aroma is of malt, yeast, and alcohol. Smells rich, fresh, and warm. Has a smooth malt flavor with some nice German hops in the finish. Nice mellow alcohol flavor reminiscent scotch. Overall this is a delightful beer that I could drink a lot of in a short time.
Poured orange-red and still with a massive head.  Strong aroma of acohol and caramel.  The flavor is sugary and the mouthfeel is smooth.  Rich and bodied, caramel malt is predominant.

transparent red/orange color with a quickly vanishing white head.  strong aroma of grapes and malt...very unique from what i have experienced.  smooth body with very malty flavor with a hint of chocolate and carmel...fairly complex with a nice balance throughout.
Clear red/amber color. Head quickly vanishes. Very low carbonation. Light aroma of carmel and molasses. Flavor is mostly malty. Smooth and creamy finish. Pretty damn good.
An all together interesting beer.Great malty aroma and decent taste.Not a beer i could drink alot of,but an enjoyable enough beer every now and then.

Copper orange, smooth, almost oily looking diminishing head, leaves good lacing.  Smells very sweet, malty, almost slighty belgian fruity, a little alcohol and hops aroma too.  Tastes really malty, some hops, a bit more of the 7.5% ABV, some bitterness to balance the sweetness, a little roastiness too.  Smooth and full in the mouth.  Would try again.  Nice beer.

Medium clear amber with a medium head, distinctive musty sweet, malty caramel aroma. Pleasant mouthfeel, sweet candy with a punch of alcohol, some bitterness to balance the finish. A very decent dopplebock, enjoyable.

Salvator has  beautiful deep amber color and supports a creamy off white head that sticks around. The aroma is not too overpowering but very richly malty, some alcohol. Perfectly balanced hops and malt. Nice Doppelbock.

Cola colored, diminishing off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt, roastiness, caramel. All of those in the flavor, with some dried fruit and a tiny bit of grass. The alcohol, while remaining in the background, comes out a little as it warms. Full-bodied. I like this a lot.

Dark amber in colour, an off-white head. Aroma is sweet and malty, slightly alcoholic. Flavour is sweet, syrupy, notes of brown sugar and maple syrup. Nice transition to a bitter finish. Oily palate. Pretty good. Bottle.

Reddish orange in color.
Decent sized head with minimal lacing.
Nose is sweet, malty, honey, doughy.
Palate is sweet, honey and spice. light bitter finish.
Huge, frothy head with a lot of bubbles coming up the sides.  Alomost, soda-like.  Definate candy/carmel smell.  Pretty good.  Tastes of carmel and maple syrup.  Good thick malty taste.

Disappointing. I think I wrote in my description of Andechs that I preferred Salvator but now that is definitely not the case. Smells OK and malty - some honey on toast. A touch of diactetyl but in a good way.
Flavour is thin, I remember it as being thick and malty but not so. OK balance but that's not what a doppelbock is about really.
Winter Jubilee '04, Amber in color with a large white head.Malty,with a touch of sweetness,caramel and toasted malt.

The color of dark amber or bourbon with a medium, bubbly head, beige.  A bit sweet, but not sticky sweet, more like hard candy.  Oaky.  Molasses, booze, and orange (?) aromas.  Nice beer.  It hold its carbonation micely for such a high ABV beer.  The mouthfeel is cleansing at first, but later in the glass is gets a tad thick (cloying?) and syrupy/sweetish. I prefer the richness of Celebrator anyday, but this is a bargain in comparison at almost half the price.
Out of the bottle. Nice deep red color. A little sweet and has some chocolate along with yeast. This one the better dopplebocks I have had, but not the best.
This is strong, and a bit too sweet. It has strong flavor and is refreshing, especially if you are about two in already. Not a bad beer at all.
The yeasty flavor and aroma are a bit too overbearing for me.   Chocolate sweetness is also evident.

Paid $1.39 for a 12 oz single.

Great looking! Pretty amber color, with a big frothy, creamy, almost sexy looking head... I can't see how they could improve the way this beer looks-- unless there were to insert foil sealed packets with hundred dollar bills in them... you get my point =)

Sweet chocolate in the armoa... caramel, toast... Reminds me a bit of goold ol' chocolate milk made with the power, rather than the syrup (yuck).

Sweet chocolate... a bit too sweet for me. Alcohol isn't masked well, but it's not overly overpowering. The sweetness is really what sticks out.

A bit thin in the mouth, but hey... not gonna complain.

Pours a light mahogany colour, smells of candy apples. Heavy toffee, malt and honey notes, sweet but tastefully balanced. Very fizzy. I liked it, but can't see myself drinking more than one (at a time).

Brown, maple syrup pouring clear. Lacey burnt butter golden head. Very pretty. Clovey nose with some roasted malt and coffee. Syrupy body. Pepper and chocolate predominate notes of toffee. Malty slightly bitter. Enjoyable. Don't drink it cold. It really does look like cognac it the proper glass. She's a beauty.

this is good.  not great.  this ain't no celebrator, but whatever.  amber in color, decent sized head that disappeared quickly.    celebrator is the first dopplebock i've ever tried, so maybe i'm ruined...  this lacks the depth and richness that i desire, but still good.

Poured an amber colored brew with a medium size head. Retention is very average as well as the carbonation. A bit of caramel and sweetness with an above average body. Not the best doppelbock I have tasted but bot bad either.

Crystal clear, dark orange ale. Medium-sized, fizzy, beige head.
The nose is very malty and minty with light  notes of dried plums, molasses and alcohol. The flavor is very malty, yet well-bittered to achieve balance. Astringent. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Crisp, clean finish which leaves one's mouth feeling parched.
Not as dark as i thought it would be.  Not as thick as i thoughtit would be. Yet like any of paulaner's other brews, this stuff its pretty good.
Nice reddish color and slightly sweet flavor. Doesn't finish so well, though. I also expected it to be a bit thicker and darker, more robust.

(Bottled, 7.9%) Clear, deep copper/amber color with a smallish, quickly vanishing head. Sweet aroma with burned sugar, alcohol and some roasted malt. Grainy-malty, sweet, slightly dark-fruity flavor with low bitterness, some smokiness, and - despite the sweetness - very evident alcohol presence. Medium-bodied, but somehow watery palate with low but fizzy carbonation, and noticeable alcohol burn. Instead of a hop bite in the finish, this one has alcohol burn. A sweet, watery and alcoholic doppelbock. Not very good.
(Bottled, at TOT ’04, was 7-4-7-4-14=3.6) Amber color, clear, flat body. Average, frothy, mostly lasting head. Roasted malty aroma with dark chocolate, lemon, honey and green tea. Sweet and acidic flavor, hints of rye. Slightly sweet finish. Medium-bodied, flat carbonation, dry and oily palate with a slightly alcoholic feeling. Surprisingly light and pale, but not bad.
filtered redish brown beer, not much head, lots of caramel aroma, very malty, sweet, but balanced. A very good bockbier!!

Nice thick head from the pour.  Good carbonation.  Aroma is a medley of honey, malt, a bit of hops and some kind of fruit.  Slight metallic palate initially then develops into a creamy mouthfeel.  Quite nice.  Flavor is smooth and sweet with more malts, a bit of caramel and a alcohol presence that increases as the beer warms.  Buttery toffee, yummy.  Color is a nice deep amber.  Finish is warming from the alcohol with a slight hops presence.  A good dopplebock.  I expected it to be a little thicker than this.  Very easy drinking though and worth the time.

Lightly hazy light copper w/ a short lasting beige head.  Munich malty aroma w/ some sherry notes.  Probably way past it's prime.  Also has a light plum fruitiness, hints of roast, and alcohol when it warms.  Very malty as it should be; well balanced, raisiny and lightly roasty, however sherry notes in the flavor as well in the finish which is a little on the dry side w/ a caramel aftertaste.  Fuller bodied w/a low level of carbonation, smooth mouthfeel w/ well hidden alcohol.  Unfortunately, this bottle is way past it's prime and I'm rating this with my past experiences with this particular brand instead of this actual bottle.  The age added some unnecessary complexities that were not very complimentary to the beer.  This is one of my other favorite styles of beer so I've had this on more than a few occasions and am just getting around to rating it now.
Deep in color with a small head. Sweet and malty with a strong flavor and a hint of the alcohol, though it is fairly well masked. I am not too familiar with the style, but this was rather nice.
Nice copper color with a nice white head. The taste is malty with notes of alcohol. Nice balance in the finish.

A very nice copper/amber color with a predominately caramel and toffee flavor.   Sweet, malty nose.  The malts can get so sweet at times that it becomes a bit much though.  Nice alcohol presence and enough hops to give it a slight bite.  A nice beer, although not a huge fan of this style.
Creamy beige head on a clear deep amber colored body. Fruity and malty aroma. Sweet malty flavor with plenty of fruit. Nice bitter finish. A full and very smooth beer!
Georgus amber, deep copper colour. Mild malty fruit aroma but a full smooth flavour with a nicely lingering bitterness. Will buy a few of these to have around.
Full head, beautiful red color. Not as heavy as expected for a double bock, but very good overall. Unfortunate that it's only a seasonal.
Sweet malty aroma of cherries.  Translucent red color with thick white head.  Sweet cherry and strawberry flavors.  slightly tart.

lots of malt and caramel on the nose, fantastic ruby/copper colour, huge malt flavour with lots of caramel, hints of pepper and citrus.  fantastic creamy, buttery mouthfeel with long lingering bitterness which complements the malty flavours superbly.

Huge malty aroma with notes of caramel, molasses and yeast apparent. Very clear copper cloured beer with dense small bubbled head that lasts fairly well. Sweet malty flavour with a sugary/yeasty middle and a dry alcohol finish with a lingering bitterness. Alcohol is very apparent in the flavour but not in a bad way. Very smooth mouthfeel with medium-full body. Bottle.

Light copper colour.  Very fragrant dense head.  Heavy toasted malt flavour balanced well by a hoppy finish.  I'm a big fan of Paulaner after visiting Munich.  Their beer continues to amaze (... except for that Hefewiezen, but that was probably just me:)

Pours clear and light brown in coloring with a tall white head.  Strong malt aroma with a bit of yeast and caramel included.  Tastes like malt, bread, and faint fruitiness.  Leaves a mildly dry, mildly sweet aftertaste.

April 2007. Dark amber brown body, moderate beige head. Malty aroma has a bit of alcohol presence. Flavour is similarly quite malty, lots of caramel malt flavours. Booze is restrained, but quite prominent on some sips. Not super complex, but has a very pleasant simple sweetness that was quite nice paired with a beer and molasses basted ham. Serving chilled mitigates the alcohol presence somewhat. Shared by Tuqueboy. 7/3/7/3/15 - 3.5
December 2003. Dark amber colour, not much in the way of head. Aroma and flavour are malty. Finish was lackluster. A pleasant but unexceptional doppelbock that may have not have stood up well to the chocolate I had had not too long before. Will have to try another one now that the LCBO is carrying bottles of this.  5/3/6/3/13 - 3.0

This is why I love doppelbocks. And supprisingly, it's the first time I've had a Salvator.

Beautiful pour with less of a head than I was expecting. Cloudy copper color. The scent seemed to pour out of the glass as I poured; a very strong smell of malt.

Man can you taste the malt! But it's wonderfully balanced by the hops! What a mixture. Carmel and toffee tastes linger. A heady sensation coats the tongue making me crave a cigar. A Partagas Serie D No. 4 would *really* hit the spot right now.

A very enjoyable beer. I could only have about two of these pint-sized bottles before I would be done for the night, though, but man what a night it could be.

Tasted in Toronto from LCBO.  Tasted in Raftman tulip. Orange / red / brown appearance.  Very little head, not lasting.  Slightly sour / tangy aroma, with a complex nose.  Sweet start in the taste, with a strong malty finish.  All malt.

First try of this doppelbock was a little bit of a disappointment.
Since the other Dopplebocks that I have had at the end of this year were better. It started with the almost flat pour which resulted in a almost non-existant head. The colour was a very nice dark caramel. The aroma was not overpowering and had a slight caramel scent with a dash of citrus. The flavour started out nice and smooth but in the middle came a alcohol bite with a kind of sour finish. I don't want to bash this beer too badly, it wasn't the worst beer that I have tasted. I will be giving this one a second chance!

This was the first Doppelbock that I ever had and the thing that I remember most is that the lack of carbonation sort of surprised me.  Good, strong, hearty, sweet, dark and enjoyable.  I think a toffee like flavor came shining through on this one the most.  My uncle bought this for our beer exchange Christmas 2001.  Good work JZ.

I've finally been able to get a couple of bottles of this stuff!! Dark amber with dark beige head. Lasts into thin whisps. Caramel aroma but faint. Carbonated oily palate. Warming alcoholic presence. Dry bitters present in the finish. Quite warming and enjoyable.

1 pint brown bottle. Bottling date of 07/02. I guess this one has aged a bit, huh? Poured out a light brown, copper color. It had a frothy white head that didn't last long, but left yeast bits floating on top of the beer. Aromas are of caramel, malts, slight baking spices, and yeast. The tastes are of caramel malts, some spiceiness, yeasty bread, and rum soaked fruit. Strong taste of rum in my bottle. Tastes very good, with a super strong malty backbone, and a slight hops bitterness in the finish. Alcohol is well hidden, but it will sneak up on you. This beer could easily replace Celebrator in my favorite bock beer catagory. Too bad it's so rare in my area. I could use another one.
Color between amber and brown.  Deep and rich.  Head ample and tan and creamy.  Aroma pleasant and buttery.  Flavor has hint of what I think is toffee.  A good, strong yet not overpowering beer.
Sweet, malty aroma. Brown colour, fluffy white-ish head. Bold flavour. Slightly bitter finish. Alcohol emerges through in the end.
A small bite on the back flanks of the tongue. Has a typical Belgian stench... yum! A slightly charred malt tinge. Covers farts nicely.

Bottled.  This looks lovely: red, frothy and fragrant.  But it's just too sweet, making the big alcohol aftertaste a little sickly.  The mouthfeel is a bit sludgy too - I guess this just isn't the kind of beer for me...

Sweet smell: grapes, figs, sour hops, slight yeast. Watery brown colored body with abundant bubblage on sides of glass and a big eggnog colored head on top.  2 dimensional taste that starts fruity with malt, grape and apple juice on the palate. The flavor then turns to a spicy hop finish and a bitter coffee taste. Aftertaste is alcohol and grape. Flavor is a little watery in all aspects. Sampled at cellar temperature. Purchased at Whole Foods in Vienna, VA.
12 oz bottle.  Big malty beer, not much hops, don't taste the alcohol, but you do feel it later.
Deep dark red with a tan foamy head. Very malty aroma. Lots of alcohol with a sweet malty flavor. Very good beer.

Large ass tan head, nice lacing. Deep amber color, clear. Grainy, fruity nose, some raisins and fresh baked bread. Full body. Slick mouthfeel, but still chewy. Medium sweet malt, bread and some alc. notes with some toffee flavors also. Finish is sweet with some roastiness. A nice double bock.
Salvator is the origianl that other dopples strive to imitate.  Malty and smooth without being overbearing.
Nice amber color, head quickly recedes, leaving minimal lacing. Aroma is very malty, maybe a touch of alcohol.  Fantastic mouthfeel, a little alcohol burn at the end on the palate.

The beer pours a nice deep copper/red colour with a fine 3 quater inch head which dissapates down to a lace on top.
The aroma of this beer is excellent..i loved the strong malt..very very nice.
taste is warm and rich..but for such a stong beer..not too "alcoholic"..very smooth on the tongue with a nice lingering aftertaste in the back of the mouth. Warming as it goes down
This is a very drinkable Double bock..one would need to be careful of how much is consumed because I am sure this will get you tipsy very quickly..but overall I loved this beer..

Means "the Saviour" so already we're in for an interesting ride!  Chocolate brown in color.  Smells like raisins or molasses.  (Would be interesting to baste a ham in this stuff!)  At 7.5% packs a punch.  A thick, rich, creamy head.  Spicy aromas.  Tastes a little like Pumpkin-Fresh Baked Apple Crisp.  Creamy, strong and lingering finish.  Good, but I think I enjoy the similar Celebrator Doppelbock an the Spaten Optimator better.
Malty aroma.  Good sweet malt body carries through to the finish.  Balances the alcohol quite nicely.  An easy drinking bock.
Pours copper with medium head.  Very nice yeasty aroma.  Strong malt flavor with nice fruit.  Nice bitterness and strong alcohol balances nicely.  Very nice beer!!
(Bottle) Pours a cooper orange color with a foamy head.  Good dopplebock flavor.

Holy Moly, this is a decent bock.  Pours dark amber ruby in color with yellow foamy head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is of malt and grains. Flavor is same with definite sweet fruitiness that comes through nicely.  Alcohol is well-hidden in flavor but the kick is immediately noticeable. Fellow Texans who are accustomed to Shiner Bock really need to try this one for a bigger better beer that better represents the essence of "bock".  Wow, I’ll take another of these please.
Copper/orange color, normal head. Aroma is fruity and also there is some kind of candy. Has a somewhat strange falvor, and I dont like this one the way many other seem to do.

Big bubbles in the head, but doesn't last. Copper-red color, very clear.  Sweet. malty nose, with a bit of alcohol. Malty flavor, pretty sweet, but just a little thin.  The alcohol flavor is evident for a 7.5%ABV beer. This beer warms me after just a few sips.

(bottedl) Red amber color with creamy off-white head.  Rich toasted malt aroma with sweet ripe fruit.  Medium-full bodied beer with big toasted maltiness, caramel, plum flavors.  Firm bitterness (aided by peppery alcohol) cuts the sweetness perfectly, keeping it from being cloying.  Very nicely done!
rich and delicious, this beer was highly recommended to me and proved to be worth the recommendation. dark and flavorful...

Bottled. Irregular size bubbles, fizzy light brownish head, fully diminishing. Clear reddish colour.
Sweet and heavy malty nose, with hint of dark bread, toasted, nutty, honey aromas. Light hoppy, flowers, weak citrus (orange) note. Floral nose from alcohol. Bittersweet character, full flavor of toasted malt. Full body, syrupy texture, soft carbonation. Pleasant warming beer.

It poured with a nice head but is dissipated quickly.  Rich red/gold in color.  Strong aroma that tells of the beers sweetness.  It's a little too sweet but not bad.  It has a good citrus/malt combo that's quite refreshing.

Pours a deep reddish/amber, medium sized tan head quickly diminishes and leaves little lacing.  Aroma is very sweet and malty, some caramel, and a bit of alcohol.  Flavor is almost overly sweet, a bit of bitterness in the finish, and again a bit of alcohol.  Medium body, alcohol gets a bit more prevelant as it warms
Intense malty aroma. Crystal clear red/orange colour with a quickly diminishing head. Rich sweet malty flavour with small hints of spice. Drinks really nicely but the bottle is too small.

Pours a nice copper color with small white head.  Sweet fruit and malts in the nose. Spice and malt in the flavor with some fruit and a bit of underlying alcohol bite. Smooth finish, warms the stomach a bit. Great beer!
Pretty good.  Red/orange color and a nice head.  Sweet aroma with malts mixed in.  The flavor was malty, some fruits, and a bit of spice near the end.

Dark reddish color with beige medium head. Aroma is of chocolate and sweet malts. Nice blend of malts and sweet fruity flavors.Finishes slightly hoppy with a sweet raisin aftertaste. A solid doppelbock.

Bottle. Mahagony color with a decent off-white/beige head. There was a nice spicey-sweet smell to the beer that lead right into the taste of the same. It's a malty/slightly fruity/slightly spicey beer with a lingering presence of just a bit of hops/alcohol. It's a nice beer, but not the best in its style.
Slight fruit aroma chocolate carmel friut taste, but nothing distinctive or bold, not as complex as its rep would have you believe. Good but great? nope
Small head, RED-brown colour. Aroma is full of malt. Taste is also dominated by a malty sweetness plus a little fruit with late bitterness. Nice balance.

way to sweet for my taste. It started off with a very appealing aroma and a great deep red color.  After that it was all down hill. I would classify this beer as almost chewy, with a hard to swallow aftertaste. Not my favorite.

This rich, reddish copper beer pours with a thick tan head that recedes to a fine layer of foam. The aroma is of roasted caramel, sweet and satisfying caramel. Nice roasted malt character and just a bit of floral hops in the nose. The first sip reveals strong malt sweetness, with caramel, brown sugar , and molasses flavors abounding. A bit of bitterness cleans the palate on the finish. The mouthfeel is smooth, with mild carbonation. Drinakbility is very good as well, especially for malt-lovers.

Deep redish amber color with a decent off-white head. Sweet fruity and malty aroma. Flavor is rich caramel sweet with dark fruit and a light bitterness. The finish is lightly sweet and slightly acidic. Full body is rich and creamy with moderate carbonation. Nice Doppelbock.
A very enjoyable doppelbock. Amber colored, decent head. Bready and malty aroma. Big sweet malt flavor with a bit of alcohol on the end. Very nice body, slightly chewy. Real good stuff.

deep amber color, thin but lasting head. the bready (slightly sour)malts are there from the start. same in the flavor as well..all malt all the time...are there any hops in this thing at all? finishes with a hint of alcohol..seriously, if malts are what you do well, then by god, sally forth...they're done well here. i've had this once before a long time ago, but felt a rating from my memory of it just wasnt acceptable.

It pours nice clear amber with a storm of bubbles that builds a nice thick sustaining head.  The lace slides down the glass quickly.  The aroma is of malt and alcohol.  Wow, the flavor is big; sweet with a drying finish.  There are hints of grain based hard liquor.  It is a rich beer that also has nice carbonation.  I like this…
Chocolate brown in color with a rich lacey head - the aroma of bread, the flavor of raisins and molasses, a very satisfying brew. Go out and buy some!
Fantastic double bock, by which all others should be measured.  Great malty aroma.  Full bodied and not for the timid.  I would like one more percentage point on the alcohol, but perhaps I'm greedy?
Pretty nice dopple...  Malt, nutty, and fruity flavors give it a nice impact, but the aroma is a bit light.  Palate is very nice, creamy smooth.

Dark copper with slight reddish tint, minimal head no lace. Heavy malt aroma, touch of banana. Big malt, molasses, light carbonation, ginger, and whiskey (no good). Sticky sweet and medium dry finish. Alright beer, had to pour out half way through.
Strong sweet, malty smell. Clear red coloured with a lasting head. Taste is strong malty, bit one-dimensional. Moderate bitter palate.
This is awful light for a double bock!  Fruity smell.  A tasty beer with a nice bite, but not at all what I was expecting.
Red orange hue like a Lake Michigan sunset. Quarter inch tan head. Good nutty smell, maybe prunes as well? Rich flavor, a little bit of chocolate and yet a little sour. Bites the tongue.
niiiiiiice for a doppel. very smooth.. Not sure I could drink more than 3 or 4 in a sitting though. Not quite as good as Celebrator, but definitely more drinkable.

Almost no head.  The alcohol shoots through like a sore thumb and does a good job of masking any other flavor.  Oily is a good description of the feel.  Not sure if I'm a fan of this one.  Maybe I got a bad bottle.

Pours a nice coppery color.  The head disappears in a few seconds.  Many people have said buttery or oily, I guess that's where this is.  Not like any of the other (decent) doppelbocks I've had, although I'd drink this before the Sam Adams.

Light copper hue and small head and some lacing. Aroma hints of molasses, herbs, honey, ripe pears, and vanilla. Starts sweet but a swipe of alcohol cleans the palate. Fruity taste and aromatic german hops are detected as well. Full-bodied with a oily and soft mouthfeel. Moderate alcoholic feel is present. A well developed bock that sneaks up on you if you're not ready.
Dark Honey colour,creamy but diminishing head.Malt flavours of caramel and butter thought it might have been more flavours and a bigger beer.

Hmmm... not exaclty what I expected, but still a nice drop. Lovely aroma. small head which doesn't last too long. Different to the (albiet few) other bocks/doppelbocks I have had. "german" hop profile if I can say that.

Light caramel color, small head.  Caramel aroma
Good flavor which is slightly candy like.  Ok finish 
but not as strong as I want.

Bottle. Glowing polished mahogony appearance. Aroma of warm malt bread and other nice things, but held back by the alcohol fumes. Dark and malty with an alcoholic fire. Mostly sweet, but with a little stewed hop bitterness in the finish. First brewed by the Paulaner monks of Munich in 1634, this is the original Doppelbock. The monks were forbidden by the other Munich breweries from selling their beer until 1751 when they were allowed  to sell their Sankt-Vater-Bier on the feast day of St. Franz of Paula. In 1799 the monks brewery became the property of the Bavarian state, after which it based through various hands and changed names several times. The popularity of Sankt-Vater-Bier, which over the years had become corrupted to Salvator, led to many copies until in 1895 the brewery was able to trade-mark the name. Other breweries now use such name variations as Triumphator, Celebrator, Detonator, Maximator and Optimator. Since 1921 the brewery has bought up several other breweries and is now one of the biggest breweries in Munich. In 2001 Heineken acquired a 49% share in the brewery with the intention of promoting the Hefeweizen at the expense of many of the other products of the brewery. There is some belief that the recipe has changed in recent years.

This amber beer has ruby glints and a medium foamy heat that dissipates into good lacing. The nose is intensely sweet and deeply malty with toffee and soft apple fruit. The palate is not nearly as sweet as the nose would indicate, but it does have a nice caramel backdrop on which the light toasted grains and overripe fruit intermingle. The finish is quick and light with a soft burst of herbal hops that quickly fades into the rich caramel finish.

A very pleasing red/amber colour with a slightly soapy looking but white, clean head. A malty toffee nose with a low hop aroma. The taste is creamy and full with a good hop presence to balance the strength of the beer. Carbonation is low which is good for this style.

Pours a ruby red with some darker brown tones and some richer yellow tinges.  Very clear though, no yeast in bottle. Head was very small to not existent.  When present it was a whitish beige.  Not tons of aroma, spicy though, with some hops and maybe a little dry malt aroma.
Begins dry and somewhat bitter but quickly explodes with a big spicy fruit flavor with sweet orange, tart cherries and a mix of light toffee and saltwater taffee adding a lightly chewy texture.  The carbonation level is not too bad and adds to the texture.  Has some yeast flavor to it and definitely a dry hopped flavor I wasnt expecting that was pleasant.  Very spicey throughout, though as it finishes the taste leaves too quickly.  This beer was well balanced and the body tastes very flavorful with lots of bursting fruity malt flavor in your mouth, but overall, is a bit dry and ends unremarkably.  A lot gentler than both Schneider Weisse and Celebrator.  Dosent kill you with sweetness, that was a plus and does not seem overly alcoholic.  I do not see a cloying or even a very sweet finish that others talked about.
Nice red amber color. Sweet malty aroma with hints of citrus. Taste is sweet, malty and faintly acetic. Decent but definitely a rung below Spaten Optimator on the Doppelbock ladder.

Bottle.  A reddish orange color with a creamy tan head.  Molasses, sweet malts, brown sugar, and burnt caramel in the aroma.  This reminds me a little of some barley wines.  The flavor is sweet and malty with some wood and caramel.

Poured a magnificent glowing crystal clear reddish copper color. The head began as nice thick tan, but soon dissipated to nothing. The aroma and flavor were malty sweet...bordering on syrupy, cherry, iced tea, and alcohol...at times very much like a weak barley wine. The feel began as crisp and bubbly, but soon became more flat and thick. Interesting beer, had the feel remained consistent I think I would have like it much more.

Finally, number 100!  Poured a deep red color, good initial head dissipates quickly.  smells mostly of malts, maybe some sweetness too.  Flavor is, once again, malts with little hop, medium carbonation, pehaps a bit of a cidery taste, and a little metallic.  A middle-of-the-road beer.

This is a full-bodied, transparent and copper colored beer with a medium-sized, but quickly dissipating tan head, as poured from the 0.5L bottle I sampled.  By the time I finished, there was virtually no lacing on the pint-sized pub glass.  This Doppelbock leads with a pleasingly bold, ripe fruit and malt aroma.  The initial flavor is malty and quite sweet with hints of raisins, ripe grapes or prunes mid-palate.  Still, by the finish, I found the beer to be well-balanced and layered with pleasing carbonation and an appropriately dry and light hop flavor.  I also noted a trace of alcohol in the long finish.

Bottle.  Pours beautiful orange-amber color with a large off-white head that diminished rapidly.  Sweet malty aroma with spice, apples and a hint of citrus with a noticible alcohol presence.  Sweetly pungent flavor, raisins, clove and a dry finish.  Syrupy texture and smooth mouthfeel.  A brew to be sipped and savored.
strong sweet malty aroma, deep reddish/copeer hue with an off white head, strong sweet malty flavour with significant alcohol tones, very sweet finish, too sweet for my liking

Very nice deep amber color with a super creamy-like head thats frothy and very tight. Looked like a lighter whipped cream and was light tan in color and nearly three fingers high. The lace clings in large patches that remain a long time on the glass. Smell is a very buttery roasted malt, like slightly burnt popcorn, but thicker. Is also somewhat sweet and toffeeish. 

Taste is super subtle of toffee, roasted malt, sweet, and is kinda creamy/silky smooth, a little bit chewy, with a lingering dryness that settles in and goes into the finish, which gets lighter. The finish, again, reminded me of that dry mouth feeling you get from eating dry popcorn. I really liked the feel of this beer, its so complex and layered. The taste is well rounded and has great subtle complexities as well. Absolutely drinkable and enjoyable. Highly recommended as far as dopplebocks go.

I enjoyed this, it was a nice surprise, as I expected the flavor to be something completely different.  Very dark  in the pour, and appearance, shiny puffy head, with a nice fruity aroma.  Heavy malt taste and feel, with hints of nuts and caramel.  Very warming in the finish, that makes you just want to sit their for a moment and enjoy what you have just drank, before moving on to something else.
Dark mahogany color with tan head and average lacing. Fruity malt aroma. Trademark dopplebock aroma and a smooth moist mouthfeel. This is a ways behind celebrator, but it still is pretty tasty.
Nice copper colour with little head. Beautiful aroma of malt and sweet caramel. Sweet, lingering malt, caramel flavour with a little bitterness to finish. A good one !

(Bottled) Copper colored with a small head. Nice malty aroma of caramel, toffee with some sweet alcohol. Sweet, complx and malty flavour of toffee, chocolate, syrup, wet grass and alcohol.
Long warming finsh with hints of dark chocolate and alcohol. An awesome beer.

Bottled.Rustic deep ginger/amber colour with lots of interest. My old man back home in Brisbane wants to try a dopplebock and this is what I’m going to take him. Its wonderful complexity. Sweet, sweet flavour. I’m near the end of it now but its been quite different from start to finish. God bless the variety of beer.
We call it "Starkbeer" in Bavaria, very popular among politicians during the "Fastentime" when you are not allowed to eat. It makes you head going round and round and roud and round and...
More red than amber color, yellowish head and big caramel, toffee aroma. Sweet, full flavored and toasty. Delicious. Mellow, slightly burnt finish, like pancakes.
Savior. Rich and nurishing. Hearty, and full and good words to describe this beer.
My personal favourite in doppelbocks. Lighter, yet more complex than most. Leaning towards aged features early on. Ripe plum and somewhat fiery young but matures rather quickly in a nice way.

I had this on draught in Germany a few years ago and enjoyed it very much. This sample was a 12oz bottle that poured crystal clear brown with a thick tight head that dissapeared in a couple minutes leaving only a few tiny dollops of white foam. Only slight lacing as well. Aroma is super sweet and malty with a hint of alcohol. Flavor is also very sweet and nothing but malt. It improves as it warms and flavor loses a little sweetness. Not nearly as impressive as when I had it on draught but a fine Doppelbock none the less and probably the best German Doppel out there.
A dark amber witha hint of rose. The head is off white. The aroma is of sweet caramel, alcohol and a hint of nuts. The flavor is full of sweet toffe and alcohol.

this medium bodied beer is dark amber in color. the cream colored head lasted only a moment and gave way to basically nothing. a burnt sugar nose continues on to a malty sweet taste, followed by a little bitter aftertaste. this beer is a mouthful!

12 oz. bottle Deep burnished copper colour, massively malty nose. Foams prettily with a vigorous pour, but is quickly subdued. The taste is heavy and sweet but finally balanced with a prickling bitterness. A most hearty beer, with plenty of character (albeit of a malty nature).

Light nut brown, much lighter than I am used to from a dopple bock, but then again this is the original
so does that mean the rest are wrong?  Anyway, good malty aroma, with some nuts and sweet caramel.
Flavour is very sweet, with some pears and light nuts.  A slightly spicy finish sits well on the palate, but I
didn't enjoy this one as much as some others.
Reddish brown almost burgundy color. Has no head. Smells sweet. Taste sweet and alcohol. Has the wet dog flavor. Warming down the esophagus.

The aroma is sweet and fruity. The color is a deep amber with a small disappearing head. The flavor is sweet with notes of juniper berries. A very nice beer, but not a good as Andechser Doppelbock Dunkel nor Carlsberg Bock.

This Salvator has a nice rusty appearance, and an average one-finger head that does not last long. This brew has a Better than average aroma, Taste is very malty, slightly nutty. Overall, not what I expected it to be, a bit better than average, however it is worth a try.

Upon opening and sampling the aroma, I knew this was gonna be a good one.  Nice vibrant dark orange color, almost no head.  Body was very creamy with wonderfuly sweet malts and spice.  This is like pumpkin pie beer.  This beer is very sweet and high in alcohol making it a good after dinner drink.
Sweet caramel, malty aroma.  Has a sweet candy like flavor with a great finish.  Great beer that I really enjoy.
dark red body and malty apricot aroma. With a sugary, apricot, and cider flavor. a creamy light carbonation palate

Sweet aroma with fruits in the background: plums, apricots, spicy berries. Pours an amber brown, fairly clear, head disappears quickly. Flavour wise, I found this fairly bland. It's like an embryonic Belgian style ale; it wants to be more but just didn't make it. Mouthfeel is interesting but not overly exciting. Alcohol is present at the end, but finish is flat. Can't really say I was especially impressed with this beer.

No head.  Nice copper colour.  Bread and fruit aroma (christmas cake).  Noticible alcohol notes.  Thick mouth feel.  Balanced flavour with no dominate characteristic.  Reminds me of a flat Maudite, not overly fond of the finish, it doesn’t invite me back for more.

Salvation in a bottle. Malty, musky, yeasty, and sweet; everything a beer thirsty s.o.b. like myself needs on a crisp spring night as this. I sense prunes and perfection in a fragance that thouroughly intoxicates my soul. Small swigs are a must as I wish to craddle and caress each dark mellow molecule across my thick and drunken taste receptor, and baptise it with each luscious wave. Hops is present, but not begging for attention like some 12 year old sissy boy with straight A's. Forget Jesus, Salvator is a pagan savior more preferable to this barbarous and looting rater of beers.

Good ale with the malt dominant from aroma to flavor to finish.  This is not a bad thing, however as the malt is very yummy.  Seems to be another layer of flavor I can't quite pin down.  Definitely repeatable.
Rich malty aroma and amber color. Sweet and smooth, not too high in alcohol. Malty sweet finish.
Has a dark reddish/amber color with little carbonation and a sweet/fruit/malt smell.  Taste is thick, malted and finishes very smooth with a little kick.  Overall a great doppelbock!!!
Dark amber color, wonderful sweet fruity aroma.  Has a rasin, fig flavor.  Smooth and very easy to drink.

Beautiful reddish dark amber colour (mahogony). Good sweet and malty aroma with notes of apples and maybe even strawberries. Full body, almost syrup like texture. Flavour is sweet and malty (plums, figs?) along with an alcohol presence and a lightly bitter finish. All in all a good doppelbock, albeit a bit too sweet for me.
Syrupy and sweet, dark brown color, flavor of carmel and figs.  Somewhat sweet burnt carmel taste on the finish.

This brew pours a very nice malty caramel aroma from a transparent light brown body with a medium head of fine to medium sized bubbles. It has a slightly fizzy initial mouth feel followed by a very nice smoky, slightly burnt, chewy full bodied spicy flavor. This is one of my favorite brews of all time. Next to Andechs, it was my favorite Doppelbock while I was overseas in Germany. Its high alcohol content can be felts even after just a few sips. It goes down very easy. I love it!

This is a very complex beer and a bit hard for me to rate as I consider myself still somewaht of a novice beer geek.  The appearance is copper in color, almost rust color.  It poured with a nice thick heat that took about 3 minutes to disappear.  Aroma is malty with fruit and a bit of alcohol.  It tastes a bit like a barley wine - sweet, fruity and alcohol but nicely balanced with malt and hops - that is to say not overly fruity which really turns me off.  It leaves a nice malty, caramel aftertaste that is also a touch sour from the fruityness.  very drinkable and enjoyable.
A very strong malt sweetness and it tends to overwhelm the other flavors. I prefer other double bocks but not a bad choice. the alcohol is well hidden.

Not always in the mood for one so syrupy sweet. I sure was this time. Been a while since I've seen this old friend. The malt richness coats the bitterness so that it slides across your tongue. Dark as it may be the roast characters lie beneath as well. Plum, raisin and perhaps other fruit. Felt like I had a nice desert mixed with my beer after dinner. Certainly not as sweet as all that, but switching gears from some substantially bitter IPAs it sure seems so.
nice beer... my first guess was that it was an abbey.  the fact i was wrong is a good thing.  approved by the wait staff.. i agree
This beer is a amber colored beer with a fruity smell.  It is slightly bitter at the first taste but leaves a sweet aftertaste.
Yet another red beer, didn't find out until after I bought it unfortunately.

Reddish-brown with pinkish hue. Apple sauce aroma with caramel and anise. Head was not substantial. Great mouthfeel and flavor, though difficult to pinpoint. Broad palate - sweet, tart , full, a touch bitter, fruity. Some minty notes, with plenty of malt and fruit. Finish is sweet, but hops present in sufficient quantities to temper this nicely.

Golden red body and a quickly dissipating white head.  Light aroma of caramel and malt.  Low carbonation, very smooth and sweet.  Tastes of caramel and banana.  Pretty good beer, although I do prefer Celebrator.

Keg
Light amber color. Caramel aroma. Good malty and caramel flavor, quite velvety.

Orange.  No head on this beer, but a lace is left on the glass.  Aroma of hops.  Slightly bitter, then sweet as it warmed.  One dimensional taste from the sweetness.  Thick. high abv is not noticeable in the taste. I am told this beer was invented when a monk was contracted to brew beer for a nobleman.  He accidentially let the beer freeze, but chipped off the ice and served it anyway.  Thus the picture on the label.

Well I must admit I am not a doppelbock fan at this point in my beer experience.  With that being said however, this beer is decent.  Good mouthfeel with sweet malty aroma and taste. Ends with an appropriate amount of bitterness as well.  A little too sweet for my taste) Syrupy at the end as well.

Salvator is markedly lighter than Celebrator (amber vs. dark ruby) but is very similar in aroma and flavor.  A malty sweet aroma is followed by sweet, smooth tones of prune, raisin, and caramel.  I am drinking Celebrator to compare beers, and Salvator seems to be overall lighter, less sweet, and less complex than its cousin.  Salvator is an enjoyable doppelbock, and one I will return to, considering its pricetag as compared to Celebrator!

This smells like hard candy. Thats pretty cool. Deep red coloring, with a quickly fading head. With the first sip, I immediately noticed a strong caramel flavor. As powerful as the caramel flavor was, I'd expected it to dominate the beer, but an apple flavor quickly came up as well, and it fought with the caramel down to the last drop, in a battle to close to call. A little thicker than I usually like, but it works well with this beer.

This one has been sitting idly by for way too long, so it was time for a rating. It poured a clear copper color with fairly noticeable carbonation, and a small off tannish head. The aroma gave off heavy malt and fruit undertones...perhaps apricot or citrus. The taste is a malty fruit mix up front...some vanilla, banana, and a heavy apricot and citrus bittering aspect, specifically in the finish. My largest problem with this beer was the strange mixing of the excess malts, which was nice, and then this syrupy and artificially sweet and sour apricotiness. The amalgamation of the two didnt allow this doppelbock to flow as well as i would have liked it to. Very low carbonation level, some noticeable alcohol at 7.5%, but nothing major. An enjoyable dessert brew.

This is a doppel that I truly enjoy drinking and this is one of my favorite beers thanks to my BF (thedm) who introduced me to fine beers and what good beers are all about almost 3 years ago!To me it has a superb taste and goes down very smooth and easy.
Deep brown color with a good head. The aroma promises a full malt experience, and that is realized. Fairly sweet with hints of molasses.

Brownish garnet, much paler than I expect from a doppel. Full, round body is slightly sugary and sticky. Nose of dark, fruity malts and alcohol. Truly a rich, delicious doppel. Hins of raisins, molassses, and warming alcohol.
very dark; rich and smooth tasting; distinct molasses smell and taste with little aftertaste

Clear deep amber body topped by a thick off-white longlasting head that leaves a good amount of lace on the glass.  Sweet and fruity (bananas) malt aroma that draws me to drink.  Sweet strong malt flavor with banana accents and a touch of alcohol.  Full bodied, smooth yet a touch dry and warming.

Pours clear amber with a medium bubbly white head. Not much retention though? Fruity-sweet aroma with a hint of hop presence. Thin mouthfeel, very sweet taste. A hint of smokey roasted grains and hop bitterness at the end. Alcohol well hidden.

Clear amber appearence, medium white head.  Aroma is very sweet, almost like sweet-tarts candy.  Tastes a little sour, bites the back of the tongue, with the primary flavor being corn.  Not very enjoyable.

ya know, this beer is the main reason i dont really like doppelbock's.  This beer had a great aroma and presence but the flavor was that old import skunky-ish malt flavor with alot of alcohol burn.  not my cup of tea.  I drank only about half of it, dumped the rest and cracked open a 03' SN bigfoot to make up for it :):):)
lighter in color then spatens doppel but a warmer not too sweet flavor. aber gut!
Medium dark amber with a creamy head. Pleasant malty flavor with a touch of molasses.
2/16/03:  bottle.  good amount of head and lacing.  candy apple aroma with malt tones.  red amber body.  sweet to the taste with some sour maltiness.

Dark, clear reddish-brown.  Sweetish aromas of caramel/toffee, malt, molasses, raisin.  More molasses in the flavors, balanced nicely by a roasty bitterness.  Alcohol does little to dry out the finish.

An amber color, fairly carbonated and the head lasts about an average length.  Very sweet, I tasted and smelled apple.  A little carmel in there too.  Not at all what I expected from a dopplebock, coming from Celebrator, but very nice.

Glorious medium-dark amber clear with large lasting yellow beige head. Lively woody hops and carmel malty sweet with hint of yeast and alcohol in the aroma. Full smooth low carb body. Big almost lusicious nicely lingering toffee sweet bready malt flavours dominate until a medium bitter less sweet finish and aftertaste kick in. ABV is pretty well masked with all that sweetness. Probably more suited to a colder season but nevertheless a very good example of  a Doppelbock.

I purchased this and the Weihenstephaner Korbinian Doppelbock at the same time and I must say that this one, rater slightly lower on average, I find far superior. The aroma is very nice and the copper color is as well. The flavor is full and lovely. A very nice doppelbock.
Not crazy about this doppelbock.  Carmel, tart, and bittersweet flavor.  Finishes dry and malty.

Had from bottle February 8, 2003
A friend recommended this beer to me, and I'm glad he did.  It pours a beautiful amber-brown with slight carbonation and a small head.  Aroma is sweet with a bit of alcohol, but not too overwhelming.  Taste is malty with a little bite of alcohol, but nothing too strong.  A fine beer and a fine recommendation.

Poured a beautiful leather colored body with a light tan head. No lacing.

Aroma had that wheat-ness to it. Maltiness and wheaty is the only way I can describe it.

Nice crisp flavor of malt. No hops present but the alcohol had a nice warming effect. I took the bite being more from the wheat than hops.

A bit of a bite on the tongue from the wheat, but that's perfectly acceptable.
This is a damn good beer, but it is light for the style.  Thin by comparison to other dopples and not as dark.  Great aroma that is typical with this style.  I like it, but there are better choices.

Deep copper color. Nice head that lasted about two minutes. Nice malty, carmelly aroma. Some hops. Nice underlying bitterness. Malty flavor. Some hop flavor. Some sweetness. Very clean. Medium body. Nice!

Pours a nice dark amber with a clean white head. Aroma is strictly clean European malts. Flavor is more of the same with a nice munich malt taste balanced by adequate hop bitterness. Not the most complex beer, but definitely a superbly balanced dopplebock.
A great golden orange color. Nice full white head. Sweet nose. Interesting flavor. Sweet to start. Tart in the middle and dry to finish.
A well made beer, strong and sweet.  Wife says it is better in Germany......

Interesting copper/amber color.  Poured with very little head, some lacing.  Initial tastes were full of caramel, but as it warmed, it gained a tiny bit of chocolate and a cherry-fruit flavor.  Becomes a bit treacly to me towards the end, there's no way I could have more than two of these.  Then the finish finally dried out.  A fine doppel.
In general I'm not a fan of Bocks, but this is one of the few I like. The dark malts, alcohol and hops balance out  the sweet caramel and malt flavor to make this a great dopplebock

The aroma is of flowers and caramel, with some light spice.  The appearance is a deep amber with a rusty/creamy head, and good lace.  The favor is great, initially caramel, then some spice in the aftertaste.  The beer is very smooth and clean.  Overall a very nice beer.
Nice light tan head - fluffy.  Amber - caramal color.  Surprisingly rich flavor for its color. Sweet persisting from start to finish.

A great ride, very strong, thick and sweet at the onset, but with a good hard, drier undercurrent that straightens out the dark berry jamsweetness, aided by a little alcohol zest.  A good one for my offcial 800.
Rich clean malt flavours predominate the profile of this beer, both in the aroma and on the palate.  Breadiness comes through and sweetness with just enough hops to balance it.
Big malty nose with hints of Spices and dried fruits.  Noticeable alcohol presence for sure.  Spices and tart berries prevail on the tongue.  Great stuff, excellent balance.
Great dark brown colour, very strong smell full of grapes! Great strong malty flavour!

Had a pint last night for New Years Eve, and I must say that it was much better than expected.  Very malty, very good taste to it.  Definately something I''d drink again, but not something I would want to drink all night on New Years Eve.
Probably my least favorite of all dopplebocks I''ve had.  It''s watery, with tea flavors up front and a burnt alcahol finish.  I don''t know if I can finish it.
Red copper in color, thin head that leaves in seconds.  Light carbonation, sweet  aroma of soy sause.  Malty taste with a sharp finish.
I like the "strong spirit" aspect of this brew. The bite and grainy aspect were wonderful. Will have again for sure.

Molasses, banana and orangepeel. Malty sweetness is accentuated by a charred smoky flavor throughout. This gives off a very strong alcohol odor and taste, though, which I don''t much care for. Overall pretty good.
Color, head, thinkness, and all around great stand by.  Not too strong tasting. Very drinkable
Dark amber in colour.  Molasses, caramel, malty aroma.  Thick, syrupy, sweet flavour.  Sweet, caramel aftertaste with a nice bitterness.
Bottled(330ml). -excellent and the best doppelbock .........................
The aroma is pretty fruity and it looks nice.  I could stand some more hops and some more carbonation, though.  Not bad.
Malt and bitter flavoured beer with a slight wheat beer aroma.  Good beer which hides its alcohol percentage well.
Sparkling light brown,lasting head. Malt nose. Rich toffee malt flavor......
Clear, dark amber w/ big frothy head. Buttery aroma w/ nice malt character. Smooth, syrupy feel. Rich, sweat butter-toffeee flavour w/ burnt caramel notes. Long dry finish.

Dark copper-amber with a frothy head that disappears quickly. Aroma of sweet malt and dark caramel. Initial sweet flavour gives way to bitter dirt and warm alcohol. The booziness becomes more prominent as the beer warms up. Not entirely unpleasant, but not ass-kicking either.
I'd heard all they hype about this one and it lived up.  Quality beer.  The Aroma just hits you hard.  Slightly Fruity.  Nice Smokey Taste, an excellent beer.

rich amber color.  head disappears swiftly.  aroma isrich and malty but there seems to be some sugar there too.  the flavor has a touch of alcohol, lots of thick malts, some caramel.  definite sugarry sweet flavor in the middle to a thick coating finish.  the body is smooth and then on the heavier side.  it sticks around in the mouth.  after a moment it is a very clean feeling left in the mouth.
Very nice beer,nice amber color with a definate maltiness some hints of raisin,seemed stronger in alcohol then it was,all around well worth buying again.
Copper colored, clear with tight head.  Slight maltiness with flight metallic flavor and aroma.  Slight sherry, licorice flavor.  Crisp with well carbonated body.  Perhaps an older bottle.

Head disappears as quickly as when a ring makes it on to your wifes finger. Nice malty start with strong aroma and alcohol content. Very enjoyable flavour makes it worth a special occation but not a weekly tradition.
Thick and strong. Feels like drinking bread almost. Roasty but with sweetness rather than sharpness. Buttery. Head disappears fast. Overall a good Doppelbock but not perfect.

Aroma has raisin and porto. Full bodied beer, sweet and malty. Porto, peach and hopflavors. Alcohol present. Well made doppelbock with a good flavor, but no specific characteristics that makes it a classic.
Amber coloured with decent head. Sweet malty aroma with caramel notes. Flavour is sugary, caramel wiht some alcahol in the end.
smooth and creamy with a pleasant aftertaste...hits you with some power at 7.5% alc...decent beer
Very sweet beginning but a very sour finish, like an overly ripe fruit juice with malt. I may have bought a bad bottle.

Has a nice malty base - rather sweet but with a slightly sour finish.  Faint hints of smoke.  Kind of unbalanced to me - the malts kind of collide.  MY sample was a rather old bottle though, so I will re-rate if I can get a more recent product.

Bright dark golden color with a light tan head.  Nose is quite maltily sweet with hints of smoke and brown sugar.  Body is very sweet with notes of brown sugar also carrying throough.  Alcohol is present as well as what I like to call notes of haylage.  Finishes slightly hoppy and sweet.  Much too sweet, which made me glad that I had to share this 500 mL bottle with my buddy, now that doesn''t happen very often.
I did''nt taste this beer under the best circumstances. I would like another one some day.
The colour is surprisingly light but still very fine with a quite big head. Loads of malt in aroma and flavour. Woody and bitter finish. A great and classic Doppelbock.
Mmmmmm.  Malty goodness.  I really love nursing a beer like this.  Great color, complex, amazingly balanced for the depth of flavor.  Tuff Stuff to the max, dudes and dudettes.
Clear dark orange coloured. Lots of caramel malts and brown sugar. A bit unpleasant alcoholic finish. Reasonable doppelbock, but nothing more than that.
Dark amber; sweet malty aroma w/molasses, marmalade, and earthy undertones.  Zippy alcohol notes and lemon candy lead into a sweet, brown sugary middle.  Gets thick and cloying at the end.
deep reddish colour, nice beige head.  malty aroma with hints of vanilla.  syrupy mouthfeel.  flavours of burnt sugar, dried cherries, alcohol.  good balance.  warming.
wow...great beer, Im really impressed because this is so much better than the paulaner oktoberfest. Great beer.
It has an apprent alcohol taste that does not detract from the overall hop flavor. It is high quality overall.
This is such a good beer that I had to re-rate it...........................
No head, but fine clarity.  Elegent aroma slowly becoming more alcoholic.  Equally elegant flavor: rich but never flabby.  Much less cloying than I remember.  Top notch.

Sweet malt and nutty aroma. Clear cherry red colour, tiny vanilla head. Bitter, burnt cherry and wood flavour, as it warms it takes on a wine flavour and a cognac feel. Sweet, syrupy, quite zingy! A very warming beer on this cold autumn night.
Nice malt and caramel smells, which come through in the flavor as well, but it''s a bit too sweet for me.
Upon uncapping of the bottle I perceived a chocolate or carmel aroma.  Carmel color.  Quickly diminishing head.  Fairly sweet with good malt flavor and slightly perceivable carmel finish.

This is a bit on the thin-bodied side, but that is somewhat made up for by the sweet and malty flavor, with very subtle hints of caramel.  This malty sweetness masks the alcohol content very well, but then it comes back through in the finish a little too much for my taste.  Still a good beer, though.

Lighter in appearance than I was expecting.  Clear red/amber color.  Nose is dominated by sweet malts, added to by vanilla and caramel.  A touch of hops in the finish, but perhaps not quite enough.  Good, but probably not the best.
Nice and sweet initally then bitter towards the end.  Alcohol taste at the finish as well.
Burnt malt aroma.Tawny red color.Soft cabonation.A little too sweet and malty for my taste.Has a nice Bitterness at the end which balances the sweetness.

Faint, roasted malt aroma. Relatively quickly disappating head. Nice red hue. Very good caramelly taste with some bitterness. A little too malty for my taste, but a good beer overall. *ppcpilot, you have the spelling right. You lead me to comment that I love caramel and dulce de leche, but for some reason, am not crazy about it in my beer.

Wow.  It''s like drinking dulce de leche (sp?.  It''s aroma and color let you know what''s coming....caramel.  It''s tastes just like chewing on a Kraft caramel candy.  This is my first dopplebock, and I will definately be trying more.  A hit of hops at the end give this a nice finish without over bitterness.  A great sit down session beer.

Cold fall in Ontario, I am a bit sick my self ... Well this is my number 600. Nice clear amber color with white thick head that sadly did not lasted to long. Aroma of sweet cherry wood with addition of raspberry. Nice and warming. Warming and intense flavours. Alcohol blended well with caramel, creamy, a bit nutty. Nice for cold windy fall season.
Great doppelbock. Sweet carmel malt and was just delightful.................

Re-Rate 10/02. On tap this was a fine brew. Creamier, not as sweet definately better than bottled.Will add a couple points. Not even close to Celebrator. Decent beer but if your looking for a good brew rather than lifting your ratings drink Celebrator.
Superb balance and complexity.  Sweet like it should be.  Eminently drinkable, yet bittersweet.

By far and above the best Dopplebock I have ever had. Not overpowering in the sweetness keeping a more quenching drinkablity that keeps you taking another swallow. Pours outt a dark caremel color with a small head and a fiant sweet burnt sugar smell. Taste starts out sweet like the average dopplebock but finishes with a refreshing cleanness that I haven''t found with any other. Great beer I recommend it to all.

Deep amber w/ no head.  Aroma of caramel and some apple (hidden deep within).  A nice well-balanced beer that takes you by surprise (who would think a doppelbock would taste like this).  Nice and malty w/ hints of caramel and apple.  Backblow was very flowery.  A Belgian on the stronger side of good.

Re-rate 10/04/02: A clear deep amber color, the head is frothy, beige, the lace is thick and clings to the glass till the very bottom of the glass. Nose is malt, caramel, woodsy, and quite pleasant. Start is sweet, the top is medium, the finish is quite dry, acidic, well hopped and a great beer and always in my "DBF". Ranks #349 on my current 1000 beer master list.

Orange red color, medium head. Very malty and robust. Complex flavor, rich and flavorful. Malty and somewhat appleish and nutty. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is smooth. Aftertaste is malty. There is some alcohol bite, not to harsh. Nice beer.

Nice doppel. Not overt with the roasty/molasses flavor. Copper color, awesome label. once it gets warm the vomitous flavor creeps in, but you soon forget. Doppelbocks arent exactly my forte, but this would be good in that RARE time. Good for the beginners. Also...nose was great with like roasted nuts and molasses.

This one pours a very clear, deep amber color with a small off-white head. The aroma is all malt. Full bodied and smooth, the flavor is rich and full of malt sweetness. Finish is long with a nice lingering sweetness. This is a great doppelbock, probably second only to Ayinger's Celebrator.
Very nice, but a bit on the sweet side.  Nice dark color, fair in the head/lace department.  Better than mega brews and a definite nice change.
This Ale tasted like a beer loaded with sugar.. I could not get past the sickley sweet flavor..pass this one up

I wasnt amused with this brew but I respect it. Cool picture on the label, kina like that ol timely place. Welcoming but dont stay to long. I felt as if I had to talk this one down until I tried to hit on it. This beer reminds me of the story of the traveling salesman, who got lost and had to stay at a farmers house. The farmer agreed to let him spend the night out in his barn, but only if the salesman agreed not to stick his dick in the holes that where on the side of the barn. When night time finally came the lonely traveling salesman decided to stick his dick in hole number one. And oh boy did it feel great. The second hole was even better then the first. As the salesman entered the third hole he felt a sharp pinch and yelled out in agonizing pain. Ahhhhhhhhhhhhh! As the sun rises and morning comes, the farmer enters the barn, to see the salesman still stuck to the hole. The farmer says to the salesman, You dont deserve an answer but Ill give one anyway, behind the first hole was my wife and that is where she stays. The second hole is my daughter supple, young and pure. And behind the third hole is a milking machine that dont let go until 50 gallons are withdrawn.
This beer has a thick, syrupy feel and taste to it.  It was certainly good to sip, but too molassasy and syrupy for me to really enjoy the whole beer.
Good God, Pauliner rocks.  This is their finest.  A very nice rich beer that is surprisingly easy drinking.
My dad and I drank lot's of these one night in Garmish.... easy to drink, but it'll catch up with you.  Nice flavor and color.
Dark brown. Densely malty, oaky and thick. Syrupy, sweet finish with quite a lot of bitterness.
pretty damn good! nice carmel coloring and beautiful finish! i love this one!
Really enjoyed this one... has a nice sweet taste and is very smooth.  My first dopplebock, I think I will really like this style of beer.  Reccomended.
Another good beer from Paulaner.  I typically prefer the darker doppel bock but this one was very good.  Quite a noticeable alcohol presence even in the aroma.

Nice deep red with small beige head.  Smells of toasted and caramel malts.  No alcohol in aroma or taste.  Smooth and easy to drink for such a strong beer.  Im concerned about the label however- says ale on the top right hand corner- whats the deal? Whatever-very good for a doppelbock.
Being the first does not make it the best.  Paulaner is a mediocre brewery as far as I am concerned.  This beer is just this side of boring.

Rererate at the Starkbierfest on the Nockherberg. Fresh from tab this classic displays all the fruity, berrylike and spicy notes it is known for, beautifull! Re-rate: Dark red in color and with a malty aroma. Moderate carbonation end a light vinous taste. Aftertaste is pretty neutral.

Brilliantly clear, light amber color (actually lighter in color tan I remember).  Lasting rocky light tan head. Aromas of malt, toffee malt and caramel malt - outstanding aroma - coming from a recovering hophead. Smooth as it floats over the tongue. Sweet malt flavors everywhere.  Also light flavors of currants and chocolate. Finishs relatively dry with a slight EToH kick. A relatively mild doppel, but very clean and refreshing.

Just before I had this one I had a Stone IPA and it may be a ratebeer no-no to compare apple beers andorange beers but I can’t help it! Anyway, it has a metallic, citrus-like flavor with hints, and I mean molecules, of toffee, cocoa and maybe tea.
Oh so sweet, very good this is on that i get when I can't decide because I know that it will be rewarding.
Clear reddish color.  Prominent flavors are the sweetness and alcohol.  I think I like Spaten's dopplebock better.
Delicious caramel sweetness, subtle but satisfying bitter finish.  Fairly complex but I failed to identify individual flavor and aroma components.

Tap;Dark oarnge-brown with huge rocky,milky head.Sweet,toffee,fruit,alcohol aromas.Lightly syrupy,full,palate.Flavors explode on the tounge.Flavors of caramel,chocolate,and dry fruit.The finish is slightly dry and has a sweet alcohol flavor.22oz(?) mug was extremely-sweetly satisfying.Became very warming which was perfect on this cool,cloudy,windy night here in IN.

Clear deep amber in color.  Nose has sweet roasted malt, caramel, chocolate and coffee notes.  Tastes much like it smells with some sweetness followed by a nice bitter kick. It's a world class dopplebock.

The lovely orange-copper color is quite striking---fine soft head too. Aroma malty and a bit estery--very attractive...Taste much like the aroma: malty sweet with molasses and spice--enough hops to be noticed...great warmth to the finish...very smooth for a powerful brew...Been drinking this stuff for many years...always a pleasure.

Well I finally found some Celebrator so I thought I would try another Dopplebock first. Nice amber & red color. Taste the carmel and molasses, very refreshing, needs a few more hops for my taste, though I wouldn't be timid in passing these out to my buddies. More carbonation would help here.

In my opinion, this is a good example of how a doppelbock should taste and smell.  Not an excellent example, but a good one.  Complex aroma and flavor of malt and alcohol.  Love the color - a brilliant orange-copper.  Not my favorite beer in this style, but good none-the-less.
Alcohol-laced caramel sprinkled with spicy, herbal hops…Heavy on the caramel and its honeyed angles, this Doppelbock can get cloying at times...Still a good brew, but perhaps a brutish one...

After drinking this Double Bock, I was very impressed with its redish appearance and sweet taste, and I  was also reminded of this kid I know: Greg Bok.  I would kill to live the life of Greg Bok...I mean come on, he's on more adderal than you could imagine and his dad drives an M5

Nice caramel nose coming from a beautiful amber beer with an attractive tan head. Extremely sweet, dark malt taste – like brown sugar. Spicy and a little smoky. A quick subtle dryness ends the flavor profile. This thing is big and fat. It stays on your lips like a lollipop and warms the belly. I once had three ½ liters of this while camping in Garmisch-Partenkirchen about 5 years ago and got a terrible hangover. The alcohol can hit you hard if you don’t watch out. It’s certainly a quality beer though.

Had a feeling like at home after horseback riding because of the aroma, smells like horseblanket, sweet malt. Nice red amber body with a light brown head. Pure Malt, honey, alcohol and licorice flavor. Syrupy with a long malty tasting finsih. Well balanced, not too sweet, not to malty!

Shockingly light in color (which seems to be the general consensus) - almost thought I was pouring an Amber Ale or IPA. The aroma is extremely fragrant and pleasing. One of the better smelling beers I’ve had in some time. The malted body is rather light and slightly reminiscent of fermented nectar. It could benefit from a bolder hops presence. However, this is definitely a distinguished Doppelbock and very appealing. Highly recommended.

Bottle. Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.  Body is medium amber. Aroma is moderately malty (malt syrup, molasses, bread). Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic. One-dimensional, too syrupy sweet, and very dull.  Never had a good sample of this.

First I was surprised like many at the lighter color of this doppelbock. It's a nice dark, red amber color with a copper head to it. Not to heavy of a aroma to it. Lighter, slightly tangy taste to it. Nice flavor. Celebrator is by far the better, but this is still a keeper.
One of the very best double bocks made. ....................................

This is what a doppelbock should be! Dark and rich, almost a reddish hue to the brown body. Very sweet and extremely malty. Hints of dark chocolate and caramel along with the underlying alcohol tones and big malt. Essential!! HIGHLY recommended to all!
Not Bad Got some smoke and malt not enough hops to balance it though........

Rerate Albertson’s, Baton Rouge, La. - 16.9 fl oz bottle.  Pours a clear copper with little to no head. Molasses like aroma, some maple syrup. Flavor is sweet, not sickenly so, but too much for drinking more than one. Good, rib-sticking, thick mouthfeel. Not quite as enthused this time around. Good winter warmer though.  Original 4.2 Great, fruity, thick flavor with an aftertaste that sticks around for a while and doesn’t let you forget what you just drank. Very pleasant malty aroma.
Good solid beer with a kick.  Nice on a cold day.  Dark color and refreshing aroma
got body and flavor.  Not too heavy, though.................................
deep amber color, very thin head, good malty flavor with hints of fruit and chocolate, malty, a nice doppelbock, but not in the class of aventinus or celebrator in my opiniion
A very warming beer. Flavour is a well balanced mix of coffee and chocolate. This beer really lives up to its name!

Clear light amber-copper color with a nice foamy lasting white head, sweet fruity and flowery aroma. Sweet and malty roasty caramel flavors very sweet in the finish, medium body with a sticky mouthfeel, alcohol well hidden, above average dopplebock worth a try always a good choice.
A perfectly acceptable doppelbock, smooth and mouth-filling. Good body. Nice maltiness. Maybe just a little too sweet, though.

Reddish color, thin and quickly dissipating foam. Nose shows instantaneous signs of dark fruit malt, raisin/plum, and a little roasted touch. Smooth layered palate with a tantilizing spritzy carbpnation. Lots of swet malt flavor, shows deep fruitiness, a little breadiness and did I say even more malt. It mellows a little in the latter half, drying slightly but remains predominantly sweet. A barley winesque alcohol warmth develops the longer the beer sits. Maybe the original doppelbock but I wouldn't put it above Celebrator or Optimator.

Very nice deep golden/bronze color. Pours with big foamy head which dissipates quickly. Nose of malt and caramel. Nice full sweet flavor of malt and fig. Touch of bite on the backend, but by no means is this a hoppy beer. Smooth finish. Overall a very nice beer and one of the best DOLLAR VALUES when it comes to Double Bock.
A nice sweet carmel flavored doppelbock.  Excellent dark, reddish color, slight roasted malt flavor I think.  Not the best dopplebock I've ever had, but quite good.
A very good dopplebock, but I have had better...............................
Sweet, caramel aroma with no bitterness in it at all.  Also a sweet, caramel flavor with some sourness in the finish.  Not terribly complex, and not terribly interesting, from my perspective.
The aroma is of intense caramel sweetness.  Flavor is dominated by the caramel, but there's also some german hops, smokiness, and a bit of alcohol.  Relatively crisp.  Overall, a very good beer.
A very sweet and hoppy doppelbock.  Pleasant aroma (spring if you will), dark amber color, fruity aftertaste.  Good with Sauerbraten!
Nice and refreshing.  This is one of those beers I could proabably drink a lot of, and fairly quickly.  Very smooth.

Not overly complex, but it does pack a punch like any doppelbock should. Great amber color with apartment wall-colored head. Decent smooth finish despite the alcohol flavor. Malt and caramel undertones. Not too bad.
Amber in color with little to no head.  Carmel/toffee nose.  Sweet toffe start, middle a little thin, alcoholic finish with somewhat strong smokey undertones (especially once it warmed).
Very enjoyable.  A smooth and enjoyable bock with a nice finish.............
Nice bock, mildly sweet and smokey accent. .................................
Well balanced double... beautiful reddish appearance. Smooth, creamy, sweet, and smokey. Not as full flavored as the best doppelbocks...

Malty nose, predominately bread, caramel, and a whiff of hops.  Little head or carbonataion to speak of.  Burnt toffee, caramel, and brown sugar malt notes, with a mildly astringent alcohol finish.  A tasty brew.  Not the best dopplebock, but very good.
Its a good creamy beer, it doesnt realy taste like any other dopplebock I have had. A very smooth beer, has a nice hint of hops and malt. Nothing spectacular, but a good beer nonetheless.
A nice Bock, but buck isn't my farourite....................................
This is good stuff. My first bock, and it's a winner. Great aroma, and tremendous coloring. A nice brew.

Nice malty aroma, raisins, rye bread, sweet. Dark amber-brown clear with thin off-white lacing head. Medium bodied with light medium carbonation. Starts sweet with malt and raisin, rye. Finish has a little bitter and sweet malt. After has some alcohol, sweetness, nuttiness.
This dopplebock may seem thin in mouthfeel - don't be fooled.  This is a smooth malty beer that is easy to drink too much of!
Thick, malty, a nice aroma and a sweet finish.  I can't believe i like this better than Optimator but i think it just edges it out.

Not my cup of tea.  I just don't get this beer.  I grew up drinking midwestern Bocks which were malty but I find dopplebocks positively cloying.  Maybe I need to drink this one in Germany.  As a festival beer, sometimes it's hard to get the point without attending the festival.

Certainly of a different style than many might like, but I find this to be a wonderfully rich, creamy beer with a flavor that goes well with food.  The caramel sweetness is not too overpowering, in my view, and it disguises what is really a rather powerful punch.  Among my very favorite beers.
Very good beer as long as you drink it at room temperature and not cold.  If it's cold it becomes sort of noxious and biting, I will update this review next time I have it so I can give finer details

A bottle of this was my introduction to Doppelbocks.  This brew pours a clear reddish orange.  The large creamy off-white head is mostly diminishing with virtually no lacing.  The malty nose is moderate consisting mostly of hay, caramel, and grain balanced by light grass, perfume, and dough with some cask wood tones.  The alcoholic flavor is warm, sweet and bitter.  The smooth body is somewhere in between light and medium with soft carbonation and a moderately alcoholic astringency to the finish.  Not my favorite style.

This dark beer has a malty, fruitcake aroma and smells like it was made for Christmas, not the Lenten period before Easter. This is a 7.5% alcohol by volume beer that I purchased for the bargain price of $1.99 per 16 oz. bottle at the Wine Exchange in Orange, California. I rate this one 4½-stars, highly recommended.
Ok beer. Not my style, but not a bad concoction. But I don't think I could drink more than one at a time.
