Thick and malty.  Quite satisfying.  Not my favorite style but reasonably well done. Tons of caramunich maltiness. I had hoped the finish would be a little less sweet.

I pulled this one off the shelf at the local HEB not knowing what to expect. We had this along with a few others and now my roomate is snoring on the couch. So, the extra alcohol is noticeable. The color of this beer is unlike any that I have ever had. Its reddish orange hue is interesting, yet the taste left a little to be desired. I guess I am not ready for beer that has a fruity taste. I  think I smelled apples. Very original.
This is Good Stuff better than the SA double bock and i love SA,,,,,This as One of my top 3 beers

Reddish brown color and a sweet aroma. The head comes quickly and goes just as quickly. A bit sweet on the palate as well but goes down easily. The alcohol is not as pronounced at first but comes around to get you in the end. Nice and drinkable, though not as flavorful as I expected.

Dark reddish caramel color with a thin creamy beige head.  Toasty coffee candy sugar aroma.  Hoppy, sweet, toasty, port-like taste.  Cloying mouth feel balanced with a slightly acidic finish.  Good beer.  Tastes more like a barley wine than other doppelbocks like Celebrator and Optimator.

My first impression of this beer was fairly average - a red/golden transparent color with a fairly weak "don't blink you might miss it" kind of head, but it's warm malty character sticks to the back of your tongue and kind of forces you to appreciate it. Relatively alchoholic - as is typical of any bock - but not at all overpowering.  A better than average beer that requires some patience.
My first bock.  Nice beer.  Interesting taste.  The extra alcohol is noticable.  Not necessarily a bad thing here.  Pours nicely out of the bottle.  Loses its head too quickly.

Smokey caramel nose, with slight overtones of vinegar and wood. Cool label, vibrant orange/rust color with chainmail head which transforms to an inch of spongey foam which persists. Substantial mouthfeel, with an acidic aftertaste.  Caramel and slightly metallic flavor, but I may come back and re-rate this on a cleaner palate.  Paulaner again comes through with a crafty brew.
Another great German beer.  Delicious and less pricey than some other worthy beers.  A staple in my beer fridge.
Very malty, with overtones of both fruit and chocolate. The high alcohol and price prevent me from drinking too much of it. If someone offers you one, do NOT say "no thanks".

Damn fine brew!  Looking at it you'd think it was a bitter dark, dark ale. No so.  Salvator is sweet and very, very smooth.  It has a nice body and leaves a chocolaty finish.  Great with Steak Au Poive or anything heavy on the seasoning.  Buy this now.
As other reviewers have noted, little aroma.  Not much head and what there was didn't stick around.  Good flavors, with a rich maltiness with loads of caramel.
Execllent bock.  Slight sour smell with hints of fruitiness(?)  Malty flavor, caramel taste with maybe some hints of woodiness.  Hoppy finish, very nice.
Almost no aroma.  Nice complex maltyness to the flavor.  Nice hints of hops in the finish.  Good example of an average bock, I just would have wished for a better aroma to acompany it.
I couldn't detect an aroma.  It has a great brown-red clear color.  The flavor is complex, and smoky.  I enjoyed the beer, would like to try more.  I'm not familiar with many bocks however

Aroma I can’t put my finger on, but it is definitely fruity. Nice frothy head, and a reddish appearance. Smooth palate, slight alcohol aftertaste, a drinkable brew I wouldn’t go out of my way to get again.
its not  bad, doesnt have a distint taste.  Looks great but not special by any means.  Would try again.
wasn't impressed at all. I was looking forward to much more than I got......

Nice amber color and lingering although slight head.  There is a fruity, sweet aroma and an even sweeter taste.  At first I thought there was no alcohol in there, but the bite at the end told me otherwise.  This is a simpler doppelbock than others I've tried, with a less complex taste.  I like it, though, especially just to sit and drink.  I don't want too many because of the spicy sweetness, but this is a definite keeper and second-place finisher (so far) to Ayinger.

Rerate: Bottled, BB 09.14, large sample. Clear amber to copper color, short lasting light brown head. Aroma of caramel malt, toffee, hint of roast, earthy and spicy hop. Slight sweet in taste, bit bitter. Finishes quite dry and bitter. Wonderful example of a doppelbock. 3.7
Original rate back in 2002: Nice doppelbock. Clear brown color, a bit too clear i think. Bit smoked taste added to the typical doppelbock. 3.7

modest head on a sparkling burnt-orange body.  hugely fragrant, no question where your beer-buying dollar (or two rather) goes--not into buying superbowl ad time but in mounds of malt, there's enough barley here to stuff a clydesdale. there's apple in the aroma certainly, also pumpkin and carrot and dense german bread. much fruitier in flavor and better balanced than spaten's doppel, with a charming spicy bourbon finish.

Nice clean copper hue with a sweet malty aroma. Slightly smokey and noticeable hop flavor with no overpowering alcohol feel. 2/22/2002 Add a nice peppery feel when it sits on your tongue to the above rating.

Why does this beer remind me of a wassail ale, particularly Catamount's?  Very complex malty nose, fruity/apple juice. Nice light copper color. Warming alcohol palate. Flavors are complex as well; sharp malt accompanies strange, clean, bitter finish.  This pattern later evolves into sharp malt and increasing alcohol, spicy notes.  Alcohol begins to predominate, as well as cloying sweetness.  Typically not my type of brew.

This tang-orange colored brew has a continual feed of carbonation rising to build the head.  It has the sort of musky beer flavor of an unrefined macro, but with detectable malting and a sweet vinousness reminiscent of barley wines. This beer had some nice parts to it, but they were arranged in to haphazard a manner to make much of a gustatory splash.
Malty aroma, malty flavor, lowly hopped, sweet & warming.  This beer is atop the charts and comes out of the cooler very quickly when I'm in a hurry and don't have time to browse.

Forgot how sweet the bock and doppelbock styles were. Excellent dark amber color and continuous lace. Really wanted to try some Celebrator this weekend but had to put it back on the rack after looking at the $15.99/6 price! This Salvator is a great double bock at an affordable price.

As some people have mentioned - its not nearly as good a celebrator, but a beer this good,and of this quality at 7.99 a six pak, you cant go wrong. With every sip you can taste the strong alcohol content reminding you to take it easy.

Not as complex in taste as main competitors Optimator and Celebrator, but the taste I prefer to nearly any Doppelbock, the Weltenburg Asam-Bock excepted.  At one point I even thought I prefered this over the Celebrator, but later tastings didn't quite confirm that.  A noticeably more slick feeling in the mouth from the alcohol, I thought.  But a good buy if you can find it cheap enough, and since it's a doppelbock, I'd still prefer it to most anything else if the occasion warrants.

Pours a clear glowing copper with a thick pillowy off-white head.  Aroma is subtle and caramely with a touch of floral German hops. Body starts light and syrupy sweet with some toffee and butterscotch, finishing semi-sweet and crisp.  Needs more thickness and complexity, but hides its alcohol well.

Clear, light copper. Thin but persistent head. Huge nose of super sweet malt, reminicent of a fresh wort. Smooth body, tons of chewy malt, sweet, bready with a nice little twang of hops. Very well balanced. Along the same lines with optimator but i think this might edge it out a little, who knows, im kinda buzzed up. Thats the beauty of strong beers, ive had 2 and its a night out.   Thanks Trap!
Malty prune or plum like aroma. Reddish colored full bodied beer. Rich malty flavor with a warming Alchol taste. Very smooth.

I am quite dissapointed in the reviews of others on this paticular beer. It is one of the best beers Ive ever tasted, if not the best. It is one of the few beers you can taste as if it were a wine!You can taste the different flavors from start to finsh. It has one of the most robust flavors of any beer I have tasted. For those of you who rate this beer as mediocre, stick to drinking American micro-brews who have bastardized what beer is supposed to taste like. This is a beer in which all others in the same family are measured by. END OF STORY!!!. P.S. " It is one thing for someone to think you are stupid, and another  to open your mouth and prove it." (Stick to Budweiser)
Doughy characteristics in its smell and its taste. A bít sweet at times, not as good as i thought it would be, a bit too cloying and sweet/sticky.
Malty aroma.  Malty, buttery taste.  Very pleasant to drink, I think because of its simplicity.  Not fair to compare to the Celebrator, a much more complex German brew.
This one smacks of rich maltiness and packs quite a wallop..................

This beer carried a sweet fruity armoa.  I could smell the malt.  It had a great (but not lasting) head and a deep mahogony color.  A very beautiful glass of beer.  It tastes of heavy malt with a good bit of yeastiness.  The toasted flavor came out like the oven was in front of my face cooking a nice beer-malt muffin.  Yep...in short...GOOD.
Liquid bread. Roasty nose would be a better description.....................
i love the rich dark color and creamy taste.................................

Any beer with a monk on the label should kick ass.  This one was good but I wouldnt go so far as to say it kicked ass.  It had an interesting maltiness to it, unlike any other.  Not a bad brew though.
A very nice aroma, which includes alcohol and sweet fruits.  A thinner body than I expected.  An above average beer, after dinner or before bed.
I was actually disappointed by this. It was a fine beer, nice taste but I think I was expecting something more interesting. Though I guess my rating is still pretty high.
VERY TASTEY BEER, VERY GOOD FOR AFTER DINNER................................
It packs a punch and tastes malty.  I can taste (and feel) the alcohol, but not in an overwhelming way.
Looks good, smells OK... tastes like meat. Should it? I'm not sure. Disappointing after the hype, but I guess it's not that expensive.

rerate 6/24/09:  Amberish orange with a bready brown foam.  Aroma of deep, rich malts with a slight under pinning of alcohol.  Very, very malty but this also has one of the more noticeable hop finishes.  Slightly toasty.  This always makes me think of breakfast cereal for some reason.  Quite good.
Tastes almost like unfermented wort, very sweet and malty. Awesome color and good head. Doesn't feel as powerful as it is. Deceptively easy to drink. Hops are almost unnnoticeable. Very satisfying.

used to be impressed by this back in the days when i drank a lot of reschs but now it's pretty underwhelming. sweet malt, sticky toffee, not a lot there really. pure tasting, not rough in any way, just really boring and stale.
transparent, reddish in colour, few head, candy sugar, caramel aroma, very malty, the sweetness is balanced by the alcohol presence, long caramel aftertaste - very good
Looks good and tastes good, but something just didn't jive on the aftertaste
expected better. the aftertaste doesn't really go anywhere and just tastes soggy
Too thick. I like the smokey nose on the full and creamy head though........
Very complex flavors but a bit lacking in balance. An easily enjoyed dopple.
A sweet, malty concoction with an alcoholic warmth.     A little thick on the tongue.   Salvator feels well rounded although the sweetness on the back end was little too much for my liking.
Huge beer.  This one has so much going on, its almost a meal into itself (which is what I believe Doppelboks were made for in the first place).
Sometimes it's a bit thin, but it's tha granddaddy..........................
A nice brew thick, rich, malty, really tasty stuff..........................

Not as impressive as Celebrator, but still good.  Frothy off-white head that doesn't last.  Creamy, toffee flavors, but I didn't get the smoky flavors other raters mentioned.  Beautiful ruby or bronze color.  A hint of hop flavor and bitterness with better balance than Celebrator.  An enjoyable brew and better than anything your average beer drinker can imagine.  Definitely worth a second try when my pallate develops a little more.

The original Dopplebock, this is the brew against which
all others are compared.

I am familiar with Celebrator and Optimator. To my palette,
Salvator is the best. All are good and each has a distinctive
character. Both Optimator and Celebrator are very dark and rich. 
They differ by the fact that Optimator is considerably sweeter.
Salvator is not as dark as either and sweeter than Celebrator. Where
Salvator shines is in its balance. Perhaps not as complex as Celebrator,
but it is a more pleasent drink--deceptively smooth and drinkable
considering the 7.5% ABV.

If you like strong, malty, full-bodied beers, this can't be beat.
It is one of my favorites.
A striking and odd but enticing Coors-like character along with its malty and roasty aroma. The flavor is tremendous, woody, dark with molasses finishing soft bittersweet.
a great winter time brew, i love to use Salvator as a base for a black-n-tan

man, this beer review stuff is weird...taste is so subjective after all! i wasn't too gung ho for this beer, even though i love paulaner's weisse beer. 

maybe that's my "problem".  with doubles and trippels and whatnot i get overwhelmed. i like and am used to drinking the lower alchohol, wheat syle beers.

who knows, perhaps these types of beers will grow on me and i'll "graduate" to the genre! evidently the dubbel that i REALLY DO like (flying fish) is somewhat weaker in flavor than the norm, so maybe i'm already on my way.....;)

I absolutely loved this beer. Quite a bit stronger than I was expecting, but still excellent. It is also probably the prettiest looking beer I have ever seen, it has a beautiful copper/amber color to it. Goes down smooth and easy.

I think this beer gets a bad rap, afterall, what IS as good as Ayinger Celebrator? If that is the standard then this might be a little disappointing, but it is very good in its own rite.  The alcohol taste is slightly more prevalent, but not so strong that it detracts from the beer's flavor, which isn't as complex as Celebrator.  A beautiful beer, it could benefit from a more even taste which is slightly underwhelming.
I love bocks and this is definitely a great representative of the bock family.  Nice color and texture.  Most important, a complex, superb taste.
I don't know Oakes and mpdempse are talking about.  This beer rocks.........
Too sweet with a hint of bitterness. Paulaner can do better. ...............

Who dropped that dark chocolate bar in my beer, b/c it was worth it!  A respectable brew, roasty all the way to my stomach!  It's no Celebrator, but in a cookie-cutter world of beer, who want's uniformity?
Wow!  Strong, strong malty/fruity/chocalaty flavor, smooth down the hatch and an even smoother finish (a big plus for me).  Another great one from Germany's best large brewery.
Nice malty flavor.  Definite apparent alcohol taste.  Hoppy finish..........
Dark but fruity and creamy, with banana citrus notes above the burnt toffee malt. Strong aftertaste that shows a bit of heat.
Alcohol apparent in the aroma.  Buttery, malt, toffe, with a warming finish.  Very smooth.  Yum.
Lighter than the typical doppelbock, but still full of wonderful malt aroma and flavor, with the aftertaste slightly drier.

Nice roasted caramel malt flavoring.
Does seem to be a bit weak for doppel,
but good anyway.
Light for a doppelbock, but nonetheless decent.  Tasted much better in glass than in bottle. Malt taste.
Light in color but full of flavor. Not as "heavy" as a some dopplebocks. ...
